RUBIN--Cynthia B.,was a tireless advocate for survivors of domestic violence. In loving memory, the Board and Staff at Sanctuary for Families 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Alfred L.,85, passed away peacefully on October 24th. Survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Renee; cherished children, Carolyn, Deborah and son-in-law, Steve Roth; adored and adoring grandchildren, Sarah, Samuel and Helena; and beloved brother, Franklin. A graduate of Bronx High School of Science, NYU (Heights) and Columbia Law School. He proudly served in the U.S. Air Force. Thereafter, he spent his career in the television industry, retiring as executive vice-president and general counsel of Metromedia. During his retirement, he served for many years as a volunteer in the literacy program of the JCC Manhattan and at the Museum of Natural History. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, October 27th, at 11:00am. 1/3

KLEIN--Susan. This is the 1st anniversary of your passing. You were my miracle, the way we met, that you fell in love with me and the happiness and fulfillment that you brought to me were a miracle. Stephanie, Eric, Bryan, Robby and I, love you and miss you. Mel 1/3

MORAN--Miriam K.,of Greenwich, CT, (formerly Darien, CT), died on Thursday, October 22, 2015, at Greenwich Hospital. She was born on December 11, 1932, in Boston, MA, to William and Hilda Kirkwood. She graduated from Trinity College in Washington, D.C. in 1954, and also attended Harvard University. Miriam was a teacher for many years at both the elementary and high school levels and enjoyed working with children of special needs; a true advocate of education. She served on the Board of Directors of India House and New York Medical College and as a trustee of the HealthCare Chaplaincy Network of New York. Miriam was a member of the Weeburn Country Club and Woodway Country Club of Darien; the Blind Brook Country Club of Rye Brook; the New York Yacht Club; the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and Belle Haven Club of Greenwich; India House of New York; The Bath and Tennis Club; Club Colette and The Everglades Club, all of Palm Beach. Miriam enjoyed bridge, golf, boating and travel. She led a highly active social life, continually entertaining friends and relatives and enjoyed being feted by them in turn. Miriam was a devoted mother, wife, and friend. She will be sorely missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. Miriam was predeceased by her husband Thomas Moran and son-in-law, James Livziey. She is survived by her children Suzanne (James) Rodenbush of Cheshire, CT, Walter (Danielle) Schwind of Fairfield, CT, Georgia Livziey of Jefferson, MA, and Scott (Ashley) Schwind of Darien, CT. and seven grandchildren. Her family would like to extend a special note of thanks to her loving and compass-ionate caregivers, especially Yvonne Jones. Funeral services will be privately held. Memorial donations may be made in Miriam Moran's name to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at: www. pdf.org/en/fund--memdon. 1/3

GORNICK--Fred, age 86, died of mesothelioma on October 22, 2015, at his home in New York City. A graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, City College of New York, and the University of Pennsylvania, he was a physical chemist and spent most of his career as a professor at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. He was an intrepid traveler, adventurous reader, and urban explorer. He is survived by his daughters, Lisa and Janet Gornick; his sister, Vivian Gornick; his sons-in-law, Kenneth Hollenbeck and Daniel Cahill; and his grandsons, Zachary and Damon Hollenbeck. Donations in his memory can be sent to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation. 1/3

BRENNAN--James B.,78, of Manasquan, NJ passed away on October 20, 2015. James was predeceased by his parents, James and Anne (nee Doyle) Brennan, who immigrated from Ireland, his brother Eugene and his wife of 52 years, Grace Hennessey. He is survived by his brother John Brennan, two daughters and their husbands, Kerry Brennan and George Vitureira, and Rosemary and Robert MacMaster, and son James Brennan and his wife Karen, and his grandchildren Evan, Emma, Shannon and Colin. James was also blessed to have the companionship of Helen Bolil. His warm friendship will be deeply missed by his many Irish cousins. With the wind at his back, he put his heart and sinew into all of his life's efforts. 1/3

DAVIES--Debora Ann. Our beloved Debora died on October 22, 2015 at age 60. She is survived by her husband, Howard Weinstein, parents, Gordon and Roberta Davies, sister, Robyn McIntosh, Beverly Schmid, extended family, and wonderful friends. She embraced all of us with her intelligence, creativity, beauty, grace and love. 1/3

PRIMM--Beny J. Primm, M.D. died on October 16, 2015. He was a prominent physician who helped thousands of people who had illnesses such as substance abuse and HIV/AIDS. He will be deeply missed by family, friends, and colleagues. Contributions may be made to Mentoring in Medicine, Inc., 177a East Main Street, #

KRELL--Jerome. Our beloved Jerry died October 24, 2015 at 88. He is survived by his wife, Enid; his children, Janice, Caren, Richard, Marlene, and their spouses; his seven grandchildren; and three great-grandsons. 1/3
BLUM--Evelyn. Happy Birthday Bubie. Love, Jane, Stanley, Robyn, Jason, Margot, Ron, Ava and ? 1/3

REISMAN--Sylvia, on October 24, 2015. Beloved wife of the late William, loving mother of Seymour (Cynthia), Jerry (Nancy) and Susan (Leonard) Fishman. Cherished grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of 16. Services today at 11am, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

EMERY--David. Surfer, psychologist, raconteur, father of five, grandfather of 10. My passionate Dad who devoured life and adventure goes to his last big home. He dreamed of peace in the world. I know he has found it. From Kansas to Kilimanjaro he left his print. Richard David Emery 1/3

MARKS--Joan, 83, beloved wife of the late Malvin Marks, adored mother of Janet (Alex), Andrew and the late Bradley. Nana to Benjamin and Becky. She had the rare talent of making life-long friends who deeply loved her. 1/3

NATHANSON--Jack 95, Loving husband of Florence for 67 years; devoted father of Charles (Shelly), Bruce (Audrey), and Margery Weinstein (Paul); adored grandfather and great-grandfather; WW II navigator, liquor industry executive; family patriarch. Funeral Monday, 11 AM, October 26 at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY 10580. 1/3

BATKIN--Stanley I.,of Scarsdale, NY, passed away on October 25, 2015, just one week after his 101 birthday. He was predeceased by Selma Batkin, his childhood sweetheart and wife for 55 years. He is survived by his daughter, Gloria Kahn, and her husband, Bob, and his son, Alan, and his wife, Jane, five grandchildren- Andrew Batkin, Erik Kahn (and his wife, Katie), Karin Kahn (and her husband, Jay Lebed), Amy Knox (and her husband, Randy), and Jennifer Ruoff (and her husband, Craig) and 10 great-grandchildren, Avery, Elizabeth, Ethan, Henry, Joseph, Lucy, Piera, Pryor, Talia and William. He leaves behind Donna Sommer Batkin, his wife for the past 21 years. He is also survived by his brother and best friend, Sandy, his business partner for over 45 years, and his sister, Doris Cantor. An alumnus of James Madison High School and New York University, Stanley had a long career in business managing, with Sandy, the folding carton company founded by their father in 1910. He was always busy with projects to which he devoted all of his energy. He was the family genealogist, publishing beautiful volumes of the Tenzer family and the Batkin family genealogies. He had a great love of Israeli art and Judaica and spent considerable time in Israel, traveling there regularly for many years. His photographic skills led him to take portraits of many Israeli artists, resulting in a show of his work at the Tel Aviv Museum of Art. Stanley was the driving force behind the move of Beth El Synagogue to its current location and the design and construction of its building. He was involved in every aspect of the interior and exterior design, using the work of Israeli artists throughout. He served as President of Beth El for six years. He wrote a book on the synagogue design process, detailing the art in the building and the biblical references in the architecture. Stanley was devoted to philanthropy and was deeply active in many organizations, mostly related to Israeli and Jewish causes. He was greatly admired by the many friends he leaves behind in Westchester, New York City and Israel. Funeral services will be at Beth El Synagogue, 1324 North Ave., New Rochelle at 12:30pm on Tuesday, October 27. 1/3

SCHNEIDER--Hallie Beth, on October 22, 2015. Died of natural causes at her home in New York City. She was a lifelong New Yorker, who had worked in the fields of social work and vocational rehabilitation. She was the daughter of Leila Schneider and the late Joseph Schneider. She is survived by her mother, her sister Emily, and her brother Adam, and was predeceased by her sister, Nancy Schneider Bonneville. 1/3

JARDINE--Lisa, died in London on October 25. Brilliant scholar, brimful of life, extraordinary daughter, wife, mother, grandmother, teacher, friend. Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society, Kings College and Jesus College, Cambridge. She was joyful to the end. The world is less exciting without our dear Lisa. Daniel and Joanna S. Rose 1/3

EPSTEIN--Jules Irwin. December 18, 1930 - October 26, 2015. We will remember him for his love for his family and friends, his boundless generosity, and for inspiring us with his passion for wine and food. Services will be held on October 28th at 11:00am at The Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. in Manhattan. He is survived by his wife Joan, sons Ron (Deborah) and Ken (Ann), sister Barbara (Arnold) and grandchildren Eli (Qianqian), Hannah and Malka. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Culinary Institute of America. 1/3

CONWAY--E. Virgil. On behalf of the Board and Staff of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, we extend our heartfelt sympathies to E. Virgil Conway's family. Mr. Conway gave the Foundation 29 years of wise and insightful service as a Board member. We will miss his intellect and leadership. William H. Wright II, Chairman; George E. Thibault, MD, President 1

BATKIN--Stanley. UJA- Federation of New York mourns the passing of Stanley Batkin, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Stanley's beloved wife, Donna; his siblings, Sandy and Doris; his children, Alan (Jane) and Gloria (Bob); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

BATKIN--Stanley. Beth El Synagogue Center mourns the passing of Stanley Batkin, our dedicated honorary past president, ardent supporter of Israel and avid photographer of its people. Among a lifetime of accomplishments, Stanley's vision and leadership conceived the unique design of our world-class Sanctuary and Synagogue Center. Stanley tirelessly worked to beautify our space with the art that he hand picked from around the globe. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Donna and his entire family. David A. Schuck, Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Emeritus Samuel E. Berger, President 1/3

CONDELL--Herbert, died peacefully at age 95 on October 26th. Mr. Condell attended New York University, class of 1941, and proudly served in the United States Army during WWII. As a CPA who loved his career, he worked up until his final days. Dearly loved father of Mark (Jeannie) and Andrew (Wendy) and adoring grandfather of Dylan, Amelia, Jackson and Joanie. His family meant everything to him, and he meant everything to them; Herb will be dearly missed. He will be laid to rest beside his beloved late wife, Joan. 1/3

CONWAY--E. Virgil. His friends and admirers at Rose Associates note with sadness the loss of E. Virgil Conway, an outstanding banker, public servant and mentor to many. He will be remembered with profound respect. 1

MOCCIA--Lena, (nee Galatola) aka Lena Marcie on Friday, October 22, 2015 at home in Coney Island as she wished, surrounded by family. She was predeceased by her husband Dominic. She is survived by her brother Michael Galatola (Regine) and too many nieces and nephews to name. She was the youngest girl of her late parents Salvatore and Maria (nee Vallone) and was predeceased by her six loving sisters and five loving brothers. She was the matriarch of her family and will be sorely missed. Visitation Duffy Funeral Home Friday, October 30, from 4 to 8. Mass of Christian burial Guardian Angel Church on Saturday, October 31, 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, Aunt Lena would prefer donations made in her memory to SNACK, 316 E. 53rd St., NYC, NY 10022 www.snacknyc.com, in honor of the special children she loved so much. 1/3
SADOK--Edward. Gone 30 years, remembered daily. Margaret, Mark, David, Lynn 1/3
SAVAGE--David. October 27, 1989. Remembered always with love by his family. He was a special kind of man. 1/3
SURATT--Samuel T. I'll always love you the most. Judy We'll always miss you. Judy, Ben, Dan 1/3

MARKS--Joan, 83, beloved wife of the late Malvin Marks, adored mother of Janet (Alex), Andrew and the late Bradley. Nana to Benjamin and Becky. She had the rare talent of making life-long friends who deeply loved her. 1/3
SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, miss you and your birthday celebrations. So much love. Audrey, Irik, and Jaar-mel 1/3

CONWAY--E. Virgil, of Bronxville on October 21, 2015. Beloved husband of Elaine, loving father of Allison Worthington, Sarah Conway, William Gay and John Gay, devoted grandfather of five. Mr. Conway served as Chairman of the MTA from 1995 to 2001. He also served as Chairman and CEO of The Seaman's Bank for Savings from 1968-1988. At the time of his death he was on the Board of Urstadt Biddle Properties and was on the Board of the New York State Thruway Authority. He spent over 50 years of his life serving the public in many facets, including Chairman of the New York Housing Partnership, Trustee of Colgate and Pace Universities and was an Elder of The Reformed Church of Bronxville. Mr. Conway was committed to Montauk where he was born and raised and spent summers in his vacation home. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 5 to 8pm Wednesday. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Thursday, October 29 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to either a) the Montauk Community Church, P.O. Box 698, Montauk, NY 11954 or b) Colgate University, 13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, NY 13346. 1

GLATT--Herbert, 87, of Maplewood, NJ, died on October 25, 2015. Founder and CEO of Magla Products, Herb is survived by his loving wife Gloria; children Mitchell, Jeffrey, Melissa, and Jordan; and six adoring grandchildren. 1/3

CONTE--Margo Ann (Callan), died peacefully Sunday; she was 73. Loving wife of Bernard Conte, whose death precedes her, adoring mother of Louise and Eric (and spouses Andrew and Jennifer), and dedicated grandmother to Parker, Logan, Baxter, and Will Conte. She also leaves behind her beloved stepmother Frances Rogers Callan, stepbrothers Byron III (and wife Allison, and their children Byron IV, Ariana, and Nathanael), Michael, and her stepsister Katherine (and husband Carmine). Born in Mineola, NY to Byron King Callan II and Martha Healy, she held a graduate degree in education from Adelphi University. Margo moved to New York City after college and taught at P.S. 124 in Chinatown. Viewing hours will be held Tuesday, October 27th, from 2-5pm and from 7-9pm at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to the Lake Wononscopomuc Association in Salisbury, CT, the Scoville Memorial Library, or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York are welcome. 1/3

NATHANSON--Jack. The partners and staff of Ganfer & Shore, LLP mourn the passing of Jack Nathanson, loving husband of Florence Nathanson, beloved father of our partner Margery N. Weinstein and her brothers Bruce and Charlie. We also extend heartfelt condolences to Jack's cherished grandchildren Rebecca and Daniel and many other grandchildren and great- grandchildren. He will be dearly missed and remembered always. 1/3

ROPPOLO--Steven J.,on October 25, at age 84. Cherished husband, beloved father and adored grandfather. He was loved by all. Funeral services at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, on Tuesday, October 27, at 9:45am. 1/3

BRODMAN--Dr. L. Elizabeth. Dr. L. Elizabeth B. Brodman. November 23, 1918 - October 19, 2015. Adored mother, spouse and sister, compassionate and ground breaking physician, died at home in Stamford, Connecticut, early in the morning on October 19, 2015. A complete obituary was in The New York Times on October 25, 2015. 1

MOSHY--Marion S. (nee Shamas), on October 24, 2015. Devoted wife of the late Moneer J. Cherished mother of Joseph, Frederick and Paul. Loving grandmother of Victoria and Julia. Visitation Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home at 97th Street and Third Ave., Brooklyn. Service Friday 10am at Our Lady of Lebanon Cathedral. 1/3

COHEN--Clifford, MD, of Brooklyn, NY, passed away October 26, 2015. Loving husband, father, grandfather and brother. Dr. Cohen grew up in Brooklyn, graduated from NYU and Loyola Medical School and served in the Army in WWII. He had a long distinguished career as a physician in Brooklyn and was loved and respected by family, friends, patients and colleagues. Funeral services on October 28, 11am at Park- side Memorial Chapel, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

GORNICK--Fred, age 86, died of mesothelioma on October 22, 2015, at his home in New York City. A graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, City College of New York, and the University of Pennsylvania, he was a physical chemist and spent most of his career as a professor at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. He was an intrepid traveler, adventurous reader, and urban explorer. He is survived by his daughters, Lisa and Janet Gornick; his sister, Vivian Gornick; his sons-in-law, Kenneth Hollenbeck and Daniel Cahill; and his grandsons, Zachary and Damon Hollenbeck. Donations in his memory can be sent to the Mesothelioma Applied Research Foundation. 1/3

WURZEL--Elaine. On October 24, 2015, at the age of 86, after a battle with lung cancer, she passed away at her residence in Port Washington. Born in Baltimore in 1929, she later attended junior college. In 1949, she married Leonard Wurzel and after four years in Manhattan, in 1953, they moved to Sands Point with their young sons, Mark and Larry. Elaine and Leonard have been members of the Community Synagogue since 1953 and have often been recognized for their devotion and involvement over the years. Elaine served as bazaar chairperson, bulletin editor, Sisterhood board member, and ran the Earners Affair for several years. She worked at Knutsen and Sargent in Port Washington and later at a podiatry office in Manhasset. She served as First Lady to Leonard, who for 22 years was the Mayor of Sands Point. She is survived by her two sons and daughters-in-law, Mark and Ellen Wurzel and Larry Wurzel and Elaine Gnessin. Grandchildren, Jill Wurzel Lekstutis and her husband Carmine Lekstutis, Max Wurzel, and Greg Wurzel, and two great-grandchildren, Alex and Chloe Lekstutis. Funeral Services will be held at The Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Rd., Sands Point, NY 11050 at 11:30am on Wednesday, October 28, 2015. Telephone: (516)883-3144, Web: commsyn.org. Burial will take place at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY 11704. Telephone: (631) 249-2290. After burial, on Wednesday, Shiva will take place at Elaine Wurzel's residence, until 8pm, with services at 7pm. On Thursday, Shiva will take place from 3pm to 8pm, with services at 7pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Community Synagogue. 1/3

PERRONE--Florry. We are very saddened by the death of Florry (Bernstein) Perrone of Boca Raton, Florida on October 25 at age 92, loving wife of the late Sam Perrone, beloved sister of Natalie Mensch and the late Sheldon Bernstein, and adored aunt of three generations of nieces and nephews. Florry was greatly admired for her courage, intelligence and, most of all, for her warm and caring nature. Interment will be in the Family Plot, Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island on Wednesday, October 28 at 11:30am. 1/3

COHEN--Clifford, MD, of Brooklyn, NY, passed away October 26, 2015. Loving husband, father, grandfather and brother. Dr. Cohen grew up in Brooklyn, graduated from NYU and Loyola Medical School and served in the Army in WWII. He had a long distinguished career as a physician in Brooklyn and was loved and respected by family, friends, patients and colleagues. Funeral services on October 28, 11am at Park- side Memorial Chapel, Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

BREINDEL--Howard, 78, died at home on October 21, 2015, after a long, joyful life and a brief illness. He was born in New York City and raised in Lakewood, NJ and Loch Sheldrake, NY. In 2007 he became a full-time resident of his lake house in Milford, PA. After graduating from The Wharton School and Columbia Law School, he began his career as an anti-trust trial attorney for the U.S. Department of Justice. He was a young litigation partner at Regan, Goldfarb, Powell & Quinn before co-founding his own successful New York City firms, Solin & Breindel, in 1976, and Breindel & Ferstendig in 1992. A highlight of Howard's career was his argument before the U.S. Supreme Court. After retiring in 2001, Howard served as an arbitrator and mediator for the American Arbitration Association and FINRA. He shared with family and friends his love of books, movies, music, travel, politics, and good food. He was smart, funny, warm, kind and generous. He loved the sun and the water, Elvis, tennis, the New York Giants and Knicks, dancing, a spirited debate, The New York Times, palindromes, blackjack and a nice gin and tonic. He became a devotee of the local gym and Ray-N-Charles, and he brought a smile on his many "errands" around town. He had a way with children and could make anyone laugh. The son of a Catskill hotel owner, Howard loved people and was most happy with a house full of family. He was a wonderful friend, mentor and husband to Carol Witschel; a terrific father to his three children, Wendy Huckstepp, Courtney Breindel, and Harlan Breindel and their spouses; a fun and loving Zip (grandfather) to Alex Huckstepp, James Huckstepp, Max Huckstepp and Elias Miller Breindel. He was a delightful uncle to many nieces and nephews, and a much-loved cousin to Marty Friedman and his family. We will all miss him very much. Howard was predeceased by his beloved mother, Helen Breindel Baron and his brother Neal Breindel. All are welcome to join his family to remember and celebrate Howard's life on November 21, from 2-5pm at the Dingman Township Fire House, 680 Log Tavern Road in Milford, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. 1/3

RUBIN--LOUIS 89, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of NYC and West Islip, passed away on October 25. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 59 years, Ruth Collinson who succumbed to cancer on July 30. Rubin began his career in commercial finance with A.J. Armstrong, becoming president in 1978. Rubin was a giant in the world of corp finance, mergers and acquisitions. Rubin finished his career as president/CEO of NatWest USA Credit Corporation. Rubin and his wife, Ruth, lived a long full and life filled with friends, family, golf, music and travel. They are survived by their daughters, Carol and Emily, their sons-in-law, Steven Kaplan and Richard Persons, their grandsons: Rob, James, Trey, Sam and Alec. A memorial celebration of their lives will be held in New York, next April. 1/3

GENDEL--Gladys, 85, on October 5th after a long illness. She was the daughter of Herschel and Feige Gendel and is survived by her brother Joshua. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Center for Jewish History, 15 W. 16th St., New York, NY 10011. 1/3

BATKIN--Stanley. Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, Jerusalem, mourns the passing of Stanley Batkin, longtime supporter and cherished past president of our Board. Our thoughts are with his wife and the Batkin Family at this difficult time. Ilan Kaufthal, Chairman Bathsheva Rifkin, President 1/3

DAWKINS--John Campbell "Jack," bought his first stock at age 13, and sold his last at 95, just days before he died on October 13, 2015 of complications from a stroke. He was born July 28, 1920 in Fort Worth, TX, and spent his last years in Bennington, VT. A stockbroker on Wall Street for many years, Jack prided himself in his "old school" trading habits: a mix of research, intuition, and a remarkable memory for corporate detail. He and his brother, Richard Dawkins, were founding partners of the Wall Street brokerage house, Faulkner, Dawkins and Sullivan, which grew into one of Wall Street's top research firms. In 1977, the firm was acquired by the financier Sandy Weill. A WWII Veteran, Jack enlisted as a Seaman and served in the Pacific at the Battle of Midway, the Doolittle Raid, and the Battle of the Coral Sea. He was serving on the U.S.S. Vincennes when it was sunk in the fiery Battle of Savo Island, and spent twenty-four hours in the water clinging to a piece of wreckage with shipmates. Rescued and recuperating on a small Pacific island, he celebrated by drinking some illegal hooch known as "torpedo juice," made from refining the alcohol in torpedo fuel. Jack wandered off to the beach and fell asleep in the velvety sand, sleeping through roll call the next morning. But his reprimand proved to be a stroke of luck: his commanding officer recommended he be returned to the United States for officer training at Yale University. Jack later returned to the Pacific theater to command a landing craft. His advice to young people? "Drink the torpedo juice and see what happens." In 1942, Jack married Jean Turbett. He graduated from Yale in 1946, and lived in Port Washington, where they raised two sons. Jack was predeceased by both sons, Bob and Bill Dawkins, and by his wife, Jean, and all four of his siblings: Thomas Dawkins, Richard B. Dawkins, Joan Dawkins Costin and Christine Dawkins Randall. Survivors include nineteen fond nieces and nephews. A good and generous man with a delightful, self- deprecating sense of humor, Jack touched many people with his kindness, optimism and wit. 1/3

KELLY--Thomas Morgan, 73, of Parkinson's Disease on October 26. Beloved husband of Nancy Ann Iannicelli and cherished father of Morgan Thomas Kelly. Mr. Kelly was a true gentleman, a man of kindness, intelligence, and courage. Born in Boston, MA, he was the son of the late Thomas and Josephine (Connolly) Kelly. Predeceased by brother Richard. Survivors include brothers John, Joseph, Paul, and Bernard; sisters Mary Patricia (Bartsch) and Ann; and many dear brothers -in-law, sisters-in-law, family, and friends. A graduate of Newman Prep, Mr. Kelly received a B.S. degree from Boston College and an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago. He was honorably discharged as a Captain in the United Sates Army. Mr. Kelly was a partner at H.C. Wainwright & Co., a founding member of Dimensional Fund Advisors, and Chairman of DHK Financial Advisors. Visiting hours on October 29 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, on Friday, October 30 at 10am. 1/3

BAUM--Charles C. Charles Baum died of pancreatic cancer on October 24 at the age of 73. He will be remembered for his wit and wisdom, love of life, generosity, intelligence, and enthusiasm for learning. Above all, he loved his wife, Patricia, his children, grandchildren, and siblings. Nothing was more important to Charles than family and friends. He was a life advisor, a business advisor, and the best question asker. He had an uncanny ability to maintain deep relationships with friends from summer camp, grade school through graduate school, and beyond. For each person in his life, he remembered a birthday, a favorite moment, a funny line. He was a one-man clipping and search service, well before Google, finding what might be meaningful to each person and sending it with a hand-written note. After spending his childhood in Montgomery, AL, Charles graduated from Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School (Class of '64, Phi Beta Kappa, magna cum laude), Harvard Business School (Class of '66), and University of Maryland Law School (Class of '79). After Harvard Business School, he went to Wall Street firm Loeb, Rhoades & Co. He moved to Baltimore in 1973 with his first wife, Jane (Shapiro) Rodbell, where he worked at United Iron & Metal (now United Holdings) with his father-in-law I.D. Shapiro. He continued to run the family office until the onset of his illness in the fall of 2015. In the mid '70s through late '90s, he was a partner at Shapiro, Robinson & Associates, advising professional athletes, including Eddie Murray, Brooks Robinson, Cal Ripken Jr., Willie Mays Aikens, and Kirby Puckett. Upon moving to Baltimore, he became quickly ingrained in the city's civic and philanthropic community. He served on the boards of Center Stage, The Aaron and Lillie Straus Foundation, and the University of Maryland Foundation. In addition, he was the Investment Committee chair of the Associated Jewish Charities of Baltimore and was serving as its President at the time of his death. He was a long time member of Beth Am Synagogue. Charles' corporate board service included Baltimore's MuniMae (now MMA Capital Management), investment advisory firm Gabelli Group Capital Partners, and telecommunications company ICTC. He also served as Chairman and CEO of Morgan Group, Inc. and was a special advisor to Baltimore's Charm City Run. Charles had numerous and diverse interests including the arts, literature, sports, travel, and politics; he never missed a day or page of the Baltimore Sun, The New York Times, or Wall Street Journal. He was proud to be involved in Bill Bradley's presidential campaign and served as a Delegate to the 2000 Democratic National Convention. He enjoyed playing sports throughout his life, especially basketball, tennis, and golf, and was an avid spectator, rooting passionately for the Orioles and, above all, for the Alabama Crimson Tide. Charles is survived by his wife Patricia (Purnell) Baum of Severna Park, MD. He had three children, Andrew (1968- 1971), Katie of Berkeley, CA, and Matthew (Deborah) Baum of Baltimore, MD; and two stepdaughters, Staci (Andrew) Hodge of Baltimore and Beth Bafford (Dan Yeoman) of Washington, DC. He received endless joy from his four grandchildren, Beatrice Kennedy and Max Charles Baum and twins Samantha and Riley Hodge. He is also survived by his sister Sylvia (Herb) Horowitz of Columbia, MD and their children Joanne Beren (Jeff Arbeit), Susan Beren (Rodrigo Pizarro), David Beren, Diana England (Richard), Laura Simon (Warren); his brother John (Diane) Baum of Baltimore, MD and their children, Emily Baum (Josh Burke) and David Baum. In addition, he is survived by Jane (nee Shapiro) Rodbell (Stan) of Baltimore, MD to whom he was married from 1966-95. He was predeceased by his mother, Josephine C. Baum and father, Max S. Baum, both of Montgomery, AL. Lastly, he is survived by many friends, whom he loved and who loved him. Please see funeral home website: http://www.sol levinson.com/ for information on memorial service, contributions and mourning. 1/3

SPEISER--Dr. Burton. Dr. Burton "Burt" Lyle Speiser, 69, of Paradise Valley, Arizona, passed away on October 18, 2015. He was born in New York City, NY on January 24, 1946, the second of four children of Mollie and Morris Speiser. Burt earned an AB in Biology from Queens College and an MD from the New Jersey College of Medicine. He completed his residency in Radiation Oncology while simultaneously earning an MS in Radiation Biology from the University of Rochester. On December 21, 1968 Burt married Jeanne Michelle Gale. They had three children-- Michael, Leonard, and Lisa. Burt was a Major in the U.S. Air Force where he served as Chief of Radiation Oncology at David Grant Medical Center (1974-1976) at Travis AFB, California. He was Associate Director of Radiation Oncology at LDS Hospital (1976-1979) in Salt Lake City, UT. He was Assistant Professor of Radiation Oncology at Indiana University (1979-1980) in Indianapolis, IN. In 1980, Dr. Speiser relocated to Phoenix, Arizona with his family where he worked for several decades as Director of Radiation Oncology at St. Joseph's Hospital and Director of Brachytherapy at Humana Hospital and St. Luke's Hospital. While Burt was passionate about his work, he was a husband and father first. He enjoyed nothing more than spending time with his family and teaching life lessons to his children every night at the dinner table. While Burt encouraged his children to pursue their own dreams, he was never prouder than when his daughter Lisa followed in his footsteps and became a physician. Burt was also an avid reader, hiker, SCUBA diver, and outdoorsman. Burt is survived by his wife of 47 years, Jeanne, his sons Michael and Leonard, his daughter Lisa, his daughters- in-law Mary and Jessica and his seven grandchildren Lauren, Emma, Henry, Anna, Mackenzie, William, and Isabella. The family will be having a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

CONWAY--E. Virgil. His friends and admirers at Rose Associates note with sadness the loss of E. Virgil Conway, an outstanding banker, public servant and mentor to many. He will be remembered with profound respect. 1

HEIMLER--Arnold Jules, 1929-2015. It is with great sadness, we announce the peaceful passing of Arnold Heimler, 86 on October 27, 2015 in Sarasota, Florida. Born in New York City, the son of Walter and Joan Heimler. A graduate of Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School and Indiana University and served in the US Coast Guard. President of Walter Heimler Inc, a manufacturer of costume jewelry for over 40 years. Loving husband of Audrey for 62 years and father of Ronald, Randy, Richard, and Robert, father-in-law to Cecilia, Debra, Chris and Jodi, and grandfather to Michael, Jessica, Rachel, Allison, and Joshua. We have lots to be thankful for and precious memories when we remember Arnold, the patriarch of our family, then, now and forever. Arnold was known by his dear friends and anyone he met for his kind nature, humility, sense of humor and loyal friendship. Donations may be made in Arnold's memory and in honor of his physician, Dr. Hani Hasson at Memorial Sloan, PO Box 27106, NY, NY 10087 or call 646-227-3549. Services will be Thursday, October 29th, 12 noon at "The Riverside" W 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. 1/3

AHERN--Edward F. (Ted) III, passed away on October 7, 2015 at his home in Farmington, CT. A native of Hartford, he graduated from Georgetown University with a BA and Trinity College with an MA before embarking on a teaching career at Housatonic Community College. An avid traveler, he saw the world as both cruise staff and opera tour director. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Thomas More Catholic Chapel in New Haven at 11am on Monday, November 2, 2015. There will be a private interment at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to the Agnes Kelley Ahern Scholarship at the University of St. Joseph in West Hartford, CT. 1/3

DOBROF--Rose. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of The New York Academy of Medicine mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Rose Dobrof, PhD. A Fellow of the Academy for decades, Dr. Dobrof was instrumental creating the Academy's Social Work Section. She was a nationally recognized expert in the field of aging, a mentor to many of the leaders in the field of gerontological social work, and leaves an invaluable legacy. We send our deepest condolences to her family. 1/3

GAYNOR--Philip. Our condolences to Helene, Ben and Josh on the passing of a remarkable man and great friend. We will miss him greatly, but we will be waiting patiently along the first base line for the inevitable long ball. With much love, Karyn, Charlie, Jessica, Marissa and Frodo 1/3

FRIEDBERG--Barry R, 94, of Manhasset, NY died peacefully on October 26, 2015 after a period of declining health. He was born on May 6, 1921 in the Bronx, where he graduated from high school and met his future wife of 72 years. After spending more than three years in the Pacific theater during World War II as a member of the Army Signal Corps, he returned to New York and civilian life, beginning a long career as a commercial photographer. In 1966 he co-founded Kordet Graphics, which became a premier specialist in pre-press color separations. He served as Kordet's Chairman of the Board until his retirement in 1986. He also served as President of Visual Promotions, Inc, until its merger with the Kordet Group in the mid-1980s. During his nearly 30 years in retirement he, together with his late wife, devoted himself to philanthropic activities, making major differences in many lives both in the Boca Raton, FL area as well as in Nassau County, NY. He was pre-deceased by a brother, Eddie Frederics, and by his devoted wife Florence. He is survived by his son, Richard Friedberg and his wife Courtenay Dodge; his daughter, Diane Houslanger and her husband Marc Houslanger; four grandchildren, Sarah Krohn and her husband Maxwell Krohn, Hannah Orowitz and her husband David Orowitz, Michelle Houslanger, and Joseph Houslanger; and two great- grandchildren. He is also survived by a brother, David Friedberg, and sister, Alice Mulberg. The funeral will take place on Wednesday October 28th at Temple B'nai Israel, Elmont, NY with interment at Beth David Cemetery. 1/3

GAYNOR--Phil, on October 26, 2015. Beloved husband of Helene and sons Ben and Josh. Funeral services to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street at 12 noon on October 28, 2015. 1/3

KLEIN--Arnold W. , M.D. The board of trustees and staff of amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the loss of Dr. Arnold Klein, a founding board member of amfAR and trustee emeritus, and an influential advocate for AIDS research and services in the early days of the epidemic. A renowned dermatologist, Dr. Klein was one of the first physicians in Los Angeles to diagnose a case of Kaposi's sarcoma, a disfiguring cancer commonly associated with AIDS. Dr. Klein was involved with several AIDS organizations and served on the board of the National AIDS Research Foundation, along with Elizabeth Taylor, Rock Hudson's physician Dr. Michael Gottlieb, and others. That organization merged with the New York-based AIDS Medical Foundation to become amfAR in 1985. We extend our deepest sympathy to Dr. Klein's family. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman Kevin Robert Frost, Chief Executive Officer 1/3

BRONSTEIN--Alvin J. The board of directors and staff of the American Civil Liberties Union mourn the passing of Alvin J. Bronstein, a true champion of civil rights and civil liberties. Al founded the A.C.L.U.'s National Prison Project in 1972 at a time when prisoners had virtually no rights. Over the next quarter-century, his tireless efforts on behalf of prisoners led to major reforms in prison systems throughout the country. After his retirement from the A.C.L.U., Al became part of a global movement for prison reform through his work with Penal Reform International. From 1964-1968, Al was Chief Staff Counsel for the Lawyers Constitutional Defense Committee, which served as a legal arm to the civil rights movement. He represented Martin Luther King, Jr., among many others, during a critical period in this nation's civil rights history. Al was beaten up for his efforts, but he never backed down. Al was more than a great lawyer, he was a moral force. In 1989, he received a MacArthur "genius award" for his contributions to prisoners' rights and criminal justice reform. On four different occasions, he was named one of the country's 100 most influential lawyers by the National Law Journal. A memorial will be held in Washington, D.C., at the Washington Ethical Society on Monday, January 18 (MLK, Jr. Day), from 2-4pm. Al's life and work were an inspiration to generations of public interest lawyers. He truly made a difference. Our deep sympathies go to Al's wife, children, and everyone who was touched by this remarkable man. He will be missed. Anthony D. Romero Executive Director of the American Civil Liberties Union 1/3

CONWAY--E. Virgil. His friends and admirers at Rose Associates note with sadness the loss of E. Virgil Conway, an outstanding banker, public servant and mentor to many. He will be remembered with profound respect. 1

CONWAY--E. Virgil. The Partnership for New York City mourns the passing of E. Virgil Conway, who joined David Rockefeller as a founding member of an organization of business leaders dedicated to renewal of the city after the fiscal and economic crises of the 1970s. For more than a decade, Virg chaired the Housing Partnership, working with government, banks and builders to bring affordable home ownership and minority business opportunities to distressed neighborhoods across the five boroughs. His contribution to making New York the vibrant city it is today was enormous and he will be remembered. 1/3

HEWITT--Genevieve F.,88, of New York City and East Hampton, New York, passed away peacefully on October 26th, 2015. She is survived by her sister Nancy Fish, her daughters Elizabeth Meyer and Katherine Meyer and her grandchildren Jake, Robby and Alice Gadon. She was the beloved wife of the late William B. Fernandez and the late Richard G. Hewitt, daughter of the late Abraham and Alice Fisch, sister of the late Richard Fisch and Stephen Fisch. A graduate of Smith and Barnard Colleges, Genevieve was the Home Building and Decorating Editor of Good Housekeeping Magazine. She also edited the Ethan Allen Treasury and wrote "The ABCs of Decorating," published by Doubleday & Company, Inc. She contributed to Woman's Day, House Beautiful and House & Garden Magazines and had a syndicated column for twelve years. Genevieve was an accomplished bridge player as a Gold Life Master. She will be sorely missed. 1/3

KELLY--Thomas Morgan, 73, of Parkinson's Disease on October 26. Beloved husband of Nancy Ann Iannicelli and cherished father of Morgan Thomas Kelly. Mr. Kelly was a true gentleman, a man of kindness, intelligence, and courage. Born in Boston, MA, he was the son of the late Thomas and Josephine (Connolly) Kelly. Predeceased by brother Richard. Survivors include brothers John, Joseph, Paul, and Bernard; sisters Mary Patricia (Bartsch) and Ann; and many dear brothers -in-law, sisters-in-law, family, and friends. A graduate of Newman Prep, Mr. Kelly received a B.S. degree from Boston College and an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago. He was honorably discharged as a Captain in the United Sates Army. Mr. Kelly was a partner at H.C. Wainwright & Co., a founding member of Dimensional Fund Advisors, and Chairman of DHK Financial Advisors. Visiting hours on October 29 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, on Friday, October 30 at 10am. 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Robert, on October 27, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Loving father of Barbara Weintraub (late Martin), Joanne and Dan Free, Larry and Lisa Davidoff, Lisa and the late Howard Davidoff. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Allison, Amanda, Melanie (Luci), Jesse, Owen, Gabrie, Benjamin, Hannah and Michael. Great-grandfather of Rachel and Seth. Services Friday, 12 Noon, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. www.riversidenassau northchapels.com 1/3

ZORN--Danny. Our love for you is so strong, and our thoughts of you so vivid, spiritually, you have never left us. Yet everyday, we wish we could talk to you and hug you. Forever in our minds and hearts. Mom, Dad, Katie and Theo 1/3

COHEN--Randi. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Jewish Communal Fund mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Randi Cohen, wife of our esteemed past president, Larry Cohen. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Larry, their sons, Michael, Benjamin, Jacob and Samuel and to the entire Cohen and Robinson family. May her memory be for a blessing. Noel J. Spiegel President Susan F. Dickman Executive Vice President & CEO 1/3

SEITELMAN--Leo H.,passed away peacefully after a short illness at the age of 97.5. Mr. Seitelman was a graduate of City College with honors in accounting. He was a Certified Public Accountant in his own practice for many years. He was also a World War II Veteran (Army-Chief Warrant Officer in Finance). One of his proudest accomplishments was being president of Temple Beth Emeth v'Ohr Progressive Shaari Zedek of Flatbush, Brooklyn. He leaves behind sons Mark (Minna) and Edward, and grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The Funeral is on Friday, October 30th, at 11:30am at The Weinstein Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., at Ave. H, Brooklyn, with burial to follow. 1/3

COHEN--Randi. With profound sadness we learned of the passing, much too soon, of our dear friend, Randi Cohen. Randi, along with her husband, Larry, were staunch supporters of Blythedale Children's Hospital and to the young patients we serve. Larry was a former Chair of the Board of Blythedale, and continues to be an esteemed member. Their multi-faceted contributions have improved the lives of countless children. We send our deep and sincere condolences to Larry, their children and the entire family. David Pedowitz, Chair Larry Levine, President & CEO Blythedale Children's Hospital, 95 Bradhurst Avenue Valhalla, NY 10595 1/3

SAVAGE--Marilyn. 10/29/45 - 2/9/94. Should have been an amazing party, but 70 is just the latest of the 22 you've been cheated out of. Definitely would have wanted to strangle you on a regular basis, but I would have never stopped loving you. Haven't. Miss you. Vicki 1/3

YORK--George. With profound sadness the family of George York are grief stricken and mourn in his sudden passing. George was President and owner of York Restoration Corp., a prominent waterproofing and restoration company that redefined the face of New York City real estate. Mr. York was also co-owner of York Studios, a motion picture and television establishment. George was an enthusiastic, passionate and savvy businessman. He demonstrated leadership and unconditional loyalty. He is survived by his loving wife Patricia and two daughters Kristina and Jenni. 1/3

WEILL--Marie-Helene, (born Lausanne, October 20, 1920) died Tuesday, a week after celebrating her 95th birthday. She is survived by her loving daughters Claudia, Kathryn and Patricia, her adored grandchildren Emily and Alison Goldfrank, Sam and Eli Teller and their father, Walter S. Teller. Marie-Helene emigrated to the US in 1939 with her parents and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1941. In 1942, she married Guy Weill (died 2006), with whom she shared a passion for music and art. Inspired by her work as a docent at The China Institute, she became a lecturer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where in 2002, the Weills had a memorable show of their Chinese paintings, "The Cultivated Landscape." She and her husband were generous donors of art to the Arthur M. Sackler Museum at Harvard and Sackler Gallery at the Smithsonian, the Brooklyn Museum, as well as patrons of the Metropolitan Opera, Carnegie Hall, Asia Society and The China Institute. Her joyous passion for life and gift for friendship inspired all who met her. Service, Thursday, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Marie-Helene Weill to Young Audiences (www.youn gaudiences.org/). 1/3

PAPPAS--Michael. Dr. Michael Pappas died Sunday, October 25, 2015 from complications of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Pappas was an internationally recognized expert in advanced biomechanical design. He received his Ph.D. in 1970 from Rutgers University in mechanical engineering specializing in computer-aided-structural-design Dr. Pappas published over 60 scholarly publications and was awarded over 50 United States patents resulting from his work in computer-aided-design and orthopedic biomechanics. His research in this field attracted international attention. Dr. Pappas, with his co- designer, Frederick F. Buechel, M.D., developed and patented the first mobile bearing knee. The innovative design of the LCS knee has been implanted in thousands of patients around the world. Dr. Pappas was a founder of Endotec, a privately-held medical device firm based in Orlando, Florida and widely recognized as a global leader in the safe application of advanced technology for human implants and implantation instruments. Born in Moscow, USSR on December 14, 1932 to John and Anna Pappas, his family came to the U.S. in 1937, settling in Newark, NJ. He received a B.S.M.E. and M.S.M.E. from the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT). He taught mechanical engineering at NJIT for more than 25 years until he became involved in the design of replacement joints. A longtime resident of Caldwell, NJ and Jensen Beach, Florida, he is survived by his wife, Cynthia, and his children Elaine Brier, Alec and John Pappas, and grandchildren Michael and John Brier. He is also survived by his siblings Julie Kole, Lucille Duran and Kathryn Veski and her Husband Vello and brothers John and Paul. Friends and relatives are invited to the family home on Sunday afternoon, November 1 from 1pm to 5pm. Please omit flowers. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack. We mourn the passing of Jack Glazer, our beloved partner and friend. Jack has been an integral part of our business since its inception. An absolute professional, Jack knew how to build both buildings and relationships. His dedication, fairness, warmth, and humor will be missed by all who dealt with him, most of all our staff and especially we, his partners, Charlie and Bella. Jack is irreplaceable. We send our deepest condolences, love and strength to Catherine, their children, Lola and Leo, and their entire family. CB Developers CBJ Management 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Robert. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Robert Davidoff, a truly gentle man and quiet philanthropist with a commitment to helping those in need. He was a generous supporter of Jewish communities worldwide and a lifelong friend to Israel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Robert's beloved children, Barbara, Joanne (Barry), Larry (Lisa), and Lisa; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

PAPPAS--Michael. Dr. Michael Pappas died Sunday, October 25, 2015 from complications of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Pappas was an internationally recognized expert in advanced biomechanical design. He received his Ph.D. in 1970 from Rutgers University in mechanical engineering specializing in computer-aided-structural-design Dr. Pappas published over 60 scholarly publications and was awarded over 50 United States patents resulting from his work in computer-aided-design and orthopedic biomechanics. His research in this field attracted international attention. Dr. Pappas, with his co- designer, Frederick F. Buechel, M.D., developed and patented the first mobile bearing knee. The innovative design of the LCS knee has been implanted in thousands of patients around the world. Dr. Pappas was a founder of Endotec, a privately-held medical device firm based in Orlando, Florida and widely recognized as a global leader in the safe application of advanced technology for human implants and implantation instruments. Born in Moscow, USSR on December 14, 1932 to John and Anna Pappas, his family came to the U.S. in 1937, settling in Newark, NJ. He received a B.S.M.E. and M.S.M.E. from the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT). He taught mechanical engineering at NJIT for more than 25 years until he became involved in the design of replacement joints. A longtime resident of Caldwell, NJ and Jensen Beach, Florida, he is survived by his wife, Cynthia, and his children Elaine Brier, Alec and John Pappas, and grandchildren Michael and John Brier. He is also survived by his siblings Julie Kole, Lucille Duran and Kathryn Veski and her Husband Vello and brothers John and Paul. Friends and relatives are invited to the family home on Sunday afternoon, November 1 from 1pm to 5pm. Please omit flowers. 1/3

ZIGMAN--Anita. It is with great sadness and profound grief that we share the death of Anita, two days after her sixtieth birthday, from complications of cancer. A wife, mother, sister, friend and colleague, she touched the lives of many; anyone who knew her was much better for it. She is survived by her two sons and husband, and her sister and brother. All will miss her terribly. Services: Sunday, 1:30pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in her name to either North Shore Animal League or Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Gerald F.,attorney, ethicist and philanthropist, passed away at 90 on October 19, 2015 in Los Angeles, CA, surrounded by his devoted family. Mr. Phillips is survived by his beloved wife and life partner of 58 years, Francine A. Phillips, daughter, Stacy D. Phillips, son, Louis M. Phillips, daughter-in- law, Jackie Phillips and grandchildren, Andrew and Alison Bloomgarden, and Bobby and Jeffrey Phillips. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations in Mr. Phillips' memory be made to the Phillips/Samuels/Victor Family Fund at the Dartmouth Ethics Institute, Dartmouth College, NH. A full tribute may be read at PhillipsLerner.com. 1/3

COHEN--Randi. With profound sadness we learned of the passing, much too soon, of our dear friend, Randi Cohen. Randi, along with her husband, Larry, were staunch supporters of Blythedale Children's Hospital and to the young patients we serve. Larry was a former Chair of the Board of Blythedale, and continues to be an esteemed member. Their multi-faceted contributions have improved the lives of countless children. We send our deep and sincere condolences to Larry, their children and the entire family. David Pedowitz, Chair Larry Levine, President & CEO Blythedale Children's Hospital, 95 Bradhurst Avenue Valhalla, NY 10595 1/3

GLAZER--Jack M.,63, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving family. Cherished and adoring husband of Catherine, loving and exceptional father to Lola and Leo, devoted brother to Carol (Ron), beloved brother-in-law to Mane, dearest uncle to Elizabeth and Andrew (Gretchen). Cousin to Simon (Bambi), Selina, (Daniel) and Eli, Aron, Abby, Riva (David) and Serj, family in Tel Aviv, Paris and Buenos Aires. Born in NYC to Rosa and Leo, Holocaust survivors from Poland. Leo saved hundreds of Jews, for which he was proclaimed "Prince of the Lodz Ghetto." Following in his father's tradition, Jack was the very definition of a "mentsch." The warmest and most generous man, friend, mentor and father figure to countless people from all walks of life, his impact and inspiration is incalculable. Brought into the family real estate business at a young age, he soon became partner to his dear childhood friend, Charles Blaichman. Deeply respected for his dedication, honesty and knowledge, he was a consummate professional. He was proudest of the family he created with the Love of his life, Catherine. They filled their home with family and friends, art, food and laughter. Their love is deep and resonant. And he fought like a lion to stay with them. Donations may be made to Yad Vashem, Doctors Without Borders or Sloan Kettering. Services at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Friday, October 30 at 10:30am. 1/3

ZIGMAN--Anita J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing of our friend and colleague, Anita J. Zigman. We express our deepest sympathies to all members of the family. 1/3

TENENBAUM--Norman. 86, passed away on October 22, 2015. A longtime resident of New York City, Mr. Tenenbaum was born and raised in Newark, NJ. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where he was a member of the Kappa Nu Fraternity. An Army veteran of the Korean War, Mr. Tenenbaum was a co-owner of C. Tenenbaum Furniture Company of Ferry Street, Newark. Fluent in seven languages and a talented designer, he spent over 40 years at designer furniture store, Maurice Villency. Mr. Tenenbaum was also an accomplished pianist, playing all over the world accompanying opera stars, and spent his free time at Lincoln Center. In recent years, he volunteered his time at The Julliard School. He is survived by sister-in-law Constance Tenenbaum, three generations of nieces and nephews, along with numerous dear friends including Rowann Villency, Dawn David and Francois Becerra. Memorial donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera House or the New York Ballet. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack. The Blaichman Family is profoundly shocked and devastated by the passing of our dearest friend. What began as a friendship between two adolescent boys from Forest Hills - laughter, adventures and music - developed into an extraordinary, life-long bond that grew to include their wives, children and countless friends. The love between our two families has been essential to our souls and we cherish the memories we have of our everyday life together, family dinners, summers in Woodstock and joyous celebrations. How fortunate we were to have Jack's generosity of spirit envelop us. We will be forever warmed by his love, empathy, humor and wisdom. To Catherine, Lola and Leo, we share your grief in this dark hour. Charlie, Aviva, Micah, Sabrina and Noah 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Robert, on October 27, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Loving father of Barbara Weintraub (late Martin), Joanne and Dan Free, Larry and Lisa Davidoff, Lisa and the late Howard Davidoff. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Allison, Amanda, Melanie (Luci), Jesse, Owen, Gabrie, Benjamin, Hannah and Michael. Great-grandfather of Rachel and Seth. Services Friday, 12 Noon, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. www.riversidenassau northchapels.com 1/3

GENDEL--Gladys, 85, on October 5th after a long illness. She was the daughter of Herschel and Feige Gendel and is survived by her brother Joshua. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Center for Jewish History, 15 W. 16th St., New York, NY 10011. 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Robert G.,CPA. Carl Marks & Co., its shareholders, employees, and affiliates, mourn the passing of our long-time friend and respected member of the firm. Bob was the leading force behind the success of our venture capital affiliates CMNY Capital LP and CMNY Capital II LP. He was an astute businessperson, sage counselor, and trusted colleague. Bob also was a loyal sports fan and was proud of his beloved Mets. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and sincere condolences to the Davidoff family. 1/3

WURZEL--Elaine. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Elaine Wurzel, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elaine's beloved children, Larry (Elaine) and Mark (Ellen); her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

OWENS--Edward S.,80, of Indianapolis, IN, died on Friday, October 23, 2015 in the company of family. Born and raised in Jackson Heights, NY, Ed attended Blessed Sacrament Elementary, Xavier High School and Fordham University, graduating in 1956. Following military service in the army, Ed enjoyed a 30 year career in computer programming that started at IBM and ended at the International Monetary Fund. He was a talented amateur photographer. In 1967 Ed married his cherished wife Mary. They spent 42 wonderful years together traveling, listening to classical music and drinking fine wines. Mary remained in his heart and on his mind since her death in 2009. A devout Catholic and recent initiate into the Knights of Columbus, Ed's preference for memorial contributions is: St Vincent de Paul Society, St. William Catholic Church, 750 Seagate Drive, Naples, FL 34103. Services: Indiana Funeral Care & Crematory. 1/3

SEITELMAN--Leo H.,passed away peacefully after a short illness at the age of 97.5. Mr. Seitelman was a graduate of City College with honors in accounting. He was a Certified Public Accountant in his own practice for many years. He was also a World War II Veteran (Army-Chief Warrant Officer in Finance). One of his proudest accomplishments was being president of Temple Beth Emeth v'Ohr Progressive Shaari Zedek of Flatbush, Brooklyn. He leaves behind sons Mark (Minna) and Edward, and grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The Funeral is on Friday, October 30th, at 11:30am at The Weinstein Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., at Ave. H, Brooklyn, with burial to follow. 1/3

BOWMAN--James Kinsey, a resident of Bedford, NY since 1966, passed away on October 22, 2015. Jim was born in Strongsville, OH and graduated from Denison University in Granville, OH in 1956. He immediately went to work for the McGraw-Hill Book Co. After a successful career as an executive with the Book Co., he retired in 1990. He then helped with his wife's company, Judith Bowman Books, specializing in antiquarian fishing and hunting books. He and his wife were both avid fly fishermen and traveled extensively in pursuit of salmon, trout, and some salt water species. Jim was a member of the Anglers Club of New York City and an honorary member of the Slagle Trout Club in Harrietta, MI. His wife Judith predeceased him in March of this year. He leaves three children and their families: Reed Bowman, Stacy Gates, and Todd Bowman. He also leaves five grandchildren and a sister, Sue Conlin of Whittier, NC. Services are private. Donations may be made to the Bedford Free Library or the Bedford Fire Department, both of Bedford, NY 10506. 1/3

DEMARAY--John G. 84, died October 24 at Lennox Hill Hospital of bilateral pneumonia. Writer, Renaissance scholar, professor Emeritus, Rutgers University, and gentle man, he was the intensely loved and wonderfully loving husband for 55 years to Hannah Disinger Demaray; and the best of sons to John and Marjorie Coyle Demaray of Somerville, NJ. After the Army, and Notre Dame Law School, he earned his Ph.D with honors at Columbia where he met Hannah. Years of adventure, reflection, and writing began--all leavened with humor and Jack's pleasure in magic. "Gladly would he learn and gladly teach"-- and so he did at universities in Cairo, Beirut, Damascus, Florence, Los Angeles, Kentucky, and New Jersey. His many books on Shaw, Milton, Dante and Shakespeare were about philosophy, pilgrimage, history, and literary genre. His life was about integrity, faith, and love. He retained, even in his final illness, anachronistic courtliness, geniality, and devotion. He is survived by his wife, several cousins, and many friends. Funeral November 7, 2:00pm, Church of the Ascension, 5th Ave. and 10th St. 1/3

DAWKINS--John Campbell "Jack," bought his first stock at age 13, and sold his last at 95, just days before he died on October 13, 2015 of complications from a stroke. He was born July 28, 1920 in Fort Worth, TX, and spent his last years in Bennington, VT. A stockbroker on Wall Street for many years, Jack prided himself in his "old school" trading habits: a mix of research, intuition, and a remarkable memory for corporate detail. He and his brother, Richard Dawkins, were founding partners of the Wall Street brokerage house, Faulkner, Dawkins and Sullivan, which grew into one of Wall Street's top research firms. In 1977, the firm was acquired by the financier Sandy Weill. A WWII Veteran, Jack enlisted as a Seaman and served in the Pacific at the Battle of Midway, the Doolittle Raid, and the Battle of the Coral Sea. He was serving on the U.S.S. Vincennes when it was sunk in the fiery Battle of Savo Island, and spent twenty-four hours in the water clinging to a piece of wreckage with shipmates. Rescued and recuperating on a small Pacific island, he celebrated by drinking some illegal hooch known as "torpedo juice," made from refining the alcohol in torpedo fuel. Jack wandered off to the beach and fell asleep in the velvety sand, sleeping through roll call the next morning. But his reprimand proved to be a stroke of luck: his commanding officer recommended he be returned to the United States for officer training at Yale University. Jack later returned to the Pacific theater to command a landing craft. His advice to young people? "Drink the torpedo juice and see what happens." In 1942, Jack married Jean Turbett. He graduated from Yale in 1946, and lived in Port Washington, where they raised two sons. Jack was predeceased by both sons, Bob and Bill Dawkins, and by his wife, Jean, and all four of his siblings: Thomas Dawkins, Richard B. Dawkins, Joan Dawkins Costin and Christine Dawkins Randall. Survivors include nineteen fond nieces and nephews. A good and generous man with a delightful, self-deprecating sense of humor, Jack touched many people with his kindness, optimism and wit. 1/3

BROOKS--Owen. Helen Keller Services mourns the passing of its former Board Trustee, Owen Brooks on October 25th at his home in Amityville. For over 40 years Mr. Brooks strengthened and furthered the mission of HKS within the blind and deaf- blind community. (A full bio including his achievements can be found at www.helenkeller.org). Our heartfelt condolences to his wife of 65 years, Marilyn Blank Brooks, his two sons and nine grandchildren. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Howard. We mourn the passing of our beloved father, Howard W. Friedman, at age 90, on October 30, 2015. He is survived by his devoted wife of 63 years, Lee, adoring children, Ira, Debra, Patti and Jane, eight grandchildren and sisters, Gloria and Myrna. Howard will be deeply missed by his family and friends, and the wider community, in which he was held in the highest regard. Funeral will be held on Sunday, November 1, 2015 at 10:30am at Boulevard-River- side Chapels at 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. 1/3

GREGORY--Niki. Niki Gregory, 62, of Cold Spring Harbor passed away on Wednesday, October 28th. Loving Wife to Husband Joe, caring Mother of Rory Golod, Matt Gregory, Alex Golod, Chloe Golod and Chris Gregory, and her Daughter-In-Law to be, Drew Damann; Niki is also survived by her parents George and Helen Papageorge, Brother Stephen Papageorge, Sister Denise Vigilo, beloved nephews Kenny and Kyle Vigilo, numerous extended family members, and an endless legion of close friends. A true matriarch, when Niki wasn't dedicating herself to her children and family, she was using her focus and passion to help others through her support of the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, and as former Chairwoman of the Maurer Foundation. A cancer survivor for nearly three decades, Niki's strength and courage served as inspiration for anyone who was lucky enough to know her. Niki's presence during her time on Earth was immeasurable, and although her physical presence is no longer with us, her spirit will be forever felt by all who loved her. Service: Memorial Mass Tuesday, November 3rd 2015, 9:45am-- Church of St. Patrick, 400 Main Street, Huntington, New York, 11743. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack. The Blaichman Family is profoundly shocked and devastated by the passing of our dearest friend. What began as a friendship between two adolescent boys from Forest Hills - laughter, adventures and music - developed into an extraordinary, life-long bond that grew to include their wives, children and countless friends. The love between our two families has been essential to our souls and we cherish the memories we have of our everyday life together, family dinners, summers in Woodstock and joyous celebrations. How fortunate we were to have Jack's generosity of spirit envelop us. We will be forever warmed by his love, empathy, humor and wisdom. To Catherine, Lola and Leo, we share your grief in this dark hour. Charlie, Aviva, Micah, Sabrina and Noah 1/3
HEIFERMAN--Julia. 9/4/1911 - 10/31/2014 Beloved mother and grandmother. You are always in our minds and hearts. Barbara and Julian, Joyce and Ivan, Craig and Paul 1/3

SILVERIO--Kathryn M.,60, passed away at home Sunday, October 25, 2015. All services are private and under the direction of John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ. Please visit Kathryn's Memorial Website at: www. johnedayfuneralhome.com. 1/3

FRANKLIN--Gwen Randolph. Gwen Randolph Franklin recently passed away at home at age 97. A lifelong resident of NYC and East Hampton, she loved to travel while leading a trailblazing career in fashion. A fashion editor at Harper's Bazaar for 25 years, she inspired a generation of working women, befriended top American designers and photographers. Gwen will be remembered for her strong spirit, love of family and amazing style. She is predeceased by son Christopher F. Randolph and husband Gordon P. Franklin; survived by Haughton Randolph, Jr./ Julienne Gallardo (Mexico City), Patricia Lyons Randolph (Gulf Stream, FL) and four grandchildren. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack. We mourn the passing of Jack Glazer, our beloved partner and friend. Jack has been an integral part of our business since its inception. An absolute professional, Jack knew how to build both buildings and relationships. His dedication, fairness, warmth, and humor will be missed by all who dealt with him, most of all our staff and especially we, his partners, Charlie and Bella. Jack is irreplaceable. We send our deepest condolences, love and strength to Catherine, their children, Lola and Leo, and their entire family. CB Developers CBJ Management 1/3

KOOTA--Dr. Gordon, passed away peacefully at home yesterday after a long and courageous fight with Alzheimer's. His wife Audrey of almost 60 years, and his two daughters, Hillary and Claudia were by his side. Dr. Koota was a dedicated surgeon, an accomplished athlete and had a unique connection to his friends. He will be deeply missed by his three grandchildren, Sam, Carly, and Adam, his son-in-law Glenn Krevlin and Jay Siegel. 1/3

SENTER--Brian Kenneth, Walla Walla, WA. Born: February 03, 1965. Died: October 24, 2015. Brian was an actor, teacher and caretaker to the many young lives he encountered in life. Survived by his beloved wife, Mary, and children Hirut, Owen, Liya, August and Ruth, he was as well loved by a great multitude of family, friends and students, each of whom, he held dear in his heart. 1/3

ZIGMAN--Anita J. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing of our friend and colleague, Anita J. Zigman. We express our deepest sympathies to all members of the family. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack M.,63, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving family. Cherished and adoring husband of Catherine, loving and exceptional father to Lola and Leo, devoted brother to Carol (Ron), beloved brother-in-law to Mane, dearest uncle to Elizabeth and Andrew (Gretchen). Cousin to Simon (Bambi), Selina, (Daniel) and Eli, Aron, Abby, Riva (David) and Serj, family in Tel Aviv, Paris and Buenos Aires. Born in NYC to Rosa and Leo, Holocaust survivors from Poland. Leo saved hundreds of Jews, for which he was proclaimed "Prince of the Lodz Ghetto." Following in his father's tradition, Jack was the very definition of a "mentsch." The warmest and most generous man, friend, mentor and father figure to countless people from all walks of life, his impact and inspiration is incalculable. Brought into the family real estate business at a young age, he soon became partner to his dear childhood friend, Charles Blaichman. Deeply respected for his dedication, honesty and knowledge, he was a consummate professional. He was proudest of the family he created with the Love of his life, Catherine. They filled their home with family and friends, art, food and laughter. Their love is deep and resonant. And he fought like a lion to stay with them. Donations may be made to Yad Vashem, Doctors Without Borders or Sloan Kettering. 1/3

PAPPAS--Michael. Dr. Michael Pappas died Sunday, October 25, 2015 from complications of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Pappas was an internationally recognized expert in advanced biomechanical design. He received his Ph.D. in 1970 from Rutgers University in mechanical engineering specializing in computer-aided-structural-design Dr. Pappas published over 60 scholarly publications and was awarded over 50 United States patents resulting from his work in computer-aided-design and orthopedic biomechanics. His research in this field attracted international attention. Dr. Pappas, with his co- designer, Frederick F. Buechel, M.D., developed and patented the first mobile bearing knee. The innovative design of the LCS knee has been implanted in thousands of patients around the world. Dr. Pappas was a founder of Endotec, a privately-held medical device firm based in Orlando, Florida and widely recognized as a global leader in the safe application of advanced technology for human implants and implantation instruments. Born in Moscow, USSR on December 14, 1932 to John and Anna Pappas, his family came to the U.S. in 1937, settling in Newark, NJ. He received a B.S.M.E. and M.S.M.E. from the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT). He taught mechanical engineering at NJIT for more than 25 years until he became involved in the design of replacement joints. A longtime resident of Caldwell, NJ and Jensen Beach, Florida, he is survived by his wife, Cynthia, and his children Elaine Brier, Alec and John Pappas, and grandchildren Michael and John Brier. He is also survived by his siblings Julie Kole, Lucille Duran and Kathryn Veski and her Husband Vello and brothers John and Paul. Friends and relatives are invited to the family home on Sunday afternoon, November 1 from 1pm to 5pm. Please omit flowers. 1/3

Petra Kvitova will chase her second W.T.A. finals title after outplaying third-seeded Maria Sharapova, 6-3, 7-6 (3), in the semifinals Saturday in Singapore.
Rory McIlroy shot a five-under-par 67 in the third round, leaving him a stroke behind the leaders at the Turkish Airlines Open in Antalya, Turkey.

Fan Yilin of China, Viktoria Komova of Russia and Daria Spiridonova and Madison Kocian of the United States tied for the top spot in the uneven bars finals at the world gymnastics championships in Glasgow.
Ashley Wagner ran away with the Skate Canada women’s title in Lethbridge, Alberta.
