MALIN--Arthur. Art Malin was a passionate, empathic, generous human being. He loved life, his family, friends, his profession, learning, playing tennis and bridge at the Tennis Club, the LA Dodgers, Chicago-style hot dogs, and serving his Beverly Hills community. Art was born in Chicago, IL, to Milton and Anna Malin. After serving in the Air Force, he attended medical school at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York, and went on to undertake psychoanalytic training at the Los Angeles Psychoanalytic Society and Institute. He became a Training and Supervising Analyst at five Los Angeles psychoanalytic institutes, and was a Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at UCLA . His vigorous professional open- mindedness led him to Self Psychology, and he was a member of the original group studying with Heinz Kohut. In addition, Art was elected to the Beverly Hills Board of Education for eight years, helped create the Maple Center, and served on the Board of Directors at Vista del Mar Child and Family Services. Arthur Malin, M.D., 90, died peacefully in Los Angeles, CA, on October 26 2015, with his wife of sixty-six years, Naomi, and family at his side. He was predeceased by his son Norman. He is also survived by his sister, Madeline; his son, Barnet, and daughter-in-law Jennifer; his two grandchildren, Lila and Miles; and his loving extended family. Abbie, you were the most generous, compassionate man of all; we will always love and miss you. 1/3

FRIEDMAN-- Howard W. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our long time member, Howard W. Friedman. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Paul Kotcher, President 1/3

SAKS--Howard J.,85, died peacefully at his home in Los Angeles with his wife, Barbara, at his side. His life was a life well lived. He enjoyed and took great pride in a successful 50-year career as a life insurance agent and estate planner, first in Manhattan and later in Los Angeles. His curiosity led him to become a world traveler and senior scholar. All of these passions were passed down to his children and grandchildren. We can't forget his love for singing and performing, and Syracuse University. Howard will be deeply missed by his beloved wife, Barbara, sons Michael Saks (Ann), Mark Saks (Donna), daughters Donna Rheingold (Scott), Gayle Saks (Ricardo Rodriguez), Valerie Sanns (Jeff Goldstein), and Leslie Rice (Wayne). He's also survived by his devoted grandchildren Carrie, Brian, Ryan, Sam, Charlotte, Rachel, Amelia, Sydney, Zach, Hunter and Zoe. In addition, he is survived by five great-grandchildren, Isabella, Ava, Jacob, Sasha, and Lilah. 1/3

McILWAIN--Robert Moore, of Bernardsville, NJ, and Vero Beach, FL, passed away on Saturday, October 24, 2015, a few days before his 88th birthday, and not long after he attended his 65th reunion at Dartmouth College. Bob enjoyed a full life with his wife Joan, sons Robert, John, David and Bill, daughters- in-law Michaela, Melissa, AnnMarie and Halley, grandchildren Chelsea, Russell, Jenny, Wesley, Juliet, Charlie and Elizabeth, a close extended family, and many special friends from Dartmouth, New Jersey, Florida and around the globe. He grew up in Radnor, PA, the son of the late Hugh and Evelyn McIlwain, with his younger brothers Pete and Tom. He graduated from The Haverford School, Haverford, PA, and spent a year in the Coast Guard before entering Dartmouth College, where he earned a bachelor of arts degree, followed by a master's degree at the college's Thayer School of Engineering and a master of business administration degree from the Tuck School of Business. Bob loved Dartmouth. He was a class president as an undergraduate and never missed a class reunion in 65 years. After college, he served as a lieutenant in the Navy for three years, then worked for McKinsey & Company, Singer Corporation, Warner- Lambert and Engelhard Corporation. He spent the last 13 years of his career as a senior executive at Englehard, retiring from there in 1992. Meeting and marrying his wife Joan was the most important event of his life. For 57 years they had a wonderful time raising four boys and having great fun with their friends and family. They enjoyed tennis, skiing, golf, dancing and bridge, and traveled to many parts of the world. Also, they were active supporting their communities. More than anything, Bob loved his family, grandchildren, his extended family and his many, many good friends. He was exceptional with people - attentive, bright, fun, humorous and loyal. He had a way with people that let them know how special they were. He loved life fully, and it meant a great deal to him to share and enjoy life with others. We will all miss his presence in our lives - his generosity and wisdom, his warm smile and the twinkle in his eyes. A service to celebrate Bob's life will be held at 11am on Saturday, November 7, at the Church of St. John on the Mountain, 379 Mount Harmony Road in Bernardsville, NJ. Those wishing to send flowers can instead honor him by supporting the John's Island Foundation, which he helped establish and develop. It serves disadvantaged people in Indian River County, FL. Donations may be made at johnsislandfoundation.org. Donations may also be made to the Foundation for Morristown Medical Center, 475 South St., Morristown, NJ, 07960 or to Dartmouth College, www.giving.dartmouth.edu. 1/3

CHRISTIANSON--Uta. Uta Meyer Christianson of New York City died on October 20, 2015 after a long illness. Wife of the late Paul Christianson, she was born in Cologne, Germany on February 23, 1940, and arrived in New York in April, 1968. That year she and Paul founded the International Student Visitors Service, which became InterExchange, a non-profit organization that manages cultural exchange programs with some 60 countries. She is survived by a brother, Franz Meyer, a sister-in-law, Susanne, and two nephews, Till and Jan, who all reside in Germany. Funeral services in Connecticut will be private. 1/3

SPEISER--Dr. Burton. Dr. Burton "Burt" Lyle Speiser, 69, of Paradise Valley, Arizona, passed away on October 18, 2015. He was born in New York City, NY on January 24, 1946, the second of four children of Mollie and Morris Speiser. Burt earned an AB in Biology from Queens College and an MD from the New Jersey College of Medicine. He completed his residency in Radiation Oncology while simultaneously earning an MS in Radiation Biology from the University of Rochester. On December 21, 1968 Burt married Jeanne Michelle Gale. They had three children-- Michael, Leonard, and Lisa. Burt was a Major in the U.S. Air Force where he served as Chief of Radiation Oncology at David Grant Medical Center (1974-1976) at Travis AFB, California. He was Associate Director of Radiation Oncology at LDS Hospital (1976-1979) in Salt Lake City, UT. He was Assistant Professor of Radiation Oncology at Indiana University (1979-1980) in Indianapolis, IN. In 1980, Dr. Speiser relocated to Phoenix, Arizona with his family where he worked for several decades as Director of Radiation Oncology at St. Joseph's Hospital and Director of Brachytherapy at Humana Hospital and St. Luke's Hospital. While Burt was passionate about his work, he was a husband and father first. He enjoyed nothing more than spending time with his family and teaching life lessons to his children every night at the dinner table. While Burt encouraged his children to pursue their own dreams, he was never prouder than when his daughter Lisa followed in his footsteps and became a physician. Burt was also an avid reader, hiker, SCUBA diver, and outdoorsman. Burt is survived by his wife of 47 years, Jeanne, his sons Michael and Leonard, his daughter Lisa, his daughters- in-law Mary and Jessica and his seven grandchildren Lauren, Emma, Henry, Anna, Mackenzie, William, and Isabella. The family will be having a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

GREGORY--Niki. Niki Gregory, 62, of Cold Spring Harbor passed away on Wednesday, October 28th. Loving Wife to Husband Joe, caring Mother of Rory Golod, Matt Gregory, Alex Golod, Chloe Golod and Chris Gregory, and her Daughter-In-Law to be, Drew Damman; Niki is also survived by her parents George and Helen Papageorge, Brother Stephen Papageorge, Sister Denise Vigilo, beloved nephews Kenny and Kyle Vigilo, numerous extended family members, and an endless legion of close friends. A true matriarch, when Niki wasn't dedicating herself to her children and family, she was using her focus and passion to help others through her support of the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, and as former Chairwoman of the Maurer Foundation. A cancer survivor for nearly three decades, Niki's strength and courage served as inspiration for anyone who was lucky enough to know her. Niki's presence during her time on Earth was immeasurable, and although her physical presence is no longer with us, her spirit will be forever felt by all who loved her. DeVECCHI--Robert P. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of Bob DeVecchi, our former President and CEO. A graduate of Yale University and the Harvard School of Business Administration, and a former Foreign Service Officer with the Department of State, Bob devoted his life to service. With his dedication and leadership, Bob helped build the IRC into a global humanitarian organization. He was a compassionate, gracious and soft-spoken man who was unafraid and relentless in support of refugees and the displaced. Bob joined the IRC in 1975 to lead the organization's efforts in resettling Vietnamese refugees as part of the largest refugee resettlement effort in U.S. history. Under Bob's leadership as Executive Director from 1985 to 1991 and then as President and CEO from 1992 to 1997, the IRC played an increasingly important role in global relief and development while maintaining its position as one of the leading U.S. resettlement agencies. In December 1991, Bob launched the IRC's relief efforts in the Balkans, which provided emergency aid on a large scale in Sarajevo and elsewhere in Bosnia until peace was reached in 1995. During this time the IRC simultaneously responded to refugee crises in Afghanistan, Iraq, Somalia, Sudan, West Africa, Ethiopia and Rwanda. After retiring from the IRC in 1997, Bob was appointed Adjunct Senior Fellow for Refugees and the Displaced at the Council on Foreign Relations. In 1996 he was awarded the Peacemakers Award of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington, D.C., and in 1998 the IRC Freedom Award for his "extraordinary contribution to the cause of refugees and human freedom." We are grateful to Bob for his enormous contributions to the IRC and the cause of refugees. In death he joins his beloved wife and partner Betsy Trippe, who passed away in 2009. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board; Timothy Geithner, Chair, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President 1/3

DEMARAY--John G. 84, died October 24 at Lennox Hill Hospital of bilateral pneumonia. Writer, Renaissance scholar, professor Emeritus, Rutgers University, and gentle man, he was the intensely loved and wonderfully loving husband for 55 years to Hannah Disinger Demaray; and the best of sons to John and Marjorie Coyle Demaray of Somerville, NJ. After the Army, and Notre Dame Law School, he earned his Ph.D with honors at Columbia where he met Hannah. Years of adventure, reflection, and writing began--all leavened with humor and Jack's pleasure in magic. "Gladly would he learn and gladly teach"-- and so he did at universities in Cairo, Beirut, Damascus, Florence, Los Angeles, Kentucky, and New Jersey. His many books on Shaw, Milton, Dante and Shakespeare were about philosophy, pilgrimage, history, and literary genre. His life was about integrity, faith, and love. He retained, even in his final illness, anachronistic courtliness, geniality, and devotion. He is survived by his wife, several cousins, and many friends. Funeral November 7, 2:00pm, Church of the Ascension, 5th Ave. and 10th St. 1/3

George was President and owner of York Restoration Corp., a prominent waterproofing and restoration company that redefined the face of New York City real estate. He demonstrated leadership and unconditional loyalty. He is survived by his loving wife Patricia and two daughters Kristina and Jenni. 1/3

KARMEL--Alex, died from complications of cancer on Saturday, October 24, 2015, at his home in Dourdan, France. Born in New York in 1931, he was the author of three novels, "Mary Ann," "Last Words," and "My Revolution," and two books of non-fiction, "Guillotine in the Wings" and "A Corner in Marais: Memoirs of a Paris Neighborhood." His novel "Mary Ann" was made into the 1961 film "Something Wild." His first wife, Marjorie Karmel, a co-founder of Lamaze International, died in 1964, and he lovingly raised their three children. He is survived by his wife of forty years, the actress and writer Marianne Servouze (Marcellin) Karmel; by his children Pepe Karmel, Marianne Karmel, and Philippa Karmel Wharton; and by his seven grandchildren: Jeremy and Caleb; Michael and Elliot; and Sophie, Emily and Molly. 1/3

WECHT--Richard, age 77, Passed away on October 28, 2015. Beloved son of the late Honorable Milton M. Wecht and Adele Kalender Wecht. Predeceased by his sister Fannie Wecht. He is survived by hi.s sister Edith Wecht Kurzweil (Martin). Services were held Friday, October 30, 2015. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack M.,63, passed away peacefully, surrounded by his loving family. Cherished and adoring husband of Catherine, loving and exceptional father to Lola and Leo, devoted brother to Carol (Ron), beloved brother-in-law to Mane, dearest uncle to Elizabeth and Andrew (Gretchen). Cousin to Simon (Bambi), Selina, (Daniel) and Eli, Aron, Abby, Riva (David) and Serj, family in Tel Aviv, Paris and Buenos Aires. Born in NYC to Rosa and Leo, Holocaust survivors from Poland. Leo saved hundreds of Jews, for which he was proclaimed "Prince of the Lodz Ghetto." Following in his father's tradition, Jack was the very definition of a "mentsch." The warmest and most generous man, friend, mentor and father figure to countless people from all walks of life, his impact and inspiration is incalculable. Brought into the family real estate business at a young age, he soon became partner to his dear childhood friend, Charles Blaichman. Deeply respected for his dedication, honesty and knowledge, he was a consummate professional. He was proudest of the family he created with the Love of his life, Catherine. They filled their home with family and friends, art, food and laughter. Their love is deep and resonant. And he fought like a lion to stay with them. Donations may be made to Yad Vashem, Doctors Without Borders or Sloan Kettering. 1/3

PARKER--H. Lawrence. Retired Managing Director at Morgan Stanley, Dies at 89. After a lengthy battle with cancer, H. Lawrence, "Larry," Parker died peacefully on October 21st, surrounded by family at his home in Hobe Sound, Florida. He is survived by his wife, Reggie Hawes Parker, his daughter, Katherine Goldsmith, and his two sons, Richard and Michael. A son, Douglas, predeceased Larry in 1976. His family also includes seven grandchildren and eight great- grandchildren. He is also survived by his two sisters, Nancy Welbourn and Alice Ober. Born and raised in the Northeastern U.S., he attended St. Andrews School in Middleton, Delaware and enlisted in the Marine Corps days after graduation in June, 1944. "PFC" Parker served during World War II aboard the U.S.S. Atlanta and was among those participating in the first landing of American troops on Japan in late August, 1945. The honor of serving as a Marine was as strong at the end of his life as it was in 1944. Larry graduated from Yale University, then immediately went to work for Morgan Stanley & Company in 1950. Rapidly distinguishing himself for diligence and for cultivating trusting and close relationships with clients, Larry was the youngest man to be made General Partner ever in 1959. Over the years he managed key accounts like GMAC, The World Bank, and Weyerhaeuser and also served as Chairman of Morgan Stanley Canada Limited from 1979-1983. He also served a term as president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, his national organization, from 1969-70. He had a distinguished career at Morgan Stanley and retired as a Managing Director in 1983. During these years, Larry hosted his family for four-season activity during vacations in Stowe, Vermont. After retirement Larry divided his time between cattle ranching in Daniel, Wyoming and his life in Hobe Sound. Always a lover of horses and the mountains, Larry joined his neighbors in frosty dawn cattle drives and hay cutting marathons and journeyed into the Wind River Range with friends and family on pack trips and elk hunting excursions. In Florida Larry was very active raising money for the Jupiter Medical Center Foundation and working at key volunteer roles at the Jupiter Island Club, most notably as chairman of the Golf and Green Committees. Throughout his life, service to others was important. He also served as Commodore of the Hobe Sound Yacht Club and was an active member in the United States Seniors' Golf Association. He was a member at Augusta National Golf Club for over 40 years and served on the Admission Committee and was Chairman of the Committee responsible for the production of the annual film of the Masters Tournament for over three decades. Larry is remembered by friends and family as a true gentleman. His generosity, kindness, respect for all, love of the outdoors, and zest for life inspired those who knew him. Nothing was more important to him than his family. Larry Parker, "The Pard" a life well lived. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Larry's honor to the Jupiter Medical Center Foundation at 1210 South Old Dixie Highway, Building East 1002, Jupiter, Florida 33458. A memorial service will be held on Jupiter Island, January 23rd at 4:30 at Christ Memorial Chapel. 1

BAUM--Charles C. Charles Baum died of pancreatic cancer on October 24 at the age of 73. He will be remembered for his wit and wisdom, love of life, generosity, intelligence, and enthusiasm for learning. Above all, he loved his wife, Patricia, his children, grandchildren, and siblings. Nothing was more important to Charles than family and friends. He was a life advisor, a business advisor, and the best question asker. He had an uncanny ability to maintain deep relationships with friends from summer camp, grade school through graduate school, and beyond. For each person in his life, he remembered a birthday, a favorite moment, a funny line. He was a one-man clipping and search service, well before Google, finding what might be meaningful to each person and sending it with a hand-written note. After spending his childhood in Montgomery, AL, Charles graduated from Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School (Class of '64, Phi Beta Kappa, magna cum laude), Harvard Business School (Class of '66), and University of Maryland Law School (Class of '79). After Harvard Business School, he went to Wall Street firm Loeb, Rhoades & Co. He moved to Baltimore in 1973 with his first wife, Jane (Shapiro) Rodbell, where he worked at United Iron & Metal (now United Holdings) with his father-in-law I.D. Shapiro. He continued to run the family office until the onset of his illness in the fall of 2015. In the mid '70s through late '90s, he was a partner at Shapiro, Robinson & Associates, advising professional athletes, including Eddie Murray, Brooks Robinson, Cal Ripken Jr., Willie Mays Aikens, and Kirby Puckett. Upon moving to Baltimore, he became quickly ingrained in the city's civic and philanthropic community. He served on the boards of Center Stage, The Aaron and Lillie Straus Foundation, and the University of Maryland Foundation. In addition, he was the Investment Committee chair of the Associated Jewish Charities of Baltimore and was serving as its President at the time of his death. He was a long time member of Beth Am Synagogue. Charles' corporate board service included Baltimore's MuniMae (now MMA Capital Management), investment advisory firm Gabelli Group Capital Partners, and telecommunications company ICTC. He also served as Chairman and CEO of Morgan Group, Inc. and was a special advisor to Baltimore's Charm City Run. Charles had numerous and diverse interests including the arts, literature, sports, travel, and politics; he never missed a day or page of the Baltimore Sun, The New York Times, or Wall Street Journal. He was proud to be involved in Bill Bradley's presidential campaign and served as a Delegate to the 2000 Democratic National Convention. He enjoyed playing sports throughout his life, especially basketball, tennis, and golf, and was an avid spectator, rooting passionately for the Orioles and, above all, for the Alabama Crimson Tide. Charles is survived by his wife Patricia (Purnell) Baum of Severna Park, MD. He had three children, Andrew (1968- 1971), Katie of Berkeley, CA, and Matthew (Deborah) Baum of Baltimore, MD; and two stepdaughters, Staci (Andrew) Hodge of Baltimore and Beth Bafford (Dan Yeoman) of Washington, DC. He received endless joy from his four grandchildren, Beatrice Kennedy and Max Charles Baum and twins Samantha and Riley Hodge. He is also survived by his sister Sylvia (Herb) Horowitz of Columbia, MD and their children Joanne Beren (Jeff Arbeit), Susan Beren (Rodrigo Pizarro), David Beren, Diana England (Richard), Laura Simon (Warren); his brother John (Diane) Baum of Baltimore, MD and their children, Emily Baum (Josh Burke) and David Baum. In addition, he is survived by Jane (nee Shapiro) Rodbell (Stan) of Baltimore, MD to whom he was married from 1966-95. He was predeceased by his mother, Josephine C. Baum and father, Max S. Baum, both of Montgomery, AL. Lastly, he is survived by many friends, whom he loved and who loved him. Please see funeral home website: http://www.sol levinson.com/ for information on memorial service, contributions and mourning. 1/3

MEADE--Margaret B. (Demm) passed away on Friday, October 30, 2015 at her daughter's home surrounded by her family. Margaret is predeceased by her loving husband Louis. Margaret is survived by their five children Liz Meade, Louis Meade Jr., Mark Meade, Margaret Meade-Hariri (Robert Hariri), and John Meade (Lisa Wesolowski, fiance). Grandchildren, Lauren Meade, Shaun Meade, Alexandra Hariri, Jack Hariri, Haley Hariri and Kyra Ernst. She is predeceased by her sisters: Mary Costa and Therese Sbano along with her brothers Vincent and George Demm. Margaret was born on December 27, 1931 in Manhattan, NY. As an adult, after having five children, she earned a BA from Brooklyn College and a Masters Degree from Richmond College. She taught at St. Marks School in Brooklyn for several years then took a job at the New York City Housing Authority where she excelled, rose through the ranks and retired as the District Manager - Manhattan South. After moving to New Jersey she worked with handicapped young adults as a Job Coach at ECLC in Chatham. She invested in LifeBank, Inc., a stem cell company, which became a great success. She loved reading and books and art and nature. She was a devoted mother of five and grandmother of six, all were the light of her life. She was kind and gentle yet still fought valiantly and unrelentingly against her cancer, always with dignity and grace. She was given five years, she lived 11 wonderful years. She had many friends and enjoyed getting together with them for Bridge and Mahjong. She will be so dearly missed by all who knew her. A Memorial Mass will be held 11:00am on Friday, November 6, 2015 at St. Patrick's Church, 85 Washington Avenue, Chatham, NJ 07928. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Chatham New Jersey library or to your local library. For further information, or to send the family a condolence, please visit: www.bradley funeralhomes.com. 1/3

TENENBAUM--Norman. 86, passed away on October 22, 2015. A longtime resident of New York City, Mr. Tenenbaum was born and raised in Newark, NJ. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where he was a member of the Kappa Nu Fraternity. An Army veteran of the Korean War, Mr. Tenenbaum was a co-owner of C. Tenenbaum Furniture Company of Ferry Street, Newark. Fluent in seven languages and a talented designer, he spent over 40 years at designer furniture store, Maurice Villency. Mr. Tenenbaum was also an accomplished pianist, playing all over the world accompanying opera stars, and spent his free time at Lincoln Center. In recent years, he volunteered his time at The Julliard School. He is survived by sister-in-law Constance Tenenbaum, three generations of nieces and nephews, along with numerous dear friends including Rowann Villency, Dawn David and Francois Becerra. Memorial donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera House or the New York Ballet. 1/3

HARSHMAN--Mary Ashley Cooper Hewitt, died in her home in Naples, FL on October 24, 2015, at age 90. She was the daughter of the late Louise Schieffelin Hewitt and Abram Stevens Hewitt, and a descendant of inventor and angler Edward R. Hewitt, New York City Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, philanthropist Peter Cooper, abolitionist and Congressman James Ashley, industrialist Cornelius Vanderbilt, and United States Chief Justice John Jay. She was a 1947 graduate of Bennington College, and a frequent student at The Art Students League. She is survived by her loving husband of 65 years, Richard, and predeceased by their son, Thomas Harshman. She is also survived by their son, Edward Harshman, their daughter Cecily Johnston, their families, and numerous relatives and friends. She will be remembered for her colorful paintings and her extraordinary gift for friendship. Gifts in her memory may be sent to Avow Hospice, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL 34105, www.avowcares.org or to Trinity-by-the-Cove Episcopal Church, 533 Galleon Drive, Naples, FL 34102. www.trinitybythecove.com. 1/3

WURZEL--Elaine. On October 24, 2015, at the age of 86, after a battle with lung cancer, she passed away at her residence in Port Washington. Born in Baltimore in 1929, she later attended junior college. In 1949, she married Leonard Wurzel and after four years in Manhattan, in 1953, they moved to Sands Point with their young sons, Mark and Larry. Elaine and Leonard have been members of the Community Synagogue since 1953 and have often been recognized for their devotion and involvement over the years. Elaine served as bazaar chairperson, bulletin editor, Sisterhood board member, and ran the Earners Affair for several years. She worked at Knutsen and Sargent in Port Washington and later at a podiatry office in Manhasset. She served as First Lady to Leonard, who for 22 years was the Mayor of Sands Point. She is survived by her two sons and daughters-in-law, Mark and Ellen Wurzel and Larry Wurzel and Elaine Gnessin. Grandchildren, Jill Wurzel Lekstutis and her husband Carmine Lekstutis, Max Wurzel, and Greg Wurzel, and two great-grandchildren, Alex and Chloe Lekstutis. Funeral Services will be held at The Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Rd., Sands Point, NY 11050 at 11:30am on Wednesday, October 28, 2015. Telephone: (516)883-3144, Web: commsyn.org. Burial will take place at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Ave., West Babylon, NY 11704. Telephone: (631) 249-2290. After burial, on Wednesday, Shiva will take place at Elaine Wurzel's residence, until 8pm, with services at 7pm. On Thursday, Shiva will take place from 3pm to 8pm, with services at 7pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Community Synagogue. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Howard. We mourn the passing of our beloved father, Howard W. Friedman, at age 90, on October 30, 2015. He is survived by his devoted wife of 63 years, Lee, adoring children, Ira, Debra, Patti and Jane, eight grandchildren and sisters, Gloria and Myrna. Howard will be deeply missed by his family and friends, and the wider community, in which he was held in the highest regard. Funeral will be held on Sunday, November 1, 2015 at 10:30am at Boulevard-River- side Chapels at 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 11557. 1/3

HELLENBRAND--Julius A. The Honorable Julius A. Hellenbrand, long-time resident of Brooklyn, New York, died on October 28th in Northridge, California. He was 102. He was married to Gail Abbey Hellenbrand (1921-1996), who was the first Jewish Assemblywoman in New York State, from 1966-1970. In the late 1950s through 1960s, they were important members of the Brooklyn Regular Democratic Party, along with neighbors and friends Abe Beame, Hugh Carey, Anthony Travia, Stanley Steingut, and Arthur Levitt. A graduate of Alexander Hamilton High School, he won the New York City Current Events Bee in 1930 sponsored by The Brooklyn Eagle; he was runner-up in 1931. With an LLD from St. John's University in 1937, in 1938 he opened a law office at 305 Broadway in Manhattan where he was joined by Eddie Sharf, a cousin. After enlisting in the Army in 1942, he was selected to learn Japanese at the Universities of Minnesota and Michigan, in anticipation of invading Japan. After the War, Sharf and Hellenbrand became partners in the Brooklyn/Queens power-house law firm, Eddie Sharf (President of national B'Nai Zion), Lester Holtzman (Congressman), Thomas Mackell (State Senator, District Attorney, Queens County), and Julius A. Hellenbrand. He practiced law for nearly thirty years before Mayor John V. Lindsay appointed him as a Judge in the Criminal Court in 1969. He ended his career on the bench in 1992, as a New York Supreme Court Judge. He was a board member of the Menorah Home on Bushwick Avenue and of Union Temple on Eastern Parkway, both in Brooklyn, where he was active in many charities and fraternal orders. He was the son of Eastern European immigrants, Fannie and Louis H. Hellenbrand, neither of whom read English well; Fannie spoke Yiddish, never comfortable with English. Louis drove milk trucks and labored as a carpenter and superintendent of apartment buildings. Julius was the brother of Samuel Hellenbrand (1917-2011), whom President Reagan appointed as Vice Chairman of Amtrak. Before that, Samuel was Vice President of Real Estate for International Telephone & Telegraph Corp. and previously, the Vice President of Real Estate for the Penn Central Railroad. Julius is survived by nieces Kathy Rocklen, Linda Silberstein, and Joan Ziskin, nephew Bob Ziskin, and by son, Harold L. (Provost Emeritus, California State University, Northridge) and his wife, Donna. 1/3

YARFITZ--Leo J.,died peacefully at his home in Boynton Beach, FL on October 24, two weeks after his 100th birthday. He was predeceased by Evelyn Yarfitz, his wife of 58 years and leaves behind Dorothy Yarfitz, his wife for the past 13 years. He is survived by his brother Raymond, children Joan, Stuart and Denise and their families, seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Born in New York City in 1915, he graduated from Morris High School and the City College of New York and served as a Captain in the Army Signal Corps during WWII. His career in the financial services industry spanned more than 40 years, with a succession of executive leadership positions at companies including Sterling Factors Corporation, AIC Financial Corporation, AS Beck Industries; Central Penn Bank; Helena Rubenstein, Inc.; United Merchants Financial Corporation; and Crocker National Bank. Husband, father, grandfather, great-grand- father, uncle, friend, mentor, intellectual, raconteur, businessman, soldier, athlete -- Leo was a man of great presence, warmth and strength who was sought out for his wise counsel and engaging company. A gentleman of his generation and citizen of the world, he will be dearly missed. Malinow & Silverman Mortuary 800-710-7100. 1/3

HENDRIE--Ann. Ann Chase Twichell Hendrie, 88, of New Haven and Mystic, CT and Little Compton, RI, died peacefully at home October 24th. She is survived by her brother, John H. Chase; her children, Chase (Russell Banks), Eliza and Cary Twichell (David Parr); four grandchildren (Andrus and Jack Nichols, and David and Lucy Kasofsky); and many beloved stepchildren, nephews, nieces, and friends. A memorial service is planned for next spring. 1/3

SCHWARTZ-WIENER-- Naomi. It is with profound sadness we share that Naomi passed away peacefully on October 29 at the age of 92. Loving mother of Lewis Schwartz, Lynne Schwartz (Alan Miller), Michael Schwartz (Elyse), Priscilla Aldrich (Lou) and Robert Schwartz (Jacinda), grandmother of five and great-grandmother of two. She touched the lives of all who knew her. Naomi lived her long and remarkable life fully and with joy. 1/3

GLAZER--Jack. The Blaichman Family is profoundly shocked and devastated by the passing of our dearest friend. What began as a friendship between two adolescent boys from Forest Hills - laughter, adventures and music - developed into an extraordinary, life-long bond that grew to include their wives, children and countless friends. The love between our two families has been essential to our souls and we cherish the memories we have of our everyday life together, family dinners, summers in Woodstock and joyous celebrations. How fortunate we were to have Jack's generosity of spirit envelop us. We will be forever warmed by his love, empathy, humor and wisdom. To Catherine, Lola and Leo, we share your grief in this dark hour. Charlie, Aviva, Micah, Sabrina and Noah 1/3

ZIMBARDO--Rose Abdelnour 1932 - 2015. Our beloved Rosie died in peace at the age of 83, on October 25, surrounded by her son and his family in Davis, California. Rose was born and raised in Brooklyn, the only child of Angie and Albert Abdelnour. She attended Brooklyn College and then Yale University, where she received her doctorate in English Literature in 1960. She had a long and illustrious academic career as a professor at City College of New York, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, the English Department of the University of San Francisco, the Fromm Institute, and the St. Ignatius Institute. Rose was an intellectual giant who turned her energies into becoming a highly celebrated and dedicated teacher of an enormous and varied range of subjects -- from Shakespeare and ancient through modern drama to major historical shifts in human thinking. From the moment she stepped into the classroom until 54 years later, when she retired, Rose brought a joyous but tough energy to teaching her students, whom she loved. They returned her respect and love, and Rose maintained life-long friendships with many of them. For her, teaching was not work; it was challenging yet always exhilarating intellectual interplay with her students. Rose received "Excellence in Teaching" Awards from both Stony Brook and the University of San Francisco. Underlying her brilliant teaching was Rose's earnest scholarship. Her research and 10 books about Shakespearean comedies, Tolkien, George Bernard Shaw, Restoration England, and other areas were widely viewed as path- breaking. Her scholarship also expressed her personal philosophy that life veers more into comedy than tragedy. As Rose wrote, "Mankind is immortal in the comic perspective not by virtue of man's subjugation of nature but by virtue of man's subjection to it. The 'fall' in tragedy ends in death; the fall in comedy ends in bed, where, by nature's arithmetic, one and one make a brand new one." Rose was preceded in death by her husband of 27 years, Martin Stevens, who was also a professor of English and a dean at Baruch College in New York. She is survived by her son, Adam Zimbardo (from her first marriage to Philip Zimbardo), and also by her two grandchildren, Philip John ("Panda") and Victoria Leigh ("Bunny") Zimbardo, who were the joy of her life and the center of her universe. A memorial service in Rose's honor will be held at the Most Holy Redeemer Church in San Francisco, 100 Diamond Street, at 10:00am on November 14, 2015, with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions to her memory may be made to either Most Holy Redeemer Church or the Middle East Children's Alliance: www.mecaforpeace.org. 1/3

KOOTA--Dr. Gordon, passed away peacefully at home yesterday after a long and courageous fight with Alzheimer's. His wife Audrey of almost 60 years, and his two daughters, Hillary and Claudia were by his side. Dr. Koota was a dedicated surgeon, an accomplished athlete and had a unique connection to his friends. He will be deeply missed by his three grandchildren, Sam, Carly, and Adam, his son-in-law Glenn Krevlin and Jay Siegel. 1/3

PEARLMAN--Sy, of Manhattan, 84, died October 20 at home. A veteran NBC News producer, winner of virtually every major TV journalism award; including the prestigious Peabody. He started his career as an editor for the New York Times. Survived by his wife, Cynthia; his children Mia and Ted; two grandchildren and a brother, Boris. 1/3
SOMERFIED--Barbara. A memorial service will be held on November 6 at 1pm at Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55th St., 5th Fl. 1/3

FLINT--George Squire, 84, skilled attorney, sailing enthusiast and vanquisher of crossword puzzles, died Friday, October 23, 2015 at his home in New York City. Born in Fort Wayne, IN, he was a sports columnist at The Daily at the University of Michigan. He was a partner at Fulton, Walter & Duncombe, of counsel at Jackson & Nash, a vice president at Tenneco Chemicals, and served in the United States Navy. A lover of Mozart and the Beatles, he raised springer spaniels at his home on Wamphassuc Point in Stonington, CT. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Emily McLees Flint, of New York City; his children Alexander Flint of Menlo Park, CA, Anthony Flint of Brookline, MA, Julia Flint of Burbank, CA, and seven grandsons. Friends and family gathered for a private memorial. 1/3

GENDEL--Gladys, 85, on October 5th after a long illness. She was the daughter of Herschel and Feige Gendel and is survived by her brother Joshua. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Center for Jewish History, 15 W. 16th St., New York, NY 10011. 1/3

BUSSEL--Irving, passed away on November 1, 2014. His passing left a great void in our lives. Yet the memory of a truly great man is a blessing to his family and to his friends. Eli, Roselyn, Lisa, Frank, Joanne, Lauren, and Jordan. 1/3

CONWAY--E. Virgil. The Partnership for New York City mourns the passing of E. Virgil Conway, who joined David Rockefeller as a founding member of an organization of business leaders dedicated to renewal of the city after the fiscal and economic crises of the 1970s. For more than a decade, Virg chaired the Housing Partnership, working with government, banks and builders to bring affordable home ownership and minority business opportunities to distressed neighborhoods across the five boroughs. His contribution to making New York the vibrant city it is today was enormous and he will be remembered. 1/3

MEYER--Gail E. Born January 16, 1950 and died October 29, 2015. Daughter of the late Esther and Benjamin Rochlin, niece of Mordecai Rochlin, sister of Alfreda Finkelstein (Martin), aunt of Ruth Sheinfield and William Stein (Sarah), and great aunt of Daniel, Lily, Philip, Max, Sam and Jacob. Funeral service will be held Sunday, November 1, 2015, 1:30pm from Westchester Reform Temple-CJL, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

VERMYLEN--Paul Anthony, of Saddle River, NJ and Shoreham, NY, died peacefully on Saturday, October 31, 2015, at age 96. Predeceased by his wife of 66 years, Nancy Primrose Barr, he is survived by his children: Paul Jr. (Robin), Jay, Peter (Cathleen), David (Stacy), Jessica Vermylen Fiddes (John), Robert (Mary), and Mark (Barbara); twenty-one grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Paul was a loyal alumnus of La Salle Military Academy, Oakdale, NY (1937), which he attended on a full scholarship in the midst of the Depression and served as Cadet Captain in his senior year. At Georgetown University (1941), he excelled on the debate and tennis teams, graduated cum laude and most importantly, met Nancy Barr. His legal education at Columbia Law School was interrupted by WWII, during which he served as a combat infantry officer in North Africa and Italy. In 1946, he married Nancy Barr and began a 60 year career at his family's business, A. Zerega's Sons, Inc., the first pasta company in the United States, founded by his great-grandfather in 1848. During his career, he grew the business before transitioning it to the fifth and now sixth generations of family management. He was a Past Chairman of the Board of the National Pasta Association, President of the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club, Saddle River Borough Councilman and active in many community organizations. Paul was a long-time parishioner of St. Gabriel's Church in Saddle River. Funeral services are being made through Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. www.feeneyfuneral home.com. Visiting hours, 2-4pm and 7-9pm Tuesday, November 3 at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. Funeral Mass, 10:00am Wednesday, November 4 at St. Gabriel's Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Children's Therapy Center in Fair Lawn, NJ would be appreciated. www.thechildre nstherapycenter.org. His family would like to extend a special note of thanks to his loving and compassionate caregivers, especially Vanessa Ramsay. 1/3

TODD--Beatrice, passed away peacefully on October 31, 2015, at the age of 93. Bea was predeceased by her loving husband, Ralph, and her wonderful son, Bruce. She was the devoted mother of Andrea and Randy; caring mother-in-law of Harold and Marcy; loving grandmother of Evan and Kelly, Jessica and Ross, Amy and Brandon; and adoring great-grand- mother of Anika, Asa, and Ryan. Bea was also the loving sister of Dr. Robert Himmelfarb. She was beautiful, elegant, smart and strong. Post. She will be sorely missed by friends and family who knew and loved her. 1/3

ROSS --H.J. A longtime resident of Coral Gables, Florida, H. J. Ross, age 93, known to his friends as Jack, peacefully passed away at his home on Friday, October 30th, 2015 following an eight year battle with vascular dementia. Jack was born to Benjamina Gaynell Cook Ross and John Daniel Ross on June 2, 1922 in Tampa, Florida. He attended school in Tampa, graduating from Tampa College High (Jesuit High School) as a top scholar and Eagle Scout, and later, at age 19 , from Georgia Institute of Technology, with a degree in civil engineering. Following his graduation from Georgia Tech, where he was a member of Sigma Nu Fratenity, Jack studied aeronautical engineering at Massachusetts Institute of Technology until the outbreak of World War II. He immediately entered military service in the Seabees, an engineering division of the US Navy. Jack was stationed in the Aleutian Islands, and, at the end of the war, at Opa Locka Air Station, Miami, Florida. In 1947, Jack founded the engineering firm Riley and Ross with a fellow Navy engineer. When his partner joined the Vietnam War effort, Jack agreed to stay and run the company, later acquiring a total interest and renaming the company H.J. Ross and Associates, Inc. Jack retired in 1978 and sold the company to Monenco Engineering Corporation. The company has subsequently been sold a number of times but still operates today in Miami as TYLin/H.J. Ross. His firm maintained offices in pre- Castro Cuba, Caracas, Venezuela and throughout Florida, namely in St. Petersburg, Ft. Lauderdale, Cape Canaveral, and Miami. Having designed the test facility for the Pratt/Whitney engines powering the Apollo space mission, H.J. Ross and Associates, Inc. also had a base in Huntsville, Alabama. Among the hundreds of major projects Jack's firm engineered, many are of particular note: signature hotels on Miami Beach including The Eden Roc, The Fontainebleau, The Deauville, and The Shelbourne, all Burdines department stores, the Eastern Airlines buildings at MIA, major parts of the Palmetto Expressway, dozens of facilities for Dade County Public Schools and various Marriott Hotels throughout the country. Jack had many passions: art, thoroughbred horses, history, hunting, boating, fishing and traveling, all of which he actively engaged, living life to the fullest. Jack was a long time member of Epiphany Catholic Church and a former Board Member of Miami Lighthouse for the Blind. He is predeceased by two of his daughters, Barbara Gaynelle Ross and Suzanne Mary Ross, as well as his parents and his sister, Sara Longmire. He is survived by his wife of thirty six years, Audrey Hand Jackson Ross, as well as his two daughters from his first marriage to Donna Guilfoyle Ross, Julie Ross Dunn Myers and Sally Ross Muccio (husband, Craig, and daughter, Donna), all of Miami. His is also survived by his wife's daughter, Melissa Jackson Loree, DVM (husband, Lee, and son, Oliver), of Atlanta, Georgia, as well as a number of nieces and nephews. A service celebrating his life well lived will take place on Tuesday, November 3rd, 2015 at 10:30am at Epiphany Catholic Church, 8235 SW 57th Ave., Miami, Florida 33143. 1/3

De BEKESSY--Antal. Antal Miklos Post De Bekessy, known as "Tony" to his family and friends, died in Paris, France, on April 16, 2015. A grandson of his beloved grandmother, Marjorie Merriweather Post, and a godson of Eleanor Roosevelt, he was also predeceased in death by his father, the noted Hungarian-Austrian author and journalist, Janos De Bekessy ("Hans Habe") (1977) and his mother, Eleanor Close-Barzin (2006). A resident of Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, he was a graduate of St. Paul's School, Concord, New Hampshire, and Princeton University (Class of 1965). A co-founder of the Breguet Construction Corporation and a Director of the Carolina Mirror Corporation, he was from time to time a director and advisor to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Metropolitan Opera, Princeton University (Departments of Romance Languages), and the Hillwood Foundation of Washington, D.C. For his work in fostering U.S. support for the art and culture of France, the French Ministry of Culture bestowed on him the honor, "Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres." He contributed generously to the conservation of the art of Venice and, true to his father's roots, generously funded the translation of guidebooks and libretti for the Austrian Gallery Belvedere Museum and the Vienna State Opera House. Closer to home, he was especially proud to have commenced the establishment of Masterships at St. Paul's School in honor of faculty members David W. Read and William R. Matthews. JORDAN--Gloria (Lampert), 91, of Haworth, NJ, died November 1st. Beloved mother of Eve and her husband Bruce Gendron, loving grandmother of Hannah, Selamu and Hadami. Service 10:30am, Tuesday, at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ. 1/3

NEUMAN--Doris, nee Lewin. Born November 20, 1924, passed away November 1, 2015. Doris Lewin Neuman died peacefully and with dignity at her home in Rio Rancho, NM with her loving family nearby. Daughter of Irving and Mildred Lewin (nee Stern, both deceased); brother of Bob (deceased in 2004) loving mother of Alan and Paul and grandmother of Shawn Chavez Neuman, Max, Jess and Karin Neuman; adored mother-in-law to Veronica Chavez Neuman and Karen Binder Brynes, step grandmother to Elana and Lily Brynes and cherished aunt to Cheryl Lewin (deceased in 2012), Lian Murray (deceased in 2013), Jim Lewin and Cornelia Auray. Doris was married for 51 years to Robert Neuman (deceased in 2001) and worked faithfully and tirelessly at his side in the Rosedale Fish Market for decades. Doris graduated from Ashley Hall in Charleston, SC and the Women's College of the University of North Carolina. Her happiest summers were spent at Camp Severance on Paradox Lake in the Adirondacks. She was an artist who found beauty in painting people, animals, landscapes and flowers. A wonderful writer, Doris was known for her remarkable ability express her sentiments with a few well- chosen words. Doris touched people's hearts with her warmth, generosity, humor and kindness. She supported the needy, dispossessed and hungry and lived to make the world a happier and more caring place. All who she touched will miss her smile, warmth and joyous laughter. The world is a little less happy, caring and warm without Doris. Special thanks to her caregivers who provided comfort and love as she moved towards her final journey. Private memorial services will be held in Albuquerque and New York City. Donations in Doris' memory may be made to Gigi's Playhouse: gigisplayhouse.org/ albuquerque or The HOPE Program: www.thehopeprogram.org/. 1/3

Wife of deceased husband Al Steinberg, loving mother of Howard (Miriam), Robert (Amy) and Steven(Carol). Grandmother and great-grandmother. She will be missed by all. Beula will be remembered as a vivacious classy woman with a generous soul. She was the Belle of the Ball. KATCHER--Francine "Franny", 73, of Ramsey, New Jersey and Highland Beach, Florida, passed away on Saturday, October 31, 2015, peacefully surrounded by her loving family and friends. She is proudest of the family she created with the love of her life, the late, Michael Katcher, who at 53, was taken from her way too early. She is survived by her dear mother, Shirley Duchen, 92, her brothers Richard Duchen and wife Jeanne, and Jeff Duchen, her devoted daughters RobynMolk and Meryl Reiss, her sons-in-law Peter Molk and Adam Reiss, and adoring grandchildren Zachary and Lindsey Molk, Michael Raye and Ryan Reiss. She will be missed by her significant other, of 15 years, Robert Golden. She was vibrant, fun loving, and so easy to be around with a gift for making everyone laugh, finding humor in everything. Her beauty, warmth, generous spirit and contagious laughter will live on in the memories of all who loved and adored her. If you were a friend of Franny's, you were a friend for life. She was loyal to so many, new and old. Robyn and Meryl will forever cherish their sweet and loving mother, their bond was immeasurable. Funeral Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York, NY on Wednesday, November 4th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, a donation can be made to Susan G. Komen, in honor of our mom, Francine Katcher. 1/3

ABRAMS--Fred, on November 2. A caring, selfless and loving man. Beloved husband of the late Sheila. Adored father of Philip, Roberta (Gary) Bologna and Cliff. Cherished grandfather of Matthew and Lonn. Devoted brother of the late Stanley Abrams and Marilyn Katz. Treasured uncle. Dear son of late the Helen and Max Abrams of Emerson Radio and Television. Dearest companion of Fran Feigenbaum. A WWII Veteran, Fred also served as past President of the Epilepsy Foundation of Long Island and past President of the board of the Menorah Home and Hospital. He made a difference. Graveside service 1pm, Wednesday, November 4 at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY. www.shermanschapel.com 1/3

GLICKENHAUS--Gloria, on November 1, 2015. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Debbie and Lewis Finkelstein, Daniel and Dorian, Barbara and Jerald Lang. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Sam, Carly, Hannah and Jakob. Devoted sister of Bernice Millman. VERMYLEN--Paul Anthony, of Saddle River, NJ and Shoreham, NY, died peacefully on Saturday, October 31, 2015, at age 96. Predeceased by his wife of 66 years, Nancy Primrose Barr, he is survived by his children: Paul Jr. (Robin), Jay, Peter (Cathleen), David (Stacy), Jessica Vermylen Fiddes (John), Robert (Mary), and Mark (Barbara); twenty-one grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Paul was a loyal alumnus of La Salle Military Academy, Oakdale, NY (1937), which he attended on a full scholarship in the midst of the Depression and served as Cadet Captain in his senior year. At Georgetown University (1941), he excelled on the debate and tennis teams, graduated cum laude and most importantly, met Nancy Barr. His legal education at Columbia Law School was interrupted by WWII, during which he served as a combat infantry officer in North Africa and Italy. In 1946, he married Nancy Barr and began a 60 year career at his family's business, A. Zerega's Sons, Inc., the first pasta company in the United States, founded by his great-grandfather in 1848. During his career, he grew the business before transitioning it to the fifth and now sixth generations of family management. He was a Past Chairman of the Board of the National Pasta Association, President of the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club, Saddle River Borough Councilman and active in many community organizations. Paul was a long-time parishioner of St. Gabriel's Church in Saddle River. Funeral services are being made through Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. www.feeneyfuneral home.com. Visiting hours, 2-4pm and 7-9pm Tuesday, November 3 at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. Funeral Mass, 10:00am Wednesday, November 4 at St. Gabriel's Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Children's Therapy Center in Fair Lawn, NJ would be appreciated. www.thechildre nstherapycenter.org. His family would like to extend a special note of thanks to his loving and compassionate caregivers, especially Vanessa Ramsay. 1/3
HIRSCH--Dr. Harvey. Missing you on your birthday and everyday. Love you, Ellen 1/3
BROKKEN--Jim. 11/03/05. A decade ago; but you still live on everyday in our minds. The Other Jim 1/3

RAHMEY--Jeanne. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Jeanne Rahmey, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jeanne's beloved children, Jack, Ness, Grace, and Stephen; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

ANDREADIS--Barbara, nee Hamilton, passed away suddenly Friday, October 30, 2015. Wife, Mother, Grandmother, Sister, Friend, she will be mourned by all who knew and loved her. She founded The Andreadis Talent Agency and spent 30 years helping other actors achieve their dreams of life on the stage, TV, and in film. Barbara leaves behind her son John Andreadis, his wife Michele and son Davide, her daughter Eleni Andreadis and her husband Charles Lambiotte, and their adult children Nick and Alex, as well as her sister, Marcy Hamilton. A celebration of life will take place at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St. on Tuesday November 3rd from 6 to 9pm. The funeral service will be held there as well on Wednesday at noon. Interment will be at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla New York following the service. 1/3

ABRAMS--Fred. The entire EPIC Long Island family mourns the passing of Fred Abrams our friend and Board member of 49 years. Fred and his late wife, Sheila, became involved in the Epilepsy Foundation of Long Island (now EPIC Long Island) in 1967 when they were elected to the Board of Directors. Since then Fred served as President and Vice-President, and remained an active and respected member of the Board until his death. Fred was an important spokesperson for people with epilepsy, both locally and on the national level, and his unwavering commitment to advocacy, education and awareness in the field will be a lasting legacy. Giving generously of both his time and resources to support a cause that was close to his heart, Fred was an inspiration to all who knew him. We extend heartfelt condolences to his children, Cliff, Roberta and Philip. Jeffrey Nagel, Chairman Board of Directors Thomas Hopkins, President & CEO EPIC Long Island 1/3

SCHUPAK--Belle, (Bella Goldstein), on November 1, age 98. Predeceased by husband of 63 years, Nathan and brothers Bernard and Joseph. Survived by sons Howard (Sonna), Paul (Rhona) and Martin (Elaine). Grandchildren Matthew (Jen), Ben (Kelley), Sarah, Elyse, Jeffrey (Jenn), Michael (Amber), Lisa (Michael Trevino). Great-grand- children Jacob, Rachel, Sam, Lucy, and Rebecca. Also survived by brother Stanley Goldstein and sister Edith Isaacs. Service November 3, at 1pm, Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains, NY. 1/3
HERSHEY--Dr. Paul E.,of Manhasset, NY, passed away on November 1, 2015 at home. Respected and admired podiatrist, beloved husband of 62 years to Marian, father of Joan and Karen. 1/3

LABADORF--Irwin Paul, passed away Sunday, November 1, 2015 at the age of 90. A resident of White Plains, NY for 50 years, Irwin was born in Manhattan and grew up on the Upper West Side. He was a proud graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School and the Wharton Business School of the University of Pennsylvania. From a young age he overcame adversity - the loss of his father at age 16 and the loss of a leg just after WWII. Yet he never let that disability get in the way of a long and wonderful life full of tennis, golf, the outdoors and traveling the world. He proudly served the United States Air Force aboard a B17 flying 19 combat missions over Germany and earning an air medal with two oak leaf clusters. Following WWII he was blessed with a happy and loving marriage of 46 years to Arlene Barkan until her untimely death to cancer. He loved classical music, the opera, theatre, the arts and took several college courses in myriad cultural subjects up until he was 89. He worked his entire life at Sobel Affiliates, then a third generation insurance brokerage firm founded by his grandfather in 1904, and subsequently run by his two sons, the fourth generation. He was a founding member of the Insurance Broker's Roundtable. He was a modest man but a great philanthropist to many causes, including Camp Vacamas for underprivileged kids, White Plains Hospital, The UJA Federation of New York, and SUNY Purchase. He is survived by his two sons Alan and Michael, their wives Robin and Corey, his five grandchildren Samantha and husband Hunter, Danielle and husband Zach, Stephanie, Juliet and Mark, and three great-grandchildren Andie, Jack and Olivia. He will always be remembered most for his love and devotion to his family. 1/3
GERSHMAN--Mortimer, 89, husband of Jacqueline. Watch industry executive. Loving husband, father and grandfather. He passed away on November 2, 2015. 1/3

WAGNER--Daniel, 96, died on October 20, 2015 at his home in New York City. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, as well as three children from his previous marriage, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. His long career was dedicated to education, at home and overseas. He was director of the Ethical Culture Schools in New York, followed by international schools in Germany and Kenya. For many years as contract executive director for International Schools Services in Princeton, he was involved in multiple facets of overseas operations and made a great many friends among International Schools' faculties and administrators during his extensive travels around the world. He is missed very much. 1/3

ZUBER--Ludwig Christian "Chris" Born in Leimen, Germany on September 26, 1914. Died on November 1, 2015 in St. Petersburg, FL. Beloved teacher and Director of Cherry Lawn School and noted Floridian artist. 1/3

ABRAMS--Fred. The entire EPIC Long Island family mourns the passing of Fred Abrams our friend and Board member of 49 years. Fred and his late wife, Sheila, became involved in the Epilepsy Foundation of Long Island (now EPIC Long Island) in 1967 when they were elected to the Board of Directors. Since then Fred served as President and Vice-President, and remained an active and respected member of the Board until his death. Fred was an important spokesperson for people with epilepsy, both locally and on the national level, and his unwavering commitment to advocacy, education and awareness in the field will be a lasting legacy. Giving generously of both his time and resources to support a cause that was close to his heart, Fred was an inspiration to all who knew him. We extend heartfelt condolences to his children, Cliff, Roberta and Philip. Jeffrey Nagel, Chairman Board of Directors Thomas Hopkins, President & CEO EPIC Long Island 1/3

CHRISTIANSON--Uta. Uta Meyer Christianson of New York City died on October 20, 2015 after a long illness. Wife of the late Paul Christianson, she was born in Cologne, Germany on February 23, 1940, and arrived in New York in April, 1968. That year she and Paul founded the International Student Visitors Service, which became InterExchange, a non-profit organization that manages cultural exchange programs with some 60 countries. She is survived by a brother, Franz Meyer, a sister-in-law, Susanne, and two nephews, Till and Jan, who all reside in Germany. Funeral services in Connecticut will be private. 1/3

COONEY--John P.,Jr., died peacefully of lung cancer at home at the age of 71 on November 2, 2015, surrounded by his family. The only son of John P. Cooney, Sr. and Katherine Rafferty Cooney, Jack, as he was known to one and all, was born on October 18, 1944 in Chicago, Illinois, graduated first from Fenwick High School in Oak Park, Illinois, then from college at Indiana University in Bloomington, and thereafter from the Duke University School of Law where he served as Note Editor of the Duke Law Journal. From 1972 to 1977 he was an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, where he became Chief of the Narcotics Unit. In 1977 he returned to the New York City law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP from which he retired in 2008 after which he became a Principal at McKool Smith, P.C. Jack's time in private practice spanned a period of remarkable growth in the prosecution of white-collar crime, and Jack's career made him one of the pre- eminent white-collar practitioners of his day. He defended countless individuals and corporations in grand jury, regulatory and other governmental investigations, both in the United States and abroad. Because Jack's cases frequently resulted in the prosecution dropping charges or not proceeding with them, his success in these cases--from those involving insider trading and anti-trust violations to others under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act--were known perhaps more often by his grateful clients and his brethren at the Bar than by the newspapers. Although some of his clients were well-known, many others were not: these were clients Jack represented by appointment by the court under the Criminal Justice Act because they were unable to pay a lawyer to represent them. Not only did these clients get the same dogged, deft and passionate representation that Jack devoted to his other clients, they got the same outstanding results. Beyond this professional pre- eminence, Jack's life embraced an unalloyed joy and enthusiasm for his pursuits--outdoors in his beloved Tetons, shooting pheasant, rooting for the Duke Blue Devils, and being with his many dear friends in New York City, Rye, NY and Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Most of all, he cherished his time with the family he so loved and now leaves: his wife, Jane (Hewett); his sons John, Brian, Luke and Nathaniel, his daughters Anne and Emma, and his grandchildren Alexa and Patrick. Jack's sister, Judith Ann Cooney, predeceased him. All these family and friends will miss Jack's consuming interests in history, literature and poetry; his lectures on the fine points of college basketball and football and major league baseball; his disquisitions on the merits of this or that Super Tuscan; but most of all his brave and ready embrace of life with all its highs and lows and of love in its every manifestation. We who are left are left, indeed, to reflect that "we shall not look upon his like again." The family will receive visitors at home on Tuesday, November 10, 2015 from 4 to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on November 11, 2015 at 11:15am at The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, N.Y. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made in Jack's memory to the Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, 14th Floor, New York NY 10022 (innercityscholarshipfund.org) or to the Yellowstone Park Foundation, 222 E. Main St., #

SCHEINER--Seth M.,82 of Kendall Park, New Jersey, died November 3, 2015 at The Atrium Acute Care of Princeton. Born in New York, NY, he has been a resident of Kendall Park, New Jersey for 30 years. Dr. Scheiner retired in 1998 as Professor Emeritus in American History from Rutgers University in New Brunswick, where he had taught since 1968. From 1962-1968, he taught at Temple University in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Eveline Scheiner, two sons and two daughter-in- laws Jeffrey and Robin Scheiner and Adam Scheiner and Lana Faye Taradash, a sister Martha Lederer, a step- daughter Ellen Goldstein and her husband Allan, a step-son Evan Shurak and his girlfriend Sarah Wilson, and seven grandchildren, Amy, Matthew, Madeline, Amelia, Noah, Carly and Brooke. A graveside service will be held on Thursday, November 5, 2015 at 11:00am. In Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. Shiva will be observed until Sunday evening Scheiner Residence. Memorial Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

CLAUDE--Elizabeth J.,died October 31, 2015 after a long and hard fought battle with lung cancer. Born in Greenville, NC and a graduate of the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, she was a strong minded southern woman with style and a sense of humor. Mother of four children and grandmother of six, she adored her family and her husband, Abram Claude, Jr. She played a leading role in many not-for-profit organizations, including The Winter Antique Show and The Art Dealers Association Show, both held in the 7th Regiment Armory. In her hometown of Bedford, NY, she spent years volunteering at Northern Westchester Hospital, Rippowam Cisqua School and St Matthew's Church and over 15 years at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, the largest women's prison in New York State, where she helped the inmates keep in touch with their children and deal with their problems. She won many awards for her work at the prison. Her greatest joy was being a loving wife, mother and grandmother and staying in close touch with her legions of friends from all generations. With sophisticated tastes, she spent endless hours in museums, art galleries and at the theater. Hers was a life well lived and she was much loved. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY at 3pm Friday, November 6th. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to Hour Children, Inc., 36-11 12th Street, Long Island City, NY 11106. 1/3

COONEY--John P.,Jr. Davis Polk & Wardwell mourns the loss of our dear friend and former partner. Jack graduated from Indiana University and received his J.D. from Duke University. He began his career at Davis Polk in 1969 and specialized in white collar criminal defense. Following five years at the U.S. Attorney's office in the Southern District, including two years as Chief of the Narcotics Unit, Jack became a partner in 1980. A fellow at the American College of Trial Lawyers, Jack was instrumental in what became for the firm a highly successful white collar crime practice. He will be missed by all of us for his generosity, warmth and wisdom. 1/3

ABRAMS--Fred. The Boards of Directors, leadership and staff of MJHS mourn the loss of esteemed board member Fred Abrams. For more than 30 years Fred advanced the mission of MJHS, regularly sharing his financial and business acumen. His involvement with MJHS dates back to the original Menorah Home and Hospital in Brooklyn and continued through what is now known as Menorah Center for Rehabilitation and Nursing Care. Fred served on a number of our boards, including MJHS Home Care and Menorah. A tireless advocate for access to quality, compassionate and innovative health services, Fred will be greatly missed. Our sympathies go to his children, Philip, Cliff, Roberta, son-in-law Gary, and his grandchildren. May his legacy--and that of his late wife Sheila--serve as a source of inspiration and may his memory be for a blessing. The family asks that donations in Fred's honor be made to MJHS Foundation, 39 Broadway, 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10006, www.mjhsfoundation.org. Dr. Arthur Goshin, Chairman MJHS Alexander S. Balko, President & CEO 1/3

McILWAIN--Robert Moore. Of Bernardsville, NJ, and Vero Beach, FL, passed away on Saturday, October 24, 2015, a few days before his 88th birthday, and not long after he attended his 65th reunion at Dartmouth College. Bob enjoyed a full life with his wife Joan, sons Robert, John, David and Bill, daughters- in-law Michaela, Melissa, AnnMarie and Halley, grandchildren Chelsea, Russell, Jenny, Wesley, Juliet, Charlie and Elizabeth, a close extended family, and many special friends from Dartmouth, New Jersey, Florida and around the globe. He grew up in Radnor, PA, the son of the late Hugh and Evelyn McIlwain, with his younger brothers Pete and Tom. He graduated from The Haverford School, Haverford, PA, and spent a year in the Coast Guard before entering Dartmouth College, where he earned a bachelor of arts degree, followed by a master's degree at the college's Thayer School of Engineering and a master of business administration degree from the Tuck School of Business. Bob loved Dartmouth. He was a class president as an undergraduate and never missed a class reunion in 65 years. After college, he served as a lieutenant in the Navy for three years, then worked for McKinsey & Company, Singer Corporation, Warner- Lambert and Engelhard Corporation. He spent the last 13 years of his career as a senior executive at Englehard, retiring from there in 1992. Meeting and marrying his wife Joan was the most important event of his life. For 57 years they had a wonderful time raising four boys and having great fun with their friends and family. They enjoyed tennis, skiing, golf, dancing and bridge, and traveled to many parts of the world. Also, they were active supporting their communities. More than anything, Bob loved his family, grandchildren, his extended family and his many, many good friends. He was exceptional with people - attentive, bright, fun, humorous and loyal. He had a way with people that let them know how special they were. He loved life fully, and it meant a great deal to him to share and enjoy life with others. We will all miss his presence in our lives - his generosity and wisdom, his warm smile and the twinkle in his eyes. A service to celebrate Bob's life will be held at 11am on Saturday, November 7, at the Church of St. John on the Mountain, 379 Mount Harmony Road in Bernardsville, NJ. Those wishing to send flowers can instead honor him by supporting the John's Island Foundation, which he helped establish and develop. It serves disadvantaged people in Indian River County, FL. Donations may be made at johnsislandfoundation.org. Donations may also be made to the Foundation for Morristown Medical Center, 475 South St., Morristown, NJ, 07960 or to Dartmouth College, www.giving.dartmouth.edu. 1/3

SOMMER-BATKIN--Donna Anne, age 87, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, November 4th at CareOne at The Cupola in Paramus, NJ. Born and raised in New York, NY, she lived in Hillsdale, NJ for 34 years before moving to New Rochelle, NY in 1994. Donna was a teacher in the NYC Public Schools for 10 years before teaching at the Moriah School in Englewood for 17 years before retiring in 1990. She enjoyed traveling, music and the arts and was passionate in her support of Jewish life. Predeceased by her first husband, Ernest L. Sommer, in 1990, and her second husband, Stanley I. Batkin, in 2015, she is survived by her three sons, Bob and his wife, Marjorie of Ridgewood, NJ; Benjamin and his wife, Jennifer Dugdale of Teaneck, NJ; Jeff and his wife, Lisa of Johannesburg, South Africa; a brother, Mordechai Lapin and his wife Monica of Pittsfield, MA; a sister, Yette Avnet and her husband Irv of Levittown, NY; and her seven grandchildren: Alex, Will, Amanda, Haley, Avraham, Sarah, and Eliana. Chapel services will be held on Friday, November 6th, at 1:00pm, Gutterman-Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ 07601. Interment will follow at the Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ 07652. Donations in Mrs. Sommer-Batkin's name may be made to Jewish Theological Seminary (www.jtsa.edu) or Plan International (www.planusa.org). 1/3
MOSCOT--Kenneth Charles. 1/9/1970 - 11/5/2010. Our broken hearts will never mend, so profoundly missed. Love is forever. 1/3

EWING--Sheila Cobb. Poet, actress, and lover of literature and the arts, died Tuesday, November 3, in Winston-Salem, NC, of multiple myeloma. Born in New York on April 1, 1939, she was married for 45 years to her beloved husband Alex C. Ewing, following the death of her first husband Michael deShee Clarke. She graduated from Vassar College in 1961, and earned masters degrees from Columbia University and Sarah Lawrence. With a firm and loving hand, she raised four children, daughter Cecilia Clarke and stepchildren Sandy, Eric and Caroline Ewing, in Millbrook, NY, where she lived from 1970 to 1990. When Alex's appointment as Chancellor of the North Carolina School of the Arts unexpectedly brought them to Winston-Salem, she embraced with gusto her new role as First Lady of NCSA. In addition, she performed in plays, wrote book reviews and travel articles, volunteered at a hospital, sang in the St. Paul's Church choir, maintained a beautiful flower garden, and played tennis and a matchless game of Scrabble. A lifelong lover of Ireland, she and Alex returned frequently to their home-away-from-home in County Cork. She lived her life with verve, style, unflagging humor and impeccable taste, and brought forth beauty from whatever she touched. She was the best friend not only of her husband but also of an astonishing number of others. She saw people deeply, and in their most critical moments reached them with her unerring insight, often expressed in long-treasured letters. In everything she did, she set very high standards for herself and always met them. In addition to her husband Alex and her four children, she is survived by her brother John Whitehouse Cobb of Denver, Colorado, her sister Victoria Mackintosh of Alresford, Hampshire, England, and eight grandchildren: Allegra Eifler, Josephine and Simon Born, Alden and Caleb Ewing, and Nathan, Seth and Henry Ewing-Crystal. The funeral will be Monday, November 9, at 11am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Winston-Salem. Contributions may be made in Sheila's memory to the Sheila Cobb Scholarship at the North Carolina School of the Arts. 1/3

BROUMAND--Hormoz, passed away in Indianapolis on Tuesday, November 3, 2015 at the age of 91. Born in Tehran, Iran to the late Khalil and Farangis Broumand-- Nejad, Hormoz came to the United States in 1944 to attend graduate school. Hormoz received his BS in Iran, his MS from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and his PhD in Food Chemistry from Cook College, Rutgers University. He completed his post-doctorate fellowship at Purdue University. He started his career as a food chemist at Continental Can Company and Nabisco before moving to Indianapolis to work for Stark & Wetzel. Hormoz started North American Laboratories in the 1960s, which he later sold, and then Food Innovations International to develop and manufacture food seasonings and spices. He was a Fellow of the Institute of Food Technologists. Hormoz was blessed with a 59 year happy and loving marriage to Rachel Tour, also from Tehran. Hormoz loved classical music, Persian poetry and literature. He served on the Board of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. He was a role model and support system for other families who had immigrated to the United States. Hormoz was one of the founding members and President of the International Society of Indianapolis. He is survived by his beautiful and devoted wife Rachel, their two sons Clifton and Stafford, his daughter-in-law Laura and his beloved grandson William. He will be remembered most for the twinkle in his eye, his unconditional generosity and his love and commitment to his family, friends and community. The family asks that donations in Hormoz's honor be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation at michaeljfox.org. 1/3

Loving mother of Michael and Ondine of Port Washington, Pasquale and Marybeth of Garden City and Fred and Lydia of Pound Ridge. Generous grandmother to Joseph, Jack, Dan, Max, Christopher and Juliette. Burial ceremony at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 1313 South York St., Mechanicsburg, PA 17055 on Saturday, November 7th at 10am. In her honor, donations can be made to Nassau Suffolk Services for Autism, 80 Hauppauge Road, Commack, NY 11725. Attn: Connie Grassle. www. Nssa.org. 1/3

FALES--Haliburton, 2d The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Haliburton Fales, 2d. He joined the Board as a Trustee in 1967 and served as its President from 1981 to 1988, becoming a Trustee Emeritus in 1994. He was deeply committed to the Morgan and its growth. Kind, generous, and thoughtful, he touched all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Colin B. Bailey, Dir. 1/3
