GOLLAY--Jean, on November 4 at the age of 97. Jean was born in New York City, graduated from Barnard College, and worked as a magazine journalist and as author of numerous books of nonfiction and fiction written under the name Jean Libman Block. During her long career she served as articles editor for Good Housekeeping and as a writer for Revlon. She was the first woman president of the Society of Magazine Writers, now the American Society of Journalists and Authors. With her second husband, Ben Gollay, she became a collector of art that will be donated to the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, FL. Her survivors include her daughter, Elizabeth J. Block, her son, Fred L. Block (Carole), her stepdaughter, Elinor Gollay (Rex), and two grand- daughters, Miriam and Jude Joffe-Block. 1/3

LEPERA--Maria, on November 4, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Pasquale. Devoted mother of Christine and Margaret. Cherished sister of Natalie Comerford, Joseph Gennaro and the late Grace Paccini and Charles Gennaro. Friends may call Thursday, November 5, 2-5 and 7-9pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, November 6, 1pm at Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church. 1/3

DEUTSCH--Larry, M.D. Beloved and dedicated Philadelphia Pediatrician for 40 years, and friend of so many in the community. Son of Rose and Moe Deutsch, he is survived by his dear wife Barbara, daughters Jennifer and Meredith, sister Carol (Dick) and brother Paul (Barbara). He will be missed by all. 1/3

FICHOPOLOS--Lily, passed away peacefully surrounded by her family on November 2, 2015. Beloved daughter of the late George and Thecla Fichopolos. Loving sister of the late Mary Johnson and sisterin-law of the late Dr. Alfred Johnson. Loving aunt of Irene Campbell and Lillian Johnson. Service Thursday, November 5, 2015, 11am at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 337 East 74th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Archdiocesan Cathedral Philoptochos Society. 1/3

HALPIN--John E. Was born in New York City on May 29, 1937 and died on November 2, 2015 at age 78 after experiencing many health problems. He leaves his loving wife of 30 years, Martha Petrash, devoted son, John Jr., daughter-in-law, Danielle Fern, and two adoring grandchildren -- Alex Carleton and Amelia Elise. John's older son, Carleton, died of Cystic Fibrosis in 1998 at age 33. John also leaves his extended family, the Noonans, whom he loved. John drew inspiration from all of his friends, many of whom were friends of Bill W., as well as colleagues and clients he respected and enjoyed working with during his long and distinguished legal career. John was part of the East Side House Settlement in Yorkville when he was a child. It was there that he received a full scholarship to Middlebury College from philanthropist, Mr. Carroll Stollenwerck. John also received a master's degree in social work from Columbia University and his law degree from Fordham University School of Law. In addition to his legal practice, for many years he was an adjunct professor at Hunter College. John helped start Sponsors for Educational Opportunity (SEO) 52 years ago, to help low-income students achieve college educations and enter the professional world. SEO has successfully helped thousands of young people. John proudly ran nine marathons, seven of them in New York City, and rode horses in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Ireland. He particularly enjoyed riding a horse in the St. Patrick's Day parade and said he loved to doff his hat to the Cardinal, who stood outside of St. Patrick's Cathedral. There will be a wake at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Friday, November 6th from 2-5pm and 7-9pm and a Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th St. on Saturday, November 7th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, if you wish, please send a contribution to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, P.O. Box 52074, Phoenix, AZ 85072 or to Sponsors for Educational Opportunity, 55 Exchange Place, New York, NY 10005. 1/3

COONEY--John P.,Jr. The Robert B. Fiske Jr. Association mourns the passing of its esteemed and beloved member and colleague John P. Cooney, Jr. on Monday, November 2, 2015 at the age of 71. Jack, as he was known, was an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York from 1972 to 1977 and was Chief of the Narcotics Unit during 1976-77. A signal highlight of his trial career, among many such, was the conviction of Vincent Papa, a mob kingpin of the narcotics trade in New York. Papa was arrested in The Bronx with a million dollars in cash in the trunk of his car, which Jack introduced into evidence against him thus sealing his fate at trial. After his career as a federal prosecutor Jack earned an unrivalled reputation as a lion of the bar representing individuals and corporations in an ever-widening spectrum of white-collar criminal cases and defending indigent defendants under the Criminal Justice Act with superb talent, real grit and utter determination. A Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, Jack was a partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell for 30 years before his retirement in 2008 when he joined McKool Smith, PC as a Principal. His wit, his enthusiasm and his charm will be missed both by his colleagues in the Association and by those on the bench and at the bar more generally. Our sympathy and condolences are extended to his wife Jane and his children and grandchildren. 1/3

FALES--Haliburton, 2d The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Haliburton Fales, 2d. He joined the Board as a Trustee in 1967 and served as its President from 1981 to 1988, becoming a Trustee Emeritus in 1994. He was deeply committed to the Morgan and its growth. Kind, generous, and thoughtful, he touched all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Colin B. Bailey, Dir. 1/3

GREENE--Barbara Isabelle, (nee Weise). Retired New York City public school principal, ardent reader and supporter of the arts, and devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend, died November 5, in Great Barrington, MA, of an intracerebral hemorrhagic stroke. Born in Brooklyn on May 31, 1930, she was married for 60 years to Martin Greene and together with him took loving care of their two daughters and four grandchildren. She managed to combine being feisty and outspoken with tenderness, great warmth, and a keen sense of humor. She graduated from New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn in 1948, from New York University with a BA, and from St. John's University with an advanced degree in school administration. An intellectual force and a master of the English language, Barbara had a long career in the city schools: as an English teacher sharing her love of language and literature and as a guidance counselor at Benjamin Franklin High School in Manhattan, encouraging many students to become the first person in their family to attend college and numerous others to pursue their dreams through higher education; as an assistant principal at Jane Addams High School in the Bronx; as a principal at William E. Grady, a vocational high school in Brooklyn; and then as the principal of Newtown High School in Elmhurst. In 1992, Barbara announced she was becoming "leisured for life." She retired to spend more time with her family and her beloved English literature, to travel, and to enjoy endless hours at her home in South Egremont, MA, in the Berkshires, reading The New York Times in her favorite sunny spot, on her deck next to an apple tree. In addition to her husband Martin, Barbara is survived by two of her sisters, Carol and Jacqueline; two daughters, Elizabeth and Alice; her son-in-law, Curtis Jones; and her four grandchildren: Sam and Ruby Jones and Isabella and Thomas Mungioli. Her memorial service will be held this Sunday, November 8, at noon at 220 Castle Hill Avenue, Great Barrington, MA. Donations in her honor may be made to Heifer International (855-948-6437), a charity she admired for its work in helping women in Africa to provide financial security for their families. 1/3
HEYMAN--Samuel J. In these 6 years, we feel you guiding us, rooting us on, surrounding us with your wisdom and love. To your adoring family, you are ever present. Ronnie and the Children 1/3

HALPIN--John E. Was born in New York City on May 29, 1937 and died on November 2, 2015 at age 78 after experiencing many health problems. He leaves his loving wife of 30 years, Martha Petrash, devoted son, John Jr., daughter-in-law, Danielle Fern, and two adoring grandchildren -- Alex Carleton and Amelia Elise. John's older son, Carleton, died of Cystic Fibrosis in 1998 at age 33. John also leaves his extended family, the Noonans, whom he loved. John drew inspiration from all of his friends, many of whom were friends of Bill W., as well as colleagues and clients he respected and enjoyed working with during his long and distinguished legal career. John was part of the East Side House Settlement in Yorkville when he was a child. It was there that he received a full scholarship to Middlebury College from philanthropist, Mr. Carroll Stollenwerck. John also received a master's degree in social work from Columbia University and his law degree from Fordham University School of Law. In addition to his legal practice, for many years he was an adjunct professor at Hunter College. John helped start Sponsors for Educational Opportunity (SEO) 52 years ago, to help low-income students achieve college educations and enter the professional world. SEO has successfully helped thousands of young people. John proudly ran nine marathons, seven of them in New York City, and rode horses in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Ireland. He particularly enjoyed riding a horse in the St. Patrick's Day parade and said he loved to doff his hat to the Cardinal, who stood outside of St. Patrick's Cathedral. There will be a wake at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Friday, November 6th from 2-5pm and 7-9pm and a Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th St. on Saturday, November 7th at 10am. In lieu of flowers, if you wish, please send a contribution to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, P.O. Box 52074, Phoenix, AZ 85072 or to Sponsors for Educational Opportunity, 55 Exchange Place, New York, NY 10005. 1/3

LENKE--Helen Rand, a generous, warm and wonderful woman who was adored by her many friends and relatives for 96 years, passed peacefully on Wednesday, November 4th. Helen is survived by her children Patricia Fox; Judith Taft (Ron Hollander); Dr. Roger Lenke (Joanne). Her six grandchildren - Brian, Laura, and Jacqueline Fox, Peter and James Taft, and Michael Lenke --will miss her boundless affection. Graveside services will be held at Mount Neboh Cemetery in Glendale, NY on Monday, November 9th at 11am, where she will join her beloved husband of 58 years, Sidney Edward Lenke, who predeceased her in 1997. Donations in Helen's memory can be made to a charity of one's choice. 1/3

COONEY--Jack. The Members and Staff of the Pawling Mountain Club mourn the loss of fellow sportsman and our dear friend, Jack Cooney. We offer our most heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jane, all their children, family and friends. We will miss him. Philip C. Bonanno Bill McMahon 1/3

LEONARD--Michael "Mickey", 84, died at home on October 31. Mickey was a gifted composer and arranger, who wrote for Broadway, film and television. His songs, including I'm All Smiles, Why Did I Choose You and Not Exactly Paris, were performed by numerous artists, including Barbra Streisand and Nancy Sinatra. He was the musical supervisor on the original Broadway production of Grease, and arranged for jazz pianist, Bill Evans. Mickey is survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Maury and Betty, their children, Bradley, Neal and Alison, and seven grandnieces and nephews. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 8 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in his honor at the charity of your choice. 1/3

HEYMAN--Annette Silverman, 102. Beloved wife of the late Lazarus Heyman (z"l), treasured mother of Samuel Heyman (z"l) and Abigail Heyman Bloch (z"l), adored mother-in-law of Ronnie Feuerstein Heyman. Grandmother of Lazarus Heyman (Kim), Eleanor Heyman Propp, Jennifer Millstone (David), Elizabeth Heyman Winter and Lazar Bloch. Proud great-grandmother of 11: Si, Sheldon, and Solomon Heyman; Stella, Juliette and Clara Propp; Pippa, Francie, Samuelle and Marielle Millstone; and Charlie Winter. Private services will be held in Danbury, CT. A dear soul, blessed with unique grace and compassion. She was a wonderful woman, wife, mother, grandparent, great grandparent and unconditional friend whose wise counsel was sought by many. Her loving and comforting nature was a blessing to all who knew her. 1/3
REEVE--Francis (Ranny), of Coram, NY, passed away on November 4. Visitations November 6, 2-4pm, 7-9pm; service November 7, 11am. 1/3

BROUMAND--Hormoz, passed away in Indianapolis on Tuesday, November 3, 2015 at the age of 91. Born in Tehran, Iran to the late Khalil and Farangis Broumand-- Nejad, Hormoz came to the United States in 1944 to attend graduate school. Hormoz received his BS in Iran, his MS from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and his PhD in Food Chemistry from Cook College, Rutgers University. He completed his post-doctorate fellowship at Purdue University. He started his career as a food chemist at Continental Can Company and Nabisco before moving to Indianapolis to work for Stark & Wetzel. Hormoz started North American Laboratories in the 1960s, which he later sold, and then Food Innovations International to develop and manufacture food seasonings and spices. He was a Fellow of the Institute of Food Technologists. Hormoz was blessed with a 59 year happy and loving marriage to Rachel Tour, also from Tehran. Hormoz loved classical music, Persian poetry and literature. He served on the Board of the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. He was a role model and support system for other families who had immigrated to the United States. Hormoz was one of the founding members and President of the International Society of Indianapolis. He is survived by his beautiful and devoted wife Rachel, their two sons Clifton and Stafford, his daughter-in-law Laura and his beloved grandson William. He will be remembered most for the twinkle in his eye, his unconditional generosity and his love and commitment to his family, friends and community. The family asks that donations in Hormoz's honor be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation at michaeljfox.org. 1/3
CREAGHAN--George B. May perpetual light shine upon you as well as our undying love. Patricia, Dennis, Georgina 1/3

MONTE--Noel H.,DDS, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Ruth, passed away on Wednesday, November 4th. Funeral at "The Riverside", 76th and Amsterdam Ave. on Friday, November 6th at 12pm. Burial to follow at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, NY. 1/3

EWING--Sheila Cobb. Poet, actress, and lover of literature and the arts, died Tuesday, November 3, in Winston-Salem, NC, of multiple myeloma. Born in New York on April 1, 1939, she was married for 45 years to her beloved husband Alex C. Ewing, following the death of her first husband Michael deShee Clarke. She graduated from Vassar College in 1961, and earned masters degrees from Columbia University and Sarah Lawrence. With a firm and loving hand, she raised four children, daughter Cecilia Clarke and stepchildren Sandy, Eric and Caroline Ewing, in Millbrook, NY, where she lived from 1970 to 1990. When Alex's appointment as Chancellor of the North Carolina School of the Arts unexpectedly brought them to Winston-Salem, she embraced with gusto her new role as First Lady of NCSA. In addition, she performed in plays, wrote book reviews and travel articles, volunteered at a hospital, sang in the St. Paul's Church choir, maintained a beautiful flower garden, and played tennis and a matchless game of Scrabble. A lifelong lover of Ireland, she and Alex returned frequently to their home-away-from-home in County Cork. She lived her life with verve, style, unflagging humor and impeccable taste, and brought forth beauty from whatever she touched. She was the best friend not only of her husband but also of an astonishing number of others. She saw people deeply, and in their most critical moments reached them with her unerring insight, often expressed in long-treasured letters. In everything she did, she set very high standards for herself and always met them. In addition to her husband Alex and her four children, she is survived by her brother John Whitehouse Cobb of Denver, Colorado, her sister Victoria Mackintosh of Alresford, Hampshire, England, and eight grandchildren: Allegra Eifler, Josephine and Simon Born, Alden and Caleb Ewing, and Nathan, Seth and Henry Ewing-Crystal. The funeral will be Monday, November 9, at 11am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Winston-Salem. Contributions may be made in Sheila's memory to the Sheila Cobb Scholarship at the North Carolina School of the Arts. 1/3

MAURER--Anne Estrin, DSW, 94, died November 5. Predeceased by loving husband Murray L. Maurer and sister Lucy Kavaler. STERN--Gloria, 88. Gloria was the source of extraordinary joy and light to those who were close to her. She was a true artist, who saw beauty in ordinary things, gave expression to them, and shared her works with those she loved and the world. She was a magnificent cook and kept her family in constant delight with her cakes, meringues, and other creations. She was gentle, compassionate, curious and a lot of fun. She was a beautiful person inside and out. She grew up and raised a family in South Africa. After losing the love of her life, her husband, Leonard Stern, to whom she was married for 44 years, she moved to the United States and courageously built a life for herself, surrounded by her growing family and new friends. She loved music, literature, swimming and the beach; she loved and found great cheer in animals; she loved to laugh and was great at it; she loved a warm, deep hug - and excelled at providing them. Above all else, she loved her family - who loved her deeply, were blessed to have her grace their lives, and who now have the privilege of carrying on her rich legacy. She is remembered with adoration by her daughter, Janine, and her husband, Alan and late husband Darryl, and her son, Colin and his wife Felicia; by her grandchildren Craig, Jeannie, Gary, Sharie, Amanda, Zac, Greg, Caitlin, Max, Mary and Sara; by her great grandchildren Sasha, Lila, Clara, Natalie, Connor, Josh, Julia, Charlie, Claire and Tyler; by her beloved Grant, Shelley, Doug, Andrea, and Kimmie; by her pals Buster and Daisy; and, by very special friends and care-takers Suzette Morgado, Kim Acosta, May Yang, Kaye Nicole Acosta, Emma Labor, Florence Enduma and Gabriela Dzurbanova. The family will hold private funeral services. 1/3

PETRILLO--Madeline, died October 15, 2015 after two months at The Friendly Home on East Avenue in Rochester, NY. Predeceased by her parents, Carmela and Peter Petrillo, her sister, Jay (Jennie) and survived by her sisters, Mary Mykins, Anne Steinberger and Eileen Petrillo, and her brothers, Joseph Petrillo and James Petrillo, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Madeline was a graduate of the University of Rochester and Teachers College, Columbia University. She lived in New York City for over 60 years, returning to Rochester due to health concerns. Her innovations as a nurse and Mental Health Consultant in Pediatrics at New York Hospital and Memorial Sloan Kettering were highlighted in her book, "Emotional Care of Hospitalized Children, An Environmental Approach." She was renowned as a lecturer throughout the United States. Madeline valued books, reading, interior design, flowers, travel and talking politics. She loved giving parties and entertaining her numerous friends in NYC. She was a scholar and will be remembered for her pioneering work with children. Her legacy is maintained in the archives of the University of Pennsylvania, The Barbara Bates Center. Her wish was to be cremated and to have a bench in Central Park engraved with her name. A Celebration lunch for family and friends will occur in November. To share a memory or send condolences: epetrillo@ rochester.rr.com. Services by Rochester Cremation, 4044 W. Henrietta Road, Rochester, NY 14623, 585-259-2300, RochesterCremation.com. 1/3

PARNESS--Melvyn H. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of Executive Vice President Emeritus, Mel Parness. Mel has given over 50 years of service to Bnai Zion, establishing his first Bnai Zion chapter when he was a teenager. Mel joined the staff of Bnai Zion in 1964 and was elected its National Secretary in 1976. He was then elected to the position Executive Vice-President in June 1983 and retired in July 2006. Even after his retirement he continued to be a driving force within the organization and lent his expertise wherever it was needed. The Bnai Zion Foundation grew in both scope and fundraising capacity during Mel's tenure. Mel's efforts led to a greatly expanded profile of the organization and increased contributions to its projects. He was a dynamic speaker and had been active in many Jewish organizations, including the America-Israel Friendship League, Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, the American Zionist Movement, the American Red Magen David, the Israel Dance Institute, and Israel Bonds. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish National Fund. Mel exemplified what it means to be a dedicated Zionist, humanist and American Jew. The funeral will take place on Sunday, November 8th, at 12:30pm at Eden Memorial Chapels, 327 Main Street Ft Lee, NJ 07024. Our hearts go out to his wife Arlyne, their children, Bari and Alan Shaffran, and Caryn and Keith Evans, and their grandchildren, Lizzie, Jonathan, Emerson, Andrew and Brady, and may his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. George W. Schaeffer, Chairman of the Board David H. Eisenberg, National President Cheryl Bier, COO 1/3

McGREEVY--Molly Paine, died on Sunday, November 1, 2015, at her home in Pittsford, NY. Born on June 11, 1936, to Hugh Eustis Paine and Helen Duncan Paine, she graduated from The Chapin School and Vassar College, completing as her senior thesis a play based on her favorite childhood character, Mary Poppins. After college, Molly moved to Paris to study mime under Marcel Marceau. Returning to Manhattan, she met and married stockbroker Thomas James McGreevy and then moved to Kansas City, MO, where their three daughters were born. A free spirit with a wild sense of humor, she told her daughters that she brought the new dance "The Twist" to that reserved Midwestern town. Molly resumed her career as an actress in local theatre, in the movie "Shoot it Black, Shoot it Blue" (1974), and as Polly Longworth in the TV soap opera Ryan's Hope (between 1977 and 1981). She also produced the documentary "Nothing by Chance" (1975). She married actor Earl Hindman in 1976 and moved to Stamford, CT, where he continued his acting career in movies, theatre, and TV (playing Wilson, the "Hi-di- ho" neighbor in "Home Improvement" who was never seen except for his head looking over the fence). Changing course, Molly received her Master of Divinity from The General Theological Seminary in New York City in 1986. She was ordained a deacon in the Episcopal Church on June 10, 1989, and was ordained a priest on December 1, 1989. During the height of the 1980s AIDS crisis in New York, Molly worked as a chaplain at Mount Sinai St. Luke's Hospital, New York, NY, and as an assistant to the rector at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields (from 1989 to 1996), providing funeral services to over 60 AIDS victims and their families. She became the associate priest at St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford, CT, from 1996 until her retirement in 2005, after which she moved to Pittsford, in 2009 to be closer to her grandchildren. Her sense of humor, opposition to injustice, and love of all God's creatures (especially her grandchildren and corgis) distinguished her clerical duties, and her prior career as an actress gave an added "elan" to her preaching. All who knew her will remember her with great love. She is survived by her three daughters, Pamela McGreevy of Pittsford, Jessica McGreevy of Norwalk, CT, and Barbara McGreevy of Shawnee Mission, KS, and her grandchildren, Natalie Newman and Alexander Newman of Pittsford. There will be a memorial service at St. Francis Episcopal Church, 2810 Long Ridge Road, Stamford, CT on Friday, December 4 at 2pm. If you wish, please make a contribution in Molly's memory to the ASPCA, St. Francis Episcopal Church, The Chapin School, and/or Vassar College. 1/3

BRAUMAN--Murray I.,died peacefully in the early morning November 5, 2015. He was 85 years old. Born in Brooklyn in 1929 to Mitchell Brauman and Jean Brauman (nee Steinberg), Murray grew up in Lakewood, New Jersey. He attended Rutgers University and graduated in 1951. Upon graduation he entered the US Army, and attended Officer Candidate School: Artillery in Fort Sill, Oklahoma, graduating in 1952. He served as a Lieutenant in Korea from 1952 to 1954. On returning to the US, he began what was to be a lifetime career in advertising, working first on Madison Avenue in Kudner Agency and D'Arcy Advertising, as a principal in Moss & Company and later Earl, Palmer, Brown. He was especially proud of the campaigns he and his team created for Brooklyn Union Gas and Gage & Tollner Restaurant. A Larchmont, NY resident from 1967 to 2014, Murray served on the Boards of the Brooklyn Bureau, Enterprise Works, and the Girl Scouts of Westchester. An avid golfer and traveler, Murray played into his eighties. Murray was a devoted father and grandfather and as a Mets fan, shared a love of baseball with his grandchildren, Rosie and Sam, both Yankees fans. Murray Brauman is survived by his devoted wife Vivienne Brauman, by his adoring daughters Amanda Brauman King and Leslie Brauman, by his grandchildren Rosemary Vasen and Sam Vasen, and by his dear sister Sandra Brauman and niece Jennifer Bennett. Donations in Murray's name may be made to The Girl Scouts of America. girlscouts.org/content/gsusa/ en/adults/donate.html/ 1/3

MIRANDA DUDZINSKI-- Mary. Beloved daughter of Maria and Saverio Esposito, deceased, of Brooklyn. Adored wife of Fedele Miranda, deceased, of Brooklyn and Thomas Dudzinski, deceased, of Camp Hill, PA. HILL--James I.,retired, President of Evelyn Hill Inc, Statue of Liberty, passed away on November 1, at age 89. He was born on Liberty Island, where his father Aaron Hill founded the concession in 1931. He joined his mother Evelyn Hill in operating the concession, retiring after 47 years. He attended DeWitt Clinton High School, Riverside Academy, and NYU. He proudly served during WWII in the United States Air Force as a gunner on a B-29. After a lengthy and courageous battle with lung cancer, he died peacefully, with his devoted wife, Racelle, by his side. Survived by four children, Bradford and Christopher Hill, Ted Halpern, and Susan Halpern, and many grandchildren. His first wife Joan predeceased him. "Gentleman Jim", best known for his gentle nature, good humor, generosity, and friendship. Many say they are better people for having known him. He will be missed. Donations may be made in Jim's honor to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10065. 1/3

MAXWELL--Brookie, artist and activist born October 15, 1956, died November 4, 2015. Daughter of William Maxwell, author and legendary editor of The New Yorker and Emily Noyes Maxwell. Loving mother of Ellis Dolin Maxwell and sister of Katharine Maxwell. At the time of her death, Ms. Maxwell was engaged in a multi-year public art project entitled Coming Home that attempts to heal the rift between America's civilian and military populations. Earlier in her career, Maxwell founded and directed Creative Arts Workshops, an arts-based NGO which helped change the lives of countless underprivileged youth. Her work is in numerous public and private collections. Donations to New York Foundation for the Arts earmarked for the Coming Home Project of B Maxwell. 1/3

GIGLIO--Richard, prominent American artist, born June 3, 1934 in New Rochelle, NY, died on September 17, 2015 in New York City. A memorial celebrating his extraordinary life and six decade commercial and fine art career will take place at 2:00pm on November 14, 2015 at the Fifteenth Street Quaker Meeting House, 15 Rutherford Place, NY, NY 10003. 1/3

MARVEL--Thomas S.,FAIA, was born in Newburgh, NY, on March 15, 1935 and passed away on November 3, 2015 in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He received a BA from Dartmouth College and an MArch from Harvard Graduate School of Design. He was awarded the Appleton Travelling Fellowship, enabling him to take a four month trip around the world. He worked at Synergetics, the office of R. Buckminster Fuller and at the IBEC Housing Corporation before moving to Puerto Rico in 1959. He established his first partnership in San Juan in 1960, and stayed active as an architect, planner and urban designer until his death. He authored three books and was a faculty member of the School of Architecture at the University of Puerto Rico. On the board of numerous civic and professional organizations at a regional and national level, Tom is survived by his beloved wife Lucilla, sons Deacon, Jonathan, Thomas, and seven grandchildren. 1/3

EPSTEIN--Roslyn, nee Moll, 87. Our beloved mother passed quietly in her sleep, with loved ones at her side, in the early hours of November 4th. Her two children, David and Andrea and four grandchildren survive her. She will be missed by all who knew her. A gathering will be held in her New York apartment on November 22, 1-4pm. 1/3

MARVEL--Thomas S.,FAIA. In loving memory of architect, planner, urban designer, sculptor, author, teacher, civic leader, world traveler Thomas S. Marvel, FAIA, who died in San Juan, Puerto Rico, his adopted home. His 56 year practice produced two United States Embassies, a Federal Courthouse, two City Halls, and dozens of academic, sacred, public spaces, and residences. Post earthquake, he initiated a collaborative effort of Caribbean urbanistes to plan for the reconstruction of Port au Prince. Tom inspired us to think big, to draw, to write, to be involved, and to have fun. From the team at Marvel Architects 1/3

DEMAIN--Gerald William. June 19, 1922-November 6, 2015. Jerry, 93, passed away peacefully at home on Friday, November 6, surrounded by his beshert, Lorrie and all his devoted children. He was born in Brooklyn and moved to Los Angeles in 1945, after serving in the US Army. In Los Angeles, he became President of Cantor Fitzgerald. 1/3

COUDERT--Jo, author of the widely read, Advice From A Failure, died peacefully at her home in Califon, NJ on Saturday, October 24th. Jo's fluent writing style and sensitivity to psychological issues made her in great demand as a nonfiction writer. One Reader's Digest article led to the book The Ditchdigger's Daughters which was made into a television movie. Jo's deep affection for animals led to the publication of many articles and books, including Seven Cats and The Art of Living.. Jo will be missed by her many friends and devoted readers, as well as by her sisters, Carolyn Coudert and Coralie Willett, and her nephew, Matthew Pordes. 1/3

GREEN--Dr. Howard. After a long illness, Dr. Howard Green passed away on October 31, 2015. Dr. Green was born September 10, 1925 in Toronto, Canada. He received his Doctorate in Medicine from the University of Toronto in 1947 and was to spend the rest of his life in medical research. After serving two years as a Captain in the United States Army, he began his career at New York University School of Medicine in 1956 and eventually rose to become Professor and Chairman of the Department of Cell Biology. From 1970 to 1980, he was a Professor of Cell Biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 1980, he became the George Higginson Professor of Cell Biology and Chairman of the Department Cell Biology at Harvard Medical School. He stepped down as Chairman in 1993, but continued on as Professor and actively ran his laboratory until 2013. Over the years, Dr. Green's work focused mainly on the properties of cells growing in tissue culture. In 1961, his laboratory created and established lines of fibroblast cells using viral oncogenes. Further development in his laboratory and in others led to the 3T3 cell lines, which became the basis for much work on cellular oncogenes. In 1974, using the same lines of 3T3 cells for support; his laboratory developed a system that allowed the cultivation of large numbers of human skin cells. Sheets of these cultured cells behaved as skin grafts when applied to open wounds. These grafts were first tested on small burn wounds in the Burn Unit at the Brigham and Women's Hospital starting in 1978 and they regenerated a functioning epidermis in these patients. This method of taking a tiny skin sample from a patient and using it to generate enough cultured grafts to cover large areas of the body with the patients own cells was used in children with large burns for the first time in 1983 at the Shriners' Burn Hospital in Boston. This work, in addition to being life saving, was the first use of stem cells as a successful treatment in patients. In order to cope with the demand for these grafts, Dr. Green founded BioSurface Technology. The company was acquired by the Genzyme Corporation, where production continues to the present day. In recognition of this pioneering work, Dr. Green received multiple honors including membership in the National Academy of Sciences (USA), the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the Institut de France (Academie des Sciences). He was the President of Scientific Council, Institut Curie, Paris, France from 1999 to 2007. He was awarded the Legion d'Honneur, Republic of France, and received honorary Doctorates from the University of Connecticut, the University of Goteborg, Sweden, the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and Louisiana State University. In addition, he received the following awards: the Blaise Pascal Medal for Biology and Life Sciences of the European Academy of Sciences, 2007; the Warren Alpert Foundation Prize, 2010; and the March of Dimes Prize in Developmental Biology, 2012. Dr. Green is survived by his wife of sixty-one years, Rosine Kauffmann Green, his brother Floyd, his niece Ingrid Fagen, and his nephew David, as well as an extended family in Canada, the United States, Australia, and France. 1/3

EHRET--Beverly Quinn, passed away peacefully on October 17, 2015. She was 86 years old and lived in White Plains, New York. Mrs. Ehret was born in Bogota, New Jersey, in 1929, to George and Dorothy Quinn. She studied piano and later graduated from The Julliard School of Music. In 1947, she married Walter Ehret, a well-known choral conductor and arranger of choral music. They were married for 63 years until his death in 2009. Music was a big part of her life. She taught piano at the Hoff- Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale for 50 years. She also enjoyed following current events, reading The New York Times everyday, and keeping up with politics. Mrs. Ehret is survived by her son, David Ehret and his wife, Pamela; her daughter, Christine Marver; and three grandchildren, Jeffrey, Julia and Sarah Marver. 1/3

COONEY--John P.,Jr., died peacefully of lung cancer at home at the age of 71 on November 2, 2015, surrounded by his family. The only son of John P. Cooney, Sr. and Katherine Rafferty Cooney, Jack, as he was known to one and all, was born on October 18, 1944 in Chicago, Illinois, graduated first from Fenwick High School in Oak Park, Illinois, then from college at Indiana University in Bloomington, and thereafter from the Duke University School of Law where he served as Note Editor of the Duke Law Journal. From 1972 to 1977 he was an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, where he became Chief of the Narcotics Unit. In 1977 he returned to the New York City law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell LLP from which he retired in 2008 after which he became a Principal at McKool Smith, P.C. Jack's time in private practice spanned a period of remarkable growth in the prosecution of white-collar crime, and Jack's career made him one of the pre- eminent white-collar practitioners of his day. He defended countless individuals and corporations in grand jury, regulatory and other governmental investigations, both in the United States and abroad. Because Jack's cases frequently resulted in the prosecution dropping charges or not proceeding with them, his success in these cases--from those involving insider trading and anti-trust violations to others under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act--were known perhaps more often by his grateful clients and his brethren at the Bar than by the newspapers. Although some of his clients were well-known, many others were not: these were clients Jack represented by appointment by the court under the Criminal Justice Act because they were unable to pay a lawyer to represent them. Not only did these clients get the same dogged, deft and passionate representation that Jack devoted to his other clients, they got the same outstanding results. Beyond this professional pre- eminence, Jack's life embraced an unalloyed joy and enthusiasm for his pursuits--outdoors in his beloved Tetons, shooting pheasant, rooting for the Duke Blue Devils, and being with his many dear friends in New York City, Rye, NY and Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Most of all, he cherished his time with the family he so loved and now leaves: his wife, Jane (Hewett); his sons John, Brian, Luke and Nathaniel, his daughters Anne and Emma, and his grandchildren Alexa and Patrick. Jack's sister, Judith Ann Cooney, predeceased him. All these family and friends will miss Jack's consuming interests in history, literature and poetry; his lectures on the fine points of college basketball and football and major league baseball; his disquisitions on the merits of this or that Super Tuscan; but most of all his brave and ready embrace of life with all its highs and lows and of love in its every manifestation. We who are left are left, indeed, to reflect that "we shall not look upon his like again." The family will receive visitors at home on Tuesday, November 10, 2015 from 4 to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on November 11, 2015 at 11:15am at The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, N.Y. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made in Jack's memory to the Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, 14th Floor, New York NY 10022 (innercityscholarshipfund.org) or to the Yellowstone Park Foundation, 222 E. Main St., #

McGREEVY--Molly Paine, died on Sunday, November 1, 2015, at her home in Pittsford, NY. Born on June 11, 1936, to Hugh Eustis Paine and Helen Duncan Paine, she graduated from The Chapin School and Vassar College, completing as her senior thesis a play based on her favorite childhood character, Mary Poppins. After college, Molly moved to Paris to study mime under Marcel Marceau. Returning to Manhattan, she met and married stockbroker Thomas James McGreevy and then moved to Kansas City, MO, where their three daughters were born. A free spirit with a wild sense of humor, she told her daughters that she brought the new dance "The Twist" to that reserved Midwestern town. Molly resumed her career as an actress in local theatre, in the movie "Shoot it Black, Shoot it Blue" (1974), and as Polly Longworth in the TV soap opera Ryan's Hope (between 1977 and 1981). She also produced the documentary "Nothing by Chance" (1975). She married actor Earl Hindman in 1976 and moved to Stamford, CT, where he continued his acting career in movies, theatre, and TV (playing Wilson, the "Hi-di- ho" neighbor in "Home Improvement" who was never seen except for his head looking over the fence). Changing course, Molly received her Master of Divinity from The General Theological Seminary in New York City in 1986. She was ordained a deacon in the Episcopal Church on June 10, 1989, and was ordained a priest on December 1, 1989. During the height of the 1980s AIDS crisis in New York, Molly worked as a chaplain at Mount Sinai St. Luke's Hospital, New York, NY, and as an assistant to the rector at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields (from 1989 to 1996), providing funeral services to over 60 AIDS victims and their families. She became the associate priest at St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford, CT, from 1996 until her retirement in 2005, after which she moved to Pittsford, in 2009 to be closer to her grandchildren. Her sense of humor, opposition to injustice, and love of all God's creatures (especially her grandchildren and corgis) distinguished her clerical duties, and her prior career as an actress gave an added "elan" to her preaching. All who knew her will remember her with great love. She is survived by her three daughters, Pamela McGreevy of Pittsford, Jessica McGreevy of Norwalk, CT, and Barbara McGreevy of Shawnee Mission, KS, and her grandchildren, Natalie Newman and Alexander Newman of Pittsford. There will be a memorial service at St. Francis Episcopal Church, 2810 Long Ridge Road, Stamford, CT on Friday, December 4 at 2pm. If you wish, please make a contribution in Molly's memory to the ASPCA, St. Francis Episcopal Church, The Chapin School, and/or Vassar College. 1/3

BRAUMAN--Murray I.,died peacefully in the early morning November 5, 2015. He was 85 years old. Born in Brooklyn in 1929 to Mitchell Brauman and Jean Brauman (nee Steinberg), Murray grew up in Lakewood, New Jersey. He attended Rutgers University and graduated in 1951. Upon graduation he entered the US Army, and attended Officer Candidate School: Artillery in Fort Sill, Oklahoma, graduating in 1952. He served as a Lieutenant in Korea from 1952 to 1954. On returning to the US, he began what was to be a lifetime career in advertising, working first on Madison Avenue in Kudner Agency and D'Arcy Advertising, as a principal in Moss & Company and later Earl, Palmer, Brown. He was especially proud of the campaigns he and his team created for Brooklyn Union Gas and Gage & Tollner Restaurant. A Larchmont, NY resident from 1967 to 2014, Murray served on the Boards of the Brooklyn Bureau, Enterprise Works, and the Girl Scouts of Westchester. An avid golfer and traveler, Murray played into his eighties. Murray was a devoted father and grandfather and as a Mets fan, shared a love of baseball with his grandchildren, Rosie and Sam, both Yankees fans. Murray Brauman is survived by his devoted wife Vivienne Brauman, by his adoring daughters Amanda Brauman King and Leslie Brauman, by his grandchildren Rosemary Vasen and Sam Vasen, and by his dear sister Sandra Brauman and niece Jennifer Bennett. DEVECCHI--Robert P.,who beginning in 1975 helped steer the International Refugee Committee into a leading global humanitarian organization as CEO and President, died on October 26, at his home in Southport, Connecticut, of natural causes. Born in New York City on October 6, 1930, DeVecchi graduated from Yale University in 1952, and received his MBA from Harvard University in 1956. DeVecchi joined the IRC in 1975 where, among his many accomplishments, he coordinated the Indochinese Refugee Resettlement Program, the largest such effort in U.S. history. In 1980, he became IRC Program Director, Executive Director in 1985, and President and CEO in 1993, a position he held until 1997, when he was elected President Emeritus. In 1997, DeVecchi was appointed Adjunct Senior Fellow for Refugees and the Displaced at the Council on Foreign Relations. In 2005, Yale University granted him an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters. His first marriage, to Florence Lincoln Sloan of New York, N.Y. and Greenwich, Connecticut, ended in divorce. His second wife, Betsy Stettinius Trippe, of New York and East Hampton, New York, died in 2009. In addition to friends and colleagues who loved and were inspired by Bob's humanity and leadership, he leaves behind two daughters, Margaret Lincoln DeVecchi of Northampton, Massachusetts and Angela DeVecchi of Watertown, Massachusetts; his stepchildren, William Douglass of Fort Lauderdale, Florida; William Duke of New York, NY; Terry Marsh of Bremen, Maine; and John Duke of Providence, Rhode Island; thirteen grandchildren; and a sister, Margaret Gabriel, of Washington, D.C. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 11am on December 4. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the International Rescue Committee. 1/3

PETRILLO--Madeline, died October 15, 2015 after two months at The Friendly Home on East Avenue in Rochester, NY. Predeceased by her parents, Carmela and Peter Petrillo, her sister, Jay (Jennie) and survived by her sisters, Mary Mykins, Anne Steinberger and Eileen Petrillo, and her brothers, Joseph Petrillo and James Petrillo, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Madeline was a graduate of the University of Rochester and Teachers College, Columbia University. She lived in New York City for over 60 years, returning to Rochester due to health concerns. Her innovations as a nurse and Mental Health Consultant in Pediatrics at New York Hospital and Memorial Sloan Kettering were highlighted in her book, "Emotional Care of Hospitalized Children, An Environmental Approach." She was renowned as a lecturer throughout the United States. Madeline valued books, reading, interior design, flowers, travel and talking politics. She loved giving parties and entertaining her numerous friends in NYC. She was a scholar and will be remembered for her pioneering work with children. Her legacy is maintained in the archives of the University of Pennsylvania, The Barbara Bates Center. Her wish was to be cremated and to have a bench in Central Park engraved with her name. GREENE--Barbara Isabelle, (nee Weise). Retired New York City public school principal, ardent reader and supporter of the arts, and devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend, died November 5, in Great Barrington, MA, of an intracerebral hemorrhagic stroke. Born in Brooklyn on May 31, 1930, she was married for 60 years to Martin Greene and together with him took loving care of their two daughters and four grandchildren. She managed to combine being feisty and outspoken with tenderness, great warmth, and a keen sense of humor. She graduated from New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn in 1947, from New York University with a BA, and from St. John's University with an advanced degree in school administration. An intellectual force and a master of the English language, Barbara had a long career in the city schools: as an English teacher sharing her love of language and literature and as a guidance counselor at Benjamin Franklin High School in Manhattan, encouraging many students to become the first person in their family to attend college and numerous others to pursue their dreams through higher education; as an assistant principal at Jane Addams High School in the Bronx; as a principal at William E. Grady, a vocational high school in Brooklyn; and then as the principal of Newtown High School in Elmhurst. In 1992, Barbara announced she was becoming "leisured for life." She retired to spend more time with her family and her beloved English literature, to travel, and to enjoy endless hours at her home in South Egremont, MA, in the Berkshires, reading The New York Times in her favorite sunny spot, on her deck next to an apple tree. In addition to her husband Martin, Barbara is survived by two of her sisters, Carol and Jacqueline; two daughters, Elizabeth and Alice; her son-in-law, Curtis Jones; and her four grandchildren: Sam and Ruby Jones and Isabella and Thomas Mungioli. Her memorial service will be held this Sunday, November 8, at noon at 220 Castle Hill Avenue, Great Barrington, MA. Donations in her honor may be made to Heifer International (855-948-6437), a charity she admired for its work in helping women in Africa to provide financial security for their families. 1/3

VAN PELT--David S.,74, of New York City, Vero Beach, FL, and Charlestown, RI passed away peacefully on October 25, 2015. He is survived by his wife, the love of his life, Betsy, and his children, Spencer and his wife, Veronica; Katie Stein and her husband, Nick; his three grandchildren, Lucy, Oliver and Charles; and his sister, Lin Hubeny and her husband, Jerry. David and Betsy would have celebrated their 46th wedding anniversary this month. David was born the son of Charles and Marion Van Pelt on May 31, 1941 and grew up in Tenafly, NJ. He graduated in 1963 with a BSBA from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and was awarded an MBA from New York University in 1971. David served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy from 1963 to 1967. He then joined Citibank N.A., where he worked for over thirty years as an international banker and a member of the Policy Committee. David retired from the bank in 1998 as an Executive Vice President. He subsequently served on the boards of several non-publicly traded companies, including as Chief Executive Officer of the European clearing house, Cedel. David served for over twenty years on the Board of the UNC Kenan-Flagler Business School. During this time he helped establish a global study program. David was the first recipient of the school's Global Leadership Award; and, in 2006, he endowed the Distinguished Professorship of Marketing Chair. David also gave his time to organizations in his communities, including serving on the Boards of East Harlem Tutorial Program and Prep for Prep, in New York City, and the Environmental Learning Center, in Vero Beach. He established the K.E.D.S Foundation, with a focus on improving educational opportunities, and was involved in the creation of a charter school, The East Harlem Scholars Academy. David had a life-long interest in the arts. Even these past few weeks he was enjoying the opera and philharmonic with his wife. He loved to travel, was fond of good food and wine, and was a voracious reader. He was a longtime fan of North Carolina basketball, the New York Giants and the New York Mets. He was a gentleman, a loving husband, father and grandfather. He was an inspiration and guide to many in his personal and professional life, and will be remembered as a man of intelligence, wisdom and integrity. A Memorial Visitation will be held on Friday, November 13th at 5pm with a Memorial Service to follow at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to East Harlem Tutorial Program, 2050 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10029. 1/3

PARNESS--Melvyn H. Bnai Zion mourns the loss of Executive Vice President Emeritus, Mel Parness. Mel has given over 50 years of service to Bnai Zion, establishing his first Bnai Zion chapter when he was a teenager. Mel joined the staff of Bnai Zion in 1964 and was elected its National Secretary in 1976. He was then elected to the position Executive Vice-President in June 1983 and retired in July 2006. Even after his retirement he continued to be a driving force within the organization and lent his expertise wherever it was needed. The Bnai Zion Foundation grew in both scope and fundraising capacity during Mel's tenure. Mel's efforts led to a greatly expanded profile of the organization and increased contributions to its projects. He was a dynamic speaker and had been active in many Jewish organizations, including the America-Israel Friendship League, Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, the American Zionist Movement, the American Red Magen David, the Israel Dance Institute, and Israel Bonds. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish National Fund. Mel exemplified what it means to be a dedicated Zionist, humanist and American Jew. The funeral will take place on Sunday, November 8th, at 12:30pm at Eden Memorial Chapels, 327 Main Street Ft Lee, NJ 07024. Our hearts go out to his wife Arlyne, their children, Bari and Alan Shaffran, and Caryn and Keith Evans, and their grandchildren, Lizzie, Jonathan, Emerson, Andrew and Brady, and may his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. George W. Schaeffer, Chairman of the Board David H. Eisenberg, National President Cheryl Bier, COO 1/3

SOCHA--Wladyslaw Wojciech, MD, PhD, died September 23, 2015 at his home in Nyack, NY. Born on June 03, 1926 in Paris France, he graduated from the Medical Academy in Cracow, Poland. He was Research Professor of Forensic Medicine, Director and Head of the Department of Pathology and Human Genetics in the Institute of Pediatrics (founded and formerly known as the American Research Hospital in Poland) in the Medical Academy in Cracow, Poland. Since 1969 in the USA, he was Research Professor of Forensic Medicine, Director of Primate Blood Group Reference Laboratory for Experimental Medicine and Surgery in Primates (LEMSIP) of New York University School of Medicine. Associate Director of WHO Collaborating Center of Haematology of Primates. He authored five books and numerous publications related to human blood serology, forensic pathology, transplantation immunology and molecular biology. He was buried in his ancestors' tomb in the cemetery of St. Salvator in Cracow, Poland. He is survived by his grieving wife, Adelia Catherine, his brother, Andrei and nephew, Martin. 1/3

EWING--Sheila Cobb. Poet, actress, and lover of literature and the arts, died Tuesday, November 3, in Winston-Salem, NC, of multiple myeloma. Born in New York on April 1, 1939, she was married for 45 years to her beloved husband Alex C. Ewing, following the death of her first husband Michael deShee Clarke. She graduated from Vassar College in 1961, and earned masters degrees from Columbia University and Sarah Lawrence. With a firm and loving hand, she raised four children, daughter Cecilia Clarke and stepchildren Sandy, Eric and Caroline Ewing, in Millbrook, NY, where she lived from 1970 to 1990. When Alex's appointment as Chancellor of the North Carolina School of the Arts unexpectedly brought them to Winston-Salem, she embraced with gusto her new role as First Lady of NCSA. In addition, she performed in plays, wrote book reviews and travel articles, volunteered at a hospital, sang in the St. Paul's Church choir, maintained a beautiful flower garden, and played tennis and a matchless game of Scrabble. A lifelong lover of Ireland, she and Alex returned frequently to their home-away-from-home in County Cork. She lived her life with verve, style, unflagging humor and impeccable taste, and brought forth beauty from whatever she touched. She was the best friend not only of her husband but also of an astonishing number of others. She saw people deeply, and in their most critical moments reached them with her unerring insight, often expressed in long-treasured letters. In everything she did, she set very high standards for herself and always met them. In addition to her husband Alex and her four children, she is survived by her brother John Whitehouse Cobb of Denver, Colorado, her sister Victoria Mackintosh of Alresford, Hampshire, England, and eight grandchildren: Allegra Eifler, Josephine and Simon Born, Alden and Caleb Ewing, and Nathan, Seth and Henry Ewing-Crystal. The funeral will be Monday, November 9, at 11am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Winston-Salem. Contributions may be made in Sheila's memory to the Sheila Cobb Scholarship at the North Carolina School of the Arts. 1/3

GOLLAY--Jean, on November 4 at the age of 97. Jean was born in New York City, graduated from Barnard College, and worked as a magazine journalist and as author of numerous books of nonfiction and fiction written under the name Jean Libman Block. During her long career she served as articles editor for Good Housekeeping and as a writer for Revlon. She was the first woman president of the Society of Magazine Writers, now the American Society of Journalists and Authors. With her second husband, Ben Gollay, she became a collector of art that will be donated to the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, FL. Her survivors include her daughter, Elizabeth J. Block, her son, Fred L. Block (Carole), her stepdaughter, Elinor Gollay (Rex), and two grand- daughters, Miriam and Jude Joffe-Block. 1/3
PETTUS--Susan Fouke. November 8, 2013. Rene has now come to join you, and we delight in the knowledge that you both are whole again and once more walking the beach with Maggie. Your Loving Family 1/3

STERN--Gloria, 88. Gloria was the source of extraordinary joy and light to those who were close to her. She was a true artist, who saw beauty in ordinary things, gave expression to them, and shared her works with those she loved and the world. She was a magnificent cook and kept her family in constant delight with her cakes, meringues, and other creations. She was gentle, compassionate, curious and a lot of fun. She was a beautiful person inside and out. She grew up and raised a family in South Africa. After losing the love of her life, her husband, Leonard Stern, to whom she was married for 44 years, she moved to the United States and courageously built a life for herself, surrounded by her growing family and new friends. She loved music, literature, swimming and the beach; she loved and found great cheer in animals; she loved to laugh and was great at it; she loved a warm, deep hug - and excelled at providing them. Above all else, she loved her family - who loved her deeply, were blessed to have her grace their lives, and who now have the privilege of carrying on her rich legacy. She is remembered with adoration by her daughter, Janine, and her husband, Alan and late husband Darryl, and her son, Colin and his wife Felicia; by her grandchildren Craig, Jeannie, Gary, Sharie, Amanda, Zac, Greg, Caitlin, Max, Mary and Sara; by her great grandchildren Sasha, Lila, Clara, Natalie, Connor, Josh, Julia, Charlie, Claire and Tyler; by her beloved Grant, Shelley, Doug, Andrea, and Kimmie; by her pals Buster and Daisy; and, by very special friends and care-takers Suzette Morgado, Kim Acosta, May Yang, Kaye Nicole Acosta, Emma Labor, Florence Enduma and Gabriela Dzurbanova. The family will hold private funeral services. 1/3

Every year since 1952, the Book Review has convened an independent panel of judges to select the New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books. Judged purely on artistic merit, it’s the only annual award of its kind. On these pages, you will find an image from each of the 10 winners for 2015. 
 
This year’s judges were Frank Viva, Monica Edinger and Marjorie Ingall. Viva has written and illustrated several acclaimed books for children, including “Along a Long Road” — a previous Times Best Illustrated winner — “Outstanding in the Rain” and “Young Frank, Architect.” He is a frequent cover artist for The New Yorker and the managing director of the design firm Viva & Co. Edinger has been an elementary- and middle-school educator for more than 25 years and currently teaches fourth grade at the Dalton School in New York City. She is also the author of the picture book “Africa Is My Home” and blogs about children’s books at Educating Alice. Ingall is a columnist for Tablet and a frequent contributor of children’s book reviews to The Times and other publications. Her book “Mamaleh Knows Best: What Jewish Mothers Do to Raise Successful, Creative, Empathetic, Independent Children” will be published next year. Tricky Vic: The Impossibly True Story of

LEONARD--Michael "Mickey", 84, died at home on October 31. Mickey was a gifted composer and arranger, who wrote for Broadway, film and television. His songs, including I'm All Smiles, Why Did I Choose You and Not Exactly Paris, were performed by numerous artists, including Barbra Streisand and Nancy Sinatra. He was the musical supervisor on the original Broadway production of Grease, and arranged for jazz pianist, Bill Evans. Mickey is survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Maury and Betty, their children, Bradley, Neal and Alison, and seven grandnieces and nephews. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 8 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in his honor at the charity of your choice. 1/3

KLEIN--Seymour (Steven) E.,born January 24, 1925 passed away peacefully in his sleep November 5, 2015. He was a devoted husband for 61 years to Felice Klein who predeceased him in March. A loving father to Lisa (Howard, deceased) and Michael, beloved brother of Burt and Joan, Bernie and Phyllis. His grandchildren, Melanie (Lucie), Owen, Gabrie and Zachary were his constant joy in life. Steve was a decorated war hero who fought in WWII. A self-made man who built his insurance firm from the ground up. His passion for politics lead him to be a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. His compassion and generosity made him a role model to all that knew him. Funeral services to be held Tuesday, November 10, at 10am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck. Donations may be made in his memory to the Port Washington Library Foundation. 1/3

She believed in family, honesty, and integrity and supported her associates, friends, and family with laughter and a smile. She leaves behind her husband, Brad, of 36 years; her children, Alana and Jake; and brother, Mark Rosner, along with thousands of friends she was able to love. "Ale iz gut." 1/3

HEYMAN--Annette Silverman, 102. Beloved wife of the late Lazarus Heyman (z"l), treasured mother of Samuel Heyman (z"l) and Abigail Heyman Bloch (z"l), adored mother-in-law of Ronnie Feuerstein Heyman. Grandmother of Lazarus Heyman (Kim), Eleanor Heyman Propp, Jennifer Millstone (David), Elizabeth Heyman Winter and Lazar Bloch. Proud great-grandmother of 11: Si, Sheldon, and Solomon Heyman; Stella, Juliette and Clara Propp; Pippa, Francie, Samuelle and Marielle Millstone; and Charlie Winter. Private services will be held in Danbury, CT. A dear soul, blessed with unique grace and compassion. LEE--Charles Carroll, Jr.,86, of Spring Island, South Carolina and Prouts Neck, Maine, died peacefully on November 5, 2015 surrounded by his children at the family home in Maine. Charlie was born to Eleanor Hurd and Charles C. Lee in New York City on July 11, 1929. His beloved wife of 59 years, Sally White Lee, died in April of 2014. Charlie is lovingly remembered by his four children and their spouses: Sally L. Swift (and Edward) of Carlisle, MA; Diana L. Hammond (and Peter) of Perth, Australia; Lucy L. LaCasse (and William) of Scarborough, ME; and Charles C. Lee, III (and Eliza) of Philadelphia, PA. He is also survived by 11 grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, his sister Mary L. Lambert of New York City, and many much loved nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sisters Eleanor L. Congdon and Cynthia L. Russell, and his brother Thomas S. Lee. Charlie attended St. Bernard's School in New York City, Middlesex School in Concord, MA, and graduated from Yale University in 1950. After college, he enlisted in the Marine Corps and served as a captain in Korea. Upon returning, Charlie worked briefly for Bates Manufacturing before joining White Weld & Co. in 1955, from which he retired as Vice Chairman upon the sale of the firm in 1978. Following his retirement, Charlie was involved in several business ventures, both in banking and corporate philanthropy. However, the majority of his time was devoted to service on a variety of school boards, community organizations and numerous affiliations with the Episcopal Church. Charlie served as the Head of the Board of Trustees at Middlesex School and Far Hills Country Day School; Head of the Vestry of St. John's on the Mountain in Bernardsville, NJ; Senior Warden at Trinity Church in New York City; and as a Trustee of General Theological Seminary in New York City, from which he received an honorary Doctorate degree in 2001. Charlie and Sally raised their four children in Far Hills, New Jersey and moved to Spring Island, South Carolina in 1998. He and Sally traveled extensively, visiting over 50 countries, exploring the natural and cultural wonders of the world. Charlie will be fondly remembered for his devotion to his wife Sally, his love of extended family, his wisdom and his wry sense of humor. He enjoyed golf with family and friends (where he showed occasional flashes of brilliance), Sunday night picnics and cribbage games with his grandchildren. All who knew Charlie will remember his quiet counsel and compassion that he imparted with humility and grace. A memorial service for Charles C Lee will be held on November 18th at 1:30pm at Trinity Church, 75 Broadway, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to St. James Church, 499 Black Point Rd, Scarborough, ME 04074 or to the Spring Island Trust Foundation, 40 Mobley Oaks Lane, Okatie, SC 29909. Services are being handled by Hobbs Funeral Home, 230 Cottage Road, Scarborough, ME. 1/3

BOEGEHOLD--Alan Lindley (1927-2015) was born March 21, 1927 in Detroit, Michigan. He received his A.B. from the University of Michigan in 1950, and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in Classical Philology from Harvard University in 1954 and 1958. He first taught as Instructor in Classics at the University of Illinois at Urbana in 1957, followed in 1960 by 41 years at Brown University in the Department of Classics where he served intermittently as Chairman and Director of Ancient Studies. His career at Brown was punctuated by visiting professorships at Harvard, Yale, and Berkeley. After his retirement he was Visiting Professor at Amherst College for two years, and Florida State University for one semester. He had a life-long relationship with the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, Greece, as director for numerous summer sessions, as a Research Fellow at the Agora Excavations, as Mellon Professor, Chairman of the Managing Committee, and a trustee of the American School and the Gennadius Library. In addition to his numerous scholarly publications, Alan took great pleasure in writing and reading poetry, producing three volumes of original work and translating the poems of Constantine Cavafy. He was an avid tennis and squash player, and knowledgeable amateur mycologist. Alan is survived by Julie, his wife of 61 years, sister Barbara, brother David, sons David and Alan, daughters Lindley and Alison, and eight grandchildren. Visit www.waring- sullivan.com for tributes 1

TRAINOR--Patricia H. Patricia H. Trainor, a longtime resident of Greenwich Village in New York City, died peacefully at her home on Sunday, November 1. Patricia was a rebel who refused to walk down the paths allotted to women in the late 1950s. Instead of teaching in the suburbs after graduating from the College of New Rochelle, she taught school in Cuba during the first year of the Castro regime. And while some toiled as secretaries in Manhattan, she did so in Zurich, where she socialized after work in four languages and traveled widely. Returning to New York City, she searched the Help Wanted-Male ads in The New York Times and was hired by Sinclair Oil as a computer programmer trainee, an almost entirely male profession at the time. While with Sinclair, she rose to become the manager of systems programming. Ironically, as one of the founders of the New York City chapter of the National Organization for Women in 1966, Patricia was instrumental in abolishing the practice of segregating help wanted ads by sex. She also chaired NOW's Image of Women committee, which campaigned to change the stereotyped image and denigration of women in mass media. Inspired by the leak of the Pentagon Papers in 1971, Patricia enrolled at New York University School of Law and received her LL.M. During that time she organized her neighbors in their tenement building, who were facing threat of eviction from a developer. Under her leadership, they were able to buy the building and eventually refurbish it into a charming residence. It was one of the first buildings in the West Village to go co-op. In 1995 she represented the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing, and she continued to practice contract law until her retirement in 1996. A world traveler and patron of the arts, she loved attending the theater and concerts with friends, believing it was art that would save the world, not politics. Patricia recently said, "I have done everything I have ever wanted to do; I have gone everywhere I have ever wanted to go." Predeceased by her young brother, John, and her parents, Helen and Charles Trainor, Patricia is survived by her brother, Thomas, of Yonkers, NY, her sister, Marilyn Wellisch, of Long Beach, NY, and other loving family members. Her family and many friends, including her fictive grandson, Cameron Gomez, will greatly miss her laughter, generosity, lively wit and sharp intellect. 1/3

COONEY--John P.,Jr. The Robert B. Fiske Jr. Association mourns the passing of its esteemed and beloved member and colleague John P. Cooney, Jr. on Monday, November 2, 2015 at the age of 71. Jack, as he was known, was an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York from 1972 to 1977 and was Chief of the Narcotics Unit during 1976-77. A signal highlight of his trial career, among many such, was the conviction of Vincent Papa, a mob kingpin of the narcotics trade in New York. Papa was arrested in The Bronx with a million dollars in cash in the trunk of his car, which Jack introduced into evidence against him thus sealing his fate at trial. After his career as a federal prosecutor Jack earned an unrivalled reputation as a lion of the bar representing individuals and corporations in an ever-widening spectrum of white-collar criminal cases and defending indigent defendants under the Criminal Justice Act with superb talent, real grit and utter determination. A Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, Jack was a partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell for 30 years before his retirement in 2008 when he joined McKool Smith, PC as a Principal. His wit, his enthusiasm and his charm will be missed both by his colleagues in the Association and by those on the bench and at the bar more generally. Our sympathy and condolences are extended to his wife Jane and his children and grandchildren. 1/3
BIER--Bernard H. Esq. My Beautiful Father, Missing you everyday. All my love, Jody 1/3

McCARTHY--Richard F.X.,a former special agent for the FBI, passed away on Saturday, November 7th at his home. He was born in Manhattan on September 4, 1927. He graduated from Niagara University and served in the U.S. Army and the U.S. Marine Corps. Richard joined the FBI in 1952 and served for 28 years in Savannah, Detroit and New York. He worked on major cases involving Russian counterintelligence and received many Letters of Commendation and Awards. From 1980-1993, Richard worked as Director of Security at Allied Maintenance, Ogden Allied and Ogden Corporation. Richard was a beloved husband and father. He is predeceased by his wife, Catherine T. McCarthy, and his son, Henry Mark. He is survived by his children: Mary Catherine, Rosemary, Richard, John, Madeleine, Nadine and Nicholas, and his eleven grandchildren. Visitation, Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Krtil Funeral Home, Inc., 1297 1st Avenue (between 69th and 70th St.). Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 10am, St. John the Evangelist Church on the corner of 55th St. and First Ave., NYC. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

BAILEY--Madeleine, "Happie" to all, passed away peacefully on October 30, 2015. One of seven children of the late John S. and Estelle M. Reilly, she is survived by her husband William P.D. Bailey, her son William P.R. Bailey and numerous nieces and nephews. Happie served on the board of trustees of St Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center for many years. She also was Eucharistic Minister and Lector with St. Joseph's Church as well as involved in multiple charity and volunteer capacities in the community. Loved by all who knew her, she was a compassionate and giving person who dedicated her life to the service and happiness of others. Family will receive visitors Friday, November 13 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, located at 1076 Madison Avenue. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at St. Joseph's Church of Yorkville, November 14 at 10am, located at 404 East 87th Street. Gifts in her memory may be made to St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th Street, New York, NY 10128. 1/3

KLEIN--Marilyn. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home at Riverdale by RiverSpringHealth mourn the passing of Marilyn Klein. Marilyn's resounding voice in the community and deep devotion to her family were an inspiration to all who knew her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Klein family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Jeffrey Maurer, Chairman, Board of Trustees Daniel Reingold, President and CEO RiverSpring Health 1/3

HOROWITZ--Richard. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of former principal timpanist Richard "Dick" Horowitz, the longest-serving orchestra member in the company's history. Horowitz joined the orchestra at the beginning of the Met's 1946-47 season, and served continuously until his retirement in 2012 at the age of 88--a total of 66 years at the Met. We extend our condolences to his family and friends, and to the thousands of artists, musicians, and backstage personnel who he worked with during his unprecedented Met career. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

COONEY--John P.,Jr. The Shakespeare Society mourns the loss of Jack Cooney, distinguished attorney, valued friend, and beloved husband of our Board Member Jane Cooney. Our thoughts and prayers are with Jane and their three beautiful children, Luke, Nathaniel, and Emma. "His life was gentle, and the elements/ So mixed in him that Nature might stand up/ And say to all the world, "This was a man." "Julius Caesar" V, v 1/3

HASSON--Dr. Robert, passed away on October 13 2015 in Laguna Niguel, CA. He is survived by his wife, Rachel Hasson, four children, three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial for the family will take place in South Carolina. A later memorial and burial at sea will take place in California. Date and details will follow. 1/3

HALEVY--Uzi. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Uzi Halevy of Houston. The Technion alumnus was a member of the ATS National Board of Directors, and the Technion Board of Governors. He was also a devoted and active leader of the ATS Houston Chapter, and was honored with a Technion Honorary Fellowship in 2014. Together with his beloved wife Micki, Mr. Halevy was a Technion Guardian, a distinction reserved for those who have reached the highest level of support. Among the projects they supported were the Uzi & Michal Halevy Fund for Innovative Applied Engineering Research and vital student support including scholarships, fellowships and dormitories. We extend our deepest condolences to Micki, and the entire family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Zahava Bar-Nir, President Scott Leemaster, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3
STEINBERG--Harold. November 10, 2011. My beloved husband. Always in my heart. Eternal Love, Monette 1/3

ROTHOLZ--William (Vevy), August 16, 1923 - November 7, 2015. Beloved husband of Rina nee Chelouche, loving father of David Rotholz (Kathy Paddor-Rotholz), Ruth van Eck-Rotholz (the late Torild van Eck), and Susan Rotholz (Eliot Bailen), cherished grandfather of Zachary Paddor-Rotholz, Miriam and Rachel van Eck, Daniel, David Eli and Julia Bailen. Services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels at 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York on Tuesday, November 10 at 1:45pm. 1/3
