Cardozo School of Law mourn the passing of Annette Heyman, mother-in-law of Ronnie Heyman, who served with distinction as a trustee of Yeshiva University and a director of Cardozo, and continues as an honorary member of Cardozo's Board of Overseers. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ronnie; her grandchildren, Lazarus (Kim), Eleanor, Jennifer (David), Elizabeth and Lazar; and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

SHERMAN--Norton. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Norton Sherman of Newton, MA. Together with his beloved wife, Claire, he was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. Among their many gifts to the Technion is the George and Beatrice Sherman Center for Education in Technology and Science. Mr. Sherman was a Life Trustee of the ATS National Board of Regents, formerly served on the organization's National Board of Directors, and for many years was a leader of the ATS New England Region. He was an Honorary Life Member of the Technion Board of Governors, and was awarded a Technion Honorary Fellowship in 1996. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Claire, children Amy, Steven and Brian, and to the entire Sherman family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Zahava Bar-Nir, President Scott Leemaster, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

FALES--Haliburton, 2nd New York University Libraries mourns the death of Haliburton Fales, 2nd, supporter of the Fales Library, founded by his father at NYU in 1957. Hal's stewardship, wise counsel, and immensely gracious presence will be sorely missed. Our thoughts are with his family. 1/3

MARUFFI--Dr. Brian L.,on November 5, 2015. Beloved husband of Lorraine, loving father of Trevor, beloved brother of Karen Power, revered teacher and mentor to his students. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in New York City. Funeral Mass, Thursday, 10:00am, St. Ignatius Loyola. 1/3
SKARIMBAS--Elias. You and I made memories that light the sky, that only time can make, that only love can make, you and I. Unavoidably Yours 1/3

COHEN--Lewis D.,a noted and highly respected attorney, has died at the age of 88 at his home in Kings Point, New York. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Mr. Cohen was a celebrated criminal defense attorney for over 40 years, having tried an estimated 200 cases to verdict. Mr. Cohen volunteered to join the Navy during WWII, and graduated from Syracuse University in 1949 with an A.B degree. He earned his law degree from Fordham Law School in 1952. Mr. Cohen was an Assistant District Attorney in the Grand Jury and Homicide Bureaus. After leaving the D.A.'s Office, Mr. Cohen began a private law practice, and was recognized as one of the finest defense attorneys in New York State. He was awarded the Kings County Criminal Bar Association's Lifetime Achievement Award in 2001. He was an avid fan of Syracuse University and the University of Virginia sports. Mr. Cohen leaves behind his beloved wife of 49 years, Maralin Cohen; his children, Douglas and Carin, daughter-in-law, Melissa, son-in-law, Terry; and his dear grandchildren, Chloe, Carly, Alexis, and Alana. Services and burial will be on Thursday, November 12th at 11:00am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck: 516-487-9600. 1/3

LAMPERT--Stanley, at age 86, on November 8. Much loved husband of Roslyn, father of Charles (Robin), Shari, Michael (Nancy), Jonathan (Debbie), and grandfather to Jamie, Randy, Iain, Rachel and Jenna. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he attended Lincoln High School, where he was an all-city basketball player. He then attended NYU where he played basketball, threw the discus and was an all-American in the shot put. He competed for the United States in the Maccabiah games, where he was a double gold medal winner in the shot put and the discus and, in 1954, went on to set a world record in the shot put. After his athletic career, he went on to equal success in the business world, becoming one of the leading life insurance and financial planning practitioners in the industry. He was a successful businessman, lover of opera and the arts, an avid golfer and gardener. The family will be sitting Shiva on Wednesday, November 11, and Thursday November 12 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at home. Gifts in his memory may be made to The Association for the Visually Impaired in Spring Valley, NY or The Metropolitan Opera Guild. 1/3

LEWIS--Stephen, 67, of East Hampton, NY on November 8, 2015. Son of the late Dr. Sydney and Beatrice Lewis, husband of the late Elizabeth; he is survived by a sister and brother-in-law, Joan Lewis and Howard Jaeckel, and two nieces, Shoshana and Franny Goldberg. Private funeral services and burial will be held in Ewing, NJ. For information: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400. 1/3
WOLNER--Rena, on November 7, 2015. Devoted sister, beloved friend, brilliant publisher. You will be missed. Jane Dystel, Jessica Toonkel, Steven and Zachary Schwinder 1/3

HERTER--Frederic Pratt, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 7 at the age of 94. Herter joined the American University of Beirut as a trustee in 1977. He served as Chairman of the Board of trustees from 1985 to 1987, and President of the University from 1987 to 1993. Through the challenging times of the civil war, he fought to keep the University's doors open and its students safe, even while Americans were barred from travelling to Lebanon. From the President's office in New York City, he fostered a vision of AUB as a world class university and medical center, and a beacon of moderation and understanding in the Middle East. A highly respected surgeon and teacher, Herter received his undergraduate degree from Harvard College, his M.D. from Harvard Medical School, and did post-graduate training in surgery at the Presbyterian Hospital, where he faithfully spent his medical career for nearly half a century. He was a pioneering surgeon and role model to generations of medical students, residents and faculty members while serving as the Auchincloss Professor of Surgery at Columbia University; Acting Chairman of Department of Surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, Acting Director of Surgery at Presbyterian Hospital, Director of Surgery at Francis Delafield Hospital; a trustee of Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital, Jackson Laboratories, and American Near East Refugee Aid; a regent of Cathedral of St. John the Divine, New York; a member of the board of governors of the Middle East Institute, Washington; a member of the board of advisers of the Hariri Foundation USA; and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. The scion of a distinguished New York family, Herter embodied the best qualities of leadership: inquisitiveness, determination, sensitivity, sense of purpose, and compassion. His legacy is a resolute belief in the ability of individuals and societies to work together for the benefit of humankind, which elevated everyone in his presence, and left the world a better place. He is survived by his beloved wife, Solange; sister, Adele Seronde; son, Eric; daughters, Caroline and Brooke; stepson, Marc; stepdaughters, Mary, Veronique and Jacqueline; and many grandchildren. Philip S. Khoury, PhD, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Fadlo R. Khuri, M.D., President, American University of Beirut, Beirut, Lebanon 1/3

HERTER--Frederic Pratt, died peacefully at home in New York City, surrounded by family, on November 7. He was the son of Mary Caroline Pratt Herter and Christian A. Herter, Governor of Massachusetts, and subsequently, Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Solange Batsell Herter; his sister, Adele Seronde; his son, Eric Herter; his daughters, Caroline Herter and Brooke James; his son-in-law; David James; four stepchildren, four grandchildren and eleven step-grandchildren. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, Harvard University and Harvard Medical School. He went to Japan with the Occupation Forces as First Lieutenant in the Army Medical Corps. He was the Auchincloss Professor of Surgery, the Acting Chairman of the Department of Surgery, and later Professor Emeritus at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, where he served for forty years. He was a member of the John Jones Surgical Society. He served as director of surgery at the Francis Delafield Hospital in New York, consultant at the Harlem and Goldwater Memorial Hospitals, and consultant at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. After his tenure at Columbia, he was appointed President of the American University of Beirut, where he served for eight years, during the troubled times of the Syrian Civil War. He continued his dedicated involvement as trustee Emeritus in later years. He shared a trusteeship with his wife, Solange, at the Cathedral of St. John The Divine in New York City, was trustee of the Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY, and a trustee of the Jackson Laboratories in Maine. Doctor Herter was the author of an autobiography "May I Cut In" and co-author with his colleague and friend, Doctor Alfred Jaretzki, of "A Proud Heritage, An Informal History of Surgery at Columbia." A giant in so many ways, he was the warmest, kindest, most thoughtful person. With never a nasty word for anybody, his honorability was always at the core of everything. May his beautiful soul rest in peace. Services will be held on Friday, November 13th at 11am at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City. 1/3

HERTER--Frederic Pratt, died peacefully at home in New York City, surrounded by family, on November 7. He was the son of Mary Caroline Pratt Herter and Christian A. Herter, Governor of Massachusetts, and subsequently, Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower. He is survived by his wife of forty years, Solange Batsell Herter; his sister, Adele Seronde; his son, Eric Herter; his daughters, Caroline Herter and Brooke James; his son-in-law; David James; four stepchildren, four grandchildren and eleven step-grandchildren. He attended St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, Harvard University and Harvard Medical School. He went to Japan with the Occupation Forces as First Lieutenant in the Army Medical Corps. He was the Auchincloss Professor of Surgery, the Acting Chairman of the Department of Surgery, and later Professor Emeritus at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, where he served for forty years. He was a member of the John Jones Surgical Society. He served as director of surgery at the Francis Delafield Hospital in New York, consultant at the Harlem and Goldwater Memorial Hospitals, and consultant at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. After his tenure at Columbia, he was appointed President of the American University of Beirut, where he served for eight years, during the troubled times of the Lebanese Civil War. He continued his dedicated involvement as trustee Emeritus in later years. He shared a trusteeship with his wife, Solange, at the Cathedral of St. John The Divine in New York City, was trustee of the Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, NY, and a trustee of the Jackson Laboratories in Maine. Doctor Herter was the author of an autobiography "May I Cut In" and co-author with his colleague and friend, Doctor Alfred Jaretzki, of "A Proud Heritage, An Informal History of Surgery at Columbia." A giant in so many ways, he was the warmest, kindest, most thoughtful person. With never a nasty word for anybody, his honorability was always at the core of everything. May his beautiful soul rest in peace. Services will be held on Friday, November 13th at 11am at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York City. 1/3

MARCUS--Kenneth Richard. Mustachioed husband, father, and grandfather died November 9, 2015, two days after his 84th birthday. Big-hearted, quick-witted, hard working, eccentric--Kenny was passionate for his family, golf, bridge, and food. Kenny was born November 7, 1931 in the Bronx and graduated from Brooklyn Law School. After serving in the US Army during the Korean War, he met and married his wife, Irma, and settled in Great Neck, NY to raise a family and start a law firm, McDonough Marcus Cohn, et al. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Irma; his children, Stephanie Goodwin (Mark), Brian (Maria), Jono (Krista), and Allison Moreida (Harris); eight grandchildren; his sister, Seena Goldner; and brother-in-law, Barry Rahinsky. 1/3

HERTER--Frederic Pratt, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 7 at the age of 94. Herter joined the American University of Beirut as a trustee in 1977. He served as Chairman of the Board of trustees from 1985 to 1987, and President of the University from 1987 to 1993. Through the challenging times of the civil war, he fought to keep the University's doors open and its students safe, even while Americans were barred from travelling to Lebanon. From the President's office in New York City, he fostered a vision of AUB as a world class university and medical center, and a beacon of moderation and understanding in the Middle East. A highly respected surgeon and teacher, Herter received his undergraduate degree from Harvard College, his M.D. from Harvard Medical School, and did post-graduate training in surgery at the Presbyterian Hospital, where he faithfully spent his medical career for nearly half a century. He was a pioneering surgeon and role model to generations of medical students, residents and faculty members while serving as the Auchincloss Professor of Surgery at Columbia University; Acting Chairman of Department of Surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, Acting Director of Surgery at Presbyterian Hospital, Director of Surgery at Francis Delafield Hospital; a trustee of Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital, Jackson Laboratories, and American Near East Refugee Aid; a regent of Cathedral of St. John the Divine, New York; a member of the board of governors of the Middle East Institute, Washington; a member of the board of advisers of the Hariri Foundation USA; and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. The scion of a distinguished New York family, Herter embodied the best qualities of leadership: inquisitiveness, determination, sensitivity, sense of purpose, and compassion. His legacy is a resolute belief in the ability of individuals and societies to work together for the benefit of humankind, which elevated everyone in his presence, and left the world a better place. He is survived by his beloved wife, Solange; sister, Adele Seronde; son, Eric; daughters, Caroline and Brooke; stepson, Marc; stepdaughters, Mary, Veronique and Jacqueline; and many grandchildren. Philip S. Khoury, PhD, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Fadlo R. Khuri, M.D., President, American University of Beirut, Beirut, Lebanon 1/3

MARCUS--Kenneth R. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Kenneth R. Marcus, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Irma, and their family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Barry Swidler, President for the Board of Governors 1/3

UHRY--Gustave Lewis, of Rye Brook, NY passed away on November 9, 2015. He was 83. Gustave was born in NYC to the late Henry and Selma Uhry. He was a graduate of Syracuse University and went on to become a Senior Partner/ Primary owner of Marshall Granger & Co in Mamaroneck, NY. He was an active congregant of the Community Synagogue of Rye, where he served as president. Beloved husband of the late Judith (Rascovar) Uhry, devoted father of Lynn Huba (husband Walter) and Dr. David Uhry (wife Renee), cherished grandfather of seven and great grandfather of one. A Funeral Service will be held 10am Thursday at Community Synagogue of Rye followed by interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. Donations may be made in Gustave's memory to the Capital Campaign of Rye Community Synagogue. For more information or to place an online condolence; www.zionchapel.com 1/3

BOEGEHOLD--Alan Lindley (1927-2015) was born March 21, 1927 in Detroit, Michigan. He received his A.B. from the University of Michigan in 1950, and his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees in Classical Philology from Harvard University in 1954 and 1958. He first taught as Instructor in Classics at the University of Illinois at Urbana in 1957, followed in 1960 by 41 years at Brown University in the Department of Classics where he served intermittently as Chairman and Director of Ancient Studies. His career at Brown was punctuated by visiting professorships at Harvard, Yale, and Berkeley. After his retirement he was Visiting Professor at Amherst College for two years, and Florida State University for one semester. He had a life-long relationship with the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, Greece, as director for numerous summer sessions, as a Research Fellow at the Agora Excavations, as Mellon Professor, Chairman of the Managing Committee, and a trustee of the American School and the Gennadius Library. In addition to his numerous scholarly publications, Alan took great pleasure in writing and reading poetry, producing three volumes of original work and translating the poems of Constantine Cavafy. He was an avid tennis and squash player, and knowledgeable amateur mycologist. Alan is survived by Julie, his wife of 61 years, sister Barbara, brother David, sons David and Alan, daughters Lindley and Alison, and eight grandchildren. Visit www.waring- sullivan.com for tributes 1

MacDONALD--Linda, nee Silling, 66. Loving wife of Stephen, wonderful mother of Michael, Katie and Emily. Wake at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th St., NYC, on Saturday, November 14, 11am - 1pm. 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Jacques. The family of Jacques Davidoff mourns the loss of a beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Jacques died peacefully in Paris after a long illness, on the 11th of November. He was 93. His family lovingly remembers him for his sharp mind, his entrepreneurial spirit, his clear vision and sense of purpose, his discipline, his great generosity and boundless love of life. His greatest joy in life was to share good times with his family and friends from all over the world. His marriage of 62 years to Monique is a legendary tale of love and complicity. We shall miss him dearly. He is survived by his wife, his children, Paul, and Alex, their wives and nine grandchildren. 1/3

NEGADO--Cesar T. Born October 2, 1938 Leyte, Philippines, son of Atty. Filomeno R. Negado and Julia Trani, died November 8, 2015, NJ. With an extensive career in the construction industry, projects spanned the Tri-State area. He is remembered as a generous man with a socially dynamic persona that people enjoyed to be around. His steadfast guidance to his sons was rooted in his wisdom and work ethic. He is survived by his partner Dolores De Leon, sons Eugene, Stefan, Cesar Nicholai, Ivan Negado. He is also survived by his sons Christopher and Caesar Negado, and his ex-wife Caridad San Pedro-Nierva. Viewing is November 12, 5-9pm at Alvarez-Marshello Funeral Home 235 Ege Ave, Jersey City NJ. Caesar O. Negado 1/3

ZACCAGNINO--Diane Owens. "Saint Diane of Battery Park City", Diane Owens Zaccagnino was born on September 26th, 1959, in Brooklyn, New York to Thelma Ruth and James Owens. She lived life to the fullest, constantly searching for opportunities to speak with others and "fuel" their dreams. Concerned about the well-being of others above all, Diane lived a life filled with conviction and purpose. She was a model to others, a teacher, an intercessor and an occasional worker of small miracles. Diane transitioned to Eternal Life on November 9th, 2015. She is survived by her husband, Michael J. Zaccagnino; her mother, Thelma; her parents-in-marriage, Sue Ann and Joseph Zaccagnino; her sisters, Joyce Pounds and Janice Fay Staunton, and Amy, Kristie, and Alexandra Zaccagnino; her brothers, Daniel Pounds, Thomas and Daniel Zaccagnino, and Matthew Amaru; and her aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins, friends, and community. Services will be held this week in New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to The New York Community Trust--Diane O. Zaccagnino Memorial Fund (909 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022). All proceeds will be directed to support cancer care and research. 1/3

WESTON--Burns H.,Bessie Dutton Murray, Distinguished Professor of Law Emeritus at the University of Iowa, died on October 28, 2015, a few days before his 82nd birthday. After surviving numerous challenges to his health, Weston was writing new books and developing human rights projects. His death was unexpected and sudden. After turning away a promising career as a pianist or conductor, Weston graduated from Yale Law School and began his legal career in 1961 with a distinguished New York law firm. Thereafter, he joined The University of Iowa College of Law, where he nurtured and inspired generations of law students and "put Iowa Law on the map" of international law and human rights. Weston authored over 28 books, wrote innumerable articles, and was on the editorial board of over 10 professional journals. In addition to taking part in numerous fact-finding human rights missions, he founded the University of Iowa Center for Human Rights (UIHCR) in 1999. Weston lectured, wrote and taught about pressing issues facing our planet: nuclear disarmament, apartheid, child labor, human rights and lately environmental survival. He co-authored (with David Bollier) a ground-breaking book "Green Governance: Ecological Survival, Human Rights, and the Law of the Commons" in 2012 and was, at the time of his death, in the final stages of completing the 4th edition of "Human Rights in the World Community: Issues and Action", with co-author, Anna Grear. Weston had a limitless capacity to enjoy so much about this world--and an equally tenacious drive to improve it. He embraced the world "with all five senses"--he was most passionate about classical music, but also loved art, travel and movies. He was happiest in the Adirondack Mountains. He was a devoted spouse, father, grandfather and brother. Weston is survived by his wife, Marta Cullberg Weston (Stockholm), his sister, Monique Weston (New York) and his two children, Timothy Bergmann Weston (Colorado) and Rebecca Burns Weston (Montana), four grandchildren, three Swedish stepchildren, and their five children. A memorial service in honor of Weston will be held by the Iowa College of Law, Iowa City on December 5, 2015 at 2pm. 1/3

MULVIHILL--James, on November 9, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Rosemary. Dear brother of Eileen Coogan and the late Peggy Keegan. Cherished uncle to many nieces and nephews. Member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians Division 2, Kerrymens P&B Association, United Irish Counties, Old Guard of the City of New York. Holy Name, Power Memorial and lona College Alumnus. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, 41-45 58th Street, Woodside, NY 11377. Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45am at St. Sebastian R. C. Church, Woodside, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to the Kerrymens Scholarship Fund or AOH Division 2 General Fund. 1/3

ROHRER--Dean Cougill, beloved father of three, grandfather of five, brother, sailor and influential attorney, passed away November 5th after a valiant battle with three degenerative diseases. Known as intelligent, strong, and persistent, he survived three years after his wife, Christina Marie's, passing. He graduated Union College in 1962; University of Virginia Law School in 1966; and distinguished himself as an attorney at Pillsbury Winthrop and Simpson Thacher, and came up the ranks with former Mayor Giuliani as an Assistant US Attorney for the Southern District of New York, prosecuting notable drug and heroin importation cases. He retired at 55 after serving as Vice President and Assistant General Counsel at GTE, the country's second largest telephone system, in Stamford, CT. He sailed over 30,000 miles, racing all over the world, including around Cape Horn. He inspired hope and helped improve many lives as a leader, friend, sponsor and example of a life well lived. 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Jacques. The family of Jacques Davidoff mourns the loss of a beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Jacques died peacefully in Paris after a long illness, on the 11th of November. He was 93. His family lovingly remembers him for his sharp mind, his entrepreneurial spirit, his clear vision and sense of purpose, his discipline, his great generosity and boundless love of life. His greatest joy in life was to share good times with his family and friends from all over the world. His marriage of 62 years to Monique is a legendary tale of love and complicity. We shall miss him dearly. He is survived by his wife, his children, Paul, and Alex, their wives and nine grandchildren. 1/3

PICOT--Pierre, died peacefully at home in Forest Hills, surrounded by his loving family, on Monday, November 9. Born in 1930 in Paris, France, to Eugenie and Efim Picot, his mother emigrated the family to NYC in 1939 after hearing Hitler's speeches. Fluent in Russian, French, and English, Pierre translated Russian Propaganda for US Armed Forces' Military Intelligence during the Korean War. He married his beloved Charlotte in 1958. A successful banker and attorney, he leaves behind his wife, two daughters Leslie Picot Zane and Liz Picot Hirsh, grandchildren, Sydney, Dylan, Ally and Austen, and sons-in-law, Andrew and David. Pierre's passing has left a hole in our hearts. 1/3

HERTER--Frederic Pratt, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 7 at the age of 94. Herter joined the American University of Beirut as a trustee in 1977. He served as Chairman of the Board of trustees from 1985 to 1987, and President of the University from 1987 to 1993. Through the challenging times of the civil war, he fought to keep the University's doors open and its students safe, even while Americans were barred from travelling to Lebanon. From the President's office in New York City, he fostered a vision of AUB as a world class university and medical center, and a beacon of moderation and understanding in the Middle East. A highly respected surgeon and teacher, Herter received his undergraduate degree from Harvard College, his M.D. from Harvard Medical School, and did post-graduate training in surgery at the Presbyterian Hospital, where he faithfully spent his medical career for nearly half a century. He was a pioneering surgeon and role model to generations of medical students, residents and faculty members while serving as the Auchincloss Professor of Surgery at Columbia University; Acting Chairman of Department of Surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, Acting Director of Surgery at Presbyterian Hospital, Director of Surgery at Francis Delafield Hospital; a trustee of Mary Imogene Bassett Hospital, Jackson Laboratories, and American Near East Refugee Aid; a regent of Cathedral of St. John the Divine, New York; a member of the board of governors of the Middle East Institute, Washington; a member of the board of advisers of the Hariri Foundation USA; and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. The scion of a distinguished New York family, Herter embodied the best qualities of leadership: inquisitiveness, determination, sensitivity, sense of purpose, and compassion. His legacy is a resolute belief in the ability of individuals and societies to work together for the benefit of humankind, which elevated everyone in his presence, and left the world a better place. He is survived by his beloved wife, Solange; sister, Adele Seronde; son, Eric; daughters, Caroline and Brooke; stepson, Marc; stepdaughters, Mary, Veronique and Jacqueline; and many grandchildren. Philip S. Khoury, PhD, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Fadlo R. Khuri, M.D., President, American University of Beirut, Beirut, Lebanon 1/3

GREENE--Lillian. Passed away peacefully on November 11th. A world traveller, Jewish scholar, linguist, gourmet, and philanthropist. A true renaissance woman. Survived by her children, Jonathan Greene (Nancy) and Linda Hochman (Howard); grandchildren Ariel, Josh, Sara, and David (Lauren); and great-grandson Noah. She will be missed but her soul will never leave us. Funeral services at Guttermans, Woodbury, Long Island at Noon, Friday, November 13. 1/3

HEINZ--Clifford Stanton. Grandson of H.J. Heinz, founder of the internationally recognized food company and contributing force behind the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, passed away on September 22, 2015; aged 96. Clifford Heinz was born in Pittsburgh, PA on August 4, 1919. He believed and adhered to the principles of a life lived with honesty, generosity, compassion and unerring hard work. He was also known for his keen wit and often ironic sense of humor which he maintained until the end. Heinz was considered a magnanimous and benevolent philanthropist, having once written: "I inherited from my grandfather, a consuming 'proprietorship ethic'," to coin a phrase. As an entrepreneur he started a wide range of companies and was always confident about his ability to manage anything. Heinz's two favorite mottos were "It can be done" and "Not if, but how." He was known for sealing his deals with an old fashioned handshake which represented the veracity of a signed contract. He believed a good education was the greatest gift one could give a person, thus he established the Heinz Ethics Program at Polytechnic School in Pasadena, CA; the Clifford S. Heinz Ethical Education Endowment at the Webb School in Claremont; and a Chair for the Economics and Public Policy of Peace at the University of California, Irvine. He is survived by his beloved Barbro; son Robert and wife Elizabeth; Caroline and husband Amre; Lisa and husband Richard; and Jeanette. His eight grandchildren are committed to carrying Clifford Heinz's legacy through the next generation and beyond. A memorial service will be held on November 15th, at Big Canyon Country Club, Newport Beach, California. 1/3

HEINZ--Clifford Stanton. Grandson of H.J. Heinz, founder of the internationally recognized food company and contributing force behind the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, passed away on September 22, 2015; aged 96. Clifford Heinz was born in Pittsburgh, PA on August 4, 1919. He believed and adhered to the principles of a life lived with honesty, generosity, compassion and unerring hard work. He was also known for his keen wit and often ironic sense of humor which he maintained until the end. Heinz was considered a magnanimous and benevolent philanthropist, having once written: "I inherited from my grandfather, a consuming 'proprietorship ethic'," to coin a phrase. As an entrepreneur he started a wide range of companies and was always confident about his ability to manage anything. Heinz's two favorite mottos were "It can be done" and "Not if, but how." He was known for sealing his deals with an old fashioned handshake which represented the veracity of a signed contract. He believed a good education was the greatest gift one could give a person, thus he established the Heinz Ethics Program at Polytechnic School in Pasadena, CA; the Clifford S. Heinz Ethical Education Endowment at the Webb School in Claremont; and a Chair for the Economics and Public Policy of Peace at the University of California, Irvine. He is survived by his beloved Barbro; son Robert and wife Elizabeth; Caroline and husband Amre; Lisa and husband Richard; and Jeanette. His eight grandchildren are committed to carrying Clifford Heinz's legacy through the next generation and beyond. A memorial service will be held on November 15th, at Big Canyon Country Club, Newport Beach, California. 1/3

Donations can be made to the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network at mbcn.org and the Anatol and Arthur Charitable Foundation, 2 Longview Ave, White Plains, NY 10601. Marian's memorial service will be at Larchmont Temple on November 13 at 12:30pm. Marian will be dearly missed. Also see JJFFH.com for more information. 1/3

HERTER--Dr. Frederic P. Dr. Craig R. Smith and the Department of Surgery at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons mourn the passing of Dr. Frederic P. Herter, our esteemed colleague and mentor. Auchincloss Professor Emeritus of Surgery and Acting Chairman of the Department of Surgery from 1969-1971, Dr. Herter completed his surgical residency training at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in 1953 and served on the faculty until his retirement in 1989. During his tenure, he was Attending Staff at Presbyterian Hospital, and Francis Delafield Hospital in New York. He became Director of the Surgical Service at Delafield in 1966. He was a leading figure in the area of research in cancer therapy. Dr. Herter received the P&S Distinguished Service Award in 1992. He was a member of the John Jones Surgical Society Steering Committee from its inception in 1997 until 2006 and co-edited, with Alfred Jaretzki III and Kenneth A. Forde, "A Proud Heritage: An Informal History of Surgery at Columbia", which was published in 2003. Dr. Herter was a tall, soft-spoken and approachable man who befriended others with ease and sincerity. He was highly respected as a teacher at the bedside and in the operating room, and his patients found him to be a good listener and a caring person. We extend our condolences to Mrs. Herter and family. Department of Surgery Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons Craig R. Smith, M.D. Chairman and Surgeon-in-Chief 1/3

He is also survived by his sons Christopher and Caesar Negado, and his ex-wife Caridad San Pedro-Nierva. Viewing is November 12, 5-9pm at Alvarez-Marshello Funeral Home 235 Ege Ave, Jersey City NJ. Caesar O. Negado 1/3

SHIKLER--Aaron A.,Painter. Born to Frank and Annie Shikler on March 18, 1922, in Brooklyn, NY. Died November 12, 2015, in New York City. Aaron graduated from the first class of The High School of Music and Art, now LaGuardia High School, 1940. He received his BFA and MFA in Art and Education from Tyler School of Art, Temple University. A member of the National Academy and The Century Association. Private First Class, Army Air Corps, WWll, cartographer. Survived by his children: Cathy Shikler van Ingen and Clifford Shikler; grandchildren Isabella, Lane, Montgomery, Benjamin and Alexei; son-in-law Armand van Ingen and daughter-in-law Christina Ross Shikler, and by his many nieces, nephews, colleagues, friends and students. LEVINE--Seymour. The Boards of Directors, leadership and staff of MJHS mourn the loss of Seymour Levine. For more than 20 years he advanced the mission of MJHS. In the 1980's, Seymour served as president of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center, which is now known as MJHS. He also played an important role in pioneering Elderplan, one of the original Social HMOs, and the establishment of MJHS Hospice. Our sympathies go out to his family. May his memory be for a blessing. Dr. Arthur Goshin, Chairman MJHS Alexander S. Balko, President & CEO 1/3

BURR--Deirdre Walsh, passed away on Wednesday, November 11, 2015 in Stamford, CT. Her family and friends will remember her as an elegant, wonderfully fun, and creative woman. Deirdre was a native New Yorker, born on September 10, 1932 to Lucy M. and William D. Ahearn. She remained a New Yorker until the final years of her life. She was a warm and loving wife, mother, stepmother, and grandmother. Deirdre is survived by her children, Meredith Smith (Larry) and Eliot Walsh (Jessica); her stepchildren, Laura Scharfenberg, Sara Fix (David), Olivia Slutsky (Alan), and John R. Burr; 13 grandchildren; and her sister, Lucy Adams. Deirdre attended the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York and graduated from Pine Manor College in Chestnut Hill, MA. She travelled extensively in Europe and Africa before returning to New York. There, she worked first for Steuben Glass, and then for the Hospitality Committee of the United Nations, where she assisted foreign delegates with all aspects of relocating to the city. In 1964, she married H. Robert Walsh, an advertising executive at Young & Rubicam, and they raised two children, Meredith and Eliot. Mr. and Mrs. Walsh remained married until 1987. Deirdre subsequently began a successful career in real estate, working for Brown Harris Stevens and Douglas Elliman for over 20 years. In 1990 she became reacquainted with an old friend, John S. Burr, and they married in 1995. They enjoyed many happy years together, doing charity work in Zimbabwe and Sri Lanka, and splitting their time between the city and a restored farmhouse in Claverack, NY. Deirdre was a talented, whimsical artist who will be remembered as a great mother and friend, and a spectacular dancer. A funeral service will be held at 11am on Friday, November 20, 2015, at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children at 410 East 92nd St., New York, NY 10128. 1/3

COLLINS--Philip S.,World's Fair Architect, dies at 86. Philip S. Collins, an architect who launched his career by designing the New Jersey State Pavilion for the 1964 World's Fair, died at his home near Princeton, NJ on October 29th. He was 86. His final illness was Multiple Systems Atrophy, a rare neurodegenerative disorder that eventually kept him from continuing a lifelong athleticism in running and cycling. Mr. Collins was born in Philadelphia in 1929 and grew up in Rydall, PA, with his sister, artist Lucinda Collins. He went to Williams College, and he was fresh out of architecture school at Princeton University when he entered and won the State of New Jersey's open competition to design the New Jersey Tercentenary Pavilion, to be constructed at a prestigious location adjacent to the Unisphere at the 1964 World's Fair at Flushing Meadows, NY. The ambitious pavilion won several awards, including the Architectural Award for Excellence by the American Institute of Steel Construction and a Citation for Excellence in Design by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. Mr. Collins was the founder of the architecture and engineering firm, CUH2A, in Princeton, NJ. The firm would grow into the largest science and technology design firm in the world, employing hundreds of architects and engineers in several international offices. Mr. Collins was predeceased by his son, Christopher Collins. He is survived by his wife, Elinor Whitney Collins; his sister, Lucinda Collins of New York City; his brother, Alan Pomeroy Collins of Trego, Montana; his daughters, Jennifer Collins, Elizabeth Tade, Dorothea Collins and Eliza Eager; and his six grandchildren. 1/3

FRICK--Alix (Halperin) Nelson, age 77, of Nantucket and New York City, died peacefully at the Sherborn, MA home of her daughter. Mrs. Nelson-Frick was a renowned author, book editor and advertising executive. Retired CEO of the New York advertising agency, Franklin Spier, Inc., she grew up in Manhattan, the daughter of legendary advertising copywriter Shirley Polykoff. Alix contributed reviews and articles to The New York Times Book Review, Newsday and women's magazines. Among her publications, she authored Amazon Best Sellers "The Stuff of Legend - A Daughter's Take on the Woman Who Transformed Advertising in the 1960's" and "My Inner India - Unraveling While Traveling from Delhi to Mumbai." Her recent book, "Hilarity - the Arc of a Life," takes stock with grace and humor of a life well-lived. She continued her thoughts and musings on her popular blog, "Hilarity," at AlixFrick.com until her passing. Wife of the Late Robert W. Frick, she and her husband spent their retirement years living on Nantucket and traveling throughout the world. She is survived by her daughter, Shawn Nelson Laughlin and her husband Buz of Sherborn, and her daughter, Corin Nelson of Santa Monica, CA; her stepdaughter, Amy L. Frick of New York City; and three grandchildren, Adden Laughlin and Phoebe Laughlin of New York City, and Gus Laughlin of Sherborn. In lieu of flowers, gifts in memory of Mrs. Alix Nelson-Frick may be made in support of the Pancreatic Cancer Research efforts of Mass General Hospital. Checks may be made out to Massachusetts General Hospital c/o Development Office, Attn: Mary McQuillen, 125 Nashua Street, Suite 540, Boston, MA 02114. Gifts online may be made at: www.giving.massgeneral.org.For the guest book and obituary, please visit: www.everettfuneral.com. 1/3

MONTGOMERY--John R.,III. John Rogerson Montgomery III, died peacefully in his home surrounded by family on November 10, 2015. Born May 16, 1930, John was the eldest son of Helen (Fyke) and John R. Montgomery. John was the third generation in his family to live in Winnetka, Illinois. He graduated from New Trier High School in 1948, Williams College in 1952, and earned his MBA at night at the University of Chicago. After college, John went to work at the Northern Trust Company. During these early years, John also served in the Korean War where he earned a bronze star. In 1966, John left the Northern Trust Company to become the first president of a new bank, Lakeside Bank, on the near Southside of Chicago. John's enthusiasm and vision as President for over 30 years was instrumental in its growth. As he used to say, "We opened the bank with 12 employees waiting for the first customers to come through the door." Today, Lakeside Bank has six branches and over a billion dollars in assets. Throughout his business career, John Montgomery was active in civic endeavors. He was especially committed to developing the near Southside of Chicago, serving as Chairman and President of the Southside Planning Board for over 30 years. He was also President of the Banker's Club of Chicago, President of the Illinois Banker's Association, and President of the Cosmopolitan Chamber of Commerce. In addition, John was involved with his alma mater and many clubs, serving as President of the Williams Class of '52, President of the University Club of Chicago, and President of Hillsboro Club in Florida. He also served for a number of years as a trustee of the John G. Shedd Aquarium. When John retired from Lakeside Bank, he continued on as Vice Chairman, on the Board of Directors, and as a member of the executive committee for many years. John was husband to Elizabeth Graham Montgomery and the late Dorothy "DeeDee" Smart Montgomery; father to John Montgomery (Lynne), DeeDee Myers (David), and Sally Jones (Ken); stepfather to William Graham and Melinda Graham; grandfather to Mari, Johnny, Jennifer, DeeDee, David, Sally, Brantner, Stephen, and Sarah; step-grandfather to Laila, Olivia, and Elizabeth; and brother to William Montgomery. The memorial service to celebrate the life of John Rogerson Montgomery III will be held on Saturday, November 28, 2015 at 4pm at the Winnetka Congregational Church, 725 Pine Street, Winnetka, IL 60093. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Tracy M. Dana, 633 3rd Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. Please note that the gift is in memory of John R. Montgomery III. 1/3

ARNOLD--Christopher C. April 14, 1963-October 30, 2015. Christopher Colver Arnold, age 52, beloved brother, devoted uncle, and friend to many, died Friday, October 30th in Southampton, NY. He was born and spent his early years in Chicago, where he attended the Latin School; later, he moved east and graduated from Phillips Academy Andover. After spending a year at Rugby School in Warwickshire, England, he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Chris was an accomplished writer, composer, lyricist, event producer, photojournalist, art gallerist and collector. He dazzled with his knowledge - quoting Caesar in Latin, Homer in Greek or Shakespeare in rhyme-- and was the life of the party with his musicality, often playing the piano and singing his own parodies of Cole Porter tunes. Chris worked in public relations for many years with his close friend Ted Kruckel at Ted, Inc. He co-produced events for clients including Van Cleef & Arpels, Christian Dior, InStyle, and Vanity Fair. Throughout his life, Chris loved photography. A decades-long friendship with legendary photographer, Bert Stern, steered him to the art world, where he became associated with the Keszler Gallery in Southampton, a venue recognized for its local support of the artist Banksy, as documented in an HBO special. Chris was inspired by new artists and the challenge of unusual installations at Art Miami and Art Hamptons, including transporting the wall of a building adorned with a piece by Banksy. "Moncle Chris" will be missed by his nieces, nephews and their friends, who loved his magic tricks, "marco polo" in the pool, piano playing and card games. His family and all who knew him mourn the loss of a kind and sensitive man whose sense of style, mischievous wit and generous spirit brightened every room he entered. Chris is survived by his brothers Rome and Greg, their wives Lisa and Mona, and Rome IV. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Southampton Hospital Foundation (631-726-8700 ext. 3). Plans for a Life Celebration/Memorial Event will be announced at a later date. 1/3

DAVIDOFF--Jacques. The family of Jacques Davidoff mourns the loss of a beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Jacques died peacefully in Paris after a long illness, on the 11th of November. He was 93. His family lovingly remembers him for his sharp mind, his entrepreneurial spirit, his clear vision and sense of purpose, his discipline, his great generosity and boundless love of life. His greatest joy in life was to share good times with his family and friends from all over the world. His marriage of 62 years to Monique is a legendary tale of love and complicity. We shall miss him dearly. He is survived by his wife, his children, Paul, and Alex, their wives and nine grandchildren. 1/3

KASTER--Lewis Ross. April 14, 1932 - November 12, 2015, of Forest Hills, New York. Our devoted father, loving grandfather, and friend "Lew," passed away on November 12, 2015. His distinguished career as a leading real estate and tax attorney commenced following his 1954 graduation from Columbia Law School, where he was a James Kent Scholar and later served as a member of the Adjunct Faculty. Career highlights included service in the U.S. Army's Judge Advocate General's Corps and serving as a partner in several law firms before retiring as of Counsel at Bryan Cave LLP. Pre- deceased by his wife, Carol (nee Goodz), he is survived by daughters Stephanie Blair Kaster and Rachel Kaster Fraser, her husband Ezra Fraser, and grandchildren Sophie and Bennett Orenstein. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Monday, November 16 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Chai Lifeline: www.chailifeline.org. 1/3

POLLINGER--Miriam "Mitzi" died suddenly on Sunday, November 1 in New York City after spending the day with her daughter, granddaughter, great-granddaughter, and two nieces Merav Slotnik and Nancy Rabin. She was 91, born on January 24, 1924, in Warsaw, Poland to Isadore and Norma Slotnik. Mitzi was a great source of kindness, love, and strength for five generations of her family. Up until her last day, she worked as the office manager and bookkeeper for a medical practice in midtown Manhattan. She was a graduate of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn. She was married and divorced twice, and her daughter Ronnie was the child of her first marriage to David Pollinger. Mitzi loved New York City and for more than the last thirty years lived on West 11th Street in the heart of Greenwich Village. She loved jazz, the Metropolitan Opera, fashion, Jewish family life, and collected friends at every opportunity. She had an addictive laugh; her ability to find the humor in life was remarkable. She enthusiastically welcomed family members and friends -- from Toronto to Jerusalem-- to stay with her on visits to New York. As the matriarch of her large extended family, she served as the central connection and information bank among numerous family members who imparted personal and professional updates, relying on Mitzi to disseminate the news. She was beloved for her passionate loyalty and devotion to her family, and was always proud of their accomplishments, but did not hesitate to give straightforward advice when warranted. She was trusted by all because she could keep a secret. She is survived by her loving daughter, Ronnie Barback and her husband Spencer; granddaughter, Rebecca Roban and her husband Ken; grandson, Michael Kanner and his wife Lisa; adoring four great-grandchildren, Danielle and Matthew Roban and Rex and Madison Kanner; three brothers, Jack Slotnick, and Fred and Sol Slotnik; and throngs of nieces and nephews. For every member of her extended family and her many friends, there will never be another Mitzi. She will be greatly missed and always remembered. 1
FRIEDMAN--Edith, 87, on November 3. Lifelong New Yorker, balletomane, concert and museum goer, library patron, teacher. We miss you. 1/3

HANSEN--Justin Clark, 49, of Larchmont, NY, passed away suddenly on November 11, 2015. Justin is survived by his children, Desmond, Asher and Grace, as well as his former wife and good friend, Amy Holzman, all of Larchmont. Justin also leaves behind his father, Donald L. Hansen of Newburgh, NY, and two siblings, Kirsten, also of Newburgh, and Chris, of Miami, Florida. GRAFF--Yveta Synek. Yveta Synek Graff, the self styled secret weapon of Czech Opera's Velvet Revolution passed away on Friday November 6th, 2015 at her home in Montecito, CA. Born in Prague, Czechoslovakia, Yveta Synek, was the only child of the distinguished judge, author, playwright, director, editor and politician Dr. Emil Synek and Eugenia Budlovska, a star of Czech theatre. A fervent anti-nazi working with the Czech government-in-exile, Dr. Synek anticipated the communist takeover in 1947 and managed to spirit his family to France. Yveta Synek flourished in Paris, studying voice with Ninon Vallin and modeling. She became "Miss Kodak" and appeared in promotional campaigns on billboards throughout France. In 1956 she obtained a coveted visa to go to America and never looked back. The young Synek arrived in New York City, met and married Robert Lincoln Love, a children's wear fashion designer and had two sons, Steve and Brett. Later on they would divorce and then she married F. Malcolm Graff, Jr., a private banker with the Bankers Trust Company. Their shared passion for opera brought them to the pinnacle of glamour in New York City, The Metropolitan Opera House. At the urging of her father and husband, she became the doyen of Czech Opera, first as a vocal coach in her native Czech language and then, with her colleague and editor Robert T. Jones, as a translator and transliterator (i.e. phonetic transcription). Today, her transliterations are permanently archived at the Juilliard School of Music and used by every opera house around the world. Yveta Graff's career started in 1977 with Eve Queler and the Opera Orchestra of New York performing Smetana's Dalibor, in Czech, on the stage of Carnegie Hall. For the next thirty years she worked at almost every opera house of note in the world overseeing productions of operas by Leos Janacek (The Cunning Little Vixen, Kat'a Kabanova, Jenufa, From the House of the Dead and The Makropulos Case), Dvorak (Rusalka) and Smetana (The Bartered Bride). Graff acted as right hand to such maestros as Rafael Kubelik, James Conlon and Sir. Charles Mackerras. She coached stars like Renee Fleming, Karita Mattila, Catherine Malfitano, Patricia Racette, Dolora Zajick, Gabriela Benackova and Ben Heppner. But of all her institutional associations, none was a greater source of pride to her than the one with The Metropolitan Opera, where she served as de facto subject-matter expert in all matters Czech for over two decades, beginning with Jenufa in 1985 and culminating with Rusalka in 2009. For her devotion to Czech Opera, Mrs. Graff received numerous medals from her native country including The Orders of the Czech Republic bestowed on her by the first democratically elected president of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel. Yveta Synek Graff is survived by her son, Steve Love, his wife, Jeanie Love, her grandson, Chase Love and her god-son, Marc Chazaud. 1/3

ACUFF--Roy Neill. ("CatDaddy" - "Pops" - "PeaPop") age 72 of Nashville, passed away on November 5, 2015. He was born in Nashville, Tennessee to the late Roy Claxton Acuff and Mildred Douglas Acuff. He is survived by his wife of 38 years, Susan Marie Haynes Acuff; sons, Roy Neill Acuff, Jr. and Alex Wolfgang Acuff "Coop"; and granddaughters, Mollie M. and Abigail Acuff. Roy Neill had many loving friends. Among them are: "Peggy-Raye" Lamb, Bill "Keebler" Hertan, Julye Bakos, Virginia Gang of Squirrel, Carolyn, Jean Hardy Robinson and the late Ervin Hardy, Todd and Jo Borman, and his sweet Lizzie Cat. The late Nellie Foster Byers was another "Mama" in Roy Neill's life. "If it hadn't been for her, no telling where I'd be," Roy Neill was quoted as saying back in 1978. Roy Neill enjoyed playing guitar, writing, painting, sculpting, collecting books, and reading The New York Times. Roy Neill and his family have so much appreciation for the amazing folks at Alive Hospice who cared for him. Enjoy your journey, Roy Neill. Peace. Services for Roy Neill will be private. Arrangements have been entrusted to Spring Hill Funeral Home and Cemetery, 5110 Gallatin Road, Nashville, Tennessee 37216. (615) 865-1101. www.springhillfh.com 1/3

BUSH--Patricia Redfearn, passed away on November 10, 2015, at the age of 77. Patty was born in Greenville, SC, the daughter of Theron and Louisa Martin Redfearn. She attended St. Catherine's School and Bennett College before transferring to Vassar. In 1959 she married William H.T. Bush, the youngest of Sen. Prescott and Dorothy Bush's five children. She made homes for her family in New Haven, CT, Columbus, GA, Hartford and Greenwich, CT, London, England and ultimately St. Louis, MO. and Hobe Sound, FL. Her many civic accomplishments included working with Charles Cunningham to establish the first docent training program at Wadsworth Athenaeum in Hartford. She continued her studies in art history, and after moving to St. Louis served as a docent at the Art Museum there for more than 30 years. She also served on the Museum's board of Trustees and as its President. She loved classical music, which led her to serve on the board of the Opera Theater of St. Louis. Just as profound as her love of fine art was her devotion to plants. She was a member of garden clubs in Hartford, St. Louis, Jupiter Island, and the Hortulus Garden Club in Greenwich, CT, of which her mother-in-law, Dorothy Walker Bush, was a member and her daughter Louisa is a member now. She was happiest when in a garden wearing her leather gloves, a trowel in her hand and mulch up to her ankles. She prided herself on knowing the Latin names for plants and their families. She received the Garden Clubs of America Medal of Merit for her extraordinary service to that organization. She also was a board member of the Center for Plant Conservation in St. Louis. She is survived by her husband, children William Prescott Bush (Lindsay), of St. Louis, and Louisa B. McCall (Christian), of Greenwich, and five grandchildren: Katherine and Alexander Bush, and Henry, William, and Lucinda McCall. Services of thanksgiving will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island on November 27 and at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in St Louis on December 12. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for memorial contributions to The St. Louis Art Museum, The Opera Theater of St. Louis, or The Missouri Botanical Garden. 1/3

LEVERE--Bernard, 93, of Cresskill, NJ, died Sunday, September 13, 2015. Husband of the late Zelda Gordon Levere. Father of Jane, David and his wife, Amy, and Peggy and her husband, Russell DaSilva. Grandfather of Michael, Jeffrey and Caroline Levere, and Ellen DaSilva and David Eckstein and Emily and Nancy DaSilva. Brother of Helene Levere Liebowitz and her husband, the late Arthur Liebowitz. Brother-in-law of Robert E. Gordon and his wife, Gladys. Bernard was a 1942 graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; a captain, in Europe, in the U.S. Army during WWII; world traveler; exceptional photographer; and active in many institutions and organizations, including Temple Emanu-El in Closter, NJ, and Jewish Home at Rockleigh. We miss him dearly. 1/3

PRESBERG--Marian Sue, 55, beloved wife of David Stolman, devoted mother of Matthew and Benjamin Stolman, adored sister of Jan Presberg, and cherished daughter of Shirley and Harry Presberg passed away on November 10 at home surrounded by family in Larchmont, NY. Donations can be made to the Metastatic Breast Cancer Network at mbcn.org and the Anatol and Arthur Charitable Foundation, 2 Longview Ave, White Plains, NY 10601. Marian's memorial service will be at Larchmont Temple on November 13 at 12:30pm. Marian will be dearly missed. Also see JJFFH.com for more information. 1/3

HEINZ--Clifford Stanton. Grandson of H.J. Heinz, founder of the internationally recognized food company and contributing force behind the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, passed away on September 22, 2015; aged 96. Clifford Heinz was born in Pittsburgh, PA on August 4, 1919. He believed and adhered to the principles of a life lived with honesty, generosity, compassion and unerring hard work. He was also known for his keen wit and often ironic sense of humor which he maintained until the end. Heinz was considered a magnanimous and benevolent philanthropist, having once written: "I inherited from my grandfather, a consuming 'proprietorship ethic'," to coin a phrase. As an entrepreneur he started a wide range of companies and was always confident about his ability to manage anything. Heinz's two favorite mottos were "It can be done" and "Not if, but how." He was known for sealing his deals with an old fashioned handshake which represented the veracity of a signed contract. He believed a good education was the greatest gift one could give a person, thus he established the Heinz Ethics Program at Polytechnic School in Pasadena, CA; the Clifford S. Heinz Ethical Education Endowment at the Webb School in Claremont; and a Chair for the Economics and Public Policy of Peace at the University of California, Irvine. He is survived by his beloved Barbro; son Robert and wife Elizabeth; Caroline and husband Amre; Lisa and husband Richard; and Jeanette. His eight grandchildren are committed to carrying Clifford Heinz's legacy through the next generation and beyond. A memorial service will be held on November 15th, at Big Canyon Country Club, Newport Beach, California. 1/3

GEBHARDT--John C.,90, died Sunday, October 18th, 2015 in Cortland, NY. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on February 19th, 1925 where he grew up. At the age of 15 he met his wife of 67 years, Frances S. Gebhardt, who predeceased him in 2011. After her death he remained in Manhattan in the apartment they shared for over 40 years. He loved (and was loved by) his friends, neighbors, building staff, and many local shopkeepers who were all invaluable to his quality of life. He wanted all to know that the most important thing in his life was his family. He felt fortunate to be with them in his final days. He is survived by his daughter Claudia (Syracuse), son Jeff and his wife Gonda (Cortland), seven grandchildren - Dana (Stefan Jakowenko), Lynn (Colin McEvoy), Aiyana, Taimah, Naomi, Maya, and Kaylee, two great-grandchildren Connor and Alexa, and his sister Anna Mae Watson (Plainview). He was greatly influenced by his time in the Army as a navigator during WWII on "The Princess Pat," a B24 Liberator with the 458th Bomb Group. He was proud of his service, but sorry that so many innocents were killed. He returned home a pacifist. A 35 year teaching career at Wingate (Brooklyn), Bayside (Queens), and Assistant Principal of English at Fort Hamilton (Brooklyn) high schools earned him the respect of fellow staff and students alike. His influence was evident as many of his students became writers; and the teachers who worked with him remained in touch, long after retirement. He published a book on teaching Shakespeare, which was used in all New York City classrooms for years, and is in the Library of Congress. For Shakespeare's 400th birthday he made a "cake" out of wood with 400 candles. He was glad that he didn't burn anything down. He was grateful to the many people who were so kind to him, especially after his wife, Fran, died. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, and all who knew him. Calling hours will be from 1:00-2:15pm on Saturday, November 21st at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, in New York City. A celebration of John's life will follow at 2:30pm. 1/3

STONE--Elaine, nee Goodside, born January 2, 1945 to parents Ray and Victor Goodside. She died on November 2, 2015 at home, surrounded by family. Elaine was a loving wife, mother and grandmother. A teacher at Grace Church School for 31 years, she taught, loved and was loved by generations of children. Elaine was a gifted watercolorist, weaver and long distance walker. She is survived by her husband Bob, daughters Liz and Amy, granddaughters Alex and Sammy, twin sister Marian and older sister, Fran. She will be missed always. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on November 21, 2015 at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn NY, 11201. 1/3

JACOBS--Natalie, on November 7th. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Mother of the late Michael Denton. Stepmother to Leonard and Kathy Jacobs, Jay and Mindy Jacobs. Loving grandmother to Steven, Sarah, Jessica and Jacqueline. She will be long remembered and much missed. 1/3

ADLER--Myril, of Briarcliff Manor, NY, our "famous unknown artist" and beloved teacher, died November 10 in her home at the age of 95. Born September 22, 1920 in Vitebsk, Russia, Myril, (known as "Milly" for most of her adult life), emigrated with her parents to the United States at age three. She graduated from high school in Brooklyn at age 16 and attended the Art Students League, and later the Pratt Institute, developing her own style, which she evolved through many media in her 80 plus year career as an artist. She married Jack Adler on October 18, 1941 and their romance and adventure went on for 54 years until his death in 1995. The two spent a year in Boulder, CO where Jack was a translator and Myril taught art to Japanese children in the internment camps. In 1948, with their one-year-old son, they moved to Europe. While Jack worked with WWII displaced persons, Myril pursued her art, with exhibitions in Paris and elsewhere. They returned to New York City in 1952 and then to Briarcliff in 1955, shortly after the birth of their daughter. For the next 53 years, hundreds of children and adults attended the Myril Adler Art Studio to learn from this unique teacher about art and life. She grew to be well-known throughout Westchester for numerous solo and group shows. Myril's restless passion drove her and Jack to travel the world, to places both common and exotic. In addition to the many artists she nurtured over the years, Myril is survived by her son David and his wife Jill of Newton, MA; her daughter, Sharon and her husband Steve of Croton, NY; three grandchildren, Jonathan, Eliza and Sarah, as well as two great-grandchildren, Miles and Zoe. 1/3

LAPPLE--Walter William, loving husband of Jane Weinberger Lapple, brother Robert Lapple and wife June, son, John David Lapple, daughters, Jody Whelton and Jodi Siegel, passed away peacefully November 11th after suffering the effects of Alzheimer's for the past eight years. He leaves behind many family members and friends who all loved and admired him for his kindness and integrity, a true gentleman who embraced life to its fullest.
