COOPER--Wilma. Best mom (Elizabeth and Marnie). Best nana (Kennedy). A loving, beautiful, smart, creative and strong woman who will be missed forever. 1/3

LEVINE--Seymour, of New York and Torrington, CT passed away on November 12, 2015. It is with profound sorrow that the partners, associates and staff of Troutman Sanders and its predecessor New York firm, Parker Chapin, mourn the passing of its former senior partner. Mr. Levine was Chairman of Parker Chapin's trusts and estates department for many years. He was loved by his clients and highly regarded by the New York Trusts and Estates Bar. A member of several bar associations' committees on trusts and estates, as well as a member of the American College of Trusts & Estates Counsel, he was listed in "The Best Lawyers in America for Trusts & Estates." Mr. Levine was a 1952 graduate of Harvard Law School. He will be sorely and truly missed. To his family, we extend our heartfelt sympathies. Troutman Sanders LLP 1/3

SHIKLER--Aaron A.,Painter. Born to Frank and Annie Shikler on March 18, 1922, in Brooklyn, NY. Died November 12, 2015, in New York City. Predeceased by his wife of 51 years, Barbara "Pete" Lurie Shikler and sisters: Eve Altman, Jean Rieder, Mollie Geller, Julia Gerstenhaber and Ethel Shikler; and by best friends and colleagues David Levine and Roy Davis. Aaron graduated from the first class of The High School of Music and Art, now LaGuardia High School, 1940. He received his BFA and MFA in Art and Education from Tyler School of Art, Temple University. A member of the National Academy and The Century Association. Private First Class, Army Air Corps, WWll, cartographer. Survived by his children: Cathy Shikler van Ingen and Clifford Shikler; grandchildren Isabella, Lane, Montgomery, Benjamin and Alexei; son-in-law Armand van Ingen and daughter-in-law Christina Ross Shikler, and by his many nieces, nephews, colleagues, friends and students. Burial private. Memorial Service in January. 1/3

UNGER--Ruth Helen, 89, of New York City, died November 10. 2015. Ruth, daughter of Phillip and Becky Dunn, loving wife of Edwin Unger, passed away peacefully on November 10th in her Manhattan home, surrounded by her family, following a long battle with COPD. She is survived by her three sons, Richard, Lawrence and David, their wives Alana, Patti and Lorraine, and five grand-children: Evan, Sarah, Ryan, Samantha and Andrina. She also had the joy of meeting and holding her great-grandson, Max Asher, only a few days before her death. Ruth Unger proudly led the National Mah Jongg League, a charitable membership organization, as president until her passing. She was involved in all aspects of the league's activities for more than 50 years. Under her leadership, it grew to become an expanding community of enthusiastic players across the country as well as a philanthropy devoted to improving the health and advancement of women. She will be sorely missed by her loyal staff and friends. 1/3
CUSHING--Frederick Ames. (1934 - 2013) We celebrate his life and the kindness that gave joy to so many people who knew him. His Family 1/3

LORCH--Siegbert, 93, of Pompton Plains, NJ, formerly of Delray Beach, FL, Oradell, NJ, and Dieburg, Germany. Survived by his beloved wife, Marjorie, daughters Susan (Scott Hammer) and Victoria Jacobine (Anthony), and grandchildren Alexander and Elizabeth Jacobine. Donations to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum (ushmm.org) would be welcome. 1/3

SCHOMER--Jesse, MD, 87, died peacefully at home in Westport, CT on November 6 2015 after a brief illness. Son of the late Alexander Schomer and the late Ethel Lewitt Schomer, he was predeceased by his wife Vivian Simes Schomer, his sister Marian Greene and brother-in-law Stanley Greene. Survived by his twin brother Morton Schomer (Judith), son Jeremy, daughters Eugenie Schomer (David Hyman) and Janet Crawford, grandsons Nicolas and Graham Hyman, and James Crawford, and five nieces and nephews. Jesse was born on August 2 1928 in New York City, graduated from Bronx High School of Science, Columbia College class of 1948, New York University School of Medicine, and served in the United States Army Medical Corps. In addition to his private practice in Manhattan and Westport, Jesse was Director of the Adult Psychiatry Clinic of New York Hospital-- Westchester Division, was on the faculty of both New York Hospital--Cornell University Medical College and the Columbia University Psychoanalytic Center, and was a long-time member of the American Psychoanalytic Society. He will be missed by family, friends, colleagues, and medical students for his exacting scientific mind, his wit and unique brand of humor, and the intellect and curiosity that informed his perspective on the world, as well as by those who remember him riding his bicycle to his office at the Willows in his distinctive reflective vest. A memorial will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please donate to a Parkinson's cure or WMNR.com. 1/3

FALES--Haliburton, 2d. The partners and staff of White & Case LLP mourn the passing of our retired partner and former Chair of the Firm, Haliburton (Hal) Fales 2d. A talented and principled litigator, Hal was educated at Harvard, the United States Naval Reserve and Columbia Law School. He started his career in our New York office in 1947 at a time when co-founder George Case was still actively involved with the Firm. He practiced law for 50 years, making partner in 1959, running the litigation department for many years, and serving as chair from 1976 through 1979. Described by colleagues as an exceptional leader, exemplary partner, mentor, and overall prince among men, Hal was actively involved in both community and professional organizations. He was a president of the New York State Bar Association, chair of the State Bar's Task Force on the Profession, and he served on the State Bar's Executive Committee. He was president of the Morgan Library in New York, the first non-Morgan family member to serve in the role. He also served as chair of St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, was a member of the Chief Judge of New York's Task Force on Women and the Courts, and worked with the National Center for State Courts and the Fund for Modern Courts. He served on the boards of the Legal Aid Society, Volunteers of Legal Services and New York Lawyers for the Public Interest. He was active on pro bono matters for the Firm and volunteered as counsel for the Women's Prison Association. Our thoughts are with his family and we recall with great affection his beloved wife, Kak, who predeceased him. Donations may be made in his name to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, The Morgan Library & Museum or the Women's Prison Association. 1/3

ACKERLEY--Mildred Clegg. Born in Floral Park, New York on June 21, 1933, died peacefully surrounded by her children in her home in Floral Park on Friday, November 13, 2015. Dedicated educator and family matriarch, she was a generous friend and mentor to many. Beloved wife of the late James Albert Ackerley and the late Leland Drennen Ackerley. Devoted mother of Dr. Mary Beth Ackerley (Alexander Casler) of Tucson, Arizona; Robert Ackerley (Nora Smith) of Houston, Texas; Leland Ackerley (Carmen DalPont) of Houston, Texas; Anne Ackerley (David Lewis) of Riverdale, New York; and Margaret Ackerley (Mark Bollinger) of McLean, Virginia. Adored grandmother to Benjamin, Sydney and Eve Ackerley; Alexis, Andrew, Leland and Will Ackerley; Jack and Juliet Lewis; and James and Caroline Bollinger. Caring sister of Frances Feeney, Mary Anne Clegg, John Clegg, Alice Wolfteich, and Paul Clegg; preceded in death by her brothers Ambrose Clegg and George Clegg. Mildred taught Mathematics at New Hyde Park Memorial High School, New Hyde Park, New York, for thirty years where she served as Advisor to the National Honor Society, Director of Student Activities, and Sewanhaka Central High School District Coordinator of Talented and Gifted Programs. Before becoming a teacher, Mildred served as a mathematician at the George C. Marshall Space Center in Huntsville, Alabama and with the American Bosch Arma Corp. in Carle Place, New York. She was elected Alumni Trustee of Adelphi University, Garden City, New York, 1967-1970; served as Vice President of the Friends of the Floral Park Library; Membership Chairperson of the Sewanhaka Federation of Teachers, Retired; and Board Member of the Nassau North Retired Teachers Association. In 2002, she was honored by Delta Gamma Fraternity for fifty years of membership and service. Family and friends may call Thursday between 5pm to 9pm at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, New York. A funeral service Friday 11am at the United Methodist Church of Floral Park, 35 Verbena Avenue, Floral Park. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make a donation to the Friends of the Floral Park Library or to the Mildred Clegg Ackerley Scholarship Fund at Adelphi University. She was a force of nature and a loving presence in all our lives; we will miss her dearly. 1/3

ROTHSCHILD--Margaret Touborg. 74, died peacefully in Manhattan on November 12 after a long illness. Born and raised in Rome, NY, she graduated from Radcliffe College magna cum laude in English Literature and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. A longtime community volunteer in Lincoln, MA while raising her four children, she did post-graduate work at the Radcliffe Seminars, culminating in the development of two seminal study tours to England to places associated with English women writers. In 1984, she joined Radcliffe as Director of Corporate and Foundation Relations. In 1986 she was a member of a New England College delegation charged with studying South African universities and evaluating their commitment to social change. She was invited to return to advise the far-thinking University of Cape Town on issues pertaining to women. In 1988 she moved to New York to lead The University of Cape Town Fund, a newly established American non- profit founded to promote advancement of black students at South Africa's oldest and most distinguished university. In that capacity, she raised more than $40 million to help black students enter, persist and thrive in the demanding research environment. Upon retirement as President of the Fund, she worked briefly as an advisor to the director of The Frick Collection. Predeceased by her husband Robert Rothschild, she is survived by her three daughters and one son, four grandsons, and four granddaughters - each of whom is named Margaret. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Schlesinger Library, c/o Office of the Recording Secretary, 124 Mt. Auburn Street, Cambridge, MA 02138. 1/3
DEAN--Andy Chen M.D. PhD. 3/26/60 - 11/15/06. We remember you with love & respect. Your Family 1/3

MELFI--John C.,43, passed away in Brooklyn on November 2, 2015. He is survived by his wife, Joanna Wisniecka of Brooklyn; parents, Charles and Ann, of Irvine, CA; sister, Lisa Bain, of Denver, CO; and brother, Michael, of Irvine, CA. He was a 1994 graduate of Brown University, received a J.D. degree from University of Oregon School of Law, and LLM (taxation) from NYU School of Law. Additional information available at www.johnmelfi.bkny.com. 1/3

FEINGOLD--William. Beloved father of Rebekah Beneteau and Tina Weinberg, grandfather of Mariah and Ariana Mulhare, partner of Marilyn Goodman. Funeral Sunday, November 15, 2pm at Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

BACH--Harry. An insatiable world traveler, learner, opera aficionado, and life-long daily reader of The New York Times, Harry Bach passed away at age 97 on November 4 in Philadelphia, PA, after leading the definition of "a good, long life." He grew up in the Lower East Side tenements, worked his way up through college and a domestic stint with the military during WWII, and ultimately became a CPA employed by everyone from Salvador Dali to New England farmers. Harry was also fluent in French, Spanish, Latin, and Yiddish. He knew great love and companionship in his life, and his generosity of heart, mind, and spirit were felt throughout his vast personal networks. He is survived by a brother, two children, five grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews, and countless other family members and loved ones, with each of whom he took the time to form a unique bond. 1/3

ALLISON--Richard C.,on November 12, 2015. Born in Manhattan in 1924, Mr. Allison was educated at the College and the Law School of the University of Virginia where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Editor of the Virginia Law Review. He served as communications officer on the U.S.S. Endicott during World War II. He commenced the practice of law in New York with the firm of Satterlee, Warfield & Stephens in 1948 and, after two years service with the C.I.A. during the Korean War, he joined the firm of Reid & Priest, where he spent over 33 years representing American and foreign clients. Mr. Allison is remembered with special appreciation by the many young lawyers he trained. His work took him to many countries and involved lengthy residences with his family in Latin America and Europe. Mr. Allison was active in the American Bar Association and was chairman of its Section of International Law, Latin American Law Committee, and International Legal Exchange Program. On Long Island, he was chairman of the Village of Roslyn Planning Board and a member of the Boards of Trustees of the Manhasset Congregational Church and Buckley Country Day School. In 1988, he was appointed by the United States as a member of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague where he served as a full time Judge until 1997. Mr. Allison was a member of Sons of the American Revolution, the St. Andrews Society of New York, the Raven Society, Phi Beta Kappa, Omicron Delta Kappa, Pi Kappa Alpha, Phi Delta Phi, the Council on Foreign Relations and the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. He was predeceased by Anne his beloved wife of 63 years, and is survived by his daughter, Anne Sidney Park, and her husband, David B. Park of Santa Fe, NM; his son, W. Scott Allison of Plandome Manor, NY; and his granddaughter, Cassandra A. Park of Denver. 1/3

FEIERSTEIN--Shirley. October 24, 1920 - September 26, 2015. Graduated from Hunter with honors in Chemistry and worked in engineering at Lever Bros. Although she was Jewish and the only woman, she earned her male colleagues' respect through her intelligence and fiery spirit. She then left Lever to work on classified government research at Sperry Gyroscope. Devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, she was predeceased by her husband in 2001. Family and friends loved her for her sheer brilliance, artistic talents, and humor. Shirley was also going "green" before it was cool. She will be greatly missed by all. 1/3

SHELTON--Sloane. 81, died September 17 after a long illness (pulmonary fibrosis) at her home in Wainscott, NY. Born March 14, 1934, in Hahira, GA, to Clarence and Ruth Shelton, her life took a decisive turn in first grade when she played Cinderella. An actress was born. In 1954, she attended Berea College (Kentucky) and wrote, directed, starred in her first play: "The Snow is Mud," about an Italian family in New York's Little Italy. "I'd never been to New York, knew no Italians, and hadn't seen much snow!" However . . . Moving to New York, she won a scholarship to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London. A long career in theatre, film and TV followed. She wrote and produced "Millay at Steepletop" shot by film historian Kevin Brownlow. Austin Pendleton directed her in "Eudora," a one woman show commissioned for her by Sybil Burton Christopher. She is survived by her nephews Tracy and Scott Shelton and her long-time companion of almost 50 years, Jan Buckaloo. Jan and Sloane were married in 2009. A memorial service is set for November 30, 1pm, at the Cherry Lane Theatre, New York City. 1/3

ROSS--Marcia Ann, nee Cohen, on November 10, 2015. Beloved wife of Bob, loving mother of Joanne, David and Amy. Grandmother of Eric, Brittany, Rachel, Michael, Keren, Matthew. Great- grandmother of Ava and Spencer. A beautiful, smart and strong woman who will be loved and missed forever. 1/3
BRADFORD--Rev. Eugene Nov. 15, 1915--Jan. 20, 2010 Suffer the little children to come unto me, and forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of heaven. 1/3

SHIKLER--Aaron A. Davis & Langdale Company, New York, mourns the loss of distinguished painter and portraitist Aaron A. Shikler (1922- 2015) on November 12, 2015. Davis & Langdale Company has proudly represented Mr. Shikler since 1952 and extends its condolences to his daughter Cathy Shikler van Ingen and his son Clifford Shikler; his son-in-law and daughter-in-law; and his granddaughter and four grandsons. FRICK--Alix (Halperin) Nelson, age 77, of Nantucket and New York City, died peacefully at the Sherborn, MA home of her daughter. Mrs. Nelson-Frick was a renowned author, book editor and advertising executive. Retired CEO of the New York advertising agency, Franklin Spier, Inc., she grew up in Manhattan, the daughter of legendary advertising copywriter Shirley Polykoff. Alix contributed reviews and articles to The New York Times Book Review, Newsday and women's magazines. Among her publications, she authored Amazon Best Sellers "The Stuff of Legend - A Daughter's Take on the Woman Who Transformed Advertising in the 1960's" and "My Inner India - Unraveling While Traveling from Delhi to Mumbai." Her recent book, "Hilarity - the Arc of a Life," takes stock with grace and humor of a life well-lived. She continued her thoughts and musings on her popular blog, "Hilarity," at AlixFrick.com until her passing. Wife of the Late Robert W. Frick, she and her husband spent their retirement years living on Nantucket and traveling throughout the world. She is survived by her daughter, Shawn Nelson Laughlin and her husband Buz of Sherborn, and her daughter, Corin Nelson of Santa Monica, CA; her stepdaughter, Amy L. Frick of New York City; and three grandchildren, Adden Laughlin and Phoebe Laughlin of New York City, and Gus Laughlin of Sherborn. In lieu of flowers, gifts in memory of Mrs. Alix Nelson-Frick may be made in support of the Pancreatic Cancer Research efforts of Mass General Hospital. Checks may be made out to Massachusetts General Hospital c/o Development Office, Attn: Mary McQuillen, 125 Nashua Street, Suite 540, Boston, MA 02114. Gifts online may be made at: www.giving.massgeneral.org.For the guest book and obituary, please visit: www.everettfuneral.com. 1/3

DILLON--Therese Anne, nee Bauer, passed peacefully away at home on Saturday, November 14th, at age 85, surrounded by her loving family. Born in the city of Waterloo in Ontario, Canada, survived by her beloved husband, Thomas Anthony Dillon, Junior of 61 years and her four children, Thomas (Maureen), Christopher (Maureen), Gregory (Dora), and Margaret (Joseph), her six grandchildren, Grace, Ben (Drea), Thomas, Nicholas, Natalie, and Rebecca, and her great-granddaughter, Maxine. Visiting Tuesday, November 17th, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. in Larchmont. Mass Wednesday, November 18th, 11am at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Fox House Shelter for Homeless Woman and Children c/o Sisters of Charity Center Development Office 6301 Riverdale Ave Bronx, NY 10471-1093. For full obituary visit: JJFFH.com. 1/3

BUSH--Patricia Redfearn, passed away on November 10, 2015, at the age of 77. Patty was born in Greenville, SC, the daughter of Theron and Louisa Martin Redfearn. She attended St. Catherine's School and Bennett College before transferring to Vassar. In 1959 she married William H.T. Bush, the youngest of Sen. Prescott and Dorothy Bush's five children. She made homes for her family in New Haven, CT, Columbus, GA, Hartford and Greenwich, CT, London, England and ultimately St. Louis, MO. and Hobe Sound, FL. Her many civic accomplishments included working with Charles Cunningham to establish the first docent training program at Wadsworth Athenaeum in Hartford. She continued her studies in art history, and after moving to St. Louis served as a docent at the Art Museum there for more than 30 years. She also served on the Museum's board of Trustees and as its President. She loved classical music, which led her to serve on the board of the Opera Theater of St. Louis. Just as profound as her love of fine art was her devotion to plants. She was a member of garden clubs in Hartford, St. Louis, Jupiter Island, and the Hortulus Garden Club in Greenwich, CT, of which her mother-in-law, Dorothy Walker Bush, was a member and her daughter Louisa is a member now. She was happiest when in a garden wearing her leather gloves, a trowel in her hand and mulch up to her ankles. She prided herself on knowing the Latin names for plants and their families. She received the Garden Clubs of America Medal of Merit for her extraordinary service to that organization. She also was a board member of the Center for Plant Conservation in St. Louis. She is survived by her husband, children William Prescott Bush (Lindsay), of St. Louis, and Louisa B. McCall (Christian), of Greenwich, and five grandchildren: Katherine and Alexander Bush, and Henry, William, and Lucinda McCall. Services of thanksgiving will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island on November 27 and at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in St Louis on December 12. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for memorial contributions to The St. Louis Art Museum, The Opera Theater of St. Louis, or The Missouri Botanical Garden. 1/3
ACKERLEY--Mildred. Loyal friend, brilliant, amusing. You remain in our hearts. Anna & Guy Longobardo 1/3

MONTGOMERY--John R.,III. John Rogerson Montgomery III, died peacefully in his home surrounded by family on November 10, 2015. Born May 16, 1930, John was the eldest son of Helen (Fyke) and John R. Montgomery. John was the third generation in his family to live in Winnetka, Illinois. He graduated from New Trier High School in 1948, Williams College in 1952, and earned his MBA at night at the University of Chicago. After college, John went to work at the Northern Trust Company. During these early years, John also served in the Korean War where he earned a bronze star. In 1966, John left the Northern Trust Company to become the first president of a new bank, Lakeside Bank, on the near Southside of Chicago. John's enthusiasm and vision as President for over 30 years was instrumental in its growth. As he used to say, "We opened the bank with 12 employees waiting for the first customers to come through the door." Today, Lakeside Bank has six branches and over a billion dollars in assets. Throughout his business career, John Montgomery was active in civic endeavors. He was especially committed to developing the near Southside of Chicago, serving as Chairman and President of the Southside Planning Board for over 30 years. He was also President of the Banker's Club of Chicago, President of the Illinois Banker's Association, and President of the Cosmopolitan Chamber of Commerce. In addition, John was involved with his alma mater and many clubs, serving as President of the Williams Class of '52, President of the University Club of Chicago, and President of Hillsboro Club in Florida. He also served for a number of years as a trustee of the John G. Shedd Aquarium. When John retired from Lakeside Bank, he continued on as Vice Chairman, on the Board of Directors, and as a member of the executive committee for many years. John was husband to Elizabeth Graham Montgomery and the late Dorothy "DeeDee" Smart Montgomery; father to John Montgomery (Lynne), DeeDee Myers (David), and Sally Jones (Ken); stepfather to William Graham and Melinda Graham; grandfather to Mari, Johnny, Jennifer, DeeDee, David, Sally, Brantner, Stephen, and Sarah; step-grandfather to Laila, Olivia, and Elizabeth; and brother to William Montgomery. The memorial service to celebrate the life of John Rogerson Montgomery III will be held on Saturday, November 28, 2015 at 4pm at the Winnetka Congregational Church, 725 Pine Street, Winnetka, IL 60093. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: Tracy M. Dana, 633 3rd Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. Please note that the gift is in memory of John R. Montgomery III. 1/3

KASTER--Lewis Ross. April 14, 1932 - November 12, 2015, of Forest Hills, New York. Our devoted father, loving grandfather, and friend "Lew," passed away on November 12, 2015. His distinguished career as a leading real estate and tax attorney commenced following his 1954 graduation from Columbia Law School, where he was a James Kent Scholar and later served as a member of the Adjunct Faculty. Career highlights included service in the U.S. Army's Judge Advocate General's Corps and serving as a partner in several law firms before retiring as of Counsel at Bryan Cave LLP. Pre- deceased by his wife, Carol (nee Goodz), he is survived by daughters Stephanie Blair Kaster and Rachel Kaster Fraser, her husband Ezra Fraser, and grandchildren Sophie and Bennett Orenstein. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Monday, November 16 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Chai Lifeline: www.chailifeline.org. 1/3

SOSEWITZ--Ben Z. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express deep regret at the loss of Ben Z. Sosewitz of Chicago, a stalwart statesman of our organization who inspired and energized us for decades. Together with his beloved late wife, Shelley, he was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of support. Mr. Sosewitz devoted decades to the various key offices he held in the ATS, from National President to Chair of the Nominating Committee and Campaign Cabinet. He was Chairman of the Technion International Board of Governors, where he was honored in 2008 with the Technion Medal - the institution's highest honor. He also received an Honorary Doctorate in 1999, and an Honorary Fellowship in 1990. In 1998, he co-founded the ATS 21st Century Leadership Development Program, which continues to this day. An indefatigable champion who loved Israel and the Technion and always challenged us to reach for excellence and greater achievements, Mr. Sosewitz leaves a great void. We offer our condolences to his daughters, Leah Sosewitz, Arna Yastrow and Miriam Sosewitz Clarke, his eight adoring grandchildren and great-granddaughter, his sisters, Sara Levin and Ida Edelson and extended family in Israel and South America and his companion, Phyllis del Gatto Caplin. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Zahava Bar-Nir, President Scott Leemaster, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

STERN--Richard Franklin, 78, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL and Fort Lee, NJ, passed away peacefully Thursday, November 5, surrounded by family. Raised in Richmond Hill, NY, Richard graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Business School, instructed in the Navy, and had a career that included working for IBM, Control Data Corp and later in financial planning and insurance with his own practice, Net Worth Planning. Richard was a "snow bird" and loved staying in New Jersey for part of the year with his family and at his permanent residence in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. In his retirement, Richard enjoyed reading, book discussion groups, travel, theater, opera and films. Richard was very proud of his children David Stern, and daughter-in-law Cindy, of Wyckoff, NJ, Laura Stern, and son-in-law David Bauhs, of Summit, NJ, as well as his six grandchildren Ben, Matt and Gabe Stern and Sophia, Adam and Sasha Bauhs. He loved hearing about and discussing all their accomplishments. Richard will be very much missed by his family that he cared so much about. Private family services were held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Temple Beth Rishon, 585 Russell Ave, Wyckoff, NJ 07481, or Congregation Ohr Shalom-Summit JCC, 67 Kent Place Boulevard, Summit, NJ 07901. 1/3

GARRETT--Sylvia Jampol, aged 97, beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great- grandmother, was born September 21, 1918 to the late Cecile and Harry Jampol of New York City. She grew up in New York City and earned a Bachelor of Arts and Masters in Education from Long Island University. Sylvia was married to Edward J. Garrett from 1939 until his death in 1982. Sylvia resided in Delray Beach, FL until her death on November 15, 2015. She remained a devoted mother to Arlene J. Blau and David B. Garrett as well as her grandchildren Stephanie, Melissa, Victoria, Kimberly and Jay and six great-grandchildren. Private funeral services will be held graveside on Tuesday, November 17th. The family will be sitting that evening from 5pm to 8:30 m at the home of Arlene and Harvey Blau; as well as Thursday, November 19th and Friday, November 20th at 12pm at the home of David and Linda Garrett. Contributions in her memory may be made to the MorseLife Foundation, Inc. morselife.org or 561-209-6103. 1/3

KASTER--Lewis. The family of Lawrence Zirinsky mourns the passing of our good friend and long time Counsel, Lewis Kaster. Starting in the late 1970's, when he was with the Javits' firm, Lew became an expert in Real Estate and Partnership Law so that he could help Larry facilitate complicated transactions and joint venture agreements. A tough negotiator with a velvet touch, Lew, as a partner at Carro, Spanbach, Robinson, Silverman and at Bryan Cave, was our family "consigliere" for almost 40 years. He concluded major transactions with Bell Labs, Prudential Insurance, Rodman Rockefeller, The New York Times, the McNallys, the Billing family and Terry Stiles - the Florida developer - as well as complex Estate matters with the IRS. No one can replace him. He will always be missed. 1/3

DAYTON--Bruce Bliss, 97, businessman, philanthropist, and community leader, died peacefully of old age November 13, 2015, at home in Long Lake, MN, surrounded by the love of his family. His wife and children and grandchildren are so moved by and grateful for the magnificent tributes and outpouring of love for Bruce Dayton in so many forms over the past few days. They know that he also would be deeply touched. A Service in Celebration of the Life of Bruce Bliss Dayton will be held Thursday, November 19, at 4pm at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1200 Marquette Ave., Minneapolis, MN. Those who cannot attend may take part online at westminstermpls.org (click Live Stream at the top of the screen). Memorials preferred to the Minneapolis Institute of Art or a charity of the donor's choice. 1/3

BLACK--Judy. We will miss your humor, wisdom, warmth generosity, style and love. We are grateful to you for opening our eyes to see the beauty around us. Your Connecticut friends, Carolyn, Ella, Harriet, Lois, Marlene & Sue. 1/3

STEINBERG--Steven, third generation owner of New York Central Art Supply, the oldest art supply store in the United States, passed away on November 15, 2015 from complications due to Parkinson's Disease, a few weeks short of his 80th birthday. Known for his boundless energy, he thrived on connecting people and projects in life and in work. In addition to art and the many artists he worked with, his passions were fishing, tennis, and most of all, music. He is survived by his loving wife, Diiana; daughter, Barrie, and her husband, Paul; son, Douglas, and his wife, Nicole; grandchildren, Alexandra, Danielle, Hudson, and Gemma; and his two best canine companions, Ollie and Gaelie. There will be a graveside service on November 17 at 1pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery on Long Island and a memorial service to be held at the National Arts Club at a later date. Donations can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation www.michaeljfox.org or to VNSNY Haven Hospice www.vnsny.org. 1/3

PADANG--Achmad Djainal, an Indonesian former Director Level-2 of the United Nations Center for Science and Technology for Development passed away on a Thursday of November 12, 2015. He was 86 years old. Born in Seram and raised in Ujung Pandang, he studied at Universitas Nasional where he obtained a Ford Scholarship and was invited to attend Columbia University in New York City, where he obtained his Masters of Arts in Political Science. He was a PhD candidate in International Relations when he was requested to join the United Nations where he spent his lifetime career. Upon his retirement, he was assigned by the United Nations Secretary General to Cambodia as an ambassador during the reconciliation period after the CambodianVietnamese War. A strong fixture within the Indonesian community of New York, he was the most prominent and one of the first members who initiated the Indonesian Muslim Community's Al Hikmah Mosque in Long Island City where he served as an honorary chairman. 1/3

MARKS--Dorothy, beloved daughter of Judge Leah Marks. Beloved mother of Alexander, Crystal and Michael. Adored sister of Marian and Scott Bruckel. Services: noon, Wednesday, November 18, Greenwich, CT. 1/3

BLACK--Judy. Far too soon, we have lost a loyal friend and a gracious worker for all that is beautiful and significant in life. We recall Judy's encouragement in the creation and activities of The Tree of Life Fellowship and of Media Judaica. We extend deepest condolences to Leon and Debra Black and to Richard Schlosberg. Rabbi Jonathan D. Levine 1/3

JUSTMAN--Daniel. Age 89, died on November 15 at home. Born in Brooklyn, he was raised in Denver, CO, and spent happy years at the National Home for Jewish Children. He served in the Navy during World War II as a radio technician at sea. After graduating from the University of Colorado School of Medicine, he completed his psychiatric training at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at Columbia University. He was a member of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute and was a practicing psychoanalyst for many years in New York City. Dan was also an accomplished tennis player. He was much loved by his wife of 47 years, Zuzana; Jessica and Alex, the children from his previous marriage to Helga Justman Miklos, and their spouses, Jack Lerner and Sandy Hoch Justman; step-sons David and Philip Boroff and Philip's partner, Michelle Kaske; and his grandchildren Eli, Michael and Claire. Services are Wednesday, November 18, 11:15am, Riverside Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave. at 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

SALISBURY--William Randall. Born April 24, 1940, in Orange, NJ. Died November 14, 2015, in Woodbridge CT. Bill earned a B.A. in 1962 from St. John's College in Annapolis, MD. As a Root Tilden Scholar at New York University School of Law, he earned an LLB degree in 1965 and an LLM in International Law the following year, while working at a New York City law firm. Bill joined the United States Department of State as a Foreign Service Officer in 1967, specializing in Political Affairs. He worked with the Office of the Legal Adviser at the State Department, and with the Office of Legal Counsel to the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. He was at one time Chairman of the Secretary of State's Open Forum Panel and Chair of the American Foreign Service Association's Legal Committee. Following his retirement from the Foreign Service, Bill worked as an actor in Washington area theaters and in TV and film. He moved to Woodbridge, CT in 2003, where he lived with his partner, Ruth Sachs. He regularly attended classes at Yale University in philosophy and classical history. Bill leaves his ex-wife Diane of Washington, DC; a son, Randall, of Washington, and a daughter, Avery, who lives in Manhattan. He also leaves two sisters, Jean Gill, of Oakdale, NY, and Sue Lauderbaugh, of Jacksonville, AL, and a brother, Jim, of Los Angeles, CA. His memorial service will be private. 1/3

HIGGINS--Francis "Lenny" Passed away at his home in River Vale, NJ on November 13th at age 87, surrounded by his loving family. He is survived by his beloved wife Kathleen Higgins of 60 years and his four children, Kitty Higgins, Leonard Higgins, Maura Higgins and Eileen Babikian, and 12 grandchildren. He retired from The New York Times and was President of the New York Newspaper Pressmen's Union. He was a Permanent Ordained Deacon in the Catholic Church. Visiting Thursday, November 19th 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Becker Funeral Home in Westwood, NJ. Funeral Mass Friday, November 20th at 11am at Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, New York New York 10017. 1

WALDER--Helene A.,beloved mother of Nancy and Barbara, passed away on November 17, 2012 at the age of 92. She was a successful business woman, accomplished bridge player and dear friend. She was known for her keen wit and wry sense of humor. In her later years, she was an active member of the 92nd Street Y. Her family and friends dearly miss her. As a remembrance, contributions may be sent to UJA/Federation. Nancy and Barbara Walder 1/3

SHARP--Phyllis, of Bronxville, NY, on November 15, 2015. Beloved wife of Don Sharp, loving mother of John. Phyllis was a graduate of Dennison University. She was a lifelong Democrat and past chair of The Bronxville Democratic Committee. She was campaign chair of Don's election as a Village of Bronxville Trustee, the fourth Democrat elected in the village. She served many years as a chair of Columbia College Parents Committee. Phyllis was a devoted member of The Bronxville High School Class of '48, keeping track of the class and hosting many reunion gathering's at her home including the record breaking 65th Reunion with a special trolley ride around the village. She was a lover of cats from her childhood to her current favorite Kerry. A memorial service will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY on Saturday, November 21st at 1:30pm. Donations may be made to Pet Assistance (PO Box 2015, New Preston, CT, 06777). 1/3

SHIKLER--Aaron A. Davis & Langdale Company, New York, mourns the loss of distinguished painter and portraitist Aaron A. Shikler (1922- 2015) on November 12, 2015. Davis & Langdale Company has proudly represented Mr. Shikler since 1952 and extends its condolences to his daughter Cathy Shikler van Ingen and his son Clifford Shikler; his son-in-law and daughter-in-law; and his granddaughter and four grandsons. Cecily Langdale Davis, President 1/3

GARRETT--Sylvia Jampol, aged 97, beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great- grandmother, was born September 21, 1918 to the late Cecile and Harry Jampol of New York City. She grew up in New York City and earned a Bachelor of Arts and Masters in Education from Long Island University. Sylvia was married to Edward J. Garrett from 1939 until his death in 1982. GREENBAUM--Carol. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Carol Greenbaum, and extends sincere sympathy to her husband and other members of her family. Jeffrey B. Lane President Warren J. Spector, Secretary 1/3

ZIGELBAUM--Marcia E.,86, longtime resident of Kings Point, NY, after a long illness. Beloved wife of 66 years of Leonard. Adored mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Daughter: the late Wendie Ravner (Harvey). Son-in-law: Harvey Ravner (Lynn). Daughter: Nancy. Grandson: Marc R. Ravner (Dana T.). Granddaughter: Samantha R. Platt (Jordan E.). She had long experience as a psychotherapist, especially for underprivileged patients. Loved by all who knew her, including her immediate and extended family, and a wide circle of friends of longstanding. 1/3

Survived by his much- beloved wife of 68 years, Bertha; children Andrea and John Campion, Michael and Tracie Waxman, and Elizabeth Waxman; grandchildren Paul and Deepti Campion, Gabriel Campion, Camille Campion, and Sarah Waxman; great-grandchild Avi Campion. ZIGELBAUM--Marcia. We will all miss your keen mind, grace and beauty. You will always be in our hearts. The Zellers 1/3
GARRETT--Sylvia. Our beloved great-grandmother. You will always be in our hearts. Love forever, Nicole and Danielle Kramer 1/3

BLACK--Judy Ellen, 67, died after a long illness on Sunday, November 15, 2015 in Washington, Connecticut, where she lived. Her loving husband of 29 years, Richard Schlosberg, and her brother, Leon Black, his wife Debra, and their four children Benjamin, Joshua, Alexander, and Victoria deeply mourn her loss. Born in New York City on September 27, 1948, she lived in New York City as well as Washington, Connecticut and Manalapan, Florida. In New York City, she attended the Ramaz School, the Fieldston School and graduated from Barnard College in 1970. She later graduated with a Master's Degree in Art History from the New York Institute of Art, a Master's Degree from the Bank Street School of Education and a Master of Business Administration from Columbia Business School in New York City. She and her husband were passionate and involved in creating gardens and deeply committed to promoting environmental conservation. She was predeceased by her mother, Shirley Black Kash, who passed away in 2014 and her father, Eli M. Black, who passed away in 1975. 1/3

KASTER--Lewis. The family of Lawrence Zirinsky mourns the passing of our good friend and long time Counsel, Lewis Kaster. Starting in the late 1970's, when he was with the Javits' firm, Lew became an expert in Real Estate and Partnership Law so that he could help Larry facilitate complicated transactions and joint venture agreements. A tough negotiator with a velvet touch, Lew, as a partner at Carro, Spanbach, Robinson, Silverman and at Bryan Cave, was our family "consigliere" for almost 40 years. He concluded major transactions with Bell Labs, Prudential Insurance, Rodman Rockefeller, The New York Times, the McNallys, the Billing family and Terry Stiles - the Florida developer - as well as complex Estate matters with the IRS. No one can replace him. He will always be missed. 1/3

ZIGELBAUM--Marcia E. Much loved part of our lives since 1964, and our companion, with husband, Leonard, on many wonderful and extensive trips. Warm surrogate mother to our whole family. The world is a much duller place now without her. Ellen and Myron Conovitz 1/3

O'HARA--F. Peter, 79, longtime resident of Larchmont, on November 15, 2015. Born in Norwich, NY to Mary Elizabeth Byrne and Frederic John O'Hara. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont. Mass at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont, 11am on November 19, 2015. Memorial contributions to The Winton and Patricia Tolles Scholarship at Hamilton College. HUDSON--Milton Willard, 88, (1927-2015) economist, of New York City and Washington DC, died peacefully on November 6, 2015 in Zurich University Hospital, Switzerland of Myelodysplastic Syndrome. He is survived by his wife, Caroline Anstey, sons Robert Hudson, James Hudson, Oliver Anstey Hudson, Calder Anstey Hudson; grandchildren David Hudson, Ryan Hudson, Brent Hudson, Lindsey Hudson and Thomas Hudson. His ashes will be scattered at sea in a private ceremony. 1/3

HARRIS--Alvin H.,MD, on November 13, 2015. Beloved husband of Maryann, loving father of Patty and Michael Chernick, Jonathan and Andee. Cherished grandfather of Joshua, Zachary, Avery and Eden. Services Tuesday, November 17, 2015 at 11:30am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

FRASER--Thomas Andrew, died peacefully, surrounded by his family on November 14, 2015. He was the only child of Margaret (Stevenson) and Thomas Fraser. He was born and raised in Riverdale, New York. Tom is survived by his loving wife of 62 years, Enid (Bazel) Fraser; his children, Michele (Terry) Geller, Suzanne Fisher, and Stuart (Elise) Fraser; grandchildren, Ryan, Kimberly, Katie, Kelly, Lauren, Thomas, Scott, Samantha and Tyler; great- grandchildren, Lyla, Cailin, Amitai, Charlotte, Blake, Mylo, Ya'ara, Thomas and Locklyn. He graduated from the School of Industrial Arts in NYC and attended Pratt Institute. He served in the U.S. Army from 1950-1953, in the Army of Occupation, 62nd AAA Division, 7th Army, in Europe. He met his loving wife, Enid, in 1953, and they married later that year. Tom and Enid were married for 62 years, always together and "in love." Tom began his career in advertising on Madison Avenue, eventually moving to Indiana, then St. Louis, Missouri. He worked for various firms including Grey Advertising, Stuart and Gunn, Gardner, Mary Wells and his own firm, Fraser Design. Tom was an expert in package design and created such iconic works as the Brillo Box, Parliament Cigarettes, Jack Daniels Whisky, Korbel Champagne and many others. He received numerous Cleo and Leo Awards for advertising excellence throughout his career. Tom was a man who led by example--a great husband, father, grandfather, great- grandfather, a great friend, and a true gentleman. He will be irreplaceable in our lives and will be greatly missed. A Celebration of Life will be held at a later date. Kindly make contributions in Tom's name to Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester, 1025 Westchester Avenue, Suite 200, White Plains, NY 10604 and www.harlemrbi.org/ donation. 1/3

ACKERLEY--Mildred Clegg. Born in Floral Park, New York on June 21, 1933, died peacefully surrounded by her children in her home in Floral Park on Friday, November 13, 2015. Dedicated educator and family matriarch, she was a generous friend and mentor to many. Beloved wife of the late James Albert Ackerley and the late Leland Drennen Ackerley. Devoted mother of Dr. Mary Beth Ackerley (Alexander Casler) of Tucson, Arizona; Robert Ackerley (Nora Smith) of Houston, Texas; Leland Ackerley (Carmen DalPont) of Houston, Texas; Anne Ackerley (David Lewis) of Riverdale, New York; and Margaret Ackerley (Mark Bollinger) of McLean, Virginia. Adored grandmother to Benjamin, Sydney and Eve Ackerley; Alexis, Andrew, Leland and Will Ackerley; Jack and Juliet Lewis; and James and Caroline Bollinger. Caring sister of Frances Feeney, Mary Anne Clegg, John Clegg, Alice Wolfteich, and Paul Clegg; preceded in death by her brothers Ambrose Clegg and George Clegg. Mildred taught Mathematics at New Hyde Park Memorial High School, New Hyde Park, New York, for thirty years where she served as Advisor to the National Honor Society, Director of Student Activities, and Sewanhaka Central High School District Coordinator of Talented and Gifted Programs. Before becoming a teacher, Mildred served as a mathematician at the George C. Marshall Space Center in Huntsville, Alabama and with the American Bosch Arma Corp. in Carle Place, New York. She was elected Alumni Trustee of Adelphi University, Garden City, New York, 1967-1970; served as Vice President of the Friends of the Floral Park Library; Membership Chairperson of the Sewanhaka Federation of Teachers, Retired; and Board Member of the Nassau North Retired Teachers Association. In 2002, she was honored by Delta Gamma Fraternity for fifty years of membership and service. Family and friends may call Thursday between 5pm to 9pm at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, New York. A funeral service Friday 11am at the United Methodist Church of Floral Park, 35 Verbena Avenue, Floral Park. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make a donation to the Friends of the Floral Park Library or to the Mildred Clegg Ackerley Scholarship Fund at Adelphi University. She was a force of nature and a loving presence in all our lives; we will miss her dearly. 1/3

MARKS--Dorothy, beloved daughter of Judge Leah Marks. Beloved mother of Alexander, Crystal and Michael. Adored sister of Marian and Scott Bruckel. Services will be announced. 1/3

GEBHARDT--John C.,90, died Sunday, October 18th, 2015 in Cortland, NY. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on February 19th, 1925 where he grew up. At the age of 15 he met his wife of 67 years, Frances S. Gebhardt, who predeceased him in 2011. After her death he remained in Manhattan in the apartment they shared for over 40 years. He loved (and was loved by) his friends, neighbors, building staff, and many local shopkeepers who were all invaluable to his quality of life. He wanted all to know that the most important thing in his life was his family. He felt fortunate to be with them in his final days. He is survived by his daughter Claudia (Syracuse), son Jeff and his wife Gonda (Cortland), seven grandchildren - Dana (Stefan Jakowenko), Lynn (Colin McEvoy), Aiyana, Taimah, Naomi, Maya, and Kaylee, two great-grandchildren Connor and Alexa, and his sister Anna Mae Watson (Plainview). He was greatly influenced by his time in the Army as a navigator during WWII on "The Princess Pat," a B24 Liberator with the 458th Bomb Group. He was proud of his service, but sorry that so many innocents were killed. He returned home a pacifist. A 35 year teaching career at Wingate (Brooklyn), Bayside (Queens), and Assistant Principal of English at Fort Hamilton (Brooklyn) high schools earned him the respect of fellow staff and students alike. His influence was evident as many of his students became writers; and the teachers who worked with him remained in touch, long after retirement. He published a book on teaching Shakespeare, which was used in all New York City classrooms for years, and is in the Library of Congress. For Shakespeare's 400th birthday he made a "cake" out of wood with 400 candles. He was glad that he didn't burn anything down. He was grateful to the many people who were so kind to him, especially after his wife, Fran, died. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, and all who knew him. Calling hours will be from 1:00-2:15pm on Saturday, November 21st at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, in New York City. A celebration of John's life will follow at 2:30pm. 1/3

Memorials preferred to the Minneapolis Institute of Art or a charity of the donor's choice. 1/3

CURRY--Beth Rivers, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on Monday, surrounded by her family. Raised on a farm in Chesterfield, SC, the first of five children, she grew up feeding chickens and exploring the hills nearby. She attended Queens College in Charlotte, graduating as student body president and valedictorian. Beth married, raised her family, and then, when her children were older, returned to Queens for business school. Soon after, she co-founded Eagle Capital Management in New York, now a $25 billion investment firm, which manages money for families, universities, foundations, and pension funds. Even as she helped build a large investment firm and sat on the boards of many institutions, Beth remained true to her South Carolina values. Eschewing the combative, confrontational style of high finance, she brought a purposeful, friendly, common-sense skepticism to Wall Street. Her disarming southern accent and small stature masked a probing, persistent, analytic intelligence. She had a wide, warm and genuine curiosity of everyone she met--from CEOs to cab drivers to strangers' children--and took as much pleasure stumbling upon a strange mushroom or beautiful moss growing in the woods as discovering new investment opportunities. Her sensitivity to every individual helped the Eagle staff challenge each other without fracture for 27 years in an industry sometimes characterized by short-term relationships and rapid turnover. Beth sometimes regretted not being a scientist and later in life took great pleasure in spending time with researchers at Weill Cornell Medical College and Rockefeller University, on whose boards she served. She was grateful to Queens for helping her make the transition from homemaker to financial executive; she served as a trustee of the college, starting in 1986 and received their Algernon Sydney Sullivan Award in 2008. In 1995 she joined the board of the Hyde and Watson Foundation, providing capital to hundreds of arts, education, healthcare, and social service organizations. Church community has always been an important part of Beth's life, and most recently she was a trustee at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Before entering the workforce, she was a devoted community volunteer who helped build the Summit Childcare Center, New Jersey's first modern infant care and pre-K facility for working mothers. Above all, Beth was a great storyteller and wit, inherited from her father and cultivated in a large Southern farm family. She could transfix friends and family by turning some small forgettable moment into an unforgettable yarn. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, Ravenel Boykin Curry III, who was also her business partner for 27 years; her three children, Ravenel Boykin Curry IV, Caroline Rivers Curry (Rob Davis), and Marshall Anderson Curry (Elizabeth Martin); her seven grandchildren, Ravenel V, Zinnia, Wick, Jackson, Quinton, Jane and Rivers; and her siblings, Jay Rivers (Cathryn), Rebecca Sullivan (Burr) and Melinda Ford (Tommy). She was predeceased by her sister Carolyn Query. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 23 at 11:15am at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to: Weill Cornell Medicine; The Rockefeller University; or Queens University of Charlotte. 1/3

RODWIN--Stanley, of Rochester and Scottsville, N.Y.,loving father, husband, and true friend to so many, passed away peacefully Saturday, November 14th, 2015 at the age of 87, after a brief illness. He was also a considerate businessman and mentor and served his country in the US Army. He was a dedicated leader of the Cornell University Class of 1950, was elected a life member of the Cornell University Council, and was active in many civic and community organizations in Scottsville and Rochester. He is predeceased by his wife Betty Mae and is survived by his four children Andrew Rodwin (Sedalia, CO), Katie Rodwin Sherman (Sharon, MA), Victoria Rodwin Ferentz (Cumberland, ME), and Brian Rodwin (New York, NY), their spouses, seven grandchildren, loving sister Carole and brother-in-law Richard Wagner, and his beloved Joyce Underberg of Rochester. Gifts in Stan's memory may be made to Cornell University, Stan Rodwin Memorial Fund, Cornell Alumni Affairs, attention: Holly Heitzman, 130 E. Seneca Street, Suite 400, Ithaca, New York 14850; or to the Scottsville Free Library, 28 Main Street, Scottsville, NY 14546. 1/3

CURRY--Elizabeth Rivers. Weill Cornell Medicine is deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend and benefactor Elizabeth Rivers Curry. An Overseer since 2012, Beth was an esteemed and dedicated leader, serving as Vice Chair of the Student Affairs and Education Committee and as a member of the Government Relations and Community Affairs Committee. Beth was committed to advancing scientific discovery - a legacy that will endure through the groundbreaking work conducted by the renowned investigators recruited with her generosity. We are honored to have enjoyed her friendship, benevolence, immense charm and strong values. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband Ravenel Boykin III, her sons Ravenel Boykin IV and Marshall Anderson, her daughter Caroline, and their family and friends. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medicine Jessica M. Bibliowicz, Chairman, Board of Overseers 1/3

JUSTMAN--Daniel. Age 89, died on November 15 at home. Born in Brooklyn, he was raised in Denver, CO, and spent happy years at the National Home for Jewish Children. He served in the Navy during World War II as a radio technician at sea. After graduating from the University of Colorado School of Medicine, he completed his psychiatric training at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at Columbia University. He was a member of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute and was a practicing psychoanalyst for many years in New York City. Dan was also an accomplished tennis player. He was much loved by his wife of 47 years, Zuzana; brother David Justman of Denver; Jessica and Alex, the children from his previous marriage to Helga Justman Miklos, and their spouses, Jack Lerner and Sandy Hoch Justman; step-sons David and Philip Boroff and Philip's partner, Michelle Kaske; and his grandchildren Eli, Michael and Claire. Services will be held on Wednesday, November 18, 11:15am, Riverside Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave. at 76 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

CURRY--Elizabeth Rivers. The trustees, faculty, staff and students of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our cherished trustee Elizabeth Rivers Curry. Beth had a deep curiosity about science and a passion for learning about the work of our investigators. Our scientists treasured their friendships with Beth and relished her delight in discovery. A friend of the University since the 1990s, Beth Curry joined The Rockefeller University Council in 2008 and was elected to the Board of Trustees in 2013, serving on a number of Board committees, including Finance & Operations, Hospital, and Audit. Beth's thoughtful and deeply engaged participation in the work of these committees and her dedication to advancing scientific research greatly strengthened the University. With her husband, Rockefeller University Council member Ravenel Boykin Curry III, Beth provided generous support that touched many facets of life at the University. A cofounder with Ravenel of Eagle Capital Management, Beth was an astute investor and a talented fund manager who contributed enormously to the firm's success. Like her husband and children, Beth shared the fruits of this success through a commitment to philanthropy and pro bono work. One of the kindest, warmest, most gracious people in the University's orbit, Beth added much to the culture and community at Rockefeller. She will be profoundly missed by all of us whose lives she touched. We send our heartfelt condolences to Beth's beloved husband, Ravenel; her three children, Boykin, Caroline, and Marshall, and their spouses; her adored grandchildren; and her entire family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry Coller, Physician-in-Chief & VP for Medical Affairs 1/3

(Susan) Kovarick; as well as a sister-in- law, Eleanor Blondin, a brother-in-law, Winton Walbridge, and his loving nieces and nephews. A private memorial service will be held for the family. SCARF--Herbert Eli, age 85, of New Haven, CT and Sag Harbor, NY, died peacefully in his home in Sag Harbor with his family by his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, best-selling author Maggie Scarf; his daughter Martha Samuelson, her husband Paul, and their sons Charlie, Tom and David; his daughter Betsy Stone, her husband Mike, and their children Deborah, Sarah and Daniel, and his daughter Susan Merrell, her husband Jim, and their children Maggie and Jake. Herb was a Sterling Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University, where he taught for over 50 years. Herb received numerous professional recognitions and awards, including being named a member of the American Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Sciences, and receiving both the Frederick Lanchester Award and the John von Neumann medal from the Operations Research Society of America. He was recognized as a Distinguished Fellow of the American Economics Association in 1991. He was recognized in many Nobel prize citations including those of Gerard Debreu and Lloyd Shapley for his ground breaking contributions to economics. He was a mentor to generations of Ph.D. students and enjoyed daily coffee with his colleagues at Yale's Cowles Foundation. Herb was an early feminist. The accomplishments of his wife and his daughters were so important to him, and he basked in their various successes. Herb had a huge number of interests, including foreign travel, music, and art. He went everywhere and listened to everything. Herb touched so many people and helped them in their lives. We will miss him immensely. There will be a celebration of Herb's life early in 2016 at Yale. 1/3

FLICKINGER--Thomas Radcliffe. 83, passed away peacefully at his home in Sea Island, GA, on Sunday morning, November 15, 2015. Tom leaves his wife of 61 years, nee Phoebe Raymond, his brother William S. Flickinger of East Amherst, NY, and four children: Wendy Ross, of Katonah, NY, Geoffrey Flickinger of North Kingstown, RI, Thomas Flickinger of Winnetka, IL, Holly Williams of Durham, NC, and 13 grandchildren. Born in Buffalo, NY on July 11, 1932 to Glenn and Awdry Flickinger, Tom attended Nichols School and graduated from Kimball Union Academy in Meriden, NH in 1950 and Harvard University in 1954. After serving in the United States Army in France, he returned to Buffalo to join S. M. Flickinger, Inc., the family food wholesaling and distribution company, which became one of the largest companies in Western New York and the biggest private employer in the city of Buffalo. He ultimately became Vice President of Purchasing and Director of Quality Assurance, responsible for all products packaged and sold under the Red & White label, the first full-line private label brand in the country, started by his grandfather, Smith Michael Flickinger. Tom's charitable work in Buffalo was extensive. He served on the board of the SPCA Serving Erie County and was President for five years. He was also a trustee of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, the Buffalo Museum of Science, the International Institute of Buffalo, the Buffalo Public Library, the Buffalo Zoo and the Food Bank of Western New York, which he helped establish in 1978 with his cousin Burt P. Flickinger, Jr. He was on the Vestry of Trinity Episcopal Church and the board of the Saturn Club where he was Dean in 1992. Tom was on the board of Kimball Union Academy for 21 years, was Chairman for two years and where one of his proudest achievements was the establishment of the Flickinger Arts Center. In addition, he was a trustee of The Nichols School in Buffalo, where he and his family also endowed the Arts Center bearing the Flickinger name. Upon moving to Sea Island, Tom became a trustee of the Coastal Georgia Historical Society, the St. Simon's Land Trust, the Coastal Youth Symphony, and served on the board of the Sea Island Property Owners Association. For almost 40 years, Tom and Penny kept a summer residence in Lorraine, Ontario, and they also spent many summer months at her family house, "Riven Rock," in Jamestown, RI. An avid jazz aficionado, Tom's jazz collection was legendary, his knowledge of musicians and songs encyclopedic and he had a special appreciation of the music of Oscar Peterson and Count Basie. Tom was also a passionate California wine collector, with a highly refined palate and a detailed knowledge of wineries, varietals and vintages. Tom played interscholastic hockey and baseball, and golf and tennis all his life. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, November 21, 2015, at Trinity Episcopal Church, 371 Delaware Avenue, in Buffalo, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the SPCA Serving Erie County or the St. Simon's Land Trust. A memorial service will also be held at Christ Church, St. Simon's Island, GA, at 11am on Tuesday, December 1, 2015. 1/3

ZUMOFF--Selma, (nee Silver) was born on February 28, 1928, and died on November 17, 2015. She was educated in the New York City public and high schools and graduated from Brooklyn College. She married Barnett Zumoff on November 11, 1951. Selma and Barney Zumoff had three daugthers: Janine (Yokheved) Cammarata-Katomski, Francine Deborah (Feygl Dvoyre) Zumoff, and Linda Irene (Leah Yael) Zumoff, four grand-daughers: Cindy Lynn (Khava Leah) Cammarata, Michelle Marie (Malke Miriom) Cammarata- LaGroue, Uta Briggs, and Kaydia Wren (Shoshana Ora) Briggs, and a great-granddaughter: Avalynn Isla LaGroue. Aside from being the best wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother anyone could wish for or imagine, Selma was beloved by everyone who knew her. She was interested in and highly active in Workmen's Circle affairs: she was the longtime farvaltung-chairman of the Midwood Arbeter-Ring shule, which was held for a long time in the basement of her house, and she was highly active for a long time in the Workmen's Circle Division of ORT. She was beautiful, charming, and bright and loved to read, especially novels and crime fiction. She loved her family intensely and they loved her. COWAN--Louise. Louise Cowan, university teacher and nationally recognized leader in humanities education, passed away Monday, November 16, in Dallas. She was 98. Dr. Cowan taught for fifty-three years at the University of Dallas, where she was chair of the English department, dean of graduate studies, University Professor, and the first occupant of the Louise Cowan Chair in Humanities. With her husband Donald Cowan, physicist and president of the university from 1962 to 1977, she worked steadily to build an internationally recognized university with a core curriculum based in the Western classics. She and political philosopher Willmoore Kendall founded the university's Institute of Philosophic Studies, a unique combination of doctoral programs in disciplines centered on the study of core texts, and she directed its growth. The dual focus of Dr. Cowan's life--on building the good city and educating to the fullest all the members of that city was expressed in her founding, along with her husband and four other intellectual leaders, the Dallas Institute of Humanities and Culture in 1980 to bring the life of the mind into dialogue with the city. She then conceived of and initiated the Teachers Academy at the institute in 1983, a program for Dallas public school teachers that from 1984-87 was funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities, which cited it as a "model for the nation." In July 2015 the Teachers Academy, which is now part of the larger Cowan Center for Education, conducted its 32nd consecutive Summer Institute for Teachers. For her work with this institute and her other contributions to the teaching of the classics, she received the Arete Award from the city of Dallas in 1965; the Dallas Historical Society's Award in the Humanities in 1980, and in 1991 the Charles Frankel Prize (now the National Humanities Award), the nation's highest award for work in the humanities, awarded in the White House. In 2010 she was named one of two women on the list of the 20 most brilliant living Christian professors. Born in Fort Worth, Dr. Cowan received her B.A. and M.A. from Texas Christian University and her Ph.D. in 1953 from Vanderbilt University, where she wrote her dissertation on the group of Southern poets and critics who dominated the national literary scene for several decades. She was widely recognized for the book published from her dissertation, The Fugitive Group, still considered an indispensable document for understanding the Southern Renascence that began in the 1920s. She was author also of The Southern Critics and editor of, among other volumes, Invitation to the Classics (with Os Guinness), Classic Texts and the Nature of Authority (with Donald Cowan), and The Terrain of Comedy, and general editor of the series The Genres of Literature. She was acclaimed as a teacher throughout the country and noted for her teaching of Shakespearean tragedy and comedy and twentieth- century Southern literature, as well as the novels of Dostoevsky, Faulkner, and Caroline Gordon. In 2014 she spoke on Southern culture at the University of the South upon being awarded an honorary Doctor of Letters. She continued her work in teaching and lecturing through her 99th year, presenting her last lecture, on the vocation of teaching, two months ago. Her belief was that great literature (Homer, Virgil, Aeschylus, Dante, Shakespeare) is the birthright of every American and that, as an integral part of democracy's very foundation, it provides an education necessary for all. In all, Louise Cowan's life and work in literature and teaching constituted an original, abiding contribution to American culture. She was preceded in death by her husband Donald, parents Will and Ouita Shillingburg, sister Doris Shillingburg, granddaughter Lucy, and granddaughter-in-law Aimee. She is survived by her son Bainard and his wife, Christine; grandchildren Claire Barbetti, Will, Donald, Elizabeth Wells, Michael, Veronica Phair, and Glencora Pipkin; twelve great-grandchildren; and thousands of students whose minds and hearts she won. Services will be at Christ the King Catholic Church, Dallas. In lieu of flowers, she wished that contributions be made to the Donald and Louise Cowan Scholarship Fund of the Braniff Graduate School, University of Dallas. Contributions may be made at alumni.udallas.edu/cowan memorial. 1/3

CURRY--Elizabeth (Beth) Rivers, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on Monday, surrounded by her family. Raised on a farm in Chesterfield, SC, the first of five children, she grew up feeding chickens and exploring the hills nearby. She attended Queens College in Charlotte, graduating as student body president and valedictorian. Beth married, raised her family, and then, when her children were older, returned to Queens for business school. Soon after, she co- founded Eagle Capital Management in New York, now a $25 billion investment firm, which manages money for families, universities, foundations, and pension funds. Even as she helped build a large firm and sat on the boards of many institutions, Beth remained true to her South Carolina values. Eschewing the combative, confrontational style of high finance, she brought a purposeful, friendly, common- sense skepticism to Wall Street. Her disarming southern accent and small stature masked a probing, persistent, analytic intelligence. She had a wide, warm and genuine curiosity about everyone she met--from CEOs to cab drivers to strangers' children-- and took as much pleasure stumbling upon a strange mushroom or beautiful moss growing in the woods as discovering new investment opportunities. Her sensitivity to every individual helped the Eagle staff challenge each other without fracture for 27 years in an industry often characterized by short-term relationships and rapid turnover. Beth sometimes regretted not being a scientist and later in life enjoyed spending time with researchers at Weill Cornell Medical College and Rockefeller University, on whose boards she served. She was grateful to Queens for helping her make the transition from homemaker to financial executive; she served as a trustee of the college, starting in 1986 and received their Algernon Sydney Sullivan Award in 2008. In 1995 she joined the board of the Hyde and Watson Foundation, providing capital to hundreds of arts, education, healthcare, and social service organizations. Church community has always been an important part of Beth's life, and most recently she was a trustee at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Before entering the workforce, she was a devoted community volunteer who helped build the Summit Childcare Center, New Jersey's first modern infant care and pre-K facility for working mothers. Above all, Beth was a great storyteller and wit, inherited from her father and cultivated in a large Southern farm family. She could transfix friends and family by turning some small forgettable moment into an unforgettable yarn. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, Ravenel Boykin Curry III, who was also her business partner for 27 years; her three children, Ravenel Boykin Curry IV, Caroline Rivers Curry (Rob Davis), and Marshall Anderson Curry (Elizabeth Martin); her seven grandchildren, Ravenel V, Zinnia, Wick, Jackson, Quinton, Jane and Rivers; and her siblings, Jay Rivers (Cathryn), Rebecca Sullivan (Burr) and Melinda Ford (Tommy). She was predeceased by her sister Carolyn Query. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 23 at 11:15am at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to: Weill Cornell Medicine; The Rockefeller University; or Queens University of Charlotte. 1/3

HUFFARD--Edith, of Stamford and New Canaan, CT, died Monday, November 16th. Mother of five, grandmother of 14, great-grandmother of 27, Edith achieved her final goal of celebrating her 100th birthday with many family members, and died peacefully in her Edge Hill apartment, one hour later. On her terms. On her schedule. As the beloved matriarch of the large Huffard clan she inspired us with her intelligence, artistry, elegance, and above all, her enjoyment of all people and philosophies. Born in Rutherford NJ, she fell in love with Phil Huffard, married, moved often, and settled in New Canaan in 1954 to raise their five children. Throughout her long and rich life, she achieved great celebrity with her bronze and stone sculptures which enhance many art collections throughout the country. She taught us well and leaves all of us aspiring to be more like her. Edith was predeceased by her husband, Paul Phillippi Huffard, Jr., her youngest daughter, Hilary Huffard, and her eldest son, Paul Phillippi Huffard III, as well as her grandson, Wick Battin Huffard. She is survived by her daughter-in-law, Deborah Huffard of Greenwich, CT, her son and daughter-in-law, Jay and Kirk Huffard of Stamford, CT, her daughter and son-in-law, Hathaway and Robert Green of Boston, MA, and her daughter and son-in-law, Honor Stanley and Rick Gallup of Swannanoa, NC, and a much loved circle of family and friends. Donations may be made to the Huffard Family Garden at Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, MA or the Hilary Huffard Endowment Fund at Memorial Sloan Kettering, in New York City. A private family burial service was held at St. Mark's Parish on Wednesday, November 18th. 1/3

VARSOS--Norma Marie, (1925-2015) died on October 4th, 2015 as a result of septic shock. Norma Marie Varsos, the daughter of Antonio and Vittoria Violante, was born and raised in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She graduated as a pharmacist at the age of nineteen from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science, the first school of pharmacy in the United States. She worked as a pharmacist at Merck Laboratories in New Jersey and later at the Philadelphia General Hospital where she met her husband, Dr. Aristedes Varsos. They married in 1956 and raised three children in Forest Hills, New York. Dr. Aristedes Varsos died in 2003 after forty seven years of marriage. They are survived by their three children: Norma Rhea Varsos, Cynthia Dayton, and George Varsos, M.D. Dr. George Varsos lives in Queens with his wife, Carmen, and son, Matthew. He is a radiation oncology specialist and Clinical Assistant Professor at Mt. Sinai Hospital of Queens. 1/3
