BRUNO--Michael S.,M.D. 93, died on November 16, 2015 in Manhattan. For 35 years Dr. Bruno was Director of the Department of Medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital ("LHH"). He was elected to four terms as President of the Medical Board, a member of the Board of Trustees and Joint Conference Committee for 24 years, and a member of the Lenox Hill Corporation. In addition he was regarded as one of the best diagnosticians in New York while he carried out his private practice as an internist. Dr. Bruno also served as Lenox Hill's Associate Dean for Medical Education for the NYU Medical Center affiliation, a position that continued his role as a mentor and guide to future generations of physicians. When he arrived at LHH in 1966, it was regarded as a community hospital. Over the years, Dr. Bruno's passion for graduate medical education made it into one of the finest programs in New York City. His leadership was instrumental in transforming LHH to an outstanding teaching hospital and tertiary care center. This helped foster many important innovations and improvements in patient care. One example of this took place in 1978 when Dr. Bruno gave approval for Dr. Simon Stertzer to perform what was the first balloon angioplasty in the United States; he also gave him the support, encouragement and resources to develop the program, which revolutionized the care of patients with heart disease throughout the world. A native of New York City, Dr. Bruno earned his BA and MD degrees from Columbia College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons respectively. After an internship at Bellevue Hospital and service in the U.S. Army in Japan, he was discharged as Captain in 1948 and appointed Chief Resident at Bellevue Hospital with additional, significant teaching and administrative responsibilities. In 1956 at the age of 34, he became Director of the Department of Medicine at Knickerbocker Hospital in Harlem, serving as President of its Medical Board and a member of the Medical Board Executive Committee. Dr. Bruno was predeceased by his loving wife, Ida Marion Bruno in 2002, and by his brother Gregory and sister Lilian. He is survived by his loving partner, Maria Goode Schwartz, his children: Lauretta Bruno, Pamela (Charlie) Williams, Michael (Meg) Bruno, his four grandchildren: Geoff (Keridy) Williams, Mike Bruno, Russell (Spencer) Bruno and Price Bruno, and one great-grandchild: Hudson Williams. Family and friends may visit Friday, November 20 from 2-4pm, or 7-9pm at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, November 21 at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, 10 County Road, Tenafly, NJ at 9:30am. Entombment: Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 225 Ridgedale Ave., East Hanover NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Michael S. Bruno, MD Scholarship Fund at Columbia College, Office of Alumni & Development, Columbia University, Columbia Alumni Center, 622 West 113th St., New York, NY, 10025, Phone: 212-851-7965 Email: jtm2@columbia.edu, or to the Michael S. Bruno, M.D. Memorial Fund, Lenox Hill Hospital, 100 East 77th Street, New York, NY, 10017, Attn: Development Office. 1/3

CURRY--Elizabeth Rivers. The trustees, faculty, staff and students of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our cherished trustee Elizabeth Rivers Curry. Beth had a deep curiosity about science and a passion for learning about the work of our investigators. Our scientists treasured their friendships with Beth and relished her delight in discovery. A friend of the University since the 1990s, Beth Curry joined The Rockefeller University Council in 2008 and was elected to the Board of Trustees in 2013, serving on a number of Board committees, including Finance & Operations, Hospital, and Audit. Beth's thoughtful and deeply engaged participation in the work of these committees and her dedication to advancing scientific research greatly strengthened the University. With her husband, Rockefeller University Council member Ravenel Boykin Curry III, Beth provided generous support that touched many facets of life at the University. A cofounder with Ravenel of Eagle Capital Management, Beth was an astute investor and a talented fund manager who contributed enormously to the firm's success. Like her husband and children, Beth shared the fruits of this success through a commitment to philanthropy and pro bono work. One of the kindest, warmest, most gracious people in the University's orbit, Beth added much to the culture and community at Rockefeller. She will be profoundly missed by all of us whose lives she touched. We send our heartfelt condolences to Beth's beloved husband, Ravenel; her three children, Boykin, Caroline, and Marshall, and their spouses; her adored grandchildren; and her entire family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry Coller, Physician-in-Chief & VP for Medical Affairs 1/3

ZUMOFF--Selma. The Workmen's Circle mourns the loss of great friend, activist, and lifelong member, Selma Zumoff. Her supportive presence in so many WC activities remains an inspiration. Our community extends its deepest sympathy to Barney, Janine, Francine, Linda, and the entire Zumoff family. Peter Pepper, President Ann Toback, Executive Director 1/3

RODGERS--Linda. The Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization mourns the passing of Linda Rodgers. Her spirit, humor and smarts will be missed. She was the last of a generation. Condolences to Peter and the rest of the family. 1/3

GIRARD--Nicole M.,age 49, of Norwalk, CT. beloved daughter of Stephen Girard and the late Barbara Gutmacher Girard. Nicole will be remembered for her free spirit, love of animals, and passion for art and photography. Nicole loved to spend time in Woodstock, NY with her close friends. Services will be held on Sunday, November 22, 2014 at 1pm at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, NY. For information, Eden Memorial Chapels, 201-947-3336. 1/3

WARACH--Marie Sieff Norkin, on November 18, 2015. She walked in beauty. Beloved mother, grandmother "Ama," wife, aunt and friend. Her calm beauty, generosity and kindness will be remembered always. Daughter of Diena and Jacob Sieff, she had one brother, Milton Sieff. She shared with them a disposition of patience, refinement and grace. A lifelong painter, she was president of the Artist Alliance of East Hampton, NY, showed at Guild Hall and Accabonac Hall, Nabi Gallery and Gallery 16. She was a children's wear and knitwear designer, children's book author/illustrator, photographer and licensed art therapist. She was married to Sam Norkin, then Bernard Warach. She is survived by Bernard Warach, son Richard Norkin, daughter Laura Norkin Gilbert DeSena, grandsons Johan and Sam Gilbert, niece, nephew, grandniece and nephew, stepchildren and step-grandchildren. Service, Friday, November 20, 1:30pm at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Long Island. 1/3

LURIE--Alvin: LexisNexis and Matthew Bender & Co. express their sincere condolences to the family of "Al" Lurie on his recent passing. For many years, Al served as a contributing author or general editor on a variety of tax publications. He was a brilliant lawyer, gifted writer, and a very dear man. Al will be greatly missed. 1/3

SWEENEY--Catherine R.,on November 18, 2015. Beloved mother of Loretta A. Curran. Loving grandmother of Cecilia Curran and Deirdre Curran. Enjoyed over 30 year career with Western Electric/ AT&T. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, New York City, Sunday, 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 11am, at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th Street, NYC. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3

CURRY--Beth. The Board of Trustees of the New York Hall of Science honors the memory of Beth Curry, a champion of education and advocate for inspiring young people through science. For her passion, insight, dedication, and good humor, we will miss her. We share our deepest sympathy with her husband and our fellow trustee, Ravenel Curry, and her children, Boykin, Caroline and Marshall. 1/3

LIPKIN--Seymour. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Seymour Lipkin, a member of the Juilliard piano faculty from 1986 to the present, and one of the great pianists of our time. With an exceptional intellect and a gentle manner, Seymour worked with thousands of young pianists during his lifetime, giving them new insights into the art of the piano. His extraordinary artistry brought him to approach the music of Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, and many other composers with sensitivity and a profound understanding of the depth of each composition. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Ellen, and his family and friends. He will be greatly missed by us all. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Yoheved Kaplinsky, Susan W. Rose Chair of Juilliard's Piano Department 1/3

BENSON--Lawrence, a very young 70, died November 18, surrounded by his family. Beloved father, brother, grandpa, cousin, uncle, friend. An entrepreneur and a Marx Brothers aficionado, he had a too-short but full life and will be sorely missed. 1/3

WEINSTEIN--Norma Markell, 90, died peacefully on November 19, 2015 in her Manhattan home. Widow of Morris N. Weinstein; beloved mother of Peter and Emily Chaya, and the late Adam J. Weinstein. Retired professor at Fashion Institute of Technology. Known for her smarts, humor and style. Funeral Sunday, November 22, 10am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or NAMI. 1/3

STACHELBERG--Susan W.,age 82 of New York City, died peacefully on November 18. Loving wife of the late Charlie Stachelberg, devoted mother of Erica, Winnie, and Cas and adoring grandmother of Will, Charlie, and Oggie. Graduate of Connecticut College and New York University, a dancer, poet and neighborhood activist. Susan instilled in her children and grandchildren a love of nature and all things beautiful, a deep sense of civic responsibility, a passion for language, and an enduring desire to respect and value others. Donations can be made to the Fresh Air Fund in honor of Susan W. Stachelberg 1/3

ROCKOWITZ--Noah, of New Rochelle, NY, on November 19th, 2015. Husband of Julie Levitan, father of Shira, Leora and Dahlia and brother of Eli. Son of the late Anna and Murray. Noah worked as an attorney at Cahill Gordon & Reindel, Belco Petroleum Corporation and Hudson General Corporation. A leader at Beth El Synagogue, the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester, The Westchester Jewish Council and Magen David Adom. A man of outstanding accomplishments, unwavering principles and devotion to family. 1/3

SHARP--Phyllis, of Bronxville, NY, on November 15, 2015. Beloved wife of Don Sharp, loving mother of John. Phyllis was a graduate of Dennison University. She was a lifelong Democrat and past chair of The Bronxville Democratic Committee. She was campaign chair of Don's election as a Village of Bronxville Trustee, the fourth Democrat elected in the village. She served many years as a chair of Columbia College Parents Committee. Phyllis was a devoted member of The Bronxville High School Class of '48, keeping track of the class and hosting many reunion gathering's at her home including the record breaking 65th Reunion with a special trolley ride around the village. She was a lover of cats from her childhood to her current favorite Kerry. A memorial service will be held at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY on Saturday, November 21st at 1:30pm. Donations may be made to Pet Assistance (PO Box 2015, New Preston, CT, 06777). 1/3

FELDMAN--Rita. Our beloved mother passed away November 11th at the age of 88. She is survived by her sons, Richard and Robert and three grandchildren. Memorial services will be held November 22nd at 3pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

FERRO--Daniel. The congregation of Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our former cantor, who served our congregation with Rabbis Bernard Bamberger and Harvey Tattelbaum. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Joy and their family. May God comfort his loved ones and may his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President 1/3

SIROTO--Leon. July 13, 1922-November 16, 2015. Anthropologist and African art expert (PhD, Columbia University); lifelong New Yorker. Curator (Chicago's Field Museum) and professor (University of Delaware), he studied the use of masks by the BaKwele people of equatorial Africa, with whom he lived for a year on a Ford Foundation grant. Fulbright Fellow at the Musee de l'Homme, Paris. Author and advisor to the Menil Collection and others. He is survived by his former wife, Edith; daughters, Susan and Janet; and grandsons, Milo and Eli Harper-Siroto; all of New York. An intrepid and omnivorous student of all cultures, he will be remembered for his erudition, dark wit, and love of nature. 1/3

GREENE--James R. It is with sadness that Bank Leumi USA mourns the loss of former esteemed director, James R. Greene. Jim joined the board of directors in February 1984 and served until September 2012. During his many years with us, he provided great wisdom and leadership to our board and chaired the Loan Committee. His international experience allowed us to understand world markets and establish our international presence in the financial industry. We are forever grateful for his service as an integral member of our board during both difficult times and successes. Jim will be dearly missed. 1/3

KOSOWSKY--Bernard D.,MD, of Brookline, MA, suddenly on Thursday, November 19, 2015. For 55 years the devoted husband of Joyce (Steg). Beloved father of Dr. Jeffrey (Miriam) Kosowsky, Dr. Joshua (Devorah) Kosowsky, Drs. Jennifer (Dror) Michaelson and Daniel (Karen) Kosowsky. Adored grandfather of 13. Dear brother of Susan (Jacques) Gorlin. Graveside services Friday, November 20, at 9:30am at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Shiva at the late residence Saturday evening through Thursday morning. Remembrances may be made to Striar Hebrew Academy, 100 Ames St., Sharon 02067; Maimonides School, c/o Development Office, 34 Philbrick Rd., Brookline, 02445; or Westchester Day School, 856 Orienta Ave., Mamaroneck, NY 10543. 1/3

ZUMOFF--Selma. (nee Silver) was born on February 28, 1928, and died on November 17, 2015. She was educated in the New York City public and high schools and graduated from Brooklyn College. She married Barnett Zumoff on November 11, 1951. Selma and Barney Zumoff had three daugthers: Janine (Yokheved) Cammarata-Katomski, Francine Deborah (Feygl Dvoyre) Zumoff, and Linda Irene (Leah Yael) Zumoff, four grand-daughers: Cindy Lynn (Khava Leah) Cammarata, Michelle Marie (Malke Miriom) Cammarata- LaGroue, Uta Briggs, and Kaydia Wren (Shoshana Ora) Briggs, and a great-granddaughter: Avalynn Isla LaGroue. Aside from being the best wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother anyone could wish for or imagine, Selma was beloved by everyone who knew her. She was interested in and highly active in Workmen's Circle affairs: she was the longtime farvaltung-chairman of the Midwood Arbeter-Ring shule, which was held for a long time in the basement of her house, and she was highly active for a long time in the Workmen's Circle Division of ORT. She was beautiful, charming, and bright and loved to read, especially novels and crime fiction. She loved her family intensely and they loved her. Koved ir ondenk, un zol zi hobn a likhtikn gan-eydn. 1/3

VARSOS--Norma Marie, (1925-2015) died on October 4th, 2015 as a result of septic shock. A mass was performed on Saturday, November 14th at our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church in Forest Hills, New York, in honor of her memory. The celebrant of the memorial was Father Pedro Cojina Vega, who flew in from his parish in Managua, Nicaragua for the event. Father Pedro is the brother- in-law of Dr. George Varsos, the son of the deceased. Norma Marie Varsos, the daughter of Antonio and Vittoria Violante, was born and raised in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She graduated as a pharmacist at the age of nineteen from the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science, the first school of pharmacy in the United States. She worked as a pharmacist at Merck Laboratories in New Jersey and later at the Philadelphia General Hospital where she met her husband, Dr. Aristedes Varsos. They married in 1956 and raised three children in Forest Hills, New York. Dr. Aristedes Varsos died in 2003 after forty seven years of marriage. They are survived by their three children: Norma Rhea Varsos, Cynthia Dayton, and George Varsos, M.D. Dr. George Varsos lives in Queens with his wife, Carmen, and son, Matthew. He is a radiation oncology specialist and Clinical Assistant Professor at Mt. Sinai Hospital of Queens. 1/3

CHAPIN--Stephen. Stephen Tuckerman Chapin, 73, an accomplished visual artist with an uncanny talent for restoring damaged art, especially African art, died at his home in Providence on November 6. He had moved there in 2014 after almost 40 years in New York City. Steve graduated from Rhode Island School of Design, where he had the first one- man show as an undergraduate and won a Carnegie grant to spend his senior year in Rome. He went on to receive an MFA from Yale School of Art. He and his late wife, the painter Maria Scotti, were among the early artists settling in Soho. In 1983, Steve withdrew from what he saw as a treacherous art world, vowing to make the art that was in him with no thought of showing his work. For many years thereafter he worked as a restorer, amassing a list of clients who valued his keen eye and incomparable ability to repair damaged art. A memorial service will be held on November 22 at 11 am on the grounds of a home Steve and Maria cherished in Hopkinton City, RI. 1/3

SCARF--Herbert Eli, age 85, of New Haven, CT and Sag Harbor, NY, died peacefully in his home in Sag Harbor with his family by his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, best-selling author Maggie Scarf; his daughter Martha Samuelson, her husband Paul, and their sons Charlie, Tom and David; his daughter Betsy Stone, her husband Mike, and their children Deborah, Sarah and Daniel, and his daughter Susan Merrell, her husband Jim, and their children Maggie and Jake. Herb was a Sterling Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University, where he taught for over 50 years. Herb received numerous professional recognitions and awards, including being named a member of the American Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Sciences, and receiving both the Frederick Lanchester Award and the John von Neumann medal from the Operations Research Society of America. He was recognized as a Distinguished Fellow of the American Economics Association in 1991. He was recognized in many Nobel prize citations including those of Gerard Debreu and Lloyd Shapley for his ground breaking contributions to economics. He was a mentor to generations of Ph.D. students and enjoyed daily coffee with his colleagues at Yale's Cowles Foundation. Herb was an early feminist. The accomplishments of his wife and his daughters were so important to him, and he basked in their various successes. Herb had a huge number of interests, including foreign travel, music, and art. He went everywhere and listened to everything. Herb touched so many people and helped them in their lives. We will miss him immensely. There will be a celebration of Herb's life early in 2016 at Yale. 1/3
SCHULSKY--Anne. Every day Mom, Every day I love and miss you. Steve 1/3

BIRCHARD--Mary Clark, passed away in Manhattan on November 5, 2015. Born in 1937 in East Orange, NJ, Mary spent her childhood years in Wellesley, MA. Mary graduated from The Baldwin School in Pennsylvania, Wellesley College, BA 1959, Union Theological Seminary in New York City (M. Div). Most of her working career was spent at Brooklyn College, New York. Her family and many friends will miss her more than words can express. Memorial service Saturday, November 21, 2015 at 1pm at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 W. 73rd St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in her name to The Wellesley Fund, 106 Central Street, Wellesley, MA 02481. 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew. The Board and Staff of Playwrights Horizons mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Matthew Rosen. He served on the Board of Trustees for more than six years. What stands out most was his deep and genuine love for theater and the process of playwriting. He attended almost every developmental reading we did, and became a personal friend and champion to many of our writers and staff. He was smart, thoughtful and compassionate. We will remember him as a highly respected lawyer, a loving father, and a friend. Our deepest sympathies to his partner Mariana Elder and his children Anthony Elder Rosen, and Amanda and Oliver. Judith O. Rubin, Chairman Tim Sanford, Artistic Director Leslie Marcus, Managing Director Adam Greenfield, Associate Artistic Director The entire Board and Staff of Playwrights Horizons 1/3

DWYER--June S. September 17, 1944, died November 9, 2015. Scholar, writer, animal lover, she was much beloved by all who met her. Her wit and intelligence will be missed. Survived by sons Quetzal and Colin and sister Anne. 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew A.,of Manhattan and Quogue, NY passed away peacefully on November 20, 2015 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. A native of South Philadelphia, Matthew graduated from Swarthmore College (1973), Boston University Law School (1976) and New York University Law School (LLM, 1979). In 1979, he joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, where he would go on to serve as co-head of the Tax Practice for over 25 years. Matthew was known in legal and business circles for his brilliant analytic mind, his ability to solve complex legal problems and to deconstruct complicated tax analysis. Both Chambers Global and Chambers USA repeatedly named Matthew in their top tier of lawyers, and he was listed in Euromoney's Guide to the World's Leading Tax Lawyers numerous times. He was named Best Lawyers' "2013 New York City Tax Lawyer of the Year," and Legal 500 U.S. Portfolio magazine included him in its list of the top 10 tax attorneys in the United States. Matthew took immense joy in his work, but he also had an abiding passion for books, music, film and art. He was particularly committed to bringing great theater to all audiences and served on the Board of Playwrights Horizons. His mind was always active, his intellect broad and deep, his wit clever and mischievous, but his heart was always with his family to whom he was profoundly devoted and whom he always loved and supported. He is survived by his children Amanda (25), Oliver (20) and Anthony (1), his wife Mariana, and his brother Kenny. We will miss him dearly. There will be a celebration of Matthew's life at 1pm on Monday, November 23, 2015 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, NYC. 1/3

METZ--Sheril. The Meltzer family deeply regrets the passing of a dear friend. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his wife Elaine, his children Diane, Dennis, Richard and his grandchildren, great- grandchildren and the rest of his family. He was a wonderful and loving husband, father, grandfather and great grandfather. A religious man of great distinction and integrity who left his mark and was always sensitive to the needs of others. He will be deeply missed. 1/3

JUSTMAN--Daniel. The members of the NY Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourn the loss of our longtime member Dr. Daniel Justman. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew, on November 20, 2015. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our partner and friend Matthew Rosen. A co-head of our tax practice, Matthew was a rare kind of lawyer -- one of the very finest tax practitioners of his generation and an unsurpassed mentor of the generations growing up under him. He led by example and will be remembered as always supporting new talent and the expansion of the practice into new spheres. Matthew joined our New York tax team in 1979 and, building upon the culture of camaraderie he inherited, enhanced the tightly knit group's reputation exponentially. Matthew handled every aspect of tax work and developed various types of financial instruments. He was repeatedly ranked among the top practitioners of his field. Raised in South Philly, Matthew attended Swarthmore College ('73) and Boston University School of Law ('76) and received an LLM from New York University School of Law ('79). He is survived by his wife, Mariana, and his children, Amanda, Anthony and Oliver. He will be missed greatly by all of us. 1/3

FASOLINO--Theresa "Dolly", 92, born January 7, 1923 died November 17, 2015 of natural causes in Margate, FL. Born in Manhattan, NY; Mrs. Fasolino was predeceased by husband Frank Fasolino; son Frank; daughter Maria Fasolino Scheiner and granddaughter Cherie Scheiner. She is survived by grandchildren Ralph Sperandeo (son of Maria) and Nicole Fasolino Scavone (daughter of Frank). Services are being held Monday 11am at The Gardens Memorial Park in Boca Raton, FL. 1/3

CHASIN--Laura. Of Cambridge, MA, on November 17. Born October 11, 1936 in New York, NY. Beloved wife since 1971 of Richard Chasin of Cambridge, MA. Mother of Peter Gill Case of Providence, RI, Matthew Case of Chapel Hill, NC, and Jessica Case of Cody, WY. Stepmother of Dana Chasin of Washington, DC and Alexandra Chasin of Brooklyn, NY. Grandmother of eleven. She is also survived by her siblings Lucy Waletzky of Bedford, NY, Marion Weber of Bolinas, CA, and Larry Rockefeller of New York, NY. Laura Chasin grew up in Manhattan and attended the Brearley School, Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, and Bryn Mawr College in Pennsylvania where she received a B.A. in History of Art. She earned an M.A. in Government from Harvard University and an M.S.W. from Simmons College School of Social Work. Chasin served on numerous Boards including the James Jackson Putnam Children's Center of Roxbury, the Conflict Management Group, the Faith and Politics Institute, the Children's Defense Fund, the Rockefeller Family Fund, and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. She was a Life Trustee of Spelman College of Atlanta, GA. In 1989, she founded the Public Conversations Project of Watertown, MA, a non-profit organization promoting constructive dialogue on issues involving clashing values, world views, and identities, such as abortion, sexual orientation, immigration, gun safety, and religious tolerance. The Project teaches extensively and has worked on dozens of issues on four continents. The Project has been given awards by the New York State Mediators Association, the American Association of Group Psychotherapy and Psychodrama, the American Family Therapy Academy, and the American Society of Professionals in Dispute Resolution. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: publicconversations.org. The family will announce memorial services in the near future. 1/3

KATCHER--Naomi Richman Zieph, 87, on November 20. Born on the kitchen table to Lena Richman and Hyman Zieph. Our beautiful, brilliant Naomi dazzled, inspired, and occasionally exasperated, her family, students, colleagues, adoring (late) husband Edward Katcher, who thought her perfect, devoted children and myriad friends and admirers. A proud daughter of the Bronx, New Yorker, American, Feminist, Democrat, Jew, Zionist, educator, wife and mother, she lived life on her terms until the very end. She was a 1948 graduate of NYU with a masters degree in political science from Queens College, a retired chairperson of the Great Neck North Middle School English Department, a former president of NYSEC (1983), a master teacher, an artist and poet, an adjunct professor of Methods at the Hofstra School of Education, and a beloved volunteer at the International Center. Survived by her sister Jeanne (Richard) Kandel, daughter Lee (Harold Rafferty), son Saul (Bonnie Dunn), nephews and nieces, cousins Elizabeth (Jerry Balsam) and Joanne Crown and a step-granddaughter. There will be a graveside service at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont on Sunday at 11am. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John E. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of John E. Zuccotti, cherished friend and Trustee Emeritus of the University. A much-admired business and civic leader, as University Trustee Mr. Zuccotti selflessly committed his energies to helping Columbia thrive and grow in the home city that he held so dear. He served on a number of key committees, including the Committee on Building and Grounds, which he chaired. More recently, his wise counsel played no small part in successful efforts to create the University's new Manhattanville campus. The new campus will be a fitting reminder of his legacy at Columbia. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife and children, and to all who feel his loss. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John E. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of John Zuccotti, an extraordinary and devoted industry leader who served with distinction in federal and New York City government. John was First Deputy Mayor under Mayor Beame and was Chairman of the City Planning Commission under Mayor John Lindsay. He served as REBNY's Chairman from 2004-2006; in 2003 John received The Harry B. Helmsley Distinguished New Yorker Award for his exceptional career accomplishments and unique service to the community. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Susan, his children Gianna, Andrew and Milena, and the entire Zuccotti family. Rob Speyer, Chairman John Banks, President 1/3

LOWE--John Budd, Jr.,of Greenwich, CT, passed away on November 20, 2015. Mr. Lowe was born in Greenwich, CT on April 9, 1928. After graduating from Greenwich High School, and Tufts University (class of 1950), he received an MBA from Columbia University Graduate School of Business. Mr. Lowe also attended the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program from which he graduated with honors. A former Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of European American Bank, Mr. Lowe was a Certified Public Accountant, a Certified Fraud Examiner, and the former President of the Columbia Graduate School of Business Alumni Association, from which he received the Alumni Medal. Mr. Lowe was a member of Tamarack Country Club, St. Michael's Parish, the past President of St. Michael's Parish Council, a Greenwich Old Timers Association annual award recipient, the lead trombonist in the Bob Button Orchestra, and the founder of the JBL Music Foundation. He is survived by his wife of 59 years Patricia (Patsy) Prial Lowe, five children John (J.B.) Lowe, III (Laura), Edward (Ted) Lowe (Susan), Deirdre Burke (Christopher), Robert Lowe (Catherine), Melissa Edwards (Bradley); and 11 grandchildren as well as his brother, Kenneth E. Lowe. His unbounded love for his family and kindness and generosity to all is his greatest legacy. Visitation will be on Monday, November 23 from 4:00pm to 8:00pm at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. A funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, November 24 at 11:00am at St. Michael the Archangel Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, 383 Main Ave., 5th Floor, Norwalk, CT 06851. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. The Trustees and staff of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation mourn the loss of our Chairman, John Zuccotti. With wisdom and heartfelt generosity John led the foundation's efforts to solve pressing problems and celebrate accomplishments in medical research, the environment, the arts, and child well-being throughout the United States. Though our hearts ache and we seek to embrace John's loving family, we also celebrate the magnificent service and accomplishments of a wonderful man. The world is a better place because of John Zuccotti. 1/3

FERRO--Daniel. The members of The Juilliard School community are deeply saddened by the passing of Daniel Ferro, a revered member of the School's voice faculty from 1972 to 2006. An individual of great dignity, intelligence, and artistry, Dan worked with our vocal students to bring them to a love of vocal repertoire and a sure understanding of vocal technique. His kind and caring attention to the various details of the education of young vocalists made him a highly respected and sought-after teacher at Juilliard. We extend our condolences to his wife, Joy, his family and his many friends and colleagues. Joseph W. Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Brian Zeger, Artistic Director, Ellen and James S. Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts; Edith Bers, Chair, Voice Faculty 1/3

WEINSTEIN--Norma Markell, 90, died peacefully on November 19, 2015 in her Manhattan home. Widow of Morris N. Weinstein; beloved mother of Peter and Emily Chaya, and the late Adam J. Weinstein. Retired professor at Fashion Institute of Technology. Known for her smarts, humor and style. Funeral Sunday, November 22, 10am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or NAMI. 1/3

KLEIMAN--Vivien Teacher, 96. Beloved mother of David (917-515-4931) and Wendy Kleiman, graduated Hunter, past president. Women's Division, AJC. A real sweetheart and an amateur artist, with a zest for life. 1/3

FERRO--Daniel, Voice Faculty Emeritus, The Juilliard School, died on November 18. In a career that stretched across five continents and included decorations by three governments for his extraordinary contributions to the arts, Daniel Ferro has taught some of opera's most legendary voices. Maestro Ferro was predeceased by his cherished wife, Beth Hollinger Ferro in 1974, his brother, Jack, and his sister, Evelyn. He is survived by his loving wife, Joy, his sons: Matthew (Katherine) and Jesse (Roni) and his five grandchildren: Jonah, Zara Beth, Aaron, Jett and Daniel. Funeral Services will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 East 79th St. on Monday, November 23 at 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Daniel Ferro Vocal Program, Inc. 575 Madison Ave., Ste. 1006, New York, NY, 10022, which will be dedicated to continue to pass on to the next generation Daniel's legacy and life-long commitment to beautiful and healthy singing. www.ferrovocalprogram.org. 1/3
STEINBERG--Meyer (Mike). Dad, you may be physically gone 12 years, but you are always with me. Lovingly, Susan 1/3
DELL--Alana, of Stamford, CT on November 18, 2015. Beloved and devoted wife of Arthur, sons Adam and Alex, daughter-in-law Tina, and Ma La La to Ryan and Carly. Simply the best! 1/3

ZIGELBAUM--Marcia E.,86, longtime resident of Kings Point, NY, after a long illness. Beloved wife of 66 years of Leonard. Adored mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Daughter: the late Wendie Ravner (Harvey). Son-in-law: Harvey Ravner (Lynn). Daughter: Nancy. Grandson: Marc R. Ravner (Dana T.). Granddaughter: Samantha R. Platt (Jordan E.). Great-grandsons: Wes Miles Ravner and Pierce Liam Ravner. Great-granddaughters: Whitney Dylan Platt and Mikayla Stone Platt. Marcia received BA and MSW degrees, both from Hunter College. She had long experience as a psychotherapist, especially for underprivileged patients. Loved by all who knew her, including her immediate and extended family, and a wide circle of friends of longstanding. 1/3
DRABKIN--Sol (Drake). November 23, 2008 Dearest husband, friend, mentor, devoted father and grandfather - How sweet it was! 1/3

COHEN--Diane Berger, 83, passed away in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, surrounded by her family. Her sense of humor, unsinkable spirit and her magnificent smile will be dearly missed by all. Born in Queens, NY. She was a graduate of Adelphi University. She was the controller of Ambiance Fashion magazine. She was an avid golfer, reaching the status of Club Champion of Muttontown Country Club and East Pointe Country Club, as well as being an accomplished bridge and mah jongg player. She is survived by her loving son Paul, daughter-in-law DeeDee, grandson Jason, her brother Bert and Laura Roth, niece and nephew Pam and Robert, she also leaves behind Steve, Jimmy and Amy Cohen and their seven lovely children and one great-grandchild. Preceded in her death by her parents Charles and Lucille Roth and the one of a kind Dr. Irwin Cohen, the love of her life. Irwin and Diane retired to Palm Beach Gardens, Florida and spent many happy years together enjoying every moment of life with their numerous friends and family. A celebration of her life is to be held at East Pointe Country Club with date to be determined. www.riverside stanetsky.com 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. We mourn his loss and send deepest condolences to Susan Zuccotti and the entire family. We remember John's unparalleled and defining contributions to the City he loved through the good and tough times. His devotion to Brookfield, the company he guided, to the many entities he shaped, and the people whose lives he made better were his hallmarks. His love of family and friends mattered most. He'll be watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, which he adored, from a high perch this year. Lisa Linden and all of us at LAK Public Relations, Inc. 1/3

ZIGELBAUM--Marcia E. Much loved part of our lives since 1964, and our companion, with husband, Leonard, on many wonderful and extensive trips. Warm surrogate mother to our whole family. The world is a much duller place now without her. Ellen and Myron Conovitz 1/3

RUTLEDGE--Neal Person, 88, died November 10, 2015, of bladder cancer. Born St. Louis, MO February 23, 1927, the son of Justice Wiley B. Rutledge, Jr., President Franklin Roosevelt's last appointment to the Supreme Court, and Annabel Person Rutledge. Sidwell Friends School, 1944; Harvard College, 1947; Yale Law School, 1950; United States Marine Corps, 1945 -1946; Clerked Judge Charles Fahy, U.S. Court of Appeals, D.C. Circuit, Justice Hugo L. Black, U.S. Supreme Court, U.S. AEC 1952-1953. Private practice, Miami FL, Claude Pepper Law Offices; Faircloth & Rutledge; Rutledge & Milledge, until 1970. Taught law, at University of Miami, Duke, North Carolina Central. Private practice, Wald, Harkrader & Ross, Washington, DC, 1974-1980. Significant cases: Green v. American Tobacco (first finding that smoking caused lung cancer); the Florida reapportionment cases, Swann v. Adams. Represented unions in the Florida East Coast Railway strike. Argued many cases before the U.S. Supreme Court. Married 52 years to Catherine LeFevre Rutledge until her death in 2000. Survived by his wife, Carolyn Killea, his children, Peter, Wiley, Philip, Sarah, and Neal Andrew, and by four grandchildren. 1/3

METZ--Sheril "Jerry" Passed away at age 86 on November 20th after a brief illness. Founding member and former President of Lido Beach Synagogue, he was the beloved husband of Elaine for 66 years, cherished father of Diane, Dovid and Rachel and Yisroel and Faye, adored grandfather of Dani and Josh, Ricki and Michael, Yacov and Shani, Chaim Shlomo and Frumi, Aliza and Yehuda, Rena and Michael, Eliyahu and Bayla, Shira and Yisroel Meir, Atara, Rafael, Ephraim and loving great-grandpa to so many great- grandchildren. He was the Patriarch of our family. His wisdom, values, teachings and traditions will be passed on to all our future generations. He will always be loved and will remain forever in our hearts. Shiva will be observed at their home through Thursday morning from 12-9:00pm. 1

ZUCCOTTI--John. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of real estate, civic and environmental leader John Zuccotti. John will be remembered for his leadership in New York City government and for his dedication to the cultural and educational vitality of the city. WCS is grateful for his personal attention to the New York Aquarium and for advancing conservation through his leadership of the board of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. We will honor John as we continue our work with the foundation to ensure a climate healthy environment across the nation and as we build a vibrant new New York Aquarium on Coney Island. We extend our heartfelt condolences to John's family, the former Susan Sessions, and their children Gianna, Andrew and Milena Zuccotti, and to their eight grandchildren, and his brother, Andrew. 1/3
ZUCCOTTI--John. The staff of the Performing Arts Center at the World Trade Center and their newly-appointed architect, REX, are bereft at the loss of their Chairman. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John Eugene, died Thursday, November 19 at age 78, from complications following a heart attack, at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, NY. Born June 23, 1937 in Greenwich Village, he was the eldest child of Italian immigrants; his father Angelo Zuccotti was the longtime maitre d' at the El Morocco. John attended St. Joseph's Academy on Washington Square Park and La Salle Military Academy in Oakdale, Long Island, followed by Princeton University. He served as an officer in the U.S. Army and then graduated from Yale Law School in 1962. During a summer internship in the office of Senator Jacob Javits, John met Susan Sessions; they married in 1963 and remained devoted for 52 years. John's long professional life began in Venezuela, where he served as an urban planning consultant, and in Washington DC, where he worked for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. In 1970, John and Susan moved to the Carroll Gardens neighborhood of Brooklyn, where they have lived ever since. John worked under Mayor John Lindsay as a commissioner for the New York City Planning Commission and later as its chairman. In 1975, he served as First Deputy Mayor under Abraham Beame, a position he held throughout the city's fiscal crisis. He became a founding member of the firm Tufo, Johnston, & Zuccotti in 1978. In 1985, he joined the real estate firm Olympia & York, shepherding it through its recapitalization as Brookfield Financial Properties. More recently, John balanced positions at Brookfield Asset Management and the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges along with work as the Chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York and board appointments at Columbia University, the New York Blood Center, the Doris Duke Foundation and others. Following the events of 9/11, he worked tirelessly and with great vision to restore Lower Manhattan, serving with the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation and on the boards of the September 11 Memorial Museum and the Performing Arts Center at the World Trade Center. A lifelong New Yorker, John was immensely proud of his service to the city he loved so much. A man of fierce intelligence with a passion for history and literature, John challenged those who cared for him to embrace the world with the same boundless energy with which he lived. His appetite for adventure was limitless; he loved to travel, ski, fish, and especially to hunt. He was deeply attached to the waters of Accabonac Harbor in Springs, NY and to the Green Mountains of Vermont. John was an unfailingly devoted husband and brother, a wise and loving father and grandfather, and a charismatic and generous friend who loomed large in the lives of all he touched. John is survived by his wife Susan; daughter Gianna and her husband David Weinstock, and their children Sophie, Noah and Lia; son Andrew and his wife Margaret Mauran Zuccotti, and their children Nicholas, Emma and Robert; daughter Milena and her husband Jason Merwin, and their children Cassie and Lily; brother Andrew and his wife Trish and their children. He leaves behind a large and loving family and innumerable friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn; the New York Blood Center; or the Group for the East End/Accabonac Protection Committee in Bridgehampton, NY. A memorial service will be announced. John was impossible to forget. He was loved and will be missed. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. Beloved and revered colleague and friend to all of us at Emigrant Bank. A fellow opera lover and admirer bids farewell. Sincere condolences to Susan and the Zuccotti family. Rest in peace, John. Harriet Edelman 1/3

CHASIN--Laura. Of Cambridge, MA, on November 17. Born October 11, 1936 in New York, NY. Beloved wife since 1971 of Richard Chasin of Cambridge, MA. Mother of Peter Gill Case of Providence, RI, Matthew Case of Chapel Hill, NC, and Jessica Case of Cody, WY. Stepmother of Dana Chasin of Washington, DC and Alexandra Chasin of Brooklyn, NY. Grandmother of eleven. She is also survived by her siblings Lucy Waletzky of Bedford, NY, Marion Weber of Bolinas, CA, and Larry Rockefeller of New York, NY. Laura Chasin grew up in Manhattan and attended the Brearley School, Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT, and Bryn Mawr College in Pennsylvania where she received a B.A. in History of Art. She earned an M.A. in Government from Harvard University and an M.S.W. from Simmons College School of Social Work. Chasin served on numerous Boards including the James Jackson Putnam Children's Center of Roxbury, the Conflict Management Group, the Faith and Politics Institute, the Children's Defense Fund, the Rockefeller Family Fund, and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. She was a Life Trustee of Spelman College of Atlanta, GA. In 1989, she founded the Public Conversations Project of Watertown, MA, a non-profit organization promoting constructive dialogue on issues involving clashing values, world views, and identities, such as abortion, sexual orientation, immigration, gun safety, and religious tolerance. The Project teaches extensively and has worked on dozens of issues on four continents. The Project has been given awards by the New York State Mediators Association, the American Association of Group Psychotherapy and Psychodrama, the American Family Therapy Academy, and the American Society of Professionals in Dispute Resolution. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: publicconversations.org. The family will announce memorial services in the near future. 1/3

DiCORCIA--Edward Thomas. Edward Thomas DiCorcia, a Houston resident since 1967, passed away on the 10th of November 2015. The joy of his life was the role of husband, "Dad", and "Grandpa". Married in 1953, Mr. DiCorcia is survived by his wife, the former Madelyn Faress of Charleston, South Carolina; daughters Jeanette DiCorcia an architect in Houston; Suzanne Shelby and son-in-law Jonathan Shelby of Madison, New Jersey; and granddaughters Jordan Shelby, an advertising sales associate with The Wall Street Journal, Hayley Shelby, an undergraduate at Drexel University in Philadelphia, and Lauren Shelby, a freshman at The Pingry School. A son, Edward, Jr., pre-deceased him in November 1977. Mr. DiCorcia, an oil industry executive served for 33 years with Exxon Company, U.S.A retiring in 1990 as Vice President of Refining. He later became President and Chief Executive Officer, The Uno-Ven Company an affiliate of UNOCAL Corporation, in Arlington Heights, Illinois, and more recently was engaged in family business enterprises. Born in 1930, DiCorcia graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School and Columbia University in the city of New York. He served as Lieutenant (LTJG) U.S. Navy 1951-1954. He was a Public Affairs Fellow at the Brookings Institution, Washington D.C, in 1967. Mr. DiCorcia held a Texas Professional Engineer license until 2005. He was active in the National Petroleum Council where he was principal author of the 1975 report: "Petroleum Storage for National Security" and the 1981 report: "Emergency Preparedness for Interruption of Petroleum Imports". He served as a Director of the Council in 1994-95. Graveside service; Saturday, November 21 at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in East Hanover, New Jersey. 1/3

LOWE--John Budd, Jr.,of Greenwich, CT, passed away on November 20, 2015. Mr. Lowe was born in Greenwich, CT on April 9, 1928. After graduating from Greenwich High School, and Tufts University (class of 1950), he received an MBA from Columbia University Graduate School of Business. Mr. Lowe also attended the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program from which he graduated with honors. A former Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of European American Bank, Mr. Lowe was a Certified Public Accountant, a Certified Fraud Examiner, and the former President of the Columbia Graduate School of Business Alumni Association, from which he received the Alumni Medal. Mr. Lowe was a member of Tamarack Country Club, St. Michael's Parish, the past President of St. Michael's Parish Council, a Greenwich Old Timers Association annual award recipient, the lead trombonist in the Bob Button Orchestra, and the founder of the JBL Music Foundation. He is survived by his wife of 59 years Patricia (Patsy) Prial Lowe, five children John (J.B.) Lowe, III (Laura), Edward (Ted) Lowe (Susan), Deirdre Burke (Christopher), Robert Lowe (Catherine), Melissa Edwards (Bradley); and 11 grandchildren as well as his brother, Kenneth E. Lowe. His unbounded love for his family and kindness and generosity to all is his greatest legacy. Visitation will be on Monday, November 23 from 4:00pm to 8:00pm at the Leo P. HENSELMANN--Caspar passed away Saturday, November 14, 2015, at 82 years of age. Caspar was born in 1933 in Germany and grew up in Ticino, Switzerland. His family immigrated in 1950 to the United States and settled in Chicago, Illinois. He received a BFA from the Art Institute of Chicago and a diploma of medical illustration from the College of Medicine from the University of Illinois, putting himself through school working as a ballroom dance instructor. Upon graduation from college he worked in Detroit, Michigan, and during this time found his calling as a sculptor. In 1960, he settled in New York City where he worked as a medical illustrator, sculptor and professor of art. He has exhibited his artwork extensively in the US and Europe, including 25 solo shows, and his works can be found in museums and in many private collections both in Europe and the US. Caspar was a sweet, loving father and husband, an accomplished artist, chef, and dancer who loved and lived life to the fullest. He and his wife Evangeline loved traveling and particularly enjoyed spending summers in the Languedoc region of France at their summer home as well as on the island of Crete in Greece. Caspar is survived by his wife Evangeline Karantzakis Henselmann, sister Beatrice Werner Henselmann, two sons,Xavier Henselmann and Samuel Henselmann, five grandchildren and a host of extended family and friends. 1/3

CARRINGTON--Kathleen. Kathleen Connell Carrington, 88, passed away peacefully on November 7, 2015 in Greenville, South Carolina. Kay, as she was known by her friends and family, was a steadfast and loving wife and mother. Born January 11, 1927 in Jersey City, New Jersey to John Norman Connell and Helen Burke Connell, Kay was one of nine children. Beautiful and unassuming, with an easy sense of humor and disarming smile, Kay graduated from Notre Dame College in Baltimore soon after the Second World War. Shortly thereafter she married Jim Carrington, a three-sport All-American, at the U.S. Naval Academy. In what has been described as a fairytale wedding, the midshipmen in their dress-whites rained rice upon the stunningly beautiful newlyweds as they ran beneath a shining arc of crossed sabers. Kay taught school until the arrival of the first of her five children, whom she raised in or near seaports around the world, from Yokosuka, Japan to Annapolis, Maryland. Like most Navy wives, while her husband was away at sea, often for months at a time, she stoically ran the householdwithout ever a complaint. Kay and Jim taught their children a great deal, but perhaps their most precious legacy was setting an example of how wonderful a marriage can be. As irony would have it, in the precise moment of Kay's sudden passing, all her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren were gathered together in California for the marriage of her grandson Michael. The thought would have pleased her to no end. Kay is survived by her daughters, Wendy Carrington, Nancy (Steve) Crown, and Kathleen (Steven) Anderson; sons, James Carrington, Jr., and Timothy (Cathleen) Carrington; sisters, Shelly Cullen, Madeleine Reilly, Elizabeth De Souza; brother, James Connell; ten grandchildren; four great-grandchildren; and many nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her parents; husband James H.H. Carrington; sisters, Elise Leahy, Mary Lou Towey, and Nancy Bockus; brother, Jack Connell; and daughter-in-law Antonella Murgia Carrington. A service celebrating Kay's life is being planned for the spring of 2016. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Rheumatology Research Foundation, 2200 Lake Boulevard NE, Atlanta, GA 30319 or www.rheumresearch.org. 1/3

SANDERS--Stephen J.,Jr. November 10, 1919-Novem- ber 4, 2015. Stephen J. Sanders, Jr., age 95, passed away suddenly, but peacefully, at his home in The Boulders, Carefree, Arizona, on Wednesday, November 4, 2015. Born November 10, 1919 in Salisbury, North Carolina, Mr. Sanders was "A Man for All Seasons." In his personal life, Mr. Sanders married Mildred Anita McCormick, March 31, 1944. He had one son, Stephen J. Sanders III. This marriage ended in divorce in January of 1964. On April 21, 1979, he married Patrice Lynn Mick and they remained happily married until his death. During World War II, Mr. Sanders served in the United States Army from 1942-1950, first as a battalion staff officer in the Infantry, then with the Military Police during the Nuremberg War Crime trials, and later with the Counter Intelligence Corps during the Cold War. He was discharged as a Captain. Upon returning to Mississippi, he served as an account executive and national advertising manager for "The Clarion-Ledger" and "Jackson Daily New", and in 1958 he founded "The Mississippi World Trade Council." In 1963, after a cataclysmic, lifechanging experience, Mr. Sanders founded a religious lay order, Fellowship Of The Crown, which grew into The Crownist Faith. In 1980, Mr. Sanders took his Faith into the marketplace, founding the Stefan Mann stores which started in Carmel, California, and grew to a total of five including a store in Trump Towers in New York and el Pedregal in North Scottsdale. Mr. Sanders hosted "The Crownist Faith Hour" on KFNX radio in Phoenix, Arizona, from 1995-2002, and "World News and Commentary with Stephen Sanders" from 1999-2002. His awards include: Military Campaign Medals: Normandy, Northern France, Rhineland, Ardennes, Central Europe. Decorations: Bronze Star for Valor: Battle of Osweiler, Luxembourg, December 18, 1944; Combat Infantryman's Badge; "E" Flag for export awarded by John F. Kennedy; and The Friendship Award, awarded by The Federal Republic of Germany. He was selected for "Who's Who in the South" and Southwest and "Who's Who in California." His writings include his book To Him Who Conquers, published by Doubleday and Company. On November 10th, memorials were held throughout the United States to honor this unique and inspirational man, who helped make the world a better place. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Sanders can be sent to: The Crownist Faith, Post Office Box 3770, Carefree, AZ 85377. 1/3

ALTSHULER--Lori, M.D.,58, of Manhattan Beach, California, died peacefully at home after a long illness on November 5, 2015. Born August 23, 1957, in Englewood, New Jersey, Lori was a loving mother to sons Eric and Daniel, while leading a distinguished career in the field of psychiatry. Lori received her B.A. and M.D. degrees from Cornell University, and completed a fellowship in biological psychiatry at the National Institute of Mental Health. At NIMH, Lori began pioneering work in magnetic resonance imaging to assess changes in the brain of patients with psychiatric disorders. Lori joined the UCLA faculty in 1989, was appointed chief of the bipolar disorders clinic at Brentwood VA in 1991, and in 1995 established the UCLA Mood Disorders Research Program. In 2004, Lori was honored with the Julia S. Gouw Endowed Chair in Mood Disorders at UCLA. Over more than 30 years, Lori advanced the understanding of fundamental mechanisms of mood dysregulation with innovative research; shared her findings extensively in research papers and talks; and took an active interest in mentoring the next generation of researchers. She received 58 grants, including 11 major research grants from NIMH and 3 from the Department of Veteran Affairs; published more than 265 articles in peer-reviewed journals; authored 23 chapters in scholarly texts; and presented more than 50 major addresses at research conferences worldwide. Lori's professional accomplishments were well recognized. She was named a Distinguished Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association in 1997, and received The 2014 Award for Research in Mood Disorders from the American College of Psychiatrists. In between she received many other awards including the Southern California Psychiatric Society's 2008 Award for Outstanding Achievement and the 2006 Falcone Prize for Outstanding Achievement in Affective Disorders Research. Her peers acknowledged her clinical acumen by electing her to the "Best Doctors in America" seven times. Reflecting her deep commitment to mentoring young physicians, Lori especially prized the teaching and mentoring awards she received. For all her professional achievements, Lori's family provided her greatest joy. Raised in a close-knit family that was a source of laughter and strength, she created the same loving environment for her boys and passed on those strong family ties. Lori also cherished many deep friendships, no doubt borne from her affability and innate empathy. Indeed, to know her was to love her. In addition to sons Eric and Daniel, Lori is survived by her parents, Gloria Altshuler (the late Leonard Elberger) and Dr. Kenneth (Ruth) Altshuler; husband Greg Monfette and step-daughter Jaime Monfette; siblings Dr. Steven (Terry) Altshuler and Dara (Robert Kaplan) Altshuler; and numerous adoring nieces, nephews, cousins, and countless friends and colleagues. The UCLA Department of Psychiatry is planning a memorial service for early 2016. Please email: 4LAmemorial@gmail.com to be notified about the memorial service. Contributions may be made to the Lori Altshuler, M.D. Memorial Fund: Communities Foundation of Texas, 5500 Caruth Haven Lane, Dallas, TX 75225, attn: Carolyn Newham or go to cftexas.org/lori-altshuler. 1/3

THOMPSON--Norman. Norman Winslow Thompson, M.D., PhD, (Hon., Linkoping University), FACS, FRACS (Hon.), FRCPSG (Hon.) Dr. Norman Winslow Thompson, a pioneer in endocrine surgery, died peacefully at home surrounded by members of his family on Tuesday, November 17th in Ann Arbor, Michigan at the age of 83. Dr. Thompson had a long and distinguished career in medicine and trained, mentored and influenced generations of surgeons around the world. He was born in Boston, MA, in 1932. He received his B.A. degree from Hope College in 1953 and his M.D. degree from the University of Michigan Medical School in Ann Arbor in 1957. He was appointed to the faculty of University of Michigan as Instructor in 1962. He advanced to a full Professor in 1971. He was subsequently appointed the first Henry King Ransom Endowed Professor of Surgery in 1979 for the duration of his academic career. Dr. Thompson was an active, participating and founding member of many professional organizations and received numerous awards including an honorary PhD from the University of Linkoping, Sweden. Dr. Thompson was a beloved teacher of surgery at the University of Michigan and helped to train over 265 chief residents in surgery. He was appointed Professor Emeritus of Surgery on his retirement in 2001. The University of Michigan has established both an endowed Professorship and a Fellowship of Endocrine Surgery in Dr. Thompson's name. Dr. Thompson is survived by his wife of 59 years, Marcia Veldman Thompson; son Robert W. Thompson, and daughters Karen L. Thompson, Susan M. Thompson-Doering and Jennifer E. Thompson McGuffin. He leaves behind five grandchildren and three step- grandchildren. A memorial gathering is being planned at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to Hope College, the University of Michigan Division of Endocrine Surgery, or the American Association of Endocrine Surgeons (AAES) Foundation. Please feel free to visit: www.niefuneralhomes.com to search for Dr. Thompson's name to leave messages for the family or view the expanded obituary. 1/3

CURRY--Elizabeth (Beth) Rivers, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on Monday, surrounded by her family. Raised on a farm in Chesterfield, SC, the first of five children, she grew up feeding chickens and exploring the hills nearby. She attended Queens College in Charlotte, graduating as student body president and valedictorian. Beth married, raised her family, and then, when her children were older, returned to Queens for business school. Soon after, she co- founded Eagle Capital Management in New York, now a $25 billion investment firm, which manages money for families, universities, foundations, and pension funds. Even as she helped build a large firm and sat on the boards of many institutions, Beth remained true to her South Carolina values. Eschewing the combative, confrontational style of high finance, she brought a purposeful, friendly, common- sense skepticism to Wall Street. Her disarming southern accent and small stature masked a probing, persistent, analytic intelligence. She had a wide, warm and genuine curiosity about everyone she met--from CEOs to cab drivers to strangers' children-- and took as much pleasure stumbling upon a strange mushroom or beautiful moss growing in the woods as discovering new investment opportunities. Her sensitivity to every individual helped the Eagle staff challenge each other without fracture for 27 years in an industry often characterized by short-term relationships and rapid turnover. Beth sometimes regretted not being a scientist and later in life enjoyed spending time with researchers at Weill Cornell Medical College and Rockefeller University, on whose boards she served. She was grateful to Queens for helping her make the transition from homemaker to financial executive; she served as a trustee of the college, starting in 1986 and received their Algernon Sydney Sullivan Award in 2008. In 1995 she joined the board of the Hyde and Watson Foundation, providing capital to hundreds of arts, education, healthcare, and social service organizations. Church community has always been an important part of Beth's life, and most recently she was a trustee at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Before entering the workforce, she was a devoted community volunteer who helped build the Summit Childcare Center, New Jersey's first modern infant care and pre-K facility for working mothers. Above all, Beth was a great storyteller and wit, inherited from her father and cultivated in a large Southern farm family. She could transfix friends and family by turning some small forgettable moment into an unforgettable yarn. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, Ravenel Boykin Curry III, who was also her business partner for 27 years; her three children, Ravenel Boykin Curry IV, Caroline Rivers Curry (Rob Davis), and Marshall Anderson Curry (Elizabeth Martin); her seven grandchildren, Ravenel V, Zinnia, Wick, Jackson, Quinton, Jane and Rivers; and her siblings, Jay Rivers (Cathryn), Rebecca Sullivan (Burr) and Melinda Ford (Tommy). She was predeceased by her sister Carolyn Query. A memorial service will be held on Monday, November 23 at 11:15am at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to: Weill Cornell Medicine; The Rockefeller University; or Queens University of Charlotte. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. Our firm - Weil, Gotshal & Manges - grieves the loss of John Zuccotti, Senior Counsel in our Real Estate practice. John was larger than life in so many respects which will be recounted for years to come in many places by the vast range of people whose lives he's touched. Here we recount a personal relationship which transcends that. John came to our firm through the long time efforts of our senior partner Ira Millstein, who had wooed him for years. John and Ira were close friends dating back to the fiscal crisis of the 1970s when John was the Deputy Mayor under Abraham Beame, in effect running the City during one of its most difficult times. Ira was his pro bono counsel and together they weathered the cross currents of bankers, unions, politics, law and many different personalities. They came to trust each other completely - they had to. From there they remained in close touch with Italian dinners in Little Italy, meetings with countless different people, and most importantly through their families. John was a very loving husband to his wife Susan and a wonderful and attentive father and grandfather. Over many years, Ira and John became each other's confidants and reliable source for advice. Finally, Ira convinced John to join Weil in 1997. Probably John would not appreciate this, but to Ira and all of us at Weil, John personified the golden rule which underlies all religions and ethics. He knew right from wrong and how to execute that. He brought that DNA to everything he was involved in, most importantly and currently to our partners and associates at Weil who sought his advice, for which he was always available. We will miss his presence and guidance deeply. And we feel for his family, to which he was so devoted. 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew A.,of Manhattan and Quogue, NY passed away peacefully on November 20, 2015 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. A native of South Philadelphia, Matthew graduated from Swarthmore College (1973), Boston University Law School (1976) and New York University Law School (LLM, 1979). In 1979, he joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, where he would go on to serve as co-head of the Tax Practice for over 25 years. Matthew was known in legal and business circles for his brilliant analytic mind, his ability to solve complex legal problems and to deconstruct complicated tax analysis. Both Chambers Global and Chambers USA repeatedly named Matthew in their top tier of lawyers, and he was listed in Euromoney's Guide to the World's Leading Tax Lawyers numerous times. He was named Best Lawyers' "2013 New York City Tax Lawyer of the Year," and Legal 500 U.S. Portfolio magazine included him in its list of the top 10 tax attorneys in the United States. Matthew took immense joy in his work, but he also had an abiding passion for books, music, film and art. He was particularly committed to bringing great theater to all audiences and served on the Board of Playwrights Horizons. His mind was always active, his intellect broad and deep, his wit clever and mischievous, but his heart was always with his family to whom he was profoundly devoted and whom he always loved and supported. He is survived by his children Amanda (25), Oliver (20) and Anthony (1), his wife Mariana, and his brother Kenny. We will miss him dearly. There will be a celebration of Matthew's life at 1pm on Monday, November 23, 2015 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, NYC. 1/3

SCARF--Herbert Eli, age 85, of New Haven, CT and Sag Harbor, NY, died peacefully in his home in Sag Harbor with his family by his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, best-selling author Maggie Scarf; his daughter Martha Samuelson, her husband Paul, and their sons Charlie, Tom and David; his daughter Betsy Stone, her husband Mike, and their children Deborah, Sarah and Daniel, and his daughter Susan Merrell, her husband Jim, and their children Maggie and Jake. Herb was a Sterling Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University, where he taught for over 50 years. Herb received numerous professional recognitions and awards, including being named a member of the American Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Sciences, and receiving both the Frederick Lanchester Award and the John von Neumann medal from the Operations Research Society of America. He was recognized as a Distinguished Fellow of the American Economics Association in 1991. He was recognized in many Nobel prize citations including those of Gerard Debreu and Lloyd Shapley for his ground breaking contributions to economics. He was a mentor to generations of Ph.D. students and enjoyed daily coffee with his colleagues at Yale's Cowles Foundation. Herb was an early feminist. The accomplishments of his wife and his daughters were so important to him, and he basked in their various successes. Herb had a huge number of interests, including foreign travel, music, and art. He went everywhere and listened to everything. Herb touched so many people and helped them in their lives. We will miss him immensely. There will be a celebration of Herb's life early in 2016 at Yale. 1/3
