Without you we live with a void no one can fill. Love, Mom and Dad 1/3

HELLMAN--Gabriel Michael, 101, died on November 18, 2015 in Overland Park, Kansas. He was predeceased by both his wife of 69 years, Rose Hellman, and his brother, Morton J. Hellman. He was born on September 27, 1914 to Jacob and Gertrude Hellman. He graduated City College of New York at age 19 and then obtained a Masters in Mathematics. He taught mathematics in the New York City School system and served in the United States Army during World War II. Afterwards, he continued his education in actuarial science. He became a highly regarded actuary with a specialty in pension planning. He retired in 1989 following a very successful career. He excelled at chess, achieving national recognition and level of Master and continued playing until age 98. He was an excellent contract bridge player, achieving Bronze Life Master status. He also was a competitive tennis player, and continued until age 89. Gabe had been the quiet patriarch of a large extended family, now spanning the globe, and he was a benefactor to many. He is survived by his sons, Dr. Richard Hellman (wife Julie) of Leawood, Kansas, Geoffrey Hellman, of Sydney, Australia, brother Burton Hellman of the Bronx, his brother-in-law Alex Eventoff and his wife Renee of Davie, Florida, his 11 grandchildren, and many nephews, nieces, and five great-grandchildren. He had a full life. The funeral will be at Mount Moriah, Newcomer & Freeman Funeral Home, in Kansas City on Sunday, November 22nd 2015. Burial will follow the service at the Beth Torah section of the Mount Moriah Cemetery. 1/3
HIRSCHSON--Albert. Always in our hearts. Fran and Victor Strauss Bad Movie Club 1/3

BLACK--Judy Ellen, 67, died after a long illness on Sunday, November 15, 2015 in Washington, Connecticut, where she lived. Her loving husband of 29 years, Richard Schlosberg, and her brother, Leon Black, his wife Debra, and their four children Benjamin, Joshua, Alexander, and Victoria deeply mourn her loss. Born in New York City on September 27, 1948, she lived in New York City as well as Washington, Connecticut and Manalapan, Florida. In New York City, she attended the Ramaz School, the Fieldston School and graduated from Barnard College in 1970. She later graduated with a Master's Degree in Art History from the New York Institute of Art, a Master's Degree from the Bank Street School of Education and a Master of Business Administration from Columbia Business School in New York City. She and her husband were passionate and involved in creating gardens and deeply committed to promoting environmental conservation. She was predeceased by her mother, Shirley Black Kash, who passed away in 2014 and her father, Eli M. Black, who passed away in 1975. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. We have lost New York City's chief champion. His imprint on this City and on Brookfield, the company he steered, will last for generations to come. Condolences to the entire Zuccotti family. Suri Kasirer and the Kasirer Consulting team. 1/3

CAWLEY--Charles M. The monks of Newark Abbey, the St. Benedict's Prep Board of Trustees, and the entire school family mourn the loss of our alumnus, great benefactor, and long-time Board member, Charles M. Cawley. Charlie's exceptional vision and boundless generosity transformed our school and changed the lives of countless St. Benedict's students. We extend our deepest sympathies to Julie and the Cawley family. 1/3

MICHNIEWICZ--Peter, age 53, loving brother, devoted son and friend, passed away suddenly in September at home in Hoboken, New Jersey. He is survived by his brother Alexander of Charlotte, North Carolina and by his dear and long-time friend Victoria Minervini of Ridgefield, New Jersey. Pete was the son of the late Peter Michniewicz and the late Irene Michniewicz (nee Breeding), both of Bel Air, Maryland. Pete was a dedicated financial services professional, working in foreign exchange trading and other functions at Credit Suisse (USA), Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS), Mocatta Metals, and Volkart Brothers, all in New York City, in a Wall Street career spanning 25 years. Prior to working on Wall Street, Pete was a manager in property accounting at Merck in Rahway, New Jersey. Lately he was working as an independent trader and studying for work in technical and fundamental financial analysis, having passed the CMT (Chartered Market Technician) Level III and CFA (Chartered Financial Analyst) Level I exams. Pete graduated with high honors from Lehigh University in 1983, receiving a Bachelor of Science degree with a double major in finance and accounting. Pete was born at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, grew up in Bel Air, Maryland, and was a resident of Hoboken for the last 25 years. He is inurned in Building 6 of the Somerset Hills Memorial Park and Mausoleum in Basking Ridge, New Jersey. Pete's love, friendship, and intellect will be greatly missed by those who knew and loved him. 1/3

WEIS--Albert Martin, 88, passed away Tuesday, November 17, 2015. Al is survived by his beloved wife of nearly 60 years, Pepi (nee Hasnas), and his children, Russell (Lara) of Fletcher, VT, Marshall of Floral Park, NY, Rebecca (Billy) of Port Washington, NY, and Monica of Port St. Lucie, FL. He is also survived by grandchildren Brian, Daniel, Melanie, Kira, and Caleb. Albert was born on November 20, 1926 to Ann and Irving Weis and raised in Lawrence, NY. He graduated from MIT in 1948, and served in the U.S. Coast Guard and the Air Force. He then joined the family brokerage business, and thus began Al's long and storied Wall Street career. He served as the Chairman of the New York Cotton Exchange from 1977-8, 1981-3, and 1997-8, and was instrumental in the formation of the New York Board of Trade, where he served as chairman from 1998-2000. He was also chairman of the Commodity Clearing Corporation. Al was an avid golfer and served as President of North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, NY and later of Sands Point Golf Club. He also enjoyed racing and breeding horses, achieving several notable wins. Al was a long-time supporter of North Shore University Hospital, St. Francis Hospital, and the Council for the Arts at MIT. Al placed family above all else and cared deeply about his wide circle of friends. He possessed a subtle humor, and a truly generous nature - qualities which endeared him to all who knew him. He was a true gentleman who made a substantial difference in many lives. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund - Albert M. Weis Annual Scholarship Fund cantorrelief.org, or to the St. Francis Hospital Foundation - In Memory of Albert M. Weis stfrancisheartcenter.com. A memorial service for Al will be held at Sands Point Golf Club, 130 Middle Neck Rd., on Monday, November 30, 2pm. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing of our former board member John Zuccotti, an extraordinary public servant who valued preservation's contribution to the City. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair Peg Breen, President 1/3

BASS--Barbara (Gross), 89, formerly of Long Beach, NY, died November 17 of Alzheimer's Disease in Bedford, MA. Loving wife of the late George Bass, sister to the late Elsie Koller. Survived by daughter Laurie Groves and her husband Dean of Bedford, MA, daughter Julie Gilbert and her husband Jan of Long Beach, NY, son Rob Bass and his wife Lauren of Easton, MA, and grandchildren Jessica and Jordan Bass of Massachusetts. Manager of Ophthalmology Department at Long Island Jewish Hospital; volunteered at Long Beach Hospital, Visiting Nurse Service of NY Hospice, and New York Citizens Committee on Health Care Decisions. Family asks that donations in Barbara's memory be made to: Carleton-Willard Homes, attn: Barbara Doyle, 100 Old Billerica Rd., Bedford, MA 01730, c/o Employee Appreciation Fund. 1/3

MOORMANN--Beatrice Wior Roth, left us on November 11, 2015. Bea was married first to Irving M. Roth, and later to Helmuth Moormann. She succumbed peacefully to cancer in her Great Neck home at the age of 94. Bea was the matriarch of a large, extended family that included two sons, Richard Roth (Susan King) and Stephen Roth (Dr. Hallam Hurt), and four grandchildren: Hallam Harper, Justin Roth, Rachel Goldman, and Adam Roth. Bea also leaves five great-grandchildren. Bea travelled widely, and had friends from all over the world. A private memorial service will be held at her home. 1/3

FASOLINO--Theresa "Dolly", 92, born January 7, 1923 died November 17, 2015 of natural causes in Margate, FL. Born in Manhattan, NY; Mrs. Fasolino was predeceased by husband Frank Fasolino; son Frank; daughter Maria Fasolino Scheiner and granddaughter Cherie Scheiner. She is survived by grandchildren Ralph Sperandeo (son of Maria) and Nicole Fasolino Scavone (daughter of Frank). Services are being held Monday 11am at The Gardens Memorial Park in Boca Raton, FL. 1/3

METZ--Sheril. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather and friend. For over 60 years, with your darling Elaine at your side, we shared great times together and enjoyed a very special friendship. Your devotion to our Jewish beliefs was a beautiful thing to behold. Rest in peace, my friend. I miss you already. Barbara Monasch 1/3

HOLLANDER--Michael. Born Michael Hollander on May 27th, 1934. Died on November 11th, 2015, after an extended battle with multiple myeloma. Michael grew up in Manhattan and attended the Bronx High School of Science, then Columbia College while simultaneously undertaking a professional dance career with the Jose Limon Company. During this period, he also taught at both the Limon studio and Juilliard School. After retiring from dance, he received a Masters in Architecture from Yale University. Upon graduation, he worked for the distinguished architectural firms Philip Johnson and John Johansen before beginning a 40 year career as an influential, distinguished professor of architecture at Pratt Institute. At Pratt, he mentored generations of future designers and planners. A generous, interdisciplinary thinker, he was both a curious learner and an infectious listener. He was predeceased by his loving wife Judith Hollander, his father and mother, Franklin and Muriel and his brother, the renowned poet John Hollander. He is survived by two sons, Samuel and Benjamin, two nieces, Martha and Elizabeth, two daughters-in-law, Jennifer and Julie, and two grandchildren, Josephine and Julius. His favorite song was Antonio Carlos Jobim's "Waters of March," which spoke of the promise of life. His beautiful soul will live on. A private remembrance will be held in his honor later this Spring. 1/3

GREENBAUM--Daniel W.,Of Chilmark, MA, died November 13, 2015 at age 89, survived by wife Anne Barry, daughters Anne and Susan Greenbaum, grandson Edward, and children and grandchildren of Anne Barry. His grandfather was a New York Supreme Court judge and his father founded liberal New York City law firm, Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst. A graduate of MIT, Dan worked as a civil engineer in NYC, retiring as Managing Partner at Vollmer Associates; amazing for a man who didn't like to wear shoes. He had a wonderful first marriage to Patricia Jean Duncan, who predeceased him, then was lucky enough to marry his college sweetheart. A Celebration of His Life will be Saturday, May 21, 2016 in Chilmark. Donations in Dan's name can be made to Hospice of Martha's Vineyard - hospiceofmv.org. 1/3
ARKIN--Tessie. April 10, 1912 -Nov. 22, 2000. Mom, miss you beyond measure. Love, Joan 1/3

EISMAN--Steven J. The partners and members of Gassman Baiamonte Betts mourn the loss of our friend and esteemed colleague, Steven J. Eisman. He was a great lawyer and dedicated Bar Leader. CURRY--Elizabeth. The Trustees and Staff of the New-York Historical Society express sincere condolences to Trustee Ravenel Curry and family on the passing of his beloved wife, Beth. Beth was a treasured member of New-York Historical's extended family and a wonderful supporter of our new Center for the Study of Women's History. We will miss Beth's charm, wit, grace, and intelligence, and will forever admire her great devotion to her family and exceptional courage. Pam B. Schafler, Chair Roger Hertog, Executive Committee Chairman Richard Reiss, Vice Chair Louise Mirrer, President & CEO 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John E. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of John Zuccotti, an extraordinary and devoted industry leader who served with distinction in federal and New York City government. John was First Deputy Mayor under Mayor Beame and was Chairman of the City Planning Commission under Mayor John Lindsay. He served as REBNY's Chairman from 2004-2006; in 2003 John received The Harry B. Helmsley Distinguished New Yorker Award for his exceptional career accomplishments and unique service to the community. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Susan, his children Gianna, Andrew and Milena, and the entire Zuccotti family. Rob Speyer, Chairman John Banks, President 1/3

STACHELBERG--Susan W.,age 82 of New York City, died peacefully on November 18. Loving wife of the late Charlie Stachelberg, devoted mother of Erica, Winnie, and Cas and adoring grandmother of Will, Charlie, and Oggie. Graduate of Connecticut College and New York University, a dancer, poet and neighborhood activist. Susan instilled in her children and grandchildren a love of nature and all things beautiful, a deep sense of civic responsibility, a passion for language, and an enduring desire to respect and value others. Donations can be made to the Fresh Air Fund in honor of Susan W. Stachelberg 1/3

BEILINSON--Martin, age 84, died on October 21, 2015. Loving and beloved husband of Irma. Loving father of Sharon and Jerry, and father-in-law of Doug and Fran. Adoring and loving grandfather of Rebecca, Hannah, Danielle, and Zachary. Devoted uncle of Ann (Henri), Jonathan (Alice), and David (Vera) and their families. Marty combined a business career in marketing research and consulting with college teaching. He was active in professional organizations and was a past president of the American Marketing Association, New York. An Army veteran, he was stationed in Germany in the mid-1950's. Marty enjoyed swimming, gardening, travel and, most of all, being with family and friends. Services were held at the Mount Hebron Cemetery in Queens, New York. 1/3

WARACH--Marie Sieff Norkin, on November 18, 2015. She walked in beauty. Beloved mother, grandmother "Ama," wife, aunt and friend. Her calm beauty, generosity and kindness will be remembered always. Daughter of Diena and Jacob Sieff, she had one brother, Milton Sieff. She shared with them a disposition of patience, refinement and grace. A lifelong painter, she was president of the Artist Alliance of East Hampton, NY, showed at Guild Hall and Accabonac Hall, Nabi Gallery and Gallery 16. She was a children's wear and knitwear designer, children's book author/illustrator, photographer and licensed art therapist. She was married to Sam Norkin, then Bernard Warach. She is survived by Bernard Warach, son Richard Norkin, daughter Laura Norkin Gilbert DeSena, grandsons Johan and Sam Gilbert, niece, nephew, grandniece and nephew, stepchildren and step-grandchildren. Service was Friday, November 20, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Long Island. 1/3

KLEIMAN--Vivien Teacher, 96. Beloved mother of David (917-515-4931) and Wendy Kleiman, graduated Hunter, past president. Women's Division, AJC. A real sweetheart and an amateur artist, with a zest for life. 1/3

GREENE--James R. It is with sadness that Bank Leumi USA mourns the loss of former esteemed director, James R. Greene. Jim joined the board of directors in February 1984 and served until September 2012. During his many years with us, he provided great wisdom and leadership to our board and chaired the Loan Committee. His international experience allowed us to understand world markets and establish our international presence in the financial industry. We are forever grateful for his service as an integral member of our board during both difficult times and successes. Jim will be dearly missed. 1/3

BROOKS--Beverly Bostdorf. Beverly Sue Bostdorf Brooks, longtime resident of New York City and lately of Sarasota, FL, died peacefully on Thursday, October 29, 2015 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. She was 80. She was born in Toledo, OH, and grew up in Perrysburg to Clayton Elwood (Dick) Bostdorf and Cora McCormick Bostdorf. She graduated summa cum laude from The Ohio State University, and later earned a Master of Social Work degree from Simmons College. As a young social worker passionate about human rights and social justice, Bev devoted her early career to implementing NYC's Model Cities Program. She served as administrator for Kings County Hospital, and later became NYC Commissioner for Special Services for Children under Mayor Ed Koch. For more than 25 years Bev was CEO of SafeSpace, a non-profit agency serving 28,000 youth, including 5,000 homeless teens. She co-founded with her husband Community Counseling & Mediation, a 33-year-old community-based organization serving 20,000 residents of NYC. In recognition of Bev's lifelong commitment to the social welfare of children and families, CCM is building a housing facility called Beverly's Place in her honor. She is survived by her husband and partner of 35 years, Emory X. Brooks; son Jeffrey Simmons and wife Christine Simmons; daughter Bethany Simmons; brother John Bostdorf; nephew Trevor Bostdorf; sister Kay Bostdorf Jewett and husband Stiles Jewett; niece Catherine Jewett; nephew James Jewett; and grandsons Nicholas and Zachary Simmons. She is also remembered by her stepchildren Douglas Brooks, Jennifer Brooks Agwunobi, and Thomas Brooks; and their children Rachael, Gabby, Abigail, Nadia, Seth and Grayson. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Humane Society of Sarasota. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John E. The partners and staff of Schulman Lobel LLP mourn the loss of John E. Zuccotti, our friend and client for many years. His numerous accomplishments affected so many. PORTON--Stephen. The Board of Directors and Officers of Montefiore Cemetery Corporation and Springfield L.I. Cemetery Society mourn the passing of our Director Stephen Porton. We will miss his wisdom and counsel over his many long years of service to our cemeteries. 1/3

HUDSON--Milton Willard, 88, (1927-2015) economist, of New York City and Washington DC, died peacefully on November 6, 2015 in Zurich University Hospital, Switzerland of Myelodysplastic Syndrome. He is survived by his wife, Caroline Anstey, sons Robert Hudson, James Hudson, Oliver Anstey Hudson, Calder Anstey Hudson; grandchildren David Hudson, Ryan Hudson, Brent Hudson, Lindsey Hudson and Thomas Hudson. His ashes will be scattered at sea in a private ceremony. 1/3

BUCKLEY--Thomas F.S.,87, a longtime reporter, columnist and critic for The New York Times, died Thursday at his home in New York City. The son of Floyd Thomas Buckley and Juliet Sparks, he was born in Chatham, NY and grew up in Beechhurst, Queens. He was a graduate of Columbia University. During his career at The New York Times, he reported from Vietnam, served as a movie critic and wrote for The New York Times Magazine. He is the author of 'Violent Neighbors,' a 1984 book on El Salvador, Central America and the United States. He was married to the late Barbara Seaman. He is survived by his sister, Faith Rose of Garden City, NY, and many nephews, nieces, grand nephews and grand nieces. He was predeceased by his sister Joy Garber. Funeral will be 10am Monday at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 316 East 88th St. Burial will be in Chatham Rural Cemetery. 1/3

VAN ALLEN--Traer, M.D. 1931 - 2015. Dr. Traer Van Allen passed away peacefully following a stroke on November 16, 2015. Traer served as Chief Resident Psychiatrist and ultimately Clinical Instructor at Cornell University Medical College. Early in his medical training he specialized in Child Psychiatry. Later, Traer dedicated himself to working with adults and was in private practice from 1963 - 2010 whilst teaching at Roosevelt and New York Presbyterian Hospitals. Traer stood out among New Yorkers not only as a tall fellow, but also as a man of great warmth, kindness and curiosity. He was adored by the elderly and earned the affection of children at every family gathering. In the words of a friend, Traer was one of the last true gentlemen. While Traer's avocation was genealogy and history of his native Canada, his passion was design. His conversation was filled with asides that could honor the innovation of a Slant Six engine, the precise color of Egyptian papyrus grass or the simple beauty of a farmhouse staircase. He was fun to listen to but also an empathetic listener. He revitalized four homes near the St. Lawrence River in Canada, one that had been in the family for generations and another that became the Van Allen Archives, a resource and library for the community and surrounding universities. His unique intelligence and humor was influential in the lives of colleagues, friends and family. Traer will be greatly missed but remembered with love and deep appreciation for his life. Traer is survived by his sister, Louise Van Allen Tarleton (Hillsborough, CA); her daughters, Leslie Hayne (Oakland, CA), Courtney Hayne McDowell (Brooklyn, NY); nephews, nieces, Godchildren and a wide range of friends. 1/3

FERRO--Daniel. The members of The Juilliard School community are deeply saddened by the passing of Daniel Ferro, a revered member of the School's voice faculty from 1972 to 2006. An individual of great dignity, intelligence, and artistry, Dan worked with our vocal students to bring them to a love of vocal repertoire and a sure understanding of vocal technique. His kind and caring attention to the various details of the education of young vocalists made him a highly respected and sought-after teacher at Juilliard. We extend our condolences to his wife, Joy, his family and his many friends and colleagues. Joseph W. Polisi, President; Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean; Brian Zeger, Artistic Director, Ellen and James S. Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts; Edith Bers, Chair, Voice Faculty 1/3

Cecily Langdale Davis, President 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. Beloved and revered colleague and friend to all of us at Emigrant Bank. A fellow opera lover and admirer bids farewell. Sincere condolences to Susan and the Zuccotti family. Rest in peace, John. Harriet Edelman 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John E. The partners and staff of Schulman Lobel LLP mourn the loss of John E. Zuccotti, our friend and client for many years. His numerous accomplishments affected so many. We express our deepest condolences to his wife Susan and the entire Zuccotti family. Michael Lobel, Partner Emeritus 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John The members of the Land Use Department of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel mourn the passing of John Zuccotti, our mentor, friend, and colleague. John was a man of extraordinary intellect, integrity, and heart. As Chair of the City Planning Commission, he implemented innovative planning policies and a more transparent planning process, and he continued to serve the City that he loved as a businessman, as a lawyer, and also as an advisor to many non-profits. We will miss his warmth and his wise counsel. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Susan, their children Gianna, Andrew and Milena and their families, and to all who mourn his passing. 1

ZUCCOTTI--John. We have lost New York City's chief champion. His imprint on this City and on Brookfield, the company he steered, will last for generations to come. Condolences to the entire Zuccotti family. Suri Kasirer and the Kasirer Consulting team. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of real estate, civic and environmental leader John Zuccotti. John will be remembered for his leadership in New York City government and for his dedication to the cultural and educational vitality of the city. WCS is grateful for his personal attention to the New York Aquarium and for advancing conservation through his leadership of the board of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. We will honor John as we continue our work with the foundation to ensure a climate healthy environment across the nation and as we build a vibrant new New York Aquarium on Coney Island. We extend our heartfelt condolences to John's family, the former Susan Sessions, and their children Gianna, Andrew and Milena Zuccotti, and to their eight grandchildren, and his brother, Andrew. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. John's colleagues at Tufo & Zuccotti mourn the death of their mentor, partner and friend. We extend our condolences to Susan, Gianna, Andrew, and Milena and their families. We remember with great affection our most recent reunion in 2014 when John was at his best. 1/3

DALL--Robert F. Hofstra University is deeply saddened by the passing of Robert F. Dall, an alumnus and member of the Board of Trustees. In the 1970s while working for Salomon Brothers, Mr. Dall conceived and oversaw the first sale of bonds backed by American home mortgages to large private investors, giving rise to a whole new trading industry on Wall Street. Mr. Dall graduated from Hofstra University in 1955 with a Bachelor of Business Administration degree. He was elected a Hofstra Trustee in 1984. In 1989 he established the Robert F. Dall Distinguished Professorship in Business, a title currently held by Professor Matthew C. Sonfield. After retiring from Salomon Brothers, Mr. Dall worked briefly for Morgan Stanley and Drexel Burnham Lambert before forming an investment partnership specializing in real estate. Hofstra University flags will be lowered to half staff in Mr. Dall's honor. Alan J. Bernon, Chair, Board of Trustees; Stuart Rabinowitz, President 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. Our firm - Weil, Gotshal & Manges - grieves the loss of John Zuccotti, Senior Counsel in our Real Estate practice. John was larger than life in so many respects which will be recounted for years to come in many places by the vast range of people whose lives he's touched. Here we recount a personal relationship which transcends that. John came to our firm through the long time efforts of our senior partner Ira Millstein, who had wooed him for years. John and Ira were close friends dating back to the fiscal crisis of the 1970s when John was the Deputy Mayor under Abraham Beame, in effect running the City during one of its most difficult times. Ira was his pro bono counsel and together they weathered the cross currents of bankers, unions, politics, law and many different personalities. They came to trust each other completely - they had to. From there they remained in close touch with Italian dinners in Little Italy, meetings with countless different people, and most importantly through their families. John was a very loving husband to his wife Susan and a wonderful and attentive father and grandfather. Over many years, Ira and John became each other's confidants and reliable source for advice. Finally, Ira convinced John to join Weil in 1997. Probably John would not appreciate this, but to Ira and all of us at Weil, John personified the golden rule which underlies all religions and ethics. He knew right from wrong and how to execute that. He brought that DNA to everything he was involved in, most importantly and currently to our partners and associates at Weil who sought his advice, for which he was always available. We will miss his presence and guidance deeply. And we feel for his family, to which he was so devoted. 1/3

NASOFF--Jerome (Jerry), 88 passed away in West Palm Beach, FL surrounded by his family. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Jerry is survived by his wife of 64 years, Elaine; sister, Ruth Levine; children, Rick (Nancy), Sue (Steven) Hirsch, and Michael (Donna). Cherished grandfather of Lauren (Mitch), Jodi, Andrew, Sarah, Kate and Danielle. Great- grandfather of Max. He was loved by all and will be dearly missed. Services at Boulevard - Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY on Wednesday, November 25 at 12pm. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. You were the friend among friends. We will miss all of our times together from our lunches to the trips around the world - Paris - Egypt - Italy - Sicily and Churchill, Canada. Your place in our hearts can never be replaced - you will always be unique. Love, Don & Barbara Zucker 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. We mourn his loss and send deepest condolences to Susan Zuccotti and the entire family. We remember John's unparalleled and defining contributions to the City he loved through the good and tough times. His devotion to Brookfield, the company he guided, to the many entities he shaped, and the people whose lives he made better were his hallmarks. His love of family and friends mattered most. He'll be watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, which he adored, from a high perch this year. Lisa Linden and all of us at LAK Public Relations, Inc. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. To many people John was a former First Deputy Mayor of New York, chairman of the Planning Commission and REBNY, founder of a law firm and real estate developer. To our family, he was a dear friend and confidant of our father. He was a gentle giant, always approachable and thoughtful. A true mensch. He will be sorely missed. We express our sincere condolences to Susan, Gianna, Andrew, Milena and the rest of the Zuccotti family. Laurie Zucker Lederman and David Lederman, Barbara and Wayne Albinder 1/3

HENSELMANN--Caspar passed away Saturday, November 14, 2015, at 82 years of age. Caspar was born in 1933 in Germany and grew up in Ticino, Switzerland. His family immigrated in 1950 to the United States and settled in Chicago, Illinois. He received a BFA from the Art Institute of Chicago and a diploma of medical illustration from the College of Medicine from the University of Illinois, putting himself through school working as a ballroom dance instructor. Upon graduation from college he worked in Detroit, Michigan, and during this time found his calling as a sculptor. In 1960, he settled in New York City where he worked as a medical illustrator, sculptor and professor of art. He has exhibited his artwork extensively in the US and Europe, including 25 solo shows, and his works can be found in museums and in many private collections both in Europe and the US. Caspar was a sweet, loving father and husband, an accomplished artist, chef, and dancer who loved and lived life to the fullest. He and his wife Evangeline loved traveling and particularly enjoyed spending summers in the Languedoc region of France at their summer home as well as on the island of Crete in Greece. Caspar is survived by his wife Evangeline Karantzakis Henselmann, sister Beatrice Werner Henselmann, two sons,Xavier Henselmann and Samuel Henselmann, five grandchildren and a host of extended family and friends. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John E. 1937-2015. Leader, Advisor, Confidant, Mentor, Colleague, Public servant, Patriot, Businessman, Builder, Nurturer, Of Institutions, Of Neighborhoods, Of Relationships, Of Family and Friends, Lifelong Learner, Indefatigable, Peripatetic World Traveler, Raconteur, Humorist, Kind Gentle and Modest, Outdoorsman, Fisherman, Expert, Pragmatist, Man of Integrity, Exemplary New Yorker, Loving Husband and Partner, Devoted Father, And Grandfather, Lifelong Friend. A man who excelled in so many aspects of life and relished every minute of it. A blessing to all who knew him and all New Yorkers. Our entire families mourn the loss of our dear friend. Howard and Abby Milstein Alan and Francie Wiener 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew A.,of Manhattan and Quogue, NY passed away peacefully on November 20, 2015 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. A native of South Philadelphia, Matthew graduated from Swarthmore College (1973), Boston University Law School (1976) and New York University Law School (LLM, 1979). In 1979, he joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, where he would go on to serve as co-head of the Tax Practice for over 25 years. Matthew was known in legal and business circles for his brilliant analytic mind, his ability to solve complex legal problems and to deconstruct complicated tax analysis. Both Chambers Global and Chambers USA repeatedly named Matthew in their top tier of lawyers, and he was listed in Euromoney's Guide to the World's Leading Tax Lawyers numerous times. He was named Best Lawyers' "2013 New York City Tax Lawyer of the Year," and Legal 500 U.S. Portfolio magazine included him in its list of the top 10 tax attorneys in the United States. Matthew took immense joy in his work, but he also had an abiding passion for books, music, film and art. He was particularly committed to bringing great theater to all audiences and served on the Board of Playwrights Horizons. His mind was always active, his intellect broad and deep, his wit clever and mischievous, but his heart was always with his family to whom he was profoundly devoted and whom he always loved and supported. He is survived by his children Amanda (25), Oliver (20) and Anthony (1), his wife Mariana, and his brother Kenny. We will miss him dearly. There will be a celebration of Matthew's life at 1pm on Monday, November 23, 2015 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, NYC. 1/3

BONDER--Ronne'. Born February 4 1935, died early October, 2015. Entrepreneur, designer, commercial artist, idea man, student of life. Father, grandfather, mentor, and friend, he was always on the go. He is survived by children Mark and Lisa, and grandchildren Jessica and Joseph. 1/3
BLOOM--Bernard D.,D.D.S. 4/11/22-11/23/92. 23 years ago today. Alive in our hearts forever. Jack 1/3

MERSZEI--Kevin Zoltan. Jan. 6, 1984 - Nov. 23, 2013 Gone, but always in our hearts and minds. In a life cut tragically short, you touched so many who remain blessed for having been your friend; foremost among them your real "brother" Robert, and your beloved bride Cristina. Without you we live with a void no one can fill. Love, Mom and Dad 1/3

CARRINGTON--Kathleen. Kathleen Connell Carrington, 88, passed away peacefully on November 7, 2015 in Greenville, South Carolina. Kay, as she was known by her friends and family, was a steadfast and loving wife and mother. Born January 11, 1927 in Jersey City, New Jersey to John Norman Connell and Helen Burke Connell, Kay was one of nine children. Beautiful and unassuming, with an easy sense of humor and disarming smile, Kay graduated from Notre Dame College in Baltimore soon after the Second World War. Shortly thereafter she married Jim Carrington, a three-sport All-American, at the U.S. Naval Academy. In what has been described as a fairytale wedding, the midshipmen in their dress-whites rained rice upon the stunningly beautiful newlyweds as they ran beneath a shining arc of crossed sabers. Kay taught school until the arrival of the first of her five children, whom she raised in or near seaports around the world, from Yokosuka, Japan to Annapolis, Maryland. Like most Navy wives, while her husband was away at sea, often for months at a time, she stoically ran the householdwithout ever a complaint. Kay and Jim taught their children a great deal, but perhaps their most precious legacy was setting an example of how wonderful a marriage can be. As irony would have it, in the precise moment of Kay's sudden passing, all her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren were gathered together in California for the marriage of her grandson Michael. The thought would have pleased her to no end. Kay is survived by her daughters, Wendy Carrington, Nancy (Steve) Crown, and Kathleen (Steven) Anderson; sons, James Carrington, Jr., and Timothy (Cathleen) Carrington; sisters, Shelly Cullen, Madeleine Reilly, Elizabeth De Souza; brother, James Connell; ten grandchildren; four great-grandchildren; and many nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her parents; husband James H.H. Carrington; sisters, Elise Leahy, Mary Lou Towey, and Nancy Bockus; brother, Jack Connell; and daughter-in-law Antonella Murgia Carrington. A service celebrating Kay's life is being planned for the spring of 2016. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Rheumatology Research Foundation, 2200 Lake Boulevard NE, Atlanta, GA 30319 or www.rheumresearch.org. 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew, on November 20, 2015. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our partner and friend Matthew Rosen. A co-head of our tax practice, Matthew was a rare kind of lawyer -- one of the very finest tax practitioners of his generation and an unsurpassed mentor of the generations growing up under him. He led by example and will be remembered as always supporting new talent and the expansion of the practice into new spheres. Matthew joined our New York tax team in 1979 and, building upon the culture of camaraderie he inherited, enhanced the tightly knit group's reputation exponentially. Matthew handled every aspect of tax work and developed various types of financial instruments. He was repeatedly ranked among the top practitioners of his field. Raised in South Philly, Matthew attended Swarthmore College ('73) and Boston University School of Law ('76) and received an LLM from New York University School of Law ('79). He is survived by his wife, Mariana, and his children, Amanda, Anthony and Oliver. He will be missed greatly by all of us. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. You were the friend among friends. We will miss all of our times together from our lunches to the trips around the world - Paris - Egypt - Italy - Sicily and Churchill, Canada. Your place in our hearts can never be replaced - you will always be unique. Love, Don & Barbara Zucker 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of real estate, civic and environmental leader John Zuccotti. John will be remembered for his leadership in New York City government and for his dedication to the cultural and educational vitality of the city. WCS is grateful for his personal attention to the New York Aquarium and for advancing conservation through his leadership of the board of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. We will honor John as we continue our work with the foundation to ensure a climate healthy environment across the nation and as we build a vibrant new New York Aquarium on Coney Island. We extend our heartfelt condolences to John's family, the former Susan Sessions, and their children Gianna, Andrew and Milena Zuccotti, and to their eight grandchildren, and his brother, Andrew. 1/3

KIPLINGER--Austin Huntington "Kip". Cornell University mourns the passing of Austin "Kip" Kiplinger '39, chairman emeritus of the Cornell University Board of Trustees and Presidential Councillor. Husband of the late Mary Louise "Gogo" Kiplinger, and father of Knight Kiplinger '69, and the late Todd Kiplinger '68. Grandfather of Brigham Kiplinger '03 and Daphne Kiplinger '07. Kip's long, full life was exemplified by his achievements in publishing and journalism, as well as by his unwavering service, leadership and philanthropy to Cornell, the impact of which can be seen across the Ithaca campus. Kip was the first of three generations of Kiplingers who are cherished members of our Cornell family. We express our deepest sympathy to Knight, Brigham and Daphne, and the entire Kiplinger family. Robert S. Harrison Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University Elizabeth Garrett President, Cornell University Harold Tanner and Peter C. Meinig Chairmen Emeriti of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University 1/3

SCARF--Herbert Eli, age 85, of New Haven, CT and Sag Harbor, NY, died peacefully in his home in Sag Harbor with his family by his side. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, best-selling author Maggie Scarf; his daughter Martha Samuelson, her husband Paul, and their sons Charlie, Tom and David; his daughter Betsy Stone, her husband Mike, and their children Deborah, Sarah and Daniel, and his daughter Susan Merrell, her husband Jim, and their children Maggie and Jake. Herb was a Sterling Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University, where he taught for over 50 years. Herb received numerous professional recognitions and awards, including being named a member of the American Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Sciences, and receiving both the Frederick Lanchester Award and the John von Neumann medal from the Operations Research Society of America. He was recognized as a Distinguished Fellow of the American Economics Association in 1991. He was recognized in many Nobel prize citations including those of Gerard Debreu and Lloyd Shapley for his ground breaking contributions to economics. He was a mentor to generations of Ph.D. students and enjoyed daily coffee with his colleagues at Yale's Cowles Foundation. Herb was an early feminist. The accomplishments of his wife and his daughters were so important to him, and he basked in their various successes. Herb had a huge number of interests, including foreign travel, music, and art. He went everywhere and listened to everything. Herb touched so many people and helped them in their lives. We will miss him immensely. There will be a celebration of Herb's life early in 2016 at Yale. 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. Our firm - Weil, Gotshal & Manges - grieves the loss of John Zuccotti, Senior Counsel in our Real Estate practice. John was larger than life in so many respects which will be recounted for years to come in many places by the vast range of people whose lives he's touched. Here we recount a personal relationship which transcends that. John came to our firm through the long time efforts of our senior partner Ira Millstein, who had wooed him for years. John and Ira were close friends dating back to the fiscal crisis of the 1970s when John was the Deputy Mayor under Abraham Beame, in effect running the City during one of its most difficult times. Ira was his pro bono counsel and together they weathered the cross currents of bankers, unions, politics, law and many different personalities. They came to trust each other completely - they had to. From there they remained in close touch with Italian dinners in Little Italy, meetings with countless different people, and most importantly through their families. John was a very loving husband to his wife Susan and a wonderful and attentive father and grandfather. Over many years, Ira and John became each other's confidants and reliable source for advice. Finally, Ira convinced John to join Weil in 1997. Probably John would not appreciate this, but to Ira and all of us at Weil, John personified the golden rule which underlies all religions and ethics. He knew right from wrong and how to execute that. He brought that DNA to everything he was involved in, most importantly and currently to our partners and associates at Weil who sought his advice, for which he was always available. We will miss his presence and guidance deeply. And we feel for his family, to which he was so devoted. 1/3

GRAF--Ruth. Congregation Rodeph Sholom notes with sorrow the death of our long-time, devoted member, Ruth Graf, widow of Ernst Graf. We will miss her love for family, friends and Temple. Our deepest condolences to her dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Martin Flumenbaum, President 1/3

GRACE--Harvey. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Harvey Grace. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Reva, and their family. Robert D. Lang, President Harvey Karofsky, Secretary 1/3

SPIRO--Andrew Eugene. Dearest Father, Ten years ago you went to Heaven, though you are with us every day. Your love, quiet strength, wisdom, humor and elegance inspire and guide us each day. We love you always, Your children 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John The members of the Land Use Department of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel mourn the passing of John Zuccotti, our mentor, friend, and colleague. John was a man of extraordinary intellect, integrity, and heart. As Chair of the City Planning Commission, he implemented innovative planning policies and a more transparent planning process, and he continued to serve the City that he loved as a businessman, as a lawyer, and also as an advisor to many non-profits. We will miss his warmth and his wise counsel. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Susan, their children Gianna, Andrew and Milena and their families, and to all who mourn his passing. 1
WEISSMAN--Morton, 11/24/62 You are remembered. You are missed. You are loved. Estelle Weissman Fassler 1/3

YARMON--Betty. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Betty Yarmon on November 23, 2015. Betty started her career in the fashion industry and became the fashion editor for Palm Beach Life. She would later on become Editor in Chief of Party Line Publishing, a public relations newsletter, started by her loving late husband, Morton Yarmon. Betty took great pride in carrying on the Yarmon tradition of giving. She was a member on the board of Beth Isreal Hospital and a Trustee of Continnum Health Partners, Betty will be best known for her beauty and elegance. She will be greatly missed by her close confidant/caregivers, Gloria De Gannes and Joseph Pearsall. Also by the Yarmon's of Toronto, Alaska, The Goldstein's of New York, Casey Cook, Hector Hilario and Gregory Ryan. Visitation will be held on Tuesday 5pm-7pm. Chapel service will be on Wednesday 10:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel" 81st Street and Madison Avenue. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery Hartsdale, NY. 1/3

Mangones. Beloved great-grandmother of Ezra S. Mangones and Thalia F. Mangones. Member of the New York Bar and longtime attorney with the Legal Aid Society. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St., Whitestone, NY. Visiting Friday, November 27, 2015 from 2pm to 5pm with a service at 3pm. 1/3

EPSTEIN--Edward, of Englewood Cliffs, Fort Lee and Boca Raton at nearly 91 years of age on November 23, 2015. Beloved husband of Eleanor (Levinson). Patriarch of a large family of four sons, Mark and Jodi, Larry and Nancy, Andrew and Laurel, Steven and Robin. Grandfather to Josh and Lindsay, Michael and Kiera, Brett, Zachary and Alissa, Jessie and Scott Rudin, Amanda and Nick Godfrey, Danielle, Erika, Caroline, Jacob, Olivia and Ben. Decorated veteran of WWII, fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Deeply involved in the Jewish community. Eternal optimist with an infectious smile. World-wide traveler and adventurer. Adoring great-grandfather to Max, Jordan, Ava, Aviva, Leo, Judah and Oliver. Will be greatly missed by the entire loving family and friends within the community. Funeral services Wednesday November 25th at 10:00am at Temple Emanu-el, Closter, NJ. Shiva to be announced later. 1/3
AMENDOLAGINE--Vita Gioia. 11/24/08 If we had a flower for every time we thought of you, we could walk through our garden forever. Your loving family misses you very much. 1/3

MITJANS--Saturnino Herrero, passed away on November 21, 2015 at the age of eighty-two. All the employees of Medula Network and Peridicos Asociados Latinoamericanos 1/3

HARVEY--Homer. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the passing of Homer Harvey, of Los Angeles. A devoted supporter for more than three decades, he followed in the footsteps of his parents, Leo and Lena, who established the Technion Harvey Prize, considered by many to be a precursor to the Nobel Prize. Homer Harvey was a successful businessman, who together with his father, and brother Lawrence, formed Harvey Aluminum, one of the world's largest privately owned aluminum companies. He was an Honorary Life Member of the Technion Board of Governors, a Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents, and a Technion Guardian, a designation for those who have reached the highest level of support. Mr. Harvey received an Honorary Technion Doctorate in 1989. We offer our sincere sympathies to his beloved wife of 65 years, Gloria, daughters Ruth Zommick, Lillian Banchik, and Julie Marquez, and the entire Harvey family. American Technion Society Zahava Bar-Nir, President Scott Leemaster, Chairman of the Board Jeffrey Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. John's colleagues at Tufo & Zuccotti mourn the death of their mentor, partner and friend. We extend our condolences to Susan, Gianna, Andrew, and Milena and their families. We remember with great affection our most recent reunion in 2014 when John was at his best. 1/3

HALPERT--Carolyn McDaniel, passed away suddenly, but peacefully, after a short illness, on Sunday, November 15, 2015. She is predeceased by her beloved husband of over 40 years, Dr. Wesley Halpert. Carolyn was born in Memphis, TN in 1938. In 1960 she graduated from Lambuth College and moved to New York City to pursue an acting career. She performed off-Broadway and in summer stock, earning her Equity and SAG cards. Carolyn's love for performing merged with her deep faith. Over the past 25 years, during her involvement with the Network of Biblical Storytellers, she wrote moving stories and performed monologues, bringing to life many often overlooked women in the Bible. Carolyn has been a devoted member of Christ Church United Methodist in NYC, singing in the choir and holding many leadership positions. Carolyn was known for her fabulous cooking and gracious hospitality. Every holiday season for the past 45 years, Carolyn and Wesley opened their home and warmly welcomed family and friends to celebrate with them. Carolyn is survived by her dear brother Jim McDaniel, sister-in-law, Becky, niece Leslie VanHiel, and nephew, Jeffrey McDaniel, as well as her nieces Amy McGahan and Nancy Watson, their husbands, Michael and Don, their children, Michelle, Emma, Michael and Chelsea, granddaughter, Ariele, and her beloved kitties Zoey and Abby. A memorial service to honor Carolyn's life will be held at Christ Church United Methodist on Sunday, January 10th, 2016 at 2pm. All are invited to attend. 1/3

LEVINE--Jeffrey Z.,73. Peacefully passed away in North Palm Beach, November 23, after a long battle with cancer. Beloved wife of 46 years, Sharen (nee) Sackler, and devoted sons Adam and Jason deeply mourn his loss. A loving brother-in-law, uncle, cousin, friend and true gentleman, his sense of humor, wisdom, and warmth will be greatly missed. Raised in Chicago, Jeff graduated from University of Illinois. While raising his family in Teaneck, NJ, Jeff enjoyed a successful career at Grey Advertising. Services: Gutterman Musicant, Hackensack, NJ, November 25, noon; Memorial Service: NPB, TBA. Donations: ACS. 1/3

MANN--Eileen E.,of New York, NY, died on November 22, 2015. Loving mother to Denise and Tracy. Mother-in-law to David and Peter. Adoring grandmother to Jillian, Katie, Teddy, Daniel and Evan. Devoted daughter to Miriam and George. Be- loved sister to Gilda and Marvin. True cousin and friend to Joyce Spector, caring partner to Barry Weinstein (the maker), and stepmother and step-grandmother to the Weinstein and Rosen families. She was one of the greats. Forever in our hearts. May you finally have peace. We love you mommy. Give Whiskey a kiss from us all. Funeral services will be held at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th St. on Tuesday, November 24th at 11:30am. Memorial donations may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, www.pdf.org. 1/3

ROSEN--Matthew. We note with sorrow the passing of our member, Matthew Rosen, and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. We mourn his loss and send deepest condolences to Susan Zuccotti and the entire family. We remember John's unparalleled and defining contributions to the City he loved through the good and tough times. His devotion to Brookfield, the company he guided, to the many entities he shaped, and the people whose lives he made better were his hallmarks. His love of family and friends mattered most. He'll be watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, which he adored, from a high perch this year. Lisa Linden and all of us at LAK Public Relations, Inc. 1/3

NASOFF--Jerome (Jerry), 88 passed away in West Palm Beach, FL surrounded by his family. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Jerry is survived by his wife of 64 years, Elaine; sister, Ruth Levine; children, Rick (Nancy), Sue (Steven) Hirsch, and Michael (Donna). Cherished grandfather of Lauren (Mitch), Jodi, Andrew, Sarah, Kate and Danielle. Great- grandfather of Max. He was loved by all and will be dearly missed. Services at Boulevard - Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY on Wednesday, November 25 at 12pm. 1/3

KLEIN--Eleanor. Died November 20, 2015. Loving sister to Linda. Loving Aunt to Marc and Wendy. Loving greataunt to Arin and Justin. Preceded in death by parents Reuben and Gussie. Eleanor spent her professional life as a buyer in the garment center. She enjoyed political discussions and spending time with family and friends. Contributions can be made to Ruth Rales Jewish Family Services www.ralesjfs.org 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. We have lost New York City's chief champion. His imprint on this City and on Brookfield, the company he steered, will last for generations to come. Condolences to the entire Zuccotti family. Suri Kasirer and the Kasirer Consulting team. 1/3

SCHREIER--Sandra, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Scarsdale, New York, died in Florida on November 22, at age 84, pre-deceased by her parents, Irving and Goldie Schwartz, and by her husband, Fred Schreier, of blessed memory. Her loving family include her brother, Stephen L. Schwartz (Lety); her sister-in-law, Ruth Borenstein; her children, Andrew (Alison), William and Rhonda; five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. SPIRO--Andrew Eugene. Dearest Father, Ten years ago you went to Heaven, though you are with us every day. Your love, quiet strength, wisdom, humor and elegance inspire and guide us each day. We love you always, Your children 1/3

TURNER--William Ian Mackenzie, Jr. William "Bill" Turner died peacefully on November 20th. He had battled declining health for several years. Bill had a very distinguished business career. He moved to Montreal in 1954 and worked for Ingersoll-Rand for nine years. After five years as President of Power Corporation, he led Consolidated-Bathurst for two decades before "retiring" to his private office eyrie in Place Ville Marie. He also served on numerous boards of major Canadian and international corporations. Bill was born in Sharon, PA. Shortly thereafter, the family returned to Toronto where Bill earned a degree in Engineering from the University of Toronto. At Harvard Business School, he met his first wife, Ann (deceased). He is survived by their four children: Bill (Barbara), Julia (Peter), Jamie (Martha) and Carol (Gerard), eleven grandchildren, his brother Peter, and three nephews. In 1989, Bill married Nancy Gray and became an active stepfather to Lisa (Alan), Susan, Andy (Larcia) and a caring step- grandfather to their ten children. Bill had many keen interests beyond business. He was exceptionally proud of Bishop's University where he served as Chancellor 1987-1995. He was an active supporter and promoter of the arts, particularly the Stratford Festival and Canada Council's Musical Instrument Bank. Bill led a major fundraising campaign in the 1980's for the Royal Victoria Hospital and was invested into the Order of Canada in 1987. He travelled to all corners of the globe but still liked nothing more than going to cheer on the Canadiens and the Expos. He was a bon vivant, a raconteur, a connoisseur of Montreal's restaurant scene, and a gracious and generous host. Perhaps his greatest legacy was his ability to demand and inspire high standards, particularly in education, and still treat everyone with decency and respect. A memorial service will take place at 1pm on Saturday, November 28th at Christ Church Cathedral, 635 St. Catherine St. West in Montreal, Quebec. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Stratford Festival, www.stratfordfestival.ca. 1/3

HANDMAN--Rita May, whose life was characterized by courage, compassion, and Junior Mints, died peacefully at home on November 23, 2015. She is survived by her children Edward and Beth, eight devoted grandchildren, and sadly predeceased by Heidi and Richard, as well as her husband Robert, sister Arlene Wolf and brother Bert Kronen. A memorial service will be held at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West, on Saturday, November 28, 11am. 1/3
MANSON--Florence Sando. 9/1/1918 - 11/25/2013 "To live in the hearts of those we leave behind is not to die." Arthur Cynthia & Jeff and family Anthony & Angela and family 1/3

ROEPER--Edgar Max. It is with great sadness that we mourn the loss of husband, brother and friend Edgar Max Roeper, 67, who passed away after a lifelong struggle with lymphoma on November 23, 2015. An avid tennis player and a fan of the game (along with the New York Rangers and Mets), Edgar had unique wit and intellect and a special relationship with each and every person who knew him. He was always clever and generous. Edgar is survived by his soulmate and wife of 20 years, Jane Epstein. He will be missed by his sisters, Lilian and Linda, and in-laws, Andy, Randy, Bruce, Sue and Jeff, and mother-in-law, Muriel, as well as his many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. The laughter and love we shared made all of our lives richer. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, November 25, 2015, at 11:30am at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. Donations in Edgar's memory may be made to the Carolinas HealthCare Foundation (Levine Cancer Institute Carolinas HealthCare Hematology Research Fund, 1221 East Morehead Street, Charlotte, NC 28204); The Weill Cornell Medicine Lymphoma Program, Division of Hematology-Oncology (525 East 68 Street, Box 403, New York, NY 10065); or The Central Park Conservancy. 1/3

YARMON--Betty. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Betty Yarmon, who served as a Trustee of the former Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners for nearly 20 years. She and her husband were steadfast in their commitment, and showed their support by generously naming the Betty and Morton Yarmon Center for Parkinson's Disease, the Betty and Morton Yarmon Neurobehavior and Alzheimer's Disease Center, the Betty and Morton Yarmon Center for Healthy Aging, and the Betty and Morton Yarmon Stroke Center at Mount Sinai Beth Israel. We extend our deepest condolence to Betty's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

EPSTEIN--Edward. It is with great sorrow that the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades mourns the loss of Edward Epstein (z"l), a man of great generosity who supported Judaism, Israel the Jewish world at large. As a founder of our JCC, he helped build not only a Jewish Community Center, but a Jewish community that will embrace Jewish life and recreation for generations to come. Ed's life is an inspiration to us all and we send our sincerest condolences to his wife Eleanor, his four sons and their wives and his grand and great grandchildren. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. He was deeply loved and will be sorely missed. JoJo Rubach, President; Jordan Shenker, CEO 1/3

HAUBENSTOCK--Eugene Ira, 98, passed away on November 21 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Formerly of Boynton Beach, FL and Fair Lawn and Paterson, NJ, he was the son of Max and Lillian Haubenstock. A graduate of Montclair Academy and Lafayette College he was a past President of Temple Emanuel in Paterson and former President of S. Federbush Co. Predeceased by his wife of 63 years, Eleanor (Prell), he is survived by daughter Eileen Kelman (Edward), sons Mark (Sue) and Steven (Cathy) and grandchildren Beth, Alex, Max and Samantha Haubenstock. Predeceased by brother Martin and survived by brother, Alan. Contributions to a charity of your choice. 1/3

NEWMAN--Milton R. (April 25, 1941-November 21, 2015) From his essay in "Grand Central Terminal: City Within the City" published 1982: We need a Warhol (Donald Trump?) to wrench it out of context, paint it garish colors, and force us, finally, to see it again. We need to rehear its stories and relearn its lessons . . . before the city builds itself into hopeless chaos. 1/3

NICKEL--Albert G. The Board of Trustees and staff of CancerCare are saddened at the loss of Albert Nickel, devoted Trustee since 2007. Al was an incredibly generous and active fundraiser and member of our Board. Always evident were his love for life, strong faith and dedication to his family. Our deepest condolences to Al's wife, Dana, and his daughters, Grace and Olivia. 1

KLEIN--Eleanor. Died November 20, 2015. Loving sister to Linda. Loving Aunt to Marc and Wendy. Loving greataunt to Arin and Justin. Preceded in death by parents Reuben and Gussie. Eleanor spent her professional life as a buyer in the garment center. She enjoyed political discussions and spending time with family and friends. Contributions can be made to Ruth Rales Jewish Family Services www.ralesjfs.org 1/3

LEWITT--Laurence Glenn, born July 26, 1930, died November 15, 2015 at the age of 85. Mr. Lewitt was a graduate of Hofstra University as well as a Chartered Life Underwriter. A long-time independent insurance agent and pension expert, Mr. Lewitt served in the Navy during the Korean War as a meteorologist. He married Roberta Lewitt on June 23, 1956 and had two children, Michael Eric of Boca Raton, FL and David Marc of Port Chester, NY. He is survived by his wife and sons as well as his brother James and his three grandchildren Alessia, Alexander and Preston. On November 16, 2015 a Shiva Minyan was held at Mr. Lewitt's home in Boynton Beach, FL. 1/3

EPSTEIN--Edward. The officers and members of the Board of Directors of the Jewish Home Family note with profound sorrow the passing of our devoted supporter and very dear friend, husband of our board member, Eleanor, and father-in-law of our board member, Nancy--Ed Epstein. Ed and his beloved wife, Ellie, were critical driving forces in the development of the Jewish Home. Their foresight, counsel, and ability to involve others in our mission of providing for elders in our community resulted in the creation of our Home and continues to this day. A successful business man and generous philanthropist, together Ed and Eleanor exhibited a profound commitment to countless organizations and causes in the local, national and international Jewish communities. He will be missed by many. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Eleanor, his children, Mark and Jodi, Larry and Nancy, Andrew and Laurel, Steven and Robin their many grandchildren, great-grandchildren and his entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Eli Ungar, Chairman of the Board Carol Silver Elliott, President and CEO 1/3
MAILER--Adele. Our condolences to Danielle and Betsy and their families. The Klinghoffer Family 1/3

BLOOM--Bernard, of New York City, died on November 23, 2015 at age 83. Loving husband of Rochelle, devoted father of Bradley and adoring grandfather of Evan, Travis and Marisa. He was a proud Canadian from Montreal who never forgot his roots. A New Yorker since 1966, he was in commercial real estate until he introduced Teuscher Chocolates of Switzerland to the US in 1977. He ran that business until his retirement in 2005. A true lover of the arts, he supported the Opera and New York Philharmonic. Funeral service Wednesday November 25, 2015, 12:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Contributions in his memory may be to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation. 1/3
FORD--Shirley R. Dear S, more precious was the light in your eyes than all the roses in the world. Eternal love, Your T. 1/3

OWEN--Richard. (1922-2015) Manhattan School of Music and its Board of Trustees are saddened by the passing of Judge Richard Owen, a deeply valued member of the School's Board of Trustees from 1979 to 2009. A true renaissance man--he was both a profoundly committed United States federal judge in New York and an accomplished composer of opera and art song--Judge Owen received an Honorary Doctor of Musical Arts from MSM in 1989. We know that his long, rich life and the many wonderful memories it inspires will be a source of comfort and joy to his family in the days and years ahead. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Owen family. Lorraine Gallard, Chair, Board of Trustees James Gandre, President 1/3

EPSTEIN--Edward, of Englewood Cliffs, Fort Lee and Boca Raton at nearly 91 years of age on November 23, 2015. Beloved husband of Eleanor (Levinson). Patriarch of a large family of four sons, Mark and Jodi, Larry and Nancy, Andrew and Laurel, Steven and Robin. Grandfather to Josh and Lindsay, Michael and Kiera, Brett, Zachary and Alissa, Jessie and Scott Rudin, Amanda and Nick Godfrey, Danielle, Erika, Caroline, Jacob, Olivia and Ben. Decorated veteran of WWII, fought in the Battle of the Bulge. Deeply involved in the Jewish community. Eternal optimist with an infectious smile. World-wide traveler and adventurer. Adoring great-grandfather to Max, Jordan, Ava, Aviva, Leo, Judah and Oliver. Will be greatly missed by the entire loving family and friends within the community. Funeral services Wednesday November 25th at 10:00am at Temple Emanu-el, Closter, NJ. Shiva to be announced later. 1/3
KIRSCHNER--Charlotte Gordon. Mommy, you've been gone 10 years, but you still loom large in my life. Love, Ann 1/3

WILLIAMS--George Burns, PhD, died in his home city of Raleigh, NC, on November 20, 2015, age 84. Son of Cora Boykins Burns and Oscar Davis Williams. Graduate of Broughton High School, UNC at Chapel Hill, Yale University. Dissertation: "Blitzkrieg and Conquest: Policy Analysis of Military and Political Decisions Preparatory to the German Attack upon Norway, April 9, 1940." Served his country in the United States Army, stationed in Germany; and in Central Intelligence Agency. College teaching career in political science: Colby College; Notre Dame University. Fluent in several languages, including German and Russian, Williams was a farmer, genealogist, lover of classical music, nature walks. Episcopalian. Member of the Order of First Families of North Carolina and the Society of the Cincinnati. On the family farm, he erected a monument to African-American slaves who worked and lived on the land in previous centuries. He is survived by close cousin, Christopher Reid of Warrenton, NC. 1/3

WATTS-- Jerry Gafio. The Graduate Center, CUNY, deeply mourns the loss of Professor Jerry Gafio Watts, a leading scholar of African American political thought. An exceptional teacher and mentor, Jerry was known for his intellectual courage and commitment to students, colleagues, and friends. We send deepest condolences to his family. In lieu of flowers, please send donations "In honor of Professor Jerry G. Watts" to the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, 40 Rector Street, 5th Floor, New York, NY 10006 or the United Negro College Fund, 1805 7th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20001. Chase F. Robinson, President, The Graduate Center 1/3

WEINSWIG--Shepard. Shepard "Shep" A. Weinswig, 79, passed away on November 23 in Fort Wayne, Indiana. He was born June 1936 to Irving and Eve Weinswig in Boston, MA and was married to Lorraine Bowers for nearly 47 years. Shep, a graduate of Harvard and the University of Arizona was employed as an optical engineer at ITT Aerospace for 37 years. He was passionate about work, reading, bridge, his dog Mr. Paddy, and his friends. Most of all, he loved his family and visiting with his grandchildren. Survivors include his wife; his daughter, Deborah Weinswig and her husband, Maxwell Kahn, of New York; his son, Mark Weinswig and his wife, ZsuZsi Hamburger, of Menlo Park; four grandchildren Ezra, Zahava, Ryan and Evan; three sisters Susan Philips of GA, Leslie Greenberg of MA, Ilise Rubinow of PA. The funeral will be held on November 25 at 11:30am at D.O. McComb & Sons, 1140 Lake Avenue in Fort Wayne, IN. Memorial donations can be made to Congregation Achduth Vesholom or the Fort Wayne Philharmonic. 1/3
POLLOCK--Jimmy. Gone 34 years. Loved and missed by Mom, Dad, Andy and Bobby. 1/3

NICKEL--Albert G. The Board of Directors of the Orthopaedic Foundation mourns the untimely passing of Albert G. Nickel 1943-2015 1/3

JONES--Wayne Allyn, Sr.,82, passed away November 23, 2015 in Binghamton, NY. Born in Batavia, NY on June 27, 1933, he was ninth in his 1955 class at VMI, a scholar graduate student at Cornell University and First Lieutenant in the Army Corps of Engineers. In 1948 he founded J&K Plumbing and Heating Co., which by 1982, was the eighth largest privately owned plumbing company in the United States. Wayne was a founding member of the Welsh Society and a founding member of the Southern Tier Sheet Metal Contractors Association Apprentice Program. He was an elder and head of the trustees of the First Presbyterian Church. Wayne and Joyce, his wife of 59 years, loved travel and visited over 150 countries together. Wayne is survived by his wife, Joyce Kathleen McPhail Jones, six children, 18 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. 1/3

NEWMAN--Milton R. (April 25, 1941-November 21, 2015) From his essay in "Grand Central Terminal: City Within the City" published 1982: We need a Warhol (Donald Trump?) to wrench it out of context, paint it garish colors, and force us, finally, to see it again. We need to rehear its stories and relearn its lessons . . . before the city builds itself into hopeless chaos. 1/3
