To his children; Elizabeth Gewirtz (Jason Juriako), Matthew Gewirtz (Lauren Rutkin), Joshua Gewirtz (Neota), Rivka Gewirtz (Bruce Little); to his grandchildren: Navah and Assata Little, Gabrielle Gewirtz, Jake, Talia and Sadie Gewirtz; to his sister Ruth (Morton) Levin, late brother Albert (Barbara) Gewirtz, and to all who were taught and touched by his intelligence, intellect, generosity and love for literature and theatre, we send our profound condolences. Funeral services; Friday November 27th, 11am at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, NJ. Charles Oransky, President; The Board of Trustees and Officers; and the Members of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, NJ 1/3

CHAUS--Josephine. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our devoted member, Josephine Chaus. With her family, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life and shall endure forever in all our hearts. 1/3

TURNER--William Ian Mackenzie, Jr. William "Bill" Turner died peacefully on November 20th. He had battled declining health for several years. Bill had a very distinguished business career. He moved to Montreal in 1954 and worked for Ingersoll-Rand for nine years. After five years as President of Power Corporation, he led Consolidated-Bathurst for two decades before "retiring" to his private office eyrie in Place Ville Marie. He also served on numerous boards of major Canadian and international corporations. Bill was born in Sharon, PA. Shortly thereafter, the family returned to Toronto where Bill earned a degree in Engineering from the University of Toronto. At Harvard Business School, he met his first wife, Ann (deceased). He is survived by their four children: Bill (Barbara), Julia (Peter), Jamie (Martha) and Carol (Gerard), eleven grandchildren, his brother Peter, and three nephews. In 1989, Bill married Nancy Gray and became an active stepfather to Lisa (Alan), Susan, Andy (Larcia) and a caring step- grandfather to their ten children. Bill had many keen interests beyond business. He was exceptionally proud of Bishop's University where he served as Chancellor 1987-1995. He was an active supporter and promoter of the arts, particularly the Stratford Festival and Canada Council's Musical Instrument Bank. Bill led a major fundraising campaign in the 1980's for the Royal Victoria Hospital and was invested into the Order of Canada in 1987. He travelled to all corners of the globe but still liked nothing more than going to cheer on the Canadiens and the Expos. He was a bon vivant, a raconteur, a connoisseur of Montreal's restaurant scene, and a gracious and generous host. Perhaps his greatest legacy was his ability to demand and inspire high standards, particularly in education, and still treat everyone with decency and respect. A memorial service will take place at 1pm on Saturday, November 28th at Christ Church Cathedral, 635 St. Catherine St. West in Montreal, Quebec. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Stratford Festival, www.stratfordfestival.ca. 1/3

MASON--Nondita. Nondita Mason, a retired professor of postcolonial literature and theory at Hunter College, died on September 25 at her Manhattan apartment, one day after returning from a 23-day trip to Italy, Greece, and Turkey with her husband, Bryant Mason. They climbed the Acropolis to see the Parthenon in Athens; cruised the Aegean to Santorini, Rhodes, Patmos, Mykonos, and Limnos; heard classical music at an illuminated Greek amphitheater at Ephesus in Turkey; toured Istanbul, and visited the Coliseum and the Vatican among other historic sites. Ms. Mason was most happy to have her Brooklyn nephew, Indro Chaudhury Sartorio, join her in Rome. The cause was long-term complications of bronchiectasis, a disease for which there is no cure. "After 15 years of suffering with this disease, she simply ran out of energy, but we had a wonderful last trip together," her husband wrote. She was 73. They lived in Manhattan and on Atlantic Avenue in Amagansett. Ms. Mason regularly taught a course on V.S. Naipaul, the focus of her doctoral dissertation at New York University. She retired in 2008. In her daily life, her husband described her as "a private person and a consummate communicator, keenly aware of justice and injustice, and always with a captivating smile for the people she met. She was radiant with energy when preparing for and engaging with students in her classrooms." She always took note when students were "full of questions and surprises," but was firm when they did not live up to expectations, her husband said. She strived to inspire them to weave their perspectives with accurate information and "logically progressive thoughts." In announcing her death to faculty, the Hunter English department called her a "superb teacher, a valued mentor to junior colleagues, and an inspiring colleague," Mr. Mason said. She brought compassion, intelligence, and insight to everything she did at the college, her colleagues stated. 1/3

GLUSHAK--Elinor (nee Mazursky) Former actress, adored mother of actress Joanna Glushak and Dr. Cai Glushak mother- in-law of Martin DiCrisci, widow of Solomon Glushak, passed away November 10th in NYC. Native of South Carolina, moved to New York in 1949. Had stage and TV career in performance and production; later joined Solomon in his entertainment law practice. Cherished by sisters Paula, Rachel, nieces, nephews and many loving friends. 1/3

POPOWICH--Lorraine Sands passed away peacefully after a long illness on November 24. She was 79. Lorraine is survived by her beloved husband of over 59 years, David Popowich; their children, Lisa (Jonathan Stein), Andrea (Robert Meislin), and Yale (Tina Skouras); grandchildren, Rachel, Ariel, Sophie, Benjamin, Harry and Julian; and sister, Judith Newman. The best wife, mother, grandmother, sister anyone could ask for or imagine, Lorraine loved her family intensely and was beloved by everyone who knew her. She was beautiful, elegant, charming, smart, and had a keen sense of humor. She kept everyone laughing until the very end. A founder and board member of the National Museum Of American Jewish History and a board member of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Lorraine was a lover and patron of the arts, an avid reader and a world traveller. She will be profoundly missed. Services at Congregation Adath Jeshurun, Elkins Park, PA on November 27th at 10:30am. Donations may be made to the Abramson Cancer Center of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. 1

DESPOSITO--Olga Immaculata, died peacefully on November 23, 2015 in her 103rd year. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Robert, Barbara Weisz (the late John) and Christine. Adoring and devoted Nana of Barbara, Zachary and Zoe. Treasured aunt to many nieces and nephews. Visitation Friday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. Mass Saturday, 9:30am at St Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, NY. Interment to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: the John A. Weisz Scholarship, 1011 First Avenue, 18th Floor, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

CHAUS--Josephine. Chairwoman and Co-Founder of Bernard Chaus Inc., a trailblazer and role model for generations of women in leadership roles, devoted and beloved grandmother, mother, wife and friend. Overcoming modest beginnings and a most difficult and challenging childhood, Josephine was the American dream. First in partnership with her late husband and then on her own, Josephine was the tireless anchor of Bernard Chaus Inc. As a young mother, she endured the shocking and early loss of her husband, best friend and business partner. Left alone, she raised her then two young sons while taking the reins as one of our Nation's first female public company chief executive officers. Josephine's was a life ever so well led; filled with challenge, success and accomplishment. With singular determination, strength and uncompromising moral values, Josephine charted a course for her company and for her family. Her modesty and retiring personality were hallmarks most especially in the glow of constant career and business accolades including a profile by The New York Times with Josephine championed as the Survivor for Seventh Avenue in a cover story in the Sunday Business Section. But Josephine's unwavering determination to surmount the uncertainties of a business that has humbled so many was not her most satisfying and enduring achievement. Her greatest loves and what for Josephine were the most meaningful blessings and constant sources of joy were her beloved sons, Ariel and Aaron, daughter in-laws Robin and Lacey, Anna's mother Cassandra, and her cherished granddaughters, Zoie, Liv and Anna. Josephine will always live on in the smiles on their faces, their strong and independent personalities, and in their zest for life. Josephine will also live on in the hearts of her colleagues at the Company who in every sense were family to Josephine, and she will live on in the hearts of all whose lives she touched with her warmth, generosity and goodness. Marching to her own contrarian drum, embracing and cherishing every day of her life; Josephine's is a legacy of utmost grace and dignity. Rare and precious in every action and deed, Josephine embodied the American dream; she will be sorely missed. Services will be held Monday November 30th at Temple Emanu-El Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of gifts, the family has asked contributions be made to favorite charities in Josephine's name. 1/3

OWEN--Richard. Born December 11, 1922, in New York, NY, the Honorable Richard Owen, S.D.N.Y., died peacefully on November 20, 2015, in New York, NY. He was just shy of 93. A member of the Dartmouth Class of 1945, his undergraduate studies were interrupted for several years when he joined the Army Air Corps and served as a navigator in the Pacific during the Second World War. After returning and completing his studies at Dartmouth, he earned his L.L.B. from Harvard Law School in 1950. He relished his days as a trial lawyer, both in private practice and with the U.S. Attorney's Office and the Department of Justice. In 1973, President Nixon appointed him to the federal bench, where he served for almost 40 years. Judge Owen presided over numerous notable cases, including the Mafia Commission case and a copyright infringement case against former Beatle, George Harrison, whom the Judge found to have subconsciously plagiarized the tune for "My Sweet Lord". While maintaining a full-time legal career, Judge Owen also pursued his other passion: music. He studied composition with Vittorio Giannini at the Manhattan School of Music where he later received an honorary doctorate and became a member of the Board of Trustees. He met his late wife, Metropolitan Opera soprano Lynn Owen (1933-2014), while studying music at Tanglewood, and they married in 1960. The leading lady in many of his musical works, she was the great love of his life and the mother of his three sons, Carl, David and Richard. Judge Owen went on to compose nine operas, including "Abigail Adams" and "Rain," all of which have been performed and acclaimed throughout the U.S. and Europe, including in Lincoln Center. He was also an avid sailor and a champion in several boat designs. Judge Owen touched many lives, especially as a mentor to a generation of young lawyers and law clerks. Both his musical and legal legacy live on in his sons, David and Richard Jr., and his five grandsons, Richard III, Christopher, Peter, James and Thomas. Donations may be made to the Carl Owen Scholarship Fund, Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Ave. New York, NY 10027. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 a.m. on Friday, December 4, at the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, New York City. 1/3

MARKIM--Alfred. With great sadness we mourn the death of Alfred Markim, on November 24, 2015. With great joy we celebrate his full, successful life. Devoted son, brother, cherished husband, father, grandfather; Al was a pioneering TV actor, award-winning producer, visionary video executive. His legacy will survive him for decades. Al is perhaps best known as Astro, in the classic 1950s TV serial Tom Corbett, Space Cadet. Born in 1927 in Wilkes Barre, PA, Al served in the Army witnessing the Nuremberg trials. He later pursued acting, including stage and screen such as; TV's "Love of Life"; "La Ronde" at The Circle In The Square Theatre off- Broadway, and often co- hosted Jerry Lewis' Muscular Dystrophy Telethons. Al produced award-nominated movies including "The Fool Killer," and "The Pawnbroker," and was Executive Producer of the classic "Boys of Summer". Al was a pioneer who brought movies into home theaters. In 1968, he co- founded Teletronics and thereafter entered a partnership with Sony, creating the world's first and largest videocassette duplicating center (later Video Corporation of America sold to Ronald Perlman's McAndrew's Forbes and merged into Technicolor). He was Chairman of the International Tape Association and was inducted into the Video Hall of Fame in 1996. In retirement, he was President of his community's HOA; produced Second Half Strategies, a cable TV show; co- acted in local productions with his actress wife Sondra; and loved poker and the New York Yankees. In addition to Sondra, his soulmate of 53 years, Al leaves behind children Nancy (Fred), Dan (Sue), Gary (Nancy), Nina (John), and Carla (Gregg), 11 adoring grandchildren, and one greatgrandchild to be. Though he is gone, his light remains within all of us. In lieu of flowers: The Jewish Home Foundation 201-784-1414, or donate.DoctorsWithoutBorde rs.org. Services by Moritz Funeral Home, Tappan, NY 845-359-0890. 1/3

POPOWICH--Lorraine Sands passed away peacefully after a long illness on November 24. She was 79. Lorraine is survived by her beloved husband of over 59 years, David Popowich; their children, Lisa (Jonathan Stein), Andrea (Robert Meislin), and Yale (Tina Skouras); grandchildren, Rachel, Ariel, Sophie, Benjamin, Harry and Julian; and sister, Judith Newman. The best wife, mother, grandmother, sister anyone could ask for or imagine, Lorraine loved her family intensely and was beloved by everyone who knew her. She was beautiful, elegant, charming, smart, and had a keen sense of humor. She kept everyone laughing until the very end. A founder and board member of the National Museum Of American Jewish History and a board member of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Lorraine was a lover and patron of the arts, an avid reader and a world traveller. She will be profoundly missed. Services at Congregation Adath Jeshurun, Elkins Park, PA on November 27th at 10:30am. Donations may be made to the Abramson Cancer Center of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. 1

WEXLER--Toby, passed away on November 27, 2015. Devoted wife of the late Frank. Loving mother, grandmother and great- grandmother. Services Sunday 9:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. 1/3

NADEL--Murray, died peacefully on November 25, 2015 at his home in Boynton Beach, FL. His adoring wife of 62 years, Renee, and his beloved children, Sue, Ric and Jill, and grandchildren, Alana, Sara, Jacob and Charlie will miss him every day. Murray was the son of European immigrant parents, born in Brooklyn, NY on August 14, 1930. He attended Boys High and then Long Island University where he earned his bachelor's degree in accounting. He served his country during the Korean War and soon married his sweetheart, Renee. Murray established Nadel Industries, a cosmetic packaging manufacturer. During his 40 years in the industry, Murray introduced breakthrough technologies that led to heavy wall polyester bottles and jars, thus eliminating breakable glass packaging from the bathroom. He also pioneered offshore manufacturing in the industry and built a strong business relationship with his Chinese partners that continues to this day. Murray was seen as a visionary in the industry and was universally respected for his integrity and innovation. Murray was also a dedicated philanthropist and passionate activist, providing ongoing support to The Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Federation/UJA, the Anti- Defamation League, and AIPAC, among many others. He was an active and generous member of Anshe Shalom Synagogue of New Rochelle, NY, Beit Chaverim Synagogue of Westport, CT, and Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach, FL. Murray was a dear friend to so many; his warmth, humor and generosity made him a man who was truly loved by all who knew him. Donations in Murray's memory may be made to Anshe Shalom Synagogue of New Rochelle, NY, Beit Chaverim Synagogue of Westport, CT, or Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach, FL. 1/3

McMANUS--James Patrick, age 52 years, of Charlestown, MA, passed away peacefully Monday, November 23, 2015, surrounded by his family after a long illness. Jimmy was the loving and affectionate husband of Natalie McManus and the adoring father of Jack, Tara and Allie. Born May 21, 1963 to James and Susan McManus, Jim was raised in Hamden, CT with his sisters Mary, Anne and Susan. Along with his wife Natalie, parents, children and sisters, Jim is survived by his former wife and the mother of his children Robin Krawczyk, brothers-in-law Mark Levinsky and Brian Rogers, nephews Matt Levinsky, Aidan Smyth, James Smyth and Dylan Rogers, nieces Sarah Levinsky Paige Levinsky, Emma Smyth and Lily Rogers, godsons Matt Santello and James Gallagher, as well as many aunts, uncles and cousins. Visiting hours will be held for Jimmy on Monday, November 30, from 3 to 7pm, in St. Cecilia Church, 18 Belvidere St., in Boston's Back Bay. A Funeral Mass will be held at 10am on Tuesday, December 1st, in St. Cecilia Church. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the James Patrick McManus New Haven Scholarship Program. Checks can be made to James Patrick McManus Fund and sent to 7 Pier 7, Charlestown, MA 02129 (inquiries email natalied45@gmail.com). Services by the Murphy Funeral Home, Dorchester. For guestbook, please visit www.jmurphyfh.com. 1/3

CHAUS--Josephine. The Mount Sinai Health System family mourns the passing of Josephine Chaus, an extraordinary woman and generous philanthropist. Personally and through the Heart Research Foundation, she and her late husband, Bernard, provided support for a variety of key initiatives, including scholarships and surgery, and in particular funding that drove significant research endeavors in cardiology. MAHON--Dr. Christopher B.,MD, Consultant Psychiatrist (Galway City, Ireland and Florida, US) Chris died at home on December 22, 2014 in Ft Lauderdale, Florida at age 78. As the first anniversary of his death approaches, the Mahon family would like to thank everyone for their support and kindness. Your telephone calls and cards were greatly appreciated and have helped us in our grief. Also a big thank you to Dr. Mary Madden of Ft. Lauderdale and the hospice nurses who attended constantly. A native of Galway, Chris went to the US after finishing medical school at NUIG. After completing his residency in psychiatry in Chicago he moved to Fort Lauderdale where he practiced until a few weeks before his death of cancer. He was the son of Patrick Joseph (Sonny) Mahon and Eileen Fox-Mahon of Mary Street and the grandson of James and Hannah Mahon of Mahon's Hotel Forster Street and Thomas Fox and Margaret Fox-Killalea of Caherlea, Claregalway and Killalea's Pub, Galway City. One of six children, four of whom were physicians, he once quipped that he was the product of genetic predestination. In fact such humor, not to mention his keen intelligence and alert scientific curiosity sustained him throughout his arduous career. He was predeceased by his brother Tom of Springfield, Illinois. Also by his long term partner Read Johnson, whose tragic death in 2008 he found devastating. He is survived by his brother Jim J. Mahon of London, his brother Paul F. Mahon MD of Springfield Illinois, his brother Eugene J. Mahon MD of New York, his sister Maeve M. Mahon-Ferriter MD of Ireland, his sisters-in-law Margaret Mahon, Sharon Mahon and Delia Battin-Mahon, his brother-in-law Patrick J. Ferriter, his nephews Sean Mahon, Jason Mahon, Dominic Mahon, Eugene R. Mahon, and John P. Mahon and his nieces Rosalind Mahon and Emer Svoboda. He is deeply missed by his family and friends and by his patients to whom he dedicated all his professional life. Chris's erudition since childhood was prodigious; his depth of reading was phenomenal; his intellectual acuity remained razor sharp until the end. Through living a day at a time the Science of Mind had come to have great intellectual appeal to him as he tried to integrate the mysteries of the human condition into one unifying philosophy and in that spirit a secular prayer to guide him on his further after life odysseys is in order "may the roads of eternity rise to meet him and may the winds of time be always at his back." 1/3

CONDON--John J. We have lost an irreplaceable friend. John was passionate, knowledgeable, curious, loyal, generous, caring, dependable, supportive... and obstinate. It was that last quality that endeared him to us the most. He was a constant part of our lives and will continue to be so. Edwin Bacher, Joyce Hensley, Dinah Lustig, Judy Nadelson, Jessica Schein, Nancy Wickham 1/3

EMORY--Linda Rodgers. Weill Cornell Medicine is saddened by the passing of our friend and benefactor Linda Rodgers Emory. Longstanding, generous supporters of Weill Cornell Medicine, Linda and the Rodgers Family Foundation helped establish two named professorships - the Rodgers Family Foundation Professorship in Pediatric Urology and the Morton Coleman, M.D. Distinguished Professorship in Medicine - and championed cancer research and geriatric and palliative medicine. Linda was also a member of the NewYork Weill Cornell Council. She was warm, funny and smart, and we will miss her friendship. Our deepest condolences to her family. 1/3

NADEL--Murray, died peacefully on November 25, 2015 at his home in Boynton Beach, FL. His adoring wife of 62 years, Renee, and his beloved children, Sue, Ric and Jill, and grandchildren, Alana, Sara, Jacob and Charlie will miss him every day. Murray was the son of European immigrant parents, born in Brooklyn, NY on August 14, 1930. He attended Boys High and then Long Island University where he earned his bachelor's degree in accounting. He served his country during the Korean War and soon married his sweetheart, Renee. Murray established Nadel Industries, a cosmetic packaging manufacturer. During his 40 years in the industry, Murray introduced breakthrough technologies that led to heavy wall polyester bottles and jars, thus eliminating breakable glass packaging from the bathroom. He also pioneered offshore manufacturing in the industry and built a strong business relationship with his Chinese partners that continues to this day. Murray was seen as a visionary in the industry and was universally respected for his integrity and innovation. Murray was also a dedicated philanthropist and passionate activist, providing ongoing support to The Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Research Foundation, Federation/UJA, the Anti- Defamation League, and AIPAC, among many others. He was an active and generous member of Anshe Shalom Synagogue of New Rochelle, NY, Beit Chaverim Synagogue of Westport, CT, and Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach, FL. Murray was a dear friend to so many; his warmth, humor and generosity made him a man who was truly loved by all who knew him. Donations in Murray's memory may be made to Anshe Shalom Synagogue of New Rochelle, NY, Beit Chaverim Synagogue of Westport, CT, or Temple Emanuel of Palm Beach, FL. 1/3

STERN--Walter Jacob, 93, on November 27, 2015. Born in Hamburg, Germany, he immigrated to the United States in 1939 with father, Leopold, mother, Alice, and sister, Marion, and became a citizen in 1943. He served as an officer in the military, including working as a translator in Japan. He received a degree from the Stern School of Business at NYU, and began a career as an executive in the garment industry. In 1962, he married Ruth Klein. Based in Englewood, New Jersey, Walter, Ruth and daughter, Michelle, shared summers on Fire Island, as well as travels to far-flung locations. After retiring in 1994, Walter took volunteer assignments in Russia and Bulgaria, where his support was appreciated by the local businesses. He spent the last 15 years of his life with partner, Roswitha Kucera, dividing their time between New Jersey, Florida and Austria. Walter is remembered for his sharp mind, devotion to family, appreciation for fine art and good food, and doing the Sunday crossword with a pen. He is survived by daughter, Michelle Stern, partner, Roswitha Kucera, and nephews, Gary, Andre and Roger Adler. Service Tuesday, December 1, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam. 1/3

SWANN--Mark. Died November 14, 2015 in Jacksonville Beach, FL. He grew up in Stockbridge, MA, son of Jack and Mary Swann. Attended Lenox School and Le Rosey in Switzerland. BA from Harvard University, 1962, member of the AD, and masters from Cambridge University, England, 1965. Married Mary Dickerman, 1966, the mother of his four children. They lived in York, PA for ten years during which time he was a reporter at the York Gazette and Daily, pioneered organic beef farming, ran several Boston Marathons, and ran for Congress on an anti-nuclear power platform. He would open his campaign speeches by pointing out that he was on the Nixon White House Enemies list - a proud distinction he assumed he earned through his work fighting nuclear power while also promoting the great passion of his life: Ocean Solar Power (OTEC). He continued this passion and worked with Hilbert and Jim Anderson, founders of Sea Solar Power, Inc. for the next 50 years. In 1976, he moved to Washington, DC, where, for 35 years, he operated a fireplace restoration and design company focused on building more efficient fireplaces. He traveled to India to become a certified meditation instructor and then spent a decade teaching meditation to prisoners. He also spent fifteen years working with his lifemate, Diane Sollee, on her Smart Marriages campaign and conferences. In 2012, Mark and Diane retired to Jacksonville Beach, FL. His other passions were skiing, soccer, working for the Democrats - especially Obama; his fireplace manual; and he was a dedicated, life-long health nut. He said it was not even funny that after all his vitamins, vegetables, and jogging, his death was caused by an exotic disease, of which he had never heard, cardiac amyloidosis, for which there is no known cure, or even treatment - except to eat vegetables and exercise. He liked to point out that of the three types of cardiac amyloidosis he had the so-called wild type and he would also like to point out, for what it is worth, that his arteries were found to be clean as a whistle, no plaque anywhere. He is survived by four children: Leda (Hoag Holmgren), Nederland, CO; Maxine (Martin Sivak), Buenos Aires, Argentina; Jake (Sonya), Haverford, PA; and Kyle (Kristen), York, ME; nine grandchildren: Soren, Anders, Callen, Clyde, Mirabelle, Yan, Misha, Camilo, and Cedric; two step-children: Will (Margie) Sollee and Joe (MacRae) Sollee; five step-grandchildren: Mattie, Jack, Kate, Claudia and Josie. He is also survived by his sisters, Rosaly Bass of Peterborough, NH and Clover Swann of Stockbridge, MA; his brother, Nick Swann, also of Stockbridge; by many nieces, nephews, cousins and beloved colleagues and friends; and by his partner of 28 years, Diane Sollee, and her large extended family in Jacksonville, FL. He was predeceased by his brother, Robert Swann, of Stockbridge. A memorial service will be held on January 23, 2016, at noon at the Sidwell Friends School Meeting House in Washington, DC. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Brennan Center for Justice, www.brennancenter.org. 1/3
SKELSON--John, of Staten Island, NY, on November 19, 2015. Beloved Partner of Phyllis Featherstone. Great photographer and teacher. Loved by all. We will always love you John. 1/3

FOSTER--Sylvia, beloved wife of the late Mark Foster, whose life was characterized by love of family and great friends, died peacefully on November 27, 2015 surrounded by those who loved her most. She is survived by her children Stacia Blake, Monica Foster and Curtis Foster and her grandchildren Nicole, James, Chelsea and Maddie. Sylvia loved her family intensely and was beloved by all who met her. She never missed a nail or hair appointment. Graveside funeral, Sunday November 29, 2015 at 1:30pm at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. 1/3

GOODMAN--Stanley L.,February 10, 1927 - November 19, 2015 in Rancho Mirage, California. Stanley was educated at Townsend Harris in New York City (1941), received a BA from New York University (1946) and an LLB from NYU school of law (1953). Stanley practiced as an attorney and CPA and developed an expertise in forensic accounting. Stanley achieved national prominence as the valuation expert in the landmark New York case of O'Brien v. O'Brien, where he testified as to the intrinsic value of a medical license under the states newly enacted equitable distribution law. Stanley also served for several years as Vice President of Temple Israel, White Plaines, NY. Stanley is survived by his wife, Melinda Raphael. With his late wife, Eileen Goodman, he has two daughters; MJ Wolff (Richard) and Lois Richards (Marc), and four grandchildren; Brett Richards, William Wolff (Katie), Sarah Wolff and Max Richards and a great grandson Parker Jake Wolff. Additionally, he is survived by Melinda's daughters; Meg Marion (Michael), Marcy Goldenberg and grandson Jonah Marion. 1/3

LEVIN--A. Leo, 96, on November 24. He was a professor at the University of Pennsylvania Law School for almost fifty years, a Director of the Federal Judicial Center (1977-1987), and a fellow for the Center for Advanced Studies in the Behavioral Sciences (1959-60). He served as President of the Jewish Publication Society and the Jewish Exponent. He is survived by his beloved wife Doris, sons Allan and Jay, three grandchildren and three great grandsons. Services were held at the Lower Merion Synagogue in Bala Cynwyd, PA. Interment was at Har Jehuda Cemetery in Upper Darby, PA. Donations in his memory may be made to the University of Pennsylvania Law School and the Lower Merion Synagogue. www.levinefuneral.com 1

SCHREIER--Sandra, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Scarsdale, New York, died in Florida on November 22, at age 84, pre-deceased by her parents, Irving and Goldie Schwartz, and by her husband, Fred Schreier, of blessed memory. Her loving family include her brother, Stephen L. Schwartz (Lety); her sister-in-law, Ruth Borenstein; her children, Andrew (Alison), William and Rhonda; five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Graveside funeral at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York, on Tuesday, November 24 at 1:00pm. 1/3

PICOWER-SELTZER--Joan Deitch, Wednesday, November 25, 2015. A creative, strong, and generous woman, Joan was a loving mother to Jenny and Eve, an extraordinary Nana to Emily, Zoe, and Hannah, and a devoted friend to many. She will be greatly missed and in our hearts forever. 1/3

WECHSLER--Rushelle, passed away on November 25 at the age of 87. Beloved mother of Antonia Wechsler. Dear wife of the late Herman J. Wechsler. Lived for many happy years in her much loved New York City and summer home on Fire Island. Memorial service to be announced in the spring. 1/3

DE PINIES--Felix, 90, died on November 27 after a brief illness. He was born in Madrid and came to the USA in 1952 as a resident at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, where he rose to Executive Surgeon Director and Chairman of the Medical Board. He is survived by his wife, Carmen, his children, Carmen and Carlos, son-in-law, Fabian, grandchildren, Isabella and Nico and his loving nieces and nephews in the US and Spain. Funeral services will be privately held. 1/3

ZELNICK--Stacy Alexandra, 45, of Clinton Corners, passed away suddenly in an accident which occurred on Tuesday, November 24th, 2015 at her home. Born on August 19, 1970, in Hollywood, FL, she was the daughter of Irene (Levitt) Zelnick and Stephen Zelnick of New York City and Clinton Corners, NY. In addition to her mother and father, she is survived by a daughter; Jade Walker of Millbrook, NY and an uncle, Edward Zelnick, MD, of Hollywood, FL. Raised in New York City, Stacy was a graduate of St. Ann's School in Brooklyn, NY and attended Bard College in Annandale on Hudson, NY. She was beautiful, graceful, athletic, artistic, musical, an outstanding writer of fiction and poetry and very smart. She was vivacious and had a great sense of humor and was quick to laugh. She was great company and was always there for her friends. Her presence could light up a room. Stacy was also an avid horse lover and an amazing and accomplished equestrian. She was manager and head horse trainer of Willowbrook Riding Stables in Clinton Corners. Stacy will be sorely missed, especially by her daughter to whom she was devoted and by her parents who were devoted to her. Services were held Saturday, November 28th, 2015. Interment was held at Rhinebeck Cemetery, Rhinebeck, NY. Services are under the direction of Burnett & White Funeral Homes 7461 S. Broadway, Red Hook, NY. For directions, or to sign the online guest book, please visit www.Burnett-White.com. 1/3

JONES--Wayne Allyn, Sr.,82, passed away November 23, 2015 in Binghamton, NY. Born in Batavia, NY on June 27, 1933, he was ninth in his 1955 class at VMI, a scholar graduate student at Cornell University and First Lieutenant in the Army Corps of Engineers. In 1948 he founded J&K Plumbing and Heating Co., which by 1982, was the eighth largest privately owned plumbing company in the United States. Wayne was a founding member of the Welsh Society and a founding member of the Southern Tier Sheet Metal Contractors Association Apprentice Program. He was an elder and head of the trustees of the First Presbyterian Church. Wayne and Joyce, his wife of 59 years, loved travel and visited over 150 countries together. Wayne is survived by his wife, Joyce Kathleen McPhail Jones, six children, 18 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. 1/3

WATTS--Jerry Gafio, 62, a leading scholar of African American political thought, died on November 16, 2015. He earned his B.A. from Harvard University and PhD from Yale University. He was a professor at CUNY Graduate Center, author of "Heroism and the Black Intellectual: Reflections on Ralph Ellison, Politics, and Afro- American Intellectual Life" and "Amiri Baraka: The Politics and Art of a Black Intellectual." He was known for his commitment to his students, to workers across class and racial/ethnic lines, and to his family, as well as for his humorous storytelling and courageous critiques of white supremacy in United States politics and academia. He is survived by his spouse, Traci West, sister Brenda Watts, and brother Robert Watts. Memorial service will be December 5, 2015 at 6:15pm at the NY Society for Ethical Culture, New York City, followed by a reception. 1/3

His movies included "Hoffa," "A Brooklyn State of Mind," "Mamamia," "Death to Smoochy" and "Goodfellas." COHEN--Rick, 64, prominent community activist and nonprofit journalist, died suddenly at his Virginia home on November 16, 2015. A son of the housing projects of East Boston, Rick graduated Boston University in 1972, paying his way through by driving a taxi and sorting mail at night. He earned a master's degree in city planning from the University of Pennsylvania in 1975. For the next 25 years, he rose rapidly through the ranks of urban government and nonprofits, serving as a planner for Action for Boston Community Development; director of the Jersey City Department of Housing and Economic Development; vice president of James Rouse's Enterprise Foundation of Columbia, Maryland; and vice president for planning and operations at the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, the nation's largest nonprofit community development intermediary. In these posts, Rick became known for his unswerving and incorruptible devotion to the interests of the poor and marginalized. Rick's reputation for courage and devotion to social justice only increased when he became executive director of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy in 1999. Under his leadership, NCRP maintained that foundations too often failed to support social justice groups, preferring instead to direct resources to safe and compliant mainstream nonprofits or institutional self- aggrandizement. He was named five times to the NonProfit Times'annual Power and Influence Top 50. Rick turned his experience into a steady stream of articles and op-eds for publications like the Washington Post, the Boston Globe, and the San Francisco Chronicle, and nonprofit outlets like Nonprofit Quarterly, Blue Avocado, and the Stanford Social Innovation Review. This prepared him for what many regard as the most productive and influential period of his career, his service as national correspondent for the Nonprofit Quarterly, beginning in 2006. There, he produced an astonishingly prolific flow of lengthy investigative stories and shorter articles, bringing his deep- seated compassion and hard- earned wisdom to bear on a broad range of interests: the decline of housing and community groups, the corrupt self-dealing of some leading charities, the plight of the rural as well as urban poor, the neglect of veterans, the struggle against racism, and the fate of Detroit. He never wavered from his lifework's consistent theme that the nation's leading public and private anti-poverty groups all too often failed to honor their professed commitment to the interests of the marginalized. As one observer noted, he was something of a "Columbo" of the nonprofit world, charming, self- deprecating and unerring in his investigatory instincts. Rick's daily journalistic output was eagerly anticipated by the widest range of readers, from foundation presidents - who respected his devotion to hard evidence even while subjected to his criticism - to grassroots nonprofit leaders, who heard their hopes and aspirations echoed in Rick's words. Rick is survived by his daughter Eleanor, his fiancee Ellen Giordano, her daughter Eve and his beloved dog Murphy. A public service celebrating Rick's life will be held in January, 2016. 1/3

FRESCO--Marlene. The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Marlene Fresco, beloved wife of NYU Langone Medical Center trustee Paolo Fresco. ZARCHIN--Jill Amy, 65, died peacefully on Friday, November 20, 2015 of complications from endometrial cancer. Jill grew up in Fair Lawn, NJ, but truly was a citizen of the world, spending 25 years with the UN, Unicef, and the Peace Corps. Her positions took her to China, Rwanda, Bosnia, Darfur, Laos, Cambodia, Myammar and Burkina Faso. Most of her posts involved the education and welfare of children. It is accurate to say the work she accomplished has made the world a better place. It was Jill's enthusiasm for life, optimism, and free-spirit that drew people to her. Her kindness and enormous heart brought them even closer. Jill is survived by her mate of more than 20 years, Scott. She also leaves her sisters Susan and Linda (David), her twin brother Jim (Cathy), her nephews Max (Jenna), Josh (Clare), Noah, her niece, Leah, her great-nieces Josephine and Juliette, her Aunt Harriet and countless friends she touched around the world with her thoughtfulness and generosity. CHAUS--Josephine. Chairwoman and Co-Founder of Bernard Chaus Inc., a trailblazer and role model for generations of women in leadership roles, devoted and beloved grandmother, mother, wife and friend. Overcoming modest beginnings and a most difficult and challenging childhood, Josephine was the American dream. First in partnership with her late husband and then on her own, Josephine was the tireless anchor of Bernard Chaus Inc. As a young mother, she endured the shocking and early loss of her husband, best friend and business partner. Left alone, she raised her then two young sons while taking the reins as one of our Nation's first female public company chief executive officers. Josephine's was a life ever so well led; filled with challenge, success and accomplishment. With singular determination, strength and uncompromising moral values, Josephine charted a course for her company and for her family. Her modesty and retiring personality were hallmarks most especially in the glow of constant career and business accolades including a profile by The New York Times with Josephine championed as the Survivor for Seventh Avenue in a cover story in the Sunday Business Section. But Josephine's unwavering determination to surmount the uncertainties of a business that has humbled so many was not her most satisfying and enduring achievement. Her greatest loves and what for Josephine were the most meaningful blessings and constant sources of joy were her beloved sons, Ariel and Aaron, daughter in-laws Robin and Lacey, Anna's mother Cassandra, and her cherished granddaughters, Zoie, Liv and Anna. Josephine will always live on in the smiles on their faces, their strong and independent personalities, and in their zest for life. Josephine will also live on in the hearts of her colleagues at the Company who in every sense were family to Josephine, and she will live on in the hearts of all whose lives she touched with her warmth, generosity and goodness. Marching to her own contrarian drum, embracing and cherishing every day of her life; Josephine's is a legacy of utmost grace and dignity. Rare and precious in every action and deed, Josephine embodied the American dream; she will be sorely missed. Services will be held Monday November 30th at Temple Emanu-El Fifth Avenue at 65th Street at 11am. In lieu of gifts, the family has asked contributions be made to favorite charities in Josephine's name. 1/3

D'ANNIBALE--Albert, World War II Veteran who helped liberate Dachau concentration camp, dies at 91. Albert, a loving husband, father and grandfather passed away peacefully in his bed, at home, from age related diseases Saturday, November 21st with his family by his side. He is survived by his wife Dolly Borgia, and his four children Juliet, Christopher Stefan, and Camille. His sister Mary Phillips, brother John and six grandchildren Marlon, Alexander, Scarlett, Olivia, Roman and Violett also survived him. He was born in Newton, NJ and was raised in Little Italy and the Bronx, NY. He was one of seven children. At age 19, he enlisted and became a G.I. in the Army. Shortly thereafter, he was sent to England to train for the D-Day invasion. He frequently recounted his war stories, like Eisenhower exhorting the troops on, after braving the English Channel and securing the Normandy beachhead. But his proudest and profoundly saddest recollections were of opening the gates of Dachau and seeing those who had been left to die in the concentration camps. Albert was a true American war hero. After the war, and aided by the GI Bill, Albert went to Theater School. He later had a career as a Playwright, Director, and Actor. He appeared in Fred Zinneman's film "Hat Full of Rain", and Co-Produced and starred in the national production of "Stalag 17", in addition to working as the Director of the Litchfield Theater in Litchfield, CT. Albert also wrote the documentary, "Jazz On A Summer's Day", directed by Bert Stern about the 1958 Newport Jazz Festival. However, some of his fondest memories, came from his time working within the Playwright Directors Unit of the Actor's Studio in NYC during the sixties and seventies, where he was chosen to coordinate the writers, as well as stage his plays. Albert authored a book of plays entitled "6 Unlucky 20th Century American Plays", which includes "Don't Get Married We Need You", produced at the Mercer Theater in Greenwich Village, NYC (1973). Albert married his second wife Ann Davies in 1968. Together, they had three children and lived in Hell's kitchen in the 60s-early 80s across the street from the Actors studio. Albert was a dedicated father and took a job teaching woodshop and playwriting in the mid 70s at the prestigious Trinity School on the upper west side where his three children, and grandchildren attended. In the early 80s, he became a financial advisor, working for Ray Dirks at John Muir & Co, where he ultimately became Senior Vice President. His career in finance lasted a decade before retiring. He was celebrated on Geraldo Rivera's Talk Show as a figure representing success and "the American dream". For the last 17 years Albert was happily married to his third wife, and the love of his life, Dolly Borgia. He was a devoted husband to an equally devoted wife. He was a true renaissance man and hero who lived life his way, and was loved by all who had the good fortune of knowing him. Reception will be held on Thursday, December 3rd from 4-6pm. Please contact the family for details. 1/3

He is also survived by his sister, Laura Whitmer Spadone; his nieces, Laura Spadone, Allison Spadone Karonis and Lele Whitmer McKenry and by his nephews Paul Spadone and Martin T. Whitmer Jr. His brother, Martin T. Whitmer, predeceased him in 2011. Bob attended Greenwich Country Day School, St. Paul's School, Concord, NH, Yale University and the Harvard Business School. He served in the US Army as 2nd Lieutenant. His business focus, marketing and advertising, included J Walter Thompson, NYC., The Stanley Works, New Britain, Conn., General Electric, Bridgeport, Conn., SCM Corp, King of Prussia, Pa., and The Danforth Group, New Canaan, Conn. He enjoyed volunteering at the Pantry of Operation Hope, agency for those in need of shelter and food. A member of the Quogue Field Club, the Quogue Beach Club and the Fairfield Beach Club, he was cherished by his many friends for his sense of humor, wisdom, thoughtfulness, love of jazz and swift work on the tennis court and golf course. He was a wily fly fisherman too. A funeral service will be held on Saturday December 5th, 11am at St Timothy's Episcopal Church, 4670 Congress Street, Fairfield, Conn. A memorial service and internment will be held during the summer in Quogue, NY. Gifts in his memory may be made to Operation Hope, 636 Old Post Road, Fairfield, Conn., 06824, or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

MASCH--Dorothy Danzig, born December 16, 1932 to Edith and Max Danzig in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Mark S. Masch, loving sister of the late Judith Danzig. She is survived by her children, Julia, Jason and Rachel Masch; daughter-in-law, Hadley Groft; grandchildren, Elizabeth and Mark Masch; sister and brother-in-law, Jeanne and Stanley Baum; and many cousins, nieces and nephews whom she adored. She will be truly missed by all who knew her. 1/3

STERN--Walter Jacob, 93, on November 27, 2015. Born in Hamburg, Germany, he immigrated to the United States in 1939 with father, Leopold, mother, Alice, and sister, Marion, and became a citizen in 1943. He served as an officer in the military, including working as a translator in Japan. He received a degree from the Stern School of Business at NYU, and began a career as an executive in the garment industry. In 1962, he married Ruth Klein. Based in Englewood, New Jersey, Walter, Ruth and daughter, Michelle, shared summers on Fire Island, as well as travels to far-flung locations. After retiring in 1994, Walter took volunteer assignments in Russia and Bulgaria, where his support was appreciated by the local businesses. He spent the last 15 years of his life with partner, Roswitha Kucera, dividing their time between New Jersey, Florida and Austria. Walter is remembered for his sharp mind, devotion to family, appreciation for fine art and good food, and doing the Sunday crossword with a pen. He is survived by daughter, Michelle Stern, partner, Roswitha Kucera, and nephews, Gary, Andre and Roger Adler. Service Tuesday, December 1, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam. 1/3

PINN--Dorothy, 92, of White Plains, NY, died Saturday, November 28, 2015. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Noah Pinn and sister of Joseph Schwartz and the late Arnold Schwartz. Beloved mother of Ellice and Howard (Myra) and cherished grandmother to Audrey and Rebecca. Services, Tuesday, December 1, 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. 1/3
HIRSCH--Henriette February 3, 1912 - November 21, 2015. Lovingly remembered by family and friends. 1/3

CIARCIA --John, "Cha Cha," owner of Little Italy's, popular Cha Cha's In Bocca Al Lupo Cafe on Mulberry St., passed away November 21, at NYU Langone Medical Center following a brief illness. Known as "The Mayor of Little Italy," he was an actor, producer, celebrity manager, boxing promoter and radio host. Cha Cha's Little Italy cafe was a popular gathering place for many of his celebrity friends, including Tony Danza, Danny DeVito, Rhea Perlman, Martin Scorsese, Robert DeNiro, Danny Aiello, Vincent Pastore and Joey Reynolds. His movies included "Hoffa," "A Brooklyn State of Mind," "Mamamia," "Death to Smoochy" and "Goodfellas." He played Albie Cianfione in HBO's "The Sopranos" and co-hosted Sirius Satellite Radio's "The Wise Guys Show." He is survived by his wife, singer Karen King, a sister, Marie 'Mary Anne' Gentile, four aunts, one uncle, five nephews, five nieces, three great nieces, three great nephews and one great-great niece. "Chach," as he was also known, was a great friend to many and a real lover of his neighborhood and the city of New York. He was one of a kind and a huge light has gone out on Mulberry St. There will be a wake on Monday and Tuesday, November 30 and December 1, from 3 to 5pm and 7 to 10pm each day, at the Youth Center of Saint Patrick's Old Cathedral, 268 Mulberry St. The Funeral Mass of The Resurrection is scheduled for 10:30am on Wednesday, December 2, at Saint Patrick's Old Cathedral (at Mott St. and Prince St.). 1/3

MAHONEY--Michael J. "While I dream of you, we're sitting near the window Laughing, bathing in the winter sun If I had to choose one moment for forever My Friend , I tell you, that would be the one" 1/3

ZUCCOTTI--John. The Board of Trustees and staff of the New York Blood Center (NYBC) mourn the loss of our beloved trustee and friend, John Zuccotti. John was a true champion for the New York City area, our region, and our institution. He will be remembered as a leader in real estate, civic and government affairs, but we will mostly remember John for his dedication, insight and wisdom as a member of our board. A practical problem-solver and devoted public servant, John made every institution he touched better. His contributions to our lifesaving mission will never be forgotten. Dr. Christopher Hillyer, President Howard P. Milstein, Chairman 1/3

ZARCHIN--Jill Amy, 65, died peacefully on Friday, November 20, 2015 of complications from endometrial cancer. Jill grew up in Fair Lawn, NJ, but truly was a citizen of the world, spending 25 years with the UN, Unicef, and the Peace Corps. Her positions took her to China, Rwanda, Bosnia, Darfur, Laos, Cambodia, Myammar and Burkina Faso. Most of her posts involved the education and welfare of children. It is accurate to say the work she accomplished has made the world a better place. It was Jill's enthusiasm for life, optimism, and free-spirit that drew people to her. Her kindness and enormous heart brought them even closer. Jill is survived by her mate of more than 20 years, Scott. She also leaves her sisters Susan and Linda (David), her twin brother Jim (Cathy), her nephews Max (Jenna), Josh (Clare), Noah, her niece, Leah, her great-nieces Josephine and Juliette, her Aunt Harriet and countless friends she touched around the world with her thoughtfulness and generosity. Funeral services will be help Tuesday, December 1st, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, NYC. A gathering for visitation will start at 10:30am. The service will begin at Noon. Following the service, Jill will be buried at Linden Hill Cemetery, next to her mother and father. Jill loved New York City. To recognize this, in lieu of flowers, we ask donations be made to the NYC Parks Department for restoration of the carousel in Central Park. 1/3

INTRILIGATOR--Marc S.,63, passed away peacefully with no pain and surrounded by family on Sunday, November 29. He is survived by his wife, Roxann, his sons, Seth, Josh, and Daniel, three daughters-in-law and three granddaughters. Marc was born on July 14 in Oceanside, NY. He received a B.A. from SUNY Binghamton in 1974 and a J.D. from Boston University School of Law in 1977. He married his high school sweetheart in 1977. He practiced commercial real estate law in New York City as a senior partner at Dreyer and Traub until 1995. He was of counsel at Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding until 2005. He was a member of the national firm Cozen O'Connor since 2005. His practice focused on real estate transaction law with concentrations in ground leasing, space leasing, condominium/cooperative law, and joint ventures. Marc was an avid golfer, music and art lover, foodie, and sports fan. He was President of Highlands Golf Club, Croton Jewish Center, and most recently First Hebrew Congregation of Peekskill where he was honored as Person of the Year. A funeral is scheduled for Tuesday, December 1 at 2pm at First Hebrew Congregation at 821 East Main Street, Peekskill, NY 10566. 1/3

STEWART--Robert S. 1938-2015. Robert passed away on November 20, 2015. Born in New York and raised in Queens, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School before attending Dartmouth College from 1955 to 1959, where he became editor-in-chief of the college newspaper. From 1959 to 1962, he attended St. John's College at Oxford University, receiving an MA in English. Mr. Stewart had a distinguished career as an editor in several major publishing houses where he worked with many notable authors, including Germaine Greer, Marvin Hamlisch, Fred Zinnemann, James Earl Jones, Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, Zbigniew Brzezinski and George Schultz. In his last position at Scribner, Mr. Stewart rose to have his own imprint, a rare honor. He is survived by his sons Robert and Matthew, his brother Alan Sussman, and predeceased by his wife Marguerite. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Search and Care: www.searchandcare.org. 1/3

ZUCKER-FRANKLIN-- Dorothea, 86, passed away on November 24th in her home in Manhattan. A highly respected hematologist and research scientist, Dorothea contributed to the basis of contemporary cell biology through her work on the microarchitecture of blood cells, including platelets, lymphocytes and megakaryocytes. Dorothea began life in Berlin, Germany, just as the National Socialist (Nazi) Party was gaining traction. She moved with her parents and younger sister, Marion, to Amsterdam, where they ultimately attended the same school as Anne Frank. On several occasions, Nazi soldiers visited the house where the family was living, and on at least one occasion, detaining them overnight. No longer able to obtain the visas needed for immigration, they went into hiding in the small town of Uithoorn during the summer of 1943. Following the liberation of Holland, Dorothea attended the Quaker international school in Ommen where she began learning English. In 1946, she boarded the MS Gripsholm with her mother and sister and crossed the Atlantic to arrive in the United States. There, she was able to attend Hunter College after completing her senior year at Forest Hills High School. She served as class president and valedictorian for the Hunter College, CUNY class of 1952 and was later awarded an honorary doctorate by the school. She recalled considerable opposition to her decision to pursue a career in medicine, but persevered and graduated from New York Medical College in 1956, as one of five women in her class. In May of 1956, she married Edward C. Franklin, M.D., beginning the warm and vivacious personal and professional partnership that lasted until his premature death in 1982. Together they purchased and cared for their much loved farm in the Berkshires, travelled internationally, collected pre-Columbian figurines, enjoyed so many of New York's cultural offerings as well as a sabbatical year in Paris and developed a passion for downhill skiing. Dorothea ultimately achieved the rank of full professor at NYU Medical School and continued to accrue professional accolades for the remainder of her career, including election as President of the American Society of Hematologists in 1995 and induction into the Institute of Medicine that same year. In addition to numerous original publications and public presentations, she co-authored a definitive atlas of hematology and saw it through three editions. She is survived by her daughter, Deborah Julie Franklin, PhD, M.D.; grandson, Edward Aaron Franklin; sister, Marion Zucker Goldstein, M.D. and nieces Lillian Goldstein Shapiro, M.D., and Naomi Goldstein. Funeral service Sunday, December 6th at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Charitable contributions to Selfhelp Community Services or Yad Vashem in her name are preferred in lieu of flowers. 1/3

ROTHSCHILD--William B.,of Rancho Mirage, CA, formerly of Maplewood, NJ, passed away at his home in Rancho Mirage, on Wednesday, November 25th at the age of 98. Bill Rothschild leaves his wife, Beverly Rothschild, his sons, Mark and Jeffrey Rothschild, and his grandchildren, Harriet, Isaac, and Jackiel Rothschild. Bill Rothschild was born May 15th, 1917 in New York City. Bill's father, Marcus Rothschild, founded the firm of M. Rothschild & Company, a leading importer of commodities from South East Asia. After attending the University of Georgia, Bill worked for his father in New York before spending six years in the US Army, acquiring the rank of Master Sargent and participated in the Normandy invasion and the Ardennes campaign. Following WWII, Bill rejoined M. Rothschild & Company, where he assisted his father and eventually became President of the firm. Bill served as President of the American/Indonesian Chamber of Commerce from 1968-71 and 1979-80. Bill was a Life Master bridge player and scratch golfer. Bill and his wife, Beverly were long time members of the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, NJ. Bill and Beverly relocated to Rancho Mirage in 2006, where they are members of Mission Hills Country Club. Bill loved golf and especially bridge and was a regular bridge player at Duncan Bridge Center in Palm Dessert. Service will be held at 10:30am, Wednesday, December 2, at Desert Memorial Park, Cathedral City, CA. 1/3

SILFEN--David M. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of the University of Pennsylvania are deeply saddened by the death of alumnus and Board of Trustees Vice Chair David M. Silfen, C'66. David always remembered the University that provided his foundation, and he spent a lifetime ensuring Penn's continuing excellence for future generations of students. At Penn, David was the former Chair of the Trustees' Development Committee and a driving force in our successful $4.3 billion fundraising campaign. As Chair and a longtime member of the Board of Overseers of the School of Arts and Sciences, David was one of its strongest advocates and provided invaluable advice in areas such as fundraising, budgeting, and strategic planning. He was also instrumental on the Investment Board and the Committee on Campus Development, which helped shape Penn's recent physical transformation. He and his wife Lyn have been among the University's most generous supporters, endowing professorships, creating the annual David and Lyn Silfen University Forum, and naming the Silfen Student Study Center among other significant contributions. Penn has lost a dear friend, and we extend our condolences to the many who mourn David's passing, especially his wife Lyn, his children, Adam, C'98, WG'03, and Jane, C'07, and grandchildren Anson and Riley. David L. Cohen, Chair, Board of Trustees Andrea Mitchell, Vice Chair, Board of Trustees Amy Gutmann, President Steven J. Fluharty, Dean, School of Arts and Sciences 1/3

He received a B.A. from SUNY Binghamton in 1974 and a J.D. from Boston University School of Law in 1977. He married his high school sweetheart in 1977. SILFEN--David M. The Columbia Business School community mourns the loss of David M. Silfen '68. Silfen was a dedicated member of the School community and leaves behind an impressive legacy of leadership and philanthropy. A member of the School's Board of Overseers, Silfen generously established the David and Lyn Silfen Professorship of Business and the David and Lyn Silfen Leadership Series, which attracts world-class leaders to campus. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Silfen family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School 1/3

Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 2, 2015.

HOLMSTROM--Carl-Eric, passed away on November 27th, 2015 at the Lourdes Noreen McKeen Residence, West Palm Beach. A previous resident of Palm Beach and New York City, Carl-Eric was born in the town of Kage in northern Sweden in the 1920s. After a successful sales career in the Swedish fashion industry, he came to America in his 30s to develop his artistic talent and pursue a career in the fabric and decorating industry. He was the former owner of the interior decorating and antique firm, Rose Cumming Ltd. in New York City, where his keen eye for high class fabric and his innovative decorating style made him a highly regarded professional amongst both clients and staff members. Throughout his life, he continued to divide his time between the residences where he felt most at home; New York City, Southampton and Palm Beach. Carl-Eric was preceded in death by his parents, John and Gerda Holmstrom, and beloved sister, Inga-Britt Sundell. He is survived and kept in loving memory by his niece, Ann-Christin Sundell Andersson (Erling Andersson), and great-niece and nephew, Linda Andersson and Erik Andersson. In lieu of flowers, a donation to Palm Beach County Hospice would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

EISENBERG--Helen Vinik, formerly of Englewood NJ, residing in Boca Raton FL, passed away November 30 2015. Predeceased by her husband Stanford and her daughter Amy, Helen is survived by her daughter Ann Friedlander and her brother Donald Vinik. A funeral service was held yesterday at Gutterman Musicant Funeral Home in Hackensack, NJ. Interment followed at Riverside Cemetery, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to the Stanford Eisenberg Knoxville Jewish Day School, PO Box 10105, Knoxville, TN 37939. 1/3

SELLNER--Arthur B.,91, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 1st. We celebrate your long life well-lived as a native New Yorker, WWII hero, NYU alum, devoted husband to Aunt Judy, skier, handyman, friend to many, witty wisecracker, and our wonderful Uncle Art. Love, Mae, Ed and Nicole. Private family service in Massachusetts. 1/3

WADDINGTON--Leslie. The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation mourns the loss of Leslie Waddington. Leslie was a man of incomparable intellect and brilliant, original wit. As an art dealer, he was the exemplar of professionalism and meticulousness. He had rare wisdom about the unique milieu known as "the art world," in which he epitomized the truest ethics and vision. As a person, he had taste and charm in profusion, bringing immense joy to those lucky enough to know him. As a friend, he was simply without equal. Our deepest sympathy to Leslie's spectacular wife Clodagh, his mainstay and savior, to his daughters Laura and Anya, his loving grandchildren, and so many other people blessed to be in Leslie's orbit. Nicholas Fox Weber and family and all the associates of the Albers Foundation. 1/3

ADLER--Renee Nora Adler. October 14, 1950 died November 19, 2015. Renee Adler was born in Brooklyn, New York to Ani and Oskar Adler, both Holocaust survivors. She grew up in Brooklyn with her brother Arnold, attended Erasmus Hall High School, and graduated from Pratt University. A free and creative spirit, Renee was much beloved by her wide circle of international friends and family. For the past thirty two years, she lived in Walden, Vermont where she worked as a potter and art teacher and was an avid gardener. Renee was a passionate world traveler. Her treasured godchildren include Risa Scobie, Aaron Watson, Cheten and Chewang Sherpa, Roie Amsterdamer and Kiva Silberfeld. Family members Ainat Maler and Rafi Maler of Israel, Esther Zuberman of Argentina and Dan and Abbe Felton of Florida join her many friends who mourn the loss of a beautiful soul. She will be forever missed. 1/3

LUDLUM--Michael C. Died November 29, with loving wife, Melissa, daughter, Catherine, and son, Gregory, by his side. Beloved brother of June Blake. Long-time CBS Radio news executive and NYU journalism professor, much respected and admired by friends, colleagues and students. Memorial service Friday, December 4, at 10:30am at Grace Episcopal Church, 200 Highfield Lane, Nutley. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, (theaftd.org). 1/3

SHORENSTEIN--Douglas. We mourn the loss of Douglas Shorenstein. A giant in the industry, he had a brilliant instinct for business and a great heart for philanthropy. His partnership with the Weiler Arnow Families and Swig Families spanned many decades, and we benefited through the generations from his thoughtful counsel, his integrity and his generosity. A leader in the community and a great friend to us all, we mourn his loss and extend our heartfelt condolences from both New York and San Francisco to his wife, Lydia, his children, Brandon, Sandra and Danielle Shorenstein; and sister, Carol Shorenstein Hays. Weiler Arnow Families and Swig Families 1/3

BERNARD--Christina M.,(nee Costiglio), 68, of Newburgh, NY passed away peacefully on November 30th following a battle with cancer. Born to Lawrence and Isabelle, Christina grew up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She later settled in the Hudson Valley to raise her family. Christina recently retired after working 44 years at New York Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell Medical Center. Christina will always be remembered for her warmth, care for others, and her unique ability to make friends into family and any house feel like home. She is survived by Edward, her beloved husband of 36 years, son David (Mark Breuer), daughter Laura, siblings Peter Costiglio (Barbara), Eugene Costiglio, and Teresa Cantwell (Thomas), and many more treasured family and friends. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Thursday, December 3, 2015 5:30pm-9pm and Friday, December 4, 2015 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York at 10am, Saturday. 1/3

EISENBERG--Helen Vinik. Today, our students dedicated their learning in memory of Helen Eisenberg O.B.M. We join her daughter Ann Friedlander and the extended Eisenberg family in mourning her loss. Our school, the Stanford Eisenberg Knoxville Jewish Day School, proudly bears her husband's name. We know that she and her husband Stanford will continue to look down from above with pride at our beautiful school. 1/3

SILFEN--David M. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the untimely passing of our member and esteemed Past President, David M. Silfen. During his consecutive terms as President, David perpetuated the legacy of Atlantic. David was a man of great intellect, humility, and, above all, integrity. LAIBE--Ann Jessie Davis. Of Greenwich, CT and Nantucket, MA, passed away November 25 after a prolonged illness. Born July 20, 1929 to the late Robert V. and Caroline Schroeder Davis and raised in Scranton, PA, Ann graduated from Scranton Central High School in 1947 and attended Skidmore College, where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1951. After graduation, she worked in summer stock in Saratoga, NY, taught at the Tuxedo Park School, and worked in New York City, where she met her beloved John Laibe, to whom she was married in 1957. Their wedded life began in Brooklyn Heights, then proceeded to Connecticut, Hong Kong, and Miami before returning to Connecticut in 1980. Along the way they traveled extensively, usually with their five children. Ann enjoyed educating young children and did so at a number of schools, including the Montessori school in Miami, and the Round Hill Nursery School in Greenwich. She also tutored adults in reading with Literacy Volunteers of America. She and John volunteered in numerous local activities, notably the soup kitchen in Stamford, CT via their parish of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich. In addition, they gave to local nonprofits, including Greenwich Hospital. Ann loved reading, gardening, jazz and classical music, and correspondence, keeping up with friends and family with the increasingly uncommon method of letter writing. Ann was preceded in death by her husband John and daughter Constance, as well as her sister Carol Davis Norton. She is survived by her brothers Dr. Robert V. Davis and Col. Richard C. Davis; daughter Anne Laibe Bertolino; sons Marc, Christopher and Timothy, their spouses, and 16 adoring grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held December 7 at 11am at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made in Ann's name to one's chosen charity or to Family Centers, 40 Arch Street, Greenwich CT 06830. www.familycenters.org. 1/3

DELLA MONICA--Armand Francis. Born August 21, 1940, Armand passed away peacefully in New York, NY on Monday, November 16, 2015, after a long struggle with leukemia. He was surrounded by his loving family. Raised in Brooklyn, NY, Armand graduated from Regis High School in 1958. He received his Bachelor's Degree in Electrical Engineering from Manhattan College in 1962, and his Master's Degree in Applied Physics from Adelphi University in 1965. Armand had a long and distinguished career, 32 years of which were spent working at Northrop Grumman, where he served as a Vice President and Program Director. Highlights of his tenure at Northrop Grumman included conducting launch operations for seven manned lunar landings, playing a key role in the historic Apollo 13 rescue mission, managing the U.S. Naval F-14 Tomcat program, and transforming the Northrop Grumman/NASA International Space Station contract business model. Armand was most recently affiliated with Harmony Holding Partners, where he served as Chief Technology Officer and was a founding partner. He led a full and active life. Armand was an avid cyclist, swimmer and runner. In addition to his athletic pursuits, he was known, among family and friends, as a passionate cook. Armand was also a recreational pilot. He resided in Palm Coast, FL, and Warren, VT. Armand is survived by his wife, Joyce Lawlor Della Monica, his sister and brother-in-law, Rachelle and Robert Izzo, his daughter, Lauren Della Monica Fay, his son and daughter-in-law, Armand and Lauren Della Monica, his daughter, Katherine Della Monica, and his grandsons, Graham and Gavin Fay. In keeping with his wishes, the family held a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Regis High School at 55 East 84th St., New York, NY 10028 or https://community.regis.org/ SSLPage.aspx?pid=219. 1/3
REISMAN--Harriet. My dearest friend of 64 years. Words cannot express my despair. You were always there for me . . . supportive, loyal, sensible and fun. I will miss you. Frances Sweeney 1/3

BRANN--Helen Wetmore. December 26, 1932 to November 30, 2015. Helen Wetmore Brann, acclaimed literary agent, died suddenly on Monday, November 30, 2015, of complications from cancer. She was 82. Born in Colorado Springs, Colorado to Maurice Robert Brann and Alice Cynthia Wetmore. She attended The Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT, and graduated from Smith College in 1954. Wishing to pursue a career as a writer, she got a job as a receptionist at the New Yorker. From 1958 to 1963 she lived in England and Ireland, working as a freelance editor while writing her own novel. In 1963, she returned to New York and worked part-time for literary agent James Oliver Brown. She soon had clients of her own, among them Diane Johnson and Edmund White. In 1968, she moved to the Sterling Lord Agency. In 1974, she took a leap of faith and started The Helen Brann Agency. Eventually she shared an office with the legendary dramatic rights literary agent, Flora Roberts, where they became close friends as well as business associates. Helen moved her business to Western Connecticut in 1990 as her client list continued to grow. For decades she has represented many talented writers, including Julian Barnes, Richard Brautigan, Gerald Clarke, Nora Johnson, Daniel Yergin, Ingrid Thoft, Chuck Scarborough, Rod McKuen, Barbara Leaming, William Wright, Stephen Sondheim, Robert B. Parker and Maya Angelou. By opening her own literary agency, she became a trail blazer for women. In 2007, Helen was involved with Hillary Clinton's Presidential campaign and she was pleased when being introduced to Mrs. Clinton, that Mrs. Clinton immediately recalled that Helen was the first woman to open a literary agency of her own. In October 2004, she married Faith Stewart-Gordon, artist and former owner of the Russian Tea Room in New York. They lived together in their Bridgewater home along with their many animals including goats, horses, cats and dogs. Helen owned several race horses and bred champion Norwich Terriers. Helen was a member of The Century Association, The Cosmopolitian Club, The Norwich and Norfolk Terrier Club and The Hale Matthews Foundation. She co-created The Flora Roberts Award for aspiring playwrights. In addition to her spouse Faith, she is survived by her sister, Cynthia Ramsey, several nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews and Faith's daughter, Ellen Kaye and grandson, Ian Tsang. She was predeceased by her beloved sister, Beatrice. A private service will be held at a later date. Donations in Helen's memory can be made to the Palliative Care Service at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065. 1/3

ZUCKER-FRANKLIN-- Dorothea, 86, passed away on November 24th in her home in Manhattan. A highly respected hematologist and research scientist, Dorothea contributed to the basis of contemporary cell biology through her work on the microarchitecture of blood cells, including platelets, lymphocytes and megakaryocytes. Dorothea began life in Berlin, Germany, just as the National Socialist (Nazi) Party was gaining traction. She moved with her parents and younger sister, Marion, to Amsterdam, where they ultimately attended the same school as Anne Frank. On several occasions, Nazi soldiers visited the house where the family was living, and on at least one occasion, detaining them overnight. No longer able to obtain the visas needed for immigration, they went into hiding in the small town of Uithoorn during the summer of 1943. Following the liberation of Holland, Dorothea attended the Quaker international school in Ommen where she began learning English. In 1946, she boarded the MS Gripsholm with her mother and sister and crossed the Atlantic to arrive in the United States. There, she was able to attend Hunter College after completing her senior year at Forest Hills High School. She served as class president and valedictorian for the Hunter College, CUNY class of 1952 and was later awarded an honorary doctorate by the school. She recalled considerable opposition to her decision to pursue a career in medicine, but persevered and graduated from New York Medical College in 1956, as one of five women in her class. In May of 1956, she married Edward C. Franklin, M.D., beginning the warm and vivacious personal and professional partnership that lasted until his premature death in 1982. Together they purchased and cared for their much loved farm in the Berkshires, travelled internationally, collected pre-Columbian figurines, enjoyed so many of New York's cultural offerings as well as a sabbatical year in Paris and developed a passion for downhill skiing. Dorothea ultimately achieved the rank of full professor at NYU Medical School and continued to accrue professional accolades for the remainder of her career, including election as President of the American Society of Hematologists in 1995 and induction into the Institute of Medicine that same year. In addition to numerous original publications and public presentations, she co-authored a definitive atlas of hematology and saw it through three editions. She is survived by her daughter, Deborah Julie Franklin, PhD, M.D.; grandson, Edward Aaron Franklin; sister, Marion Zucker Goldstein, M.D. and nieces Lillian Goldstein Shapiro, M.D., and Naomi Goldstein. Funeral service Sunday, December 6th at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Charitable contributions to Selfhelp Community Services or Yad Vashem in her name are preferred in lieu of flowers. 1/3

HALPERN--Sylvia nee Stillman, beloved wife of the late Harry A. Halpern, whose life was characterized by an overwhelming love of family, passed away peacefully on November 29, 2015 at the age of 101. Sylvia was born on July 19, 1914 to Rose and Jack Stillman and was a devoted friend and sister to her two brothers Ray Stillman (Elsie), deceased and Fred Stillman (Sylvia). The stories from their childhood and her courtship with Harry were endless. Her greatest legacies are her children, grandchildren and great-children. Loving and caring mother of Joel A. Halpern, deceased, and Linda Lesser (Warren). Cherished grandmother of Jon (Sarah), Julie (Jim), Jason, Beth (Larry) and Mark. Adored great-grandmother to her 11 precious great-grandchildren, Kelsey, Joel, Sophia, Olivia, Leah, Mac, Jackson, Reed, Samara, Paige and Max. Sylvia became "nana" to everyone who knew her. She lit up a room with her smile and laughter and always had stories and songs to share. Sylvia was an active member of Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, where the religious school is named after her and her late husband. She was committed to the vital work of Hadassah and her dedication and vision inspired many young women to follow her lead. Our extraordinary nana lived every moment of her life to the fullest. Charming, graceful and beautiful in every way, her boundless energy and spirit touched everyone she knew. Her selfless devotion to our family will forever remain in our hearts and minds and will serve as an inspiration. We, her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren will miss her deeply and we will live our lives with her love, kindness and generosity as our guiding spirit. Services will be held on Thursday, December 3, at Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, New York, at 11:00am. 1/3
