SILFEN--David M.,69, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 28th, surrounded by his loving family. David was a long-time senior executive at Goldman Sachs, enjoying a 28 year career with the Wall Street firm. David joined Goldman Sachs in 1968, where he was the first MBA hired in the Trading and Arbitrage division. He was named to the partnership in 1978. In 1990 David become co-head of the then-Equities Division, where he had global responsibility for the firm's activities for all equity securities. He was also a member of the Executive Committee, the senior governing body of the firm, and helped steer the firm towards its initial public offering. David managed and mentored many colleagues who would go on to illustrious careers of their own. He was very proud of their accomplishments. For the last 18 years, David enjoyed a second career as a dedicated philanthropist. He served on a number of boards for his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, including acting as the Vice Chair of the Board of Trustees and Chair of the Board of Overseers of the College of Arts and Sciences. David also served as a Trustee of the Riverdale Country Day School, and on the Board of Overseers for Columbia Business School and the Board of Regents for the Smithsonian Institution, where he chaired the Investment Committee. Outside of his work, David loved playing golf, traveling, and the company of his dogs. His greatest joy was becoming a grandfather. David was born in Queens to Herman and Esther Silfen. A lifelong New Yorker and devoted resident of the City, he is survived by his wife of 44 years, Lyn, son, Adam, daughter, Jane, daughter-in-law, Kelly, and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Dr. Ellen Margolin, and a very many friends. He will be missed. 1/3

JOHNSON--Sally Logemann. Sally Logemann Johnson, one of the stars of the 1970s Medieval and Renaissance music revival, died in Manhattan November 30, 2015 of ovarian cancer. In the 1960s and 70s, as Sally Logemann, Ms. Johnson was a founding member of the Waverly Consort and founder and director of the New York Renaissance Band, appearing at New York's Lincoln Center and at concert halls and music festivals worldwide. Starting as a modern oboist, Sally eventually played over a dozen instruments, including baroque oboe, shawm, recorder, dulcian, krummhorn, rackett, bells, harp and drums. She recorded extensively for Columbia, Nonesuch and Arabesque. Her groups also performed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Library of Congress, colleges and universities throughout the US and at The White House (a Shakespeare Birthday concert in 1983). Her foreign tours included most of South America, the Casals Festival in Puerto Rico and the Medeira Bach Festival. Born Sally Ann Elizabeth Bartel in Spokane WA, August 7, 1936, Sally was a musical prodigy, winning Major Bowes Amateur Hour on piano at age five. She graduated from Roosevelt High School in Seattle WA in 1954 and was immediately hired to play oboe and English horn for two years in the Vancouver (BC) Symphony. Sally attended the University of Washington then moved to New York with her first husband Joseph Golden, principal French horn for the New York Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein, for whom he also played in the original production of West Side Story. Sally graduated from the Manhattan School of Music, then, after Joe's death from melanoma in 1960, joined the Master of Music program at New York University. There she began playing Medieval and Renaissance music, and, with fellow students, started the Waverly Consort (named for Waverly Place, site of the NYU music building). In 1972, she formed her own group, the New York Renaissance Band, with a dozen players, specializing in big-band Renaissance sound. After leaving music in the 1980s, Sally was a sales rep for United Airlines, computer specialist for CNA Insurance (she survived 9/11 in an underground vault on Wall St.) and realtor for Corcoran Group. She also sang backup for French pop outfits. Her survivors include Peter Johnson of NYC, her husband of 31 years, her son David Golden, daughter-in-law Janet Golden, and grandchildren Rebecca, Sarah and Noah Golden, all of Milford CT. Final arrangements are private. Please send memorial contributions to WPKN Radio, 244 University Avenue, Bridgeport CT 06604. 1/3

WOLFE--Janet, passed away peacefully November 30 at home surrounded by her loving family. She was 101 years old. Born in NYC in 1914, Janet attended Dalton, Ethical Culture, and the Northampton School for Girls. During WWII, she served in the American Red Cross in Rome. After the war, she worked with Roberto Rosselini on Paisan, toured with Orson Welles' Mercury Theater, and taught the rhumba to Arthur Murray. She married composer Sandy Matlovsky in 1952 and had two daughters, Alisa and Deborah. Throughout the 70's, 80's and 90's, Janet was the inspiration for a series of short stories in the New Yorker's Talk of The Town. In 1971, she founded the NYCHA Symphony Orchestra, giving opportunity and visibility to classical musicians of color. She served as its executive director for over 40 years. Janet is survived by her two adoring daughters and two beloved grandsons, Jake and Sam. 1/3

SILFEN--David M. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the untimely passing of our member and esteemed Past President, David M. Silfen. During his consecutive terms as President, David perpetuated the legacy of Atlantic. David was a man of great intellect, humility, and, above all, integrity. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the family, Lyn, Jane, Adam and Kelly, and David's grandchildren with whom he was blessed before his illness, Anson and Riley. David will be sorely missed. Rest in peace Dear Friend. Dennis A. Suskind, President Harvey L. Radler, Vice President 1/3

Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

His devotion to the Scholarship that the Society sponsors will be missed. His hard work and effort was only surpassed by his kindness and being the consummate gentleman surgeon. John E Sherman MD, FACS Vice President, Society of Honorary Police Surgeons, NYPD 1/3

WADDINGTON--Leslie. The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation mourns the loss of Leslie Waddington. Leslie was a man of incomparable intellect and brilliant, original wit. As an art dealer, he was the exemplar of professionalism and meticulousness. He had rare wisdom about the unique milieu known as "the art world," in which he epitomized the truest ethics and vision. As a person, he had taste and charm in profusion, bringing immense joy to those lucky enough to know him. As a friend, he was simply without equal. Our deepest sympathy to Leslie's spectacular wife Clodagh, his mainstay and savior, to his daughters Laura and Anya, his loving grandchildren, and so many other people blessed to be in Leslie's orbit. Nicholas Fox Weber and family and all the associates of the Albers Foundation. 1/3
MALIN--Irving. Mar. 18, 1934 - Dec. 3, 2014 Sadness echoes in the silence. 1/3

BORKON--Doris. November 23, 1926 - November 30, 2015. Beloved mother and grandmother. She is survived by her daughters Nadine Tekula Bompane and Joan Michel Tekula, and her three grandchildren, Samuel Francis Bompane, Emily Juliana Janice and Joseph Stanley Janice. She was an amazing woman and will be missed. 1/3

GREENBERG--Hilda, 93, daughter of Dr. Abraham and Esther Weiss. Sister of Dr. Joseph Weiss (Eunice). Devoted wife for 61 years of Rabbi Sidney Greenberg. Adoring mother of Shira Ruskay, z"l (John), Reena Keren, Dr. Adena Greenberg (Shlomi Liran). Grandmother of nine. Great-grandmother of 13. Rebbetzin par excellence. Extraordinary woman of valor, lived life with a heart full of gratitude and love. Funeral Thursday, December 3, 9:30am at B'nai Jeshurun. Contributions may be made to B'nai Jeshurun, AKIM Philadelphia, or Shira Ruskay Center -JBFCS. 1/3

SILFEN--David M.,69, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 28th, surrounded by his loving family. David was a long-time senior executive at Goldman Sachs, enjoying a 28 year career with the Wall Street firm. David joined Goldman Sachs in 1968, where he was the first MBA hired in the Trading and Arbitrage division. He was named to the partnership in 1978. In 1990 David become co-head of the then-Equities Division, where he had global responsibility for the firm's activities for all equity securities. He was also a member of the Executive Committee, the senior governing body of the firm, and helped steer the firm towards its initial public offering. David managed and mentored many colleagues who would go on to illustrious careers of their own. He was very proud of their accomplishments. For the last 18 years, David enjoyed a second career as a dedicated philanthropist. He served on a number of boards for his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, including acting as the Vice Chair of the Board of Trustees and Chair of the Board of Overseers of the College of Arts and Sciences. David also served as a Trustee of the Riverdale Country Day School, and on the Board of Overseers for Columbia Business School and the Board of Regents for the Smithsonian Institution, where he chaired the Investment Committee. Outside of his work, David loved playing golf, traveling, and the company of his dogs. His greatest joy was becoming a grandfather. David was born in Queens to Herman and Esther Silfen. A lifelong New Yorker and devoted resident of the City, he is survived by his wife of 44 years, Lyn, son, Adam, daughter, Jane, daughter-in-law, Kelly, and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Dr. Ellen Margolin, and a very many friends. He will be missed. 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas. The Board of Directors of the Mayo Foundation For The Handicap mourn the passing of our long time loyal director. His service provided guidance to our organization, which provides caring and compassionate care to handicap people in the west of Ireland. He also gave guidance to the O'Dwyer Foundation in Ireland. The Mayo Foundation For The Handicap extends our sympathy to the family, Eileen, Maureen and Timothy and to his grandchildren. William O'Dwyer, President Mayo Foundation For The Handicap 1/3

SILFEN--David. The Smithsonian Community is saddened by the passing of our accomplished and generous colleague, David Silfen. David served a decade as the inaugural Chair of the Regents Investment Committee, and his foresight and investment acumen was instrumental in developing the Smithsonian's Endowment. We are grateful for his dedication and the pursuit of excellence that embodied his many and varied contributions. David was a steadfast contributor of his time, talent and resources since 1997, serving on the Smithsonian National Board and the Regents Finance Committee. We will miss him. Our thoughts are with David's wife, Lyn, his children, Adam and Jane, family and friends. 1/3

Goldstein, CEO 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas J.,Jr., on December 2, 2015. Beloved husband of Eileen for over 50 years; father of Maureen McAloon and Timothy Hughes; father-in-law of Jim McAloon and Michelle Hughes; adored "Pa" of Sean, Kate, Colleen and Rory McAloon and Evan, Quinn and Jackson Hughes. He led a distinguished 54-year career as an attorney including serving as ADA with the Homicide Bureau in Manhattan and as Secretary to Hon. John M. Murtagh in the NYS Supreme Court before entering private practice. Visitation: Friday 2-5 and 6-9; Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison, NYC. Funeral mass: Saturday 9:45, St. Margaret of Cortona, 6000 Riverdale Ave., Bx, NYC. Burial: Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Mayo Foundation for the Handicapped would be appreciated. 1/3

DITCHIK--Michael, age 53, died on November 24, 2015 in Seattle, after a tragic accident. He is survived by his wife, Kay Shabazian-Ditchik, his son, Matthew, his parents, Bernard and Florence (Faigie) Ditchik, and his sisters, Carrie Singer and Ellen Mandel. The family will be receiving friends and family on Saturday from 12-5pm and 7-9pm, and Sunday from 12-5pm at the home of Bernard and Florence Ditchik in Island Park, NY. Donations can be made to the National Parkinson Foundation or the American Cancer Society. 1/3

BRODSKY--Hy, died peacefully in Montauk, NY, on November 29, 2015. He is survived by his wife of 16 years, Arlene Goldberg Brodsky of Montauk, NY, his sister, Annette Itzkan, and his sons, Russell, Phillip and William Brodsky. 1/3

HALPERN--Sylvia nee Stillman, beloved wife of the late Harry A. Halpern, whose life was characterized by an overwhelming love of family, passed away peacefully on November 29, 2015 at the age of 101. Sylvia was born on July 19, 1914 to Rose and Jack Stillman and was a devoted friend and sister to her two brothers Ray Stillman (Elsie), deceased and Fred Stillman (Sylvia). The stories from their childhood and her courtship with Harry were endless. Her greatest legacies are her children, grandchildren and great-children. Loving and caring mother of Joel A. Halpern, deceased, and Linda Lesser (Warren). Cherished grandmother of Jon (Sarah), Julie (Jim), Jason, Beth (Larry) and Mark. Adored great-grandmother to her 11 precious great-grandchildren, Kelsey, Joel, Sophia, Olivia, Leah, Mac, Jackson, Reed, Samara, Paige and Max. Sylvia became "nana" to everyone who knew her. She lit up a room with her smile and laughter and always had stories and songs to share. Sylvia was an active member of Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, where the religious school is named after her and her late husband. She was committed to the vital work of Hadassah and her dedication and vision inspired many young women to follow her lead. Our extraordinary nana lived every moment of her life to the fullest. Charming, graceful and beautiful in every way, her boundless energy and spirit touched everyone she knew. Her selfless devotion to our family will forever remain in our hearts and minds and will serve as an inspiration. We, her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren will miss her deeply and we will live our lives with her love, kindness and generosity as our guiding spirit. Services will be held on Thursday, December 3, at Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, New York, at 11:00am. 1/3

BRANN--Helen Wetmore. December 26, 1932 to November 30, 2015. Helen Wetmore Brann, acclaimed literary agent, died suddenly on Monday, November 30, 2015, of complications from cancer. She was 82. Born in Colorado Springs, Colorado to Maurice Robert Brann and Alice Cynthia Wetmore. She attended The Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT, and graduated from Smith College in 1954. Wishing to pursue a career as a writer, she got a job as a receptionist at the New Yorker. From 1958 to 1963 she lived in England and Ireland, working as a freelance editor while writing her own novel. In 1963, she returned to New York and worked part-time for literary agent James Oliver Brown. She soon had clients of her own, among them Diane Johnson and Edmund White. In 1968, she moved to the Sterling Lord Agency. In 1974, she took a leap of faith and started The Helen Brann Agency. Eventually she shared an office with the legendary dramatic rights literary agent, Flora Roberts, where they became close friends as well as business associates. Helen moved her business to Western Connecticut in 1990 as her client list continued to grow. For decades she has represented many talented writers, including Julian Barnes, Richard Brautigan, Gerald Clarke, Nora Johnson, Daniel Yergin, Ingrid Thoft, Chuck Scarborough, Rod McKuen, Barbara Leaming, William Wright, Stephen Sondheim, Robert B. Parker and Maya Angelou. By opening her own literary agency, she became a trail blazer for women. In 2007, Helen was involved with Hillary Clinton's Presidential campaign and she was pleased when being introduced to Mrs. Clinton, that Mrs. Clinton immediately recalled that Helen was the first woman to open a literary agency of her own. In October 2004, she married Faith Stewart-Gordon, artist and former owner of the Russian Tea Room in New York. They lived together in their Bridgewater home along with their many animals including goats, horses, cats and dogs. Helen owned several race horses and bred champion Norwich Terriers. Helen was a member of The Century Association, The Cosmopolitian Club, The Norwich and Norfolk Terrier Club and The Hale Matthews Foundation. She co-created The Flora Roberts Award for aspiring playwrights. In addition to her spouse Faith, she is survived by her sister, Cynthia Ramsey, several nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews and Faith's daughter, Ellen Kaye and grandson, Ian Tsang. She was predeceased by her beloved sister, Beatrice. A private service will be held at a later date. Donations in Helen's memory can be made to the Palliative Care Service at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065. 1/3

LUDLUM--Michael C. Died November 29, with loving wife, Melissa, daughter, Catherine, and son, Gregory, by his side. Beloved brother of June Blake. BERNARD--Christina M.,(nee Costiglio), 68, of Newburgh, NY passed away peacefully on November 30th following a battle with cancer. Born to Lawrence and Isabelle, Christina grew up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She later settled in the Hudson Valley to raise her family. Christina recently retired after working 44 years at New York Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell Medical Center. Christina will always be remembered for her warmth, care for others, and her unique ability to make friends into family and any house feel like home. She is survived by Edward, her beloved husband of 36 years, son David (Mark Breuer), daughter Laura, siblings Peter Costiglio (Barbara), Eugene Costiglio, and Teresa Cantwell (Thomas), and many more treasured family and friends. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Thursday, December 3, 2015 5:30pm-9pm and Friday, December 4, 2015 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York at 10am, Saturday. 1/3

BERGER--Samuel R. The International Crisis Group's Board of Trustees and Staff mourn the loss of Samuel R. Berger, a man of political acumen, policy leadership, humanitarian vision and great personal warmth. Mr. Berger, known to all as "Sandy," provided decades of insight and advice as an attorney and public servant, notably as National Security Adviser under President Bill Clinton. He brought his personal commitment to forging peace and resolving conflict to the International Crisis Group, where he served on the Board of Trustees. We offer deep condolences to his wife, Susan, his three children, and his five grandchildren, as well as to all who were touched by his life as a statesman and humanitarian. 1/3

ROSEN--Selma, of Palm Beach, FL and Greenwich, CT passed away on December 2, 2015. SPERLING--Kenneth Lewis, 57, of Orange, CT passed away peacefully this Thursday morning, December 3 2015, at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Ken was born on April 11, 1958 in New York. Ken is survived by his loving and supportive wife Ros, caring sons Daniel and Benjamin (fiance Ariel Levin), sister Kathy (Mike Occi), and parents Florence Sperling, Renee and Stan Babit, and Joan Newborn. Ken is predeceased by his father Philip Sperling. Ken was an active member of his community, both personally and professionally. He taught the world how to live and fight a courageous battle with cancer filled with dignity and courage. The family wishes to thank 4th floor staff at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital and the 12 North staff at Smilow Cancer Hospital. Ken believed that it is not the number of days that you live, but it is how you choose to live them. Funeral services will be held at Congregation B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Rd in Woodbridge on Sunday, December 6, at 11:00am. Interment services will follow at B'nai Jacob Memorial Park on Wintergreen Ave in New Haven. Donations can be made in memory of Ken Sperling to Congregation B'nai Jacob or Next Generation Men (ngmatlanta.org). A traditional period of mourning will be observed at the Sperling home through Thursday, December 10, beginning at 1:00pm each day. Funeral services in care of Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, New Haven. 1/3

CECIL--Jane, of New York City, passed away peacefully in her home on December 2, 2015. Jane was predeceased by her husband Bill and survived by her sons William (Mac) and Charles, daughters -in-law Sharon and Kathy, her grandchildren Laurie, Jim, Bill, Clare and Kate and her great-grandchildren Eliza, Polly, Jayden, Tess, Eloise and Nicholas. Jane was an actress appearing in plays, movies and TV. She was beloved by family and friends. Donations in her memory may be made to the Actorsfund.org. Memorial Service Tuesday, December 8, 2015, 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. 1/3

CHANG--John B.,MD. The Society of Honorary Police Surgeons of The NYPD mourn the loss of our esteemed President and head of the Scholarship Committee. As an Honorary Police Surgeon for over 20 years, John helped countless members of the NYPD and served the Society as an officer for the past six years. His devotion to the Scholarship that the Society sponsors will be missed. His hard work and effort was only surpassed by his kindness and being the consummate gentleman surgeon. John E Sherman MD, FACS Vice President, Society of Honorary Police Surgeons, NYPD 1/3

SILFEN--David. Riverdale Country School extends condolences to the family of our good friend and trustee emeritus. He will be greatly missed. Dominic A.A. Randolph, the Riverdale Country School community and the Board of Trustees 1/3

HADLEY--Arthur T.,II, a decorated World War II veteran, a writer and journalist, passed away on November 25th, at the age of 91. He was the son of Morris and Katherine Hadley and the grandson of Arthur Hadley, President of Yale University. At the age of 18 in 1942, after graduating from Groton, he enlisted in the US Army and saw combat in the European theatre. He was severely wounded in the final stages of the war and retired from the Army as a Captain and tank officer, having been awarded both the Purple Heart and the Silver Star. He went on to Yale University, graduating in three years as a Scholar of the House, magna cum laude, and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. After graduation in 1949, he joined Newsweek, where he covered the Pentagon during the Korean War and later the White House in the last year of the Truman administration and first term of the Eisenhower administration. He was Assistant Executive Editor of the New York Herald Tribune and won several prizes for his magazine reporting from Vietnam. He later became Washington Bureau Chief of the New Times magazine. He is the author of numerous magazine articles, two plays, and ten books, including "The Straw Giant" and "The Nation's Safety and Arms Control." He was Press Secretary to three Democratic presidential candidates during their primary campaigns, and is a founding member of the International Institute of Strategic Studies in London. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Jane Byington Hadley. Three other marriages ended in divorce. He is survived by his sister, Barbara Stanton, his children, Arthur, Kate Baker, George, Nicholas, Elisabeth Wheeler, Caroline Thies, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, January 29th at 3pm at the Century Association of New York. 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas. The Board of Directors of the Mayo Foundation For The Handicap mourn the passing of our long time loyal director. His service provided guidance to our organization, which provides caring and compassionate care to handicap people in the west of Ireland. He also gave guidance to the O'Dwyer Foundation in Ireland. The Mayo Foundation For The Handicap extends our sympathy to the family, Eileen, Maureen and Timothy and to his grandchildren. William O'Dwyer, President Mayo Foundation For The Handicap 1/3

GILLESPIE-- Eileen D.,(nee Dealy), passed away peacefully at her home on December 2, 2015, surrounded by her loving husband and family. Eileen is survived by her husband of 60 years, George J. Gillespie, III, who is a Retired Partner and Special Counsel to the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP, along with her four children and spouses: Gail G. Garcia (Michael) of Bluffton, SC, John D. Gillespie (Andrea Borden) of Guilford, CT, Myles D. Gillespie (Kimberly Idler) of Rye, NY and Eileen G. Fahey (Timothy) of Scarborough, ME. She is also survived by her ten loving grandchildren: Lindsay D. Garcia, William W. Garcia, Henry G. Garcia, Bradford Casey Gillespie, Lucas T. Gillespie, Chloe S. Gillespie, Myles D. Gillespie, Jr., John T. Gillespie, Caroline M. Gillespie and George T. Fahey, and by her sister, Margaret D. Ackerman (Robert) of Boston, MA and her brother, James J. Dealy (Angela) of Cincinnati, OH. She is predeceased by her sister, Marcia T. Dealy of New Brunswick, NJ and her brother, John T. Dealy (Constance) of Portsmouth, RI. Eileen was born on October 12, 1931, and grew up in Riverdale and Carmel, NY. She was a long time resident of Harrison, NY and enjoyed spending her summers along with her husband, children and grandchildren in Prouts Neck, ME. She was a graduate of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich, CT and Newton College, Newton, MA. She was a founder and owner of The Painted Finish, Ltd., Greenwich, CT, an interior design firm. Eileen was honored with the naming of the science building at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich, CT where she served on the Board of Trustees for many years. She also served on the Advisory Board for St. Vincent's Hospital, Westchester and St. Joseph's School for the Deaf, Bronx, NY. Eileen will be remembered for many things; her love of art and antiques, sense of style, and impeccable taste. Most importantly her family and friends will remember her for her poise and grace, her generous spirit and her deep and abiding faith. Family will receive visitors on Friday, December 4, 4-8pm, at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York 10580, (914)967-0129. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, December 5, at 10am at The Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY 10580. 1/3

ROSEN--Selma, of Palm Beach, FL and Greenwich, CT passed away on December 2, 2015. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Marty, Selma is survived by her four children, Robert Rosen, Harold Rosen, Lee Rosen, and Susan Alisberg, their spouses Nancy, Marian, and Andy, ten grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren. Funeral and burial service on December 4 will be for the family. The family will sit Shiva at Robert's house in Greenwich, CT on Friday from 12 to 4pm and on Sunday from 11 to 4pm and at Lee's house in Delray Beach, FL on Sunday from 11-5pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in her name to Columbia University Medical Center, Division of Cardiology, Attention: Dr. Alan Schwartz, 177 Washington Avenue, Room 435, NY, NY 10032. 1/3

SILFEN--David M.,69, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 28th, surrounded by his loving family. David was a long-time senior executive at Goldman Sachs, enjoying a 28 year career with the Wall Street firm. David joined Goldman Sachs in 1968, where he was the first MBA hired in the Trading and Arbitrage division. He was named to the partnership in 1978. In 1990 David become co-head of the then-Equities Division, where he had global responsibility for the firm's activities for all equity securities. He was also a member of the Executive Committee, the senior governing body of the firm, and helped steer the firm towards its initial public offering. David managed and mentored many colleagues who would go on to illustrious careers of their own. He was very proud of their accomplishments. For the last 18 years, David enjoyed a second career as a dedicated philanthropist. He served on a number of boards for his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, including acting as the Vice Chair of the Board of Trustees and Chair of the Board of Overseers of the College of Arts and Sciences. David also served as a Trustee of the Riverdale Country Day School, and on the Board of Overseers for Columbia Business School and the Board of Regents for the Smithsonian Institution, where he chaired the Investment Committee. Outside of his work, David loved playing golf, traveling, and the company of his dogs. His greatest joy was becoming a grandfather. David was born in Queens to Herman and Esther Silfen. A lifelong New Yorker and devoted resident of the City, he is survived by his wife of 44 years, Lyn, son, Adam, daughter, Jane, daughter-in-law, Kelly, and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Dr. Ellen Margolin, and a very many friends. He will be missed. 1/3

ROSEN--Selma. I am deeply saddened at the loss of my special friend, neighbor, travel companion and brilliant bridge partner. With Marty and Paul we certainly painted the town from here to China. The many wonderful memories and times we shared, I shall always treasure. Rest in peace my Dear, Dear Selma. My heartfelt condolences to her children: Bobby, Harold, Lee, and Suzie, and their spouses, her 10 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. You all brought boundless joy to Selma's life, especially in the last decades. Irma Milstein and the entire Milstein Family 1/3

DRAKE--Susan Elston Wallace, beloved wife of Philip M. Drake, died as she lived, quietly with her daughter, Margaret, and her husband of 66 years at her side on Saturday, November 28, 2015 in Naples, Florida. She was a devoted mother to four daughters, Anne, Kathleen, Margaret (Todd Vallely) and Susan Holly (Todd Sylvestri). Susan had three grandchildren, Kathleen Grosse, Ross and Kevin Sylvestri and two great-grandchildren, Anna Bella and Michael Morrell. Susan was born on October 12, 1921, in Indianapolis, Indiana to Josephine and Lew Wallace. She was predeceased by her parents and brothers, Lew and William, and her sister, Margaret Daly. Susan graduated from Bennett College in Milbrook, NY. She worked at Simon & Schuster in New York before marrying Phil. She was a dog lover and had a dog at her side most of her life. Sue had many interests, including tennis and golf in her earlier years and needlepoint, Nantucket basket weaving, Mahjong and croquet. She worked on her needlepoint projects with great love, ultimately giving her creations to those closest to her. She approached these interests with great enthusiasm and basically taught herself croquet in her senior years. She was a member of the croquet clubs in Marion, Massachusetts, Greenwich, Connecticut and Naples, Florida and was considered a tough opponent on the court. Sue was an avid reader who enjoyed sharing her love of literature with her friends. She was known by many for the wonderful, well thought out gifts that she gave for no reason at all. Along with her husband, Philip, Susan helped establish the Whitby School in Greenwich in 1958. Susan was the great- granddaughter of Major General Lew Wallace, whose statue stands in Statuary Hall in the United States Capitol. He fought in three significant battles in the Civil War. In 1880, he authored Ben Hur, a best-selling novel that has been called the most significant Christian book in the 19th century. Sue enjoyed being near or in the water and was most happy in her home in Marion, Massachusetts where she spent over 45 summers enjoying her family and friends. Services will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, December 5 at St. Michael The Archangel Roman Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the General Lew Wallace Study and Museum, 200 Wallace Avenue, PO Box 662, Crawfordsville, IN 47933. 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas J.,Jr., on December 2, 2015. Beloved husband of Eileen for over 50 years; father of Maureen McAloon and Timothy Hughes; father-in-law of Jim McAloon and Michelle Hughes; adored "Pa" of Sean, Kate, Colleen and Rory McAloon and Evan, Quinn and Jackson Hughes. He led a distinguished 54-year career as an attorney including serving as ADA with the Homicide Bureau in Manhattan and as Secretary to Hon. John M. Murtagh in the NYS Supreme Court before entering private practice. Visitation: Friday 2-5 and 6-9; Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison, NYC. Funeral mass: Saturday 9:45, St. Margaret of Cortona, 6000 Riverdale Ave., Bx, NYC. Burial: Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Mayo Foundation for the Handicapped would be appreciated. 1/3

BUCHWALD--Dr. Charles, born 1935, died December 3, 2015. Beloved husband of Debby, father and grandfather to David and Maureen, Emma and Olivia; Adam and Susie, Zachary and Ezra. Stepfather and grandfather to Ivy and Sam. Brother of Alex and Ginny, Greta, Don and Maggie. Loyal believer in the New York Mets, nee Brooklyn Dodgers. Devout Democrat, district leader of the Eleanor Roosevelt Democratic Club for 20 years. Services Sunday, December 6, 11am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3
STEINBERG--Meyer (Mike), 6/19/19-12/4/03 Missed and loved everyday. Jean, Bonnie, Carol and Lois 1/3

THUR--Paul, September 22, 1930 - December 2, 2015. Survived by son Jeffrey (Mindy), grandchildren Nicole and Alexander, and nephews Jules and Alan. Predeceased by his wife Barbara and sister Gerta. A graveside service will take place on Sunday, December 6, 2pm, at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. 1/3

HUGHES--Thomas. The lawyers and staff of O'Dwyer & Bernstien, LLP mourn the loss of their friend and colleague Thomas J. Hughes. Tom was a model and inspiration to the lawyers of the firm, an "old school" lawyer in the best sense: unfailingly courteous, affable, collegial, constant to his word, with legal acumen second to none; the kind of lawyer who made lasting relationships with his adversaries because he conducted himself with such grace and respect for the law and fellow members of the bar, they were enriched by their association with him. Tom will be missed. We mourn with Eileen, Maureen and Jim, Tim and Michelle and his devoted grandchildren and extended family. 1/3

FRANK--Charlotte S. Died suddenly at home over Thanksgiving weekend. Family and friends deeply mourn the loss of this visionary leader, co-founder of The Transition Network, a national organization for women over 50 - for which she received an Ashoka Fellowship - and the Caring Collaborative. Known for her numerous interests, sharp intelligence, warmth, generosity, and pluck, she was formerly Director of Contracting and Procurement for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and COO of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Survived by brothers Harvey and Fred, sister Suzanne, and eight nieces and nephews. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Children's Defense Fund and Meals On Wheels. Memorial at later date. 1/3

MULLANY--Peter F.,82, of Glen Rock, NJ, died Tuesday, December 1, 2015. Peter was born and raised in New York City and lived in Glen Rock for the past 45 years. He was a Professor of English, Philosophy and Humanities, as well as Dean, at Fairleigh Dickinson University for 43 years before retiring in 2013. His greatest passion was his alma mater, Fordham University, where he earned a BA (1955), MA (1957) and Phd (1967). In 1977, he returned to teach at Fordham every semester until 2010. Peter was a fixture at football games and alumni events. He graduated from his beloved Regis High School in 1951. Peter will live forever in the hearts of many, including his children Peter and Darby, his loving companion Claire Gensch, his brothers Tom and Patrick, all of their families including many grandchildren, nieces and nephews. A wake will be held at Vander Plaat Funeral Home located at 257 Godwin Avenue in Wyckoff, NJ on Saturday, December 5, from 4-6pm and Sunday, December 6, from 2-6pm. Mass will be held on Monday, December 7 at 10:30am at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Ridgewood, NJ and a burial service immediately after at Gate of Heaven in Hawthorne, NY. Contributions can be made to Fordham University in Peter's memory. 1/3

SCHLESINGER--Sheldon J.,85, of Golden Beach, passed away December 2, 2015 surrounded by his family and members of his law firm. He was born in Brooklyn, NY and moved to Florida to attend the University of Miami and the University of Miami School of Law where he met his beloved wife Barbara to whom he was married for 60 years. They had two sons, Scott and Gregg, who both followed their father's lead and became lawyers and practiced with him. They were fortunate to have six grandchildren, a constant source of happiness. He knew as a very young man that he was going to be a lawyer and he enjoyed every minute of his career. His favorite place was in a courtroom. His passing will leave a void in the legal community where he was greatly respected by judges, colleagues and opponents alike. As avid supporters of civic and charitable organizations, the Schlesinger family is actively involved in the South Florida community. Mr. Schlesinger served on the Board of Governors of Nova- Southeastern Law Center and served as chairman of the Board of Trustees of Broward Community College. Early on he got involved with Broward Community College because he believed strongly in giving an opportunity for a college education to anyone who wanted one; a building on the Hollywood Campus is named for him. Sheldon J. Schlesinger was one of the most successful personal injury and medical malpractice attorneys in the United States. For over 60 years, he represented individuals and consumers in landmark cases across the nation. He was listed in every edition of the book "The Best Lawyers in America." He had, and deserved, a reputation for being one of the best trial attorneys in the United States. The Miami Herald described Shelly as "The Dean of Broward Civil Litigators." The Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel described him as a "Bulldog for the Underdog," a "super-lawyer in every sense of the word," and "one of the most powerful personal injury attorneys in the country." At the conclusion of a lengthy trial where his client emerged victorious, the presiding judge entered a court order describing him as "one of the most experienced and skilled attorneys which the Florida Bar has to offer," and that his "experience and ability in medical malpractice litigation is exceeded by no one." Mr. Schlesinger won significant verdicts and settlements in numerous high profile cases. He set national records for plaintiffs' attorneys, including products liability cases against major automotive manufacturers. In 1995, he was part of the landmark legal team that successfully defeated the tobacco industry on behalf of the citizens of Florida. He was one of the founders of the Broward County Trial Lawyers Association and served as its president. He was a member of the Inner Circle of Advocates, one of the nation's most prestigious organizations for plaintiff lawyers. Because of the number of high profile cases he won, he was the subject of numerous interviews and stories in newspapers, magazines and television. He appeared in Time, People, Forbes, Florida Trend, New York Times and the Wall Street Journal. He appeared on CBS 60 Minutes, ABC's 20/20, the Phil Donahue Show, and numerous other national and local television and news programs. Recently, he was inducted into the Trial Lawyer Hall of Fame held at Temple University in Pennsylvania; he was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award at the Florida Verdicts Hall of Fame by the Daily Business Review; and he was honored to give a Legacy lecture to his cherished Inner Circle of Advocates. He is survived by his sons: Scott (m. Anne) and Gregg; his six grandchildren: Charlotte, Alexander, Molly, Theodora, Samuel, and Theodore; and his brother-in-law, Larry Butler (m. Grace). The funeral will be held Sunday, December 6, 2015 at 2:00pm at Temple Beth El, 1351 South 14th Avenue, Hollywood, FL 33020, interment to follow at Temple Beth El Memorial Gardens, 4900 Old Griffin Road, Davie, FL 33314, (954) 584-7151. The family will receive visitors on December 6, 2015 following the interment, and on December 7 and 8, 2015 at the residence. Call (954)467-8800 for further details. 1/3

EMORY--Linda Rodgers. The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation and our Board of Directors mourn the loss of our dear friend Linda Rodgers Emory. Linda's creativity, passion, and commitment to the fight against cancer in honor of all patients and families will always provide us inspiration. Our deepest appreciation and condolences go out to her loved ones. 1/3

TAKETOMO-- Yasuhiko, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences is deeply saddened by the passing of our distinguished colleague, Clinical Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry, Yasuhiko Taketomo, M.D., an exceptional psychiatrist, educator, and leader who was a member of our department for more than 45 years. His principles and wisdom set the highest of standards in the field of psychiatry. He never lost sight of the humanity and dignity of people in his care. He was a well-loved, and highly respected colleague, mentor, and friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Taketomo family. T. Byram Karasu, M.D. Silverman Professor & the University Chairman Department of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences Albert Einstein College of Medicine 1/3

SPERLING--Kenneth Lewis, 57, of Orange, CT passed away peacefully this Thursday morning, December 3 2015, at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Ken was born on April 11, 1958 in New York. Ken is survived by his loving and supportive wife Ros, caring sons Daniel and Benjamin (fiance Ariel Levin), sister Kathy (Mike Occi), and parents Florence Sperling, Renee and Stan Babit, and Joan Newborn. Ken is predeceased by his father Philip Sperling. Ken was an active member of his community, both personally and professionally. He taught the world how to live and fight a courageous battle with cancer filled with dignity and courage. The family wishes to thank 4th floor staff at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital and the 12 North staff at Smilow Cancer Hospital. Ken believed that it is not the number of days that you live, but it is how you choose to live them. Funeral services will be held at Congregation B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Rd in Woodbridge on Sunday, December 6, at 11:00am. Interment services will follow at B'nai Jacob Memorial Park on Wintergreen Ave in New Haven. Donations can be made in memory of Ken Sperling to Congregation B'nai Jacob or Next Generation Men (ngmatlanta.org). A traditional period of mourning will be observed at the Sperling home through Thursday, December 10, beginning at 1:00pm each day. Funeral services in care of Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, New Haven. 1/3
SHARPE--Tina, 72, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away on Wednesday, December 2, 2015. See: www.glickfamily funeralhome.com 1/3

MULLANY--Peter F.,82, of Glen Rock, NJ, died Tuesday, December 1, 2015. Peter was born and raised in New York City and lived in Glen Rock for the past 45 years. He was a Professor of English, Philosophy and Humanities, as well as Dean, at Fairleigh Dickinson University for 43 years before retiring in 2013. His greatest passion was his alma mater, Fordham University, where he earned a BA (1955), MA (1957) and Phd (1967). In 1977, he returned to teach at Fordham every semester until 2010. Peter was a fixture at football games and alumni events. He graduated from his beloved Regis High School in 1951. Peter will live forever in the hearts of many, including his children Peter and Darby, his loving companion Claire Gensch, his brothers Tom and Patrick, all of their families including many grandchildren, nieces and nephews. A wake will be held at Vander Plaat Funeral Home located at 257 Godwin Avenue in Wyckoff, NJ on Saturday, December 5, from 4-6pm and Sunday, December 6, from 2-6pm. Mass will be held on Monday, December 7 at 10:30am at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Ridgewood, NJ and a burial service immediately after at Gate of Heaven in Hawthorne, NY. Contributions can be made to Fordham University in Peter's memory. 1/3
WEIN--Robert P.,on December 1, 2015. Long-time Certified Public Accountant. Funeral Service Sunday, 9:30am, at "The Riverside," Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th Street, New York City. 1/3

SILFEN--David M.,69, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 28th, surrounded by his loving family. David was a long-time senior executive at Goldman Sachs, enjoying a 28 year career with the Wall Street firm. David joined Goldman Sachs in 1968, where he was the first MBA hired in the Trading and Arbitrage division. He was named to the partnership in 1978. In 1990 David become co-head of the then-Equities Division, where he had global responsibility for the firm's activities for all equity securities. He was also a member of the Executive Committee, the senior governing body of the firm, and helped steer the firm towards its initial public offering. David managed and mentored many colleagues who would go on to illustrious careers of their own. He was very proud of their accomplishments. For the last 18 years, David enjoyed a second career as a dedicated philanthropist. He served on a number of boards for his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, including acting as the Vice Chair of the Board of Trustees and Chair of the Board of Overseers of the College of Arts and Sciences. David also served as a Trustee of the Riverdale Country Day School, and on the Board of Overseers for Columbia Business School and the Board of Regents for the Smithsonian Institution, where he chaired the Investment Committee. Outside of his work, David loved playing golf, traveling, and the company of his dogs. His greatest joy was becoming a grandfather. David was born in Queens to Herman and Esther Silfen. A lifelong New Yorker and devoted resident of the City, he is survived by his wife of 44 years, Lyn, son, Adam, daughter, Jane, daughter-in-law, Kelly, and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Dr. Ellen Margolin, and a very many friends. He will be missed. 1/3

LOWE--E. Nobles, 103, of New York City and Carmel, NY, died on December 1, 2015 after a brief illness. He was born on October 4, 1912, in Minturn, Arkansas to the late James and Lula Ether Lowe. Nobles received his B.A. and LL.B. from the University of Arkansas. He was General Counsel of Westvaco Corporation for 34 years prior to going into private practice. Nobles is survived by his wife, Margaret Breece Lowe; daughter Nancy Lowe; sons, Edwin and James; his four grandsons, Michael, Christian, William and Thomas; four great-grandchildren, Alison, Theo and Zoe; his brother, Thomas and several nieces and nephews. Nobles was active in the Practicing Law Institute, American Arbitration Association and the American Bar among other law-related organizations. Funeral services will be held at 10:00am on Friday, December 11 at the Drew Methodist Church in Carmel, NY. 1

CASADONTE--Thomas. Thomas "Thom" David Casadonte, 52, a prominent community and industry leader died suddenly at his Rutherford, NJ home on December 2, 2015. He is survived by his beloved wife, Teresa (nee Beaulac), his loving daughters Kathryne and Madeleine, his mother Ellen, his brothers Joseph and Edward, his son-in-law to be, Matthew Gross and is pre-deceased by his father Joseph A. Casadonte. A graduate of the University of Maryland Baltimore County and Columbia University-Columbia Business School, his career included significant roles with Sony, IBM, George P. Johnson, Maritz. Over the last five years his most passionate role being Bloomberg LP's Global Head of Experiential and Event Marketing. Mr. Casadonte was a member of the Rutherford Board of Education for 12 years and served as its President from 2007-2013. Services will be held at Calhoun Mania Funeral Home in Rutherford, NJ, Sunday, December 6th, 2015 2-7pm. Funeral services to be held Monday, December 7th, 2015 at Queen of Peace Church in North Arlington, NJ at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Rutherford Education Foundation, P.O. Box 246, Rutherford, NJ 07070 are appreciated. 1/3

SILFEN--David. The Smithsonian Community is saddened by the passing of our accomplished and generous colleague, David Silfen. David served a decade as the inaugural Chair of the Regents Investment Committee, and his foresight and investment acumen was instrumental in developing the Smithsonian's Endowment. We are grateful for his dedication and the pursuit of excellence that embodied his many and varied contributions. David was a steadfast contributor of his time, talent and resources since 1997, serving on the Smithsonian National Board and the Regents Finance Committee. We will miss him. Our thoughts are with David's wife, Lyn, his children, Adam and Jane, family and friends. 1/3

ACTIS-GRANDE--Caryl. After a tenacious struggle with lung cancer, Caryl Actis-Grande passed away at her home in Westport, Connecticut on Saturday November 28, 2015. She was 77 years old. As the co-founder and CEO of Actis-Grande & Associates, she was a longtime fixture in the fashion industry operating buying offices in Paris, London, New York, Milan and Florence. She played an integral role in launching the careers of designers including Azzedine Alaia, Jean Paul Gaultier and Patrick Kelly. Born Caryl Sherman in New York, New York on March 22, 1938, she graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1960 and later received her Master of Arts in Liberal Arts from St. John's College in Santa Fe, New Mexico. Ms. Actis-Grande began her career in the training program at Bloomingdale's and then became the fashion director for women's accessories at B. Altman and Company. In 1976, she and her husband Richard Actis-Grande, a former Look magazine editor, opened their own Paris- based firm Actis-Grande Associates - a buying office whose list of clients would grow to include Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus, Holt Renfrew, Lane Crawford and Harvey Nichols. Outside of work, Ms. Actis- Grande was a world traveller, a voracious reader, an avid museumgoer, and an active member of the Santa Fe Opera Guild. She and her husband kept homes in New Mexico, London, Paris, New York, and The Bahamas. She enjoyed pursuits both sporting and intellectual - equally at home trekking through the high peaks of Nepal or attending an author reading at the Hay-on-Wye festival in Wales. She had just moved to Westport, Connecticut this fall when her cancer became terminal. Upon receiving the diagnosis, her response was an echo of Edith Piaf, "I regret nothing. No tears. It has been a full and wonderful life." Ms Actis-Grande is survived by her husband of 56 years, Richard, and her two devoted nephews--Mr. Richard A. Sherman of Summit, New Jersey and Mr. John S. Brodie of Manhattan. She was a beloved "Granny" to Kyle and Amy Sherman as well as Nicholas and Alexandra Brodie. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. John's College, Santa Fe, New Mexico. 1/3

ZUCKER-FRANKLIN-- Dorothea, 86, passed away on November 24th in her home in Manhattan. A highly respected hematologist and research scientist, Dorothea contributed to the basis of contemporary cell biology through her work on the microarchitecture of blood cells, including platelets, lymphocytes and megakaryocytes. Dorothea began life in Berlin, Germany, just as the National Socialist (Nazi) Party was gaining traction. She moved with her parents and younger sister, Marion, to Amsterdam, where they ultimately attended the same school as Anne Frank. On several occasions, Nazi soldiers visited the house where the family was living, and on at least one occasion, detaining them overnight. No longer able to obtain the visas needed for immigration, they went into hiding in the small town of Uithoorn during the summer of 1943. Following the liberation of Holland, Dorothea attended the Quaker international school in Ommen where she began learning English. In 1946, she boarded the MS Gripsholm with her mother and sister and crossed the Atlantic to arrive in the United States. There, she was able to attend Hunter College after completing her senior year at Forest Hills High School. She served as class president and valedictorian for the Hunter College, CUNY class of 1952 and was later awarded an honorary doctorate by the school. She recalled considerable opposition to her decision to pursue a career in medicine, but persevered and graduated from New York Medical College in 1956, as one of five women in her class. In May of 1956, she married Edward C. Franklin, M.D., beginning the warm and vivacious personal and professional partnership that lasted until his premature death in 1982. Together they purchased and cared for their much loved farm in the Berkshires, travelled internationally, collected pre-Columbian figurines, enjoyed so many of New York's cultural offerings as well as a sabbatical year in Paris and developed a passion for downhill skiing. Dorothea ultimately achieved the rank of full professor at NYU Medical School and continued to accrue professional accolades for the remainder of her career, including election as President of the American Society of Hematologists in 1995 and induction into the Institute of Medicine that same year. In addition to numerous original publications and public presentations, she co-authored a definitive atlas of hematology and saw it through three editions. She is survived by her daughter, Deborah Julie Franklin, PhD, M.D.; grandson, Edward Aaron Franklin; sister, Marion Zucker Goldstein, M.D. and nieces Lillian Goldstein Shapiro, M.D., and Naomi Goldstein. Funeral service Sunday, December 6th at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Charitable contributions to Selfhelp Community Services or Yad Vashem in her name are preferred in lieu of flowers. 1/3

CASADONTE--Thomas. Thomas "Thom" David Casadonte, 52, a prominent community and industry leader died suddenly at his Rutherford, NJ home on December 2, 2015. He is survived by his beloved wife, Teresa (nee Beaulac), his loving daughters Kathryne and Madeleine, his mother Ellen, his brothers Joseph and Edward, his son-in-law to be, Matthew Gross and is pre-deceased by his father Joseph A. Casadonte. A graduate of the University of Maryland Baltimore County and Columbia University-Columbia Business School, his career included significant roles with Sony, IBM, George P. Johnson, Maritz. Over the last five years his most passionate role being Bloomberg LP's Global Head of Experiential and Event Marketing. Mr. Casadonte was a member of the Rutherford Board of Education for 12 years and served as its President from 2007-2013. Services will be held at Calhoun Mania Funeral Home in Rutherford, NJ, Sunday, December 6th, 2015 2-7pm. Funeral services to be held Monday, December 7th, 2015 at Queen of Peace Church in North Arlington, NJ at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Rutherford Education Foundation, P.O. Box 246, Rutherford, NJ 07070 are appreciated. 1/3

LAIBE--Ann Jessie Davis. Of Greenwich, CT and Nantucket, MA, passed away November 25 after a prolonged illness. Born July 20, 1929 to the late Robert V. and Caroline Schroeder Davis and raised in Scranton, PA, Ann graduated from Scranton Central High School in 1947 and attended Skidmore College, where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1951. After graduation, she worked in summer stock in Saratoga, NY, taught at the Tuxedo Park School, and worked in New York City, where she met her beloved John Laibe, to whom she was married in 1957. Their wedded life began in Brooklyn Heights, then proceeded to Connecticut, Hong Kong, and Miami before returning to Connecticut in 1980. Along the way they traveled extensively, usually with their five children. Ann enjoyed educating young children and did so at a number of schools, including the Montessori school in Miami, and the Round Hill Nursery School in Greenwich. She also tutored adults in reading with Literacy Volunteers of America. She and John volunteered in numerous local activities, notably the soup kitchen in Stamford, CT via their parish of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich. In addition, they gave to local nonprofits, including Greenwich Hospital. Ann loved reading, gardening, jazz and classical music, and correspondence, keeping up with friends and family with the increasingly uncommon method of letter writing. Ann was preceded in death by her husband John and daughter Constance, as well as her sister Carol Davis Norton. She is survived by her brothers Dr. Robert V. Davis and Col. Richard C. Davis; daughter Anne Laibe Bertolino; sons Marc, Christopher and Timothy, their spouses, and 16 adoring grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held December 7 at 11am at St. Michael the Archangel Church in Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made in Ann's name to one's chosen charity or to Family Centers, 40 Arch Street, Greenwich CT 06830. www.familycenters.org. 1/3

POMEROY--Dr. Leon Ralph. Of Woodbridge, VA, died November 24 at Fairfax Trauma ICU, following an automobile accident. Leon, born December 6, 1933 in Westfield, MA, was the son of L. Ralph Pomeroy and Rachel (Harlow) Pomeroy, of Westfield, MA. He was married to Dr. Wendy Anwar Pomeroy. 1/3

TRACY--William C.,93, born in Brooklyn, NY January 6, 1922, died in Brunswick, Maine on December 2, 2015. He was retired as Associate Dean of the Journalism School at Columbia University in New York in 1988. He was a World War II Veteran. While at Springfield College in Massachusetts, he went to enlist the day after the attack on Pearl Harbor. He was advised to go back to College and was told he'd help his country best by being a good student and waiting until his number was called. Shortly after, he enlisted in the US Navy. His V-12 training included Trinity College, Chicago, Harvard and cryptology. He saw duty in Europe and Asia as an Ensign. He later joined the reserves as LTJG. He leaves his wife, Eleanor (Johnson) Tracy, of 61 years; twin sons, William IV (Ellen Carucci) and Henry (Dr. Andrea Tracy); and two grandchildren he adored, Simon Tracy of Los Angeles, and Vivian Tracy, a student at Occidental College, Los Angeles. To them he was Bop, lover of classical music and soulmate. He also leaves a twin brother, George (Terry Gibson) of Buford, NC. Condolences may be expressed to the family www.Funeral Alternatives.net. Services are under the care of Funeral Alternatives, 8 Pleasant St. Brunswick. 1/3
CZARTORYSKI--Kevin. 8/14/64 - 12/5/2010 Loved and not forgotten, until we meet again. Patricia, Carol, Diane & Bob 1/3

ROTHSCHILD--William B.,of Rancho Mirage, CA, formerly of Maplewood, NJ, passed away at his home in Rancho Mirage, on Wednesday, November 25th at the age of 98. Bill Rothschild leaves his wife, Beverly Rothschild, his sons, Mark and Jeffrey Rothschild, and his grandchildren, Harriet, Isaac, and Jackiel Rothschild. Bill Rothschild was born May 15th, 1917 in New York City. Bill's father, Marcus Rothschild, founded the firm of M. Rothschild & Company, a leading importer of commodities from South East Asia. After attending the University of Georgia, Bill worked for his father in New York before spending six years in the US Army, acquiring the rank of Master Sargent and participated in the Normandy invasion and the Ardennes campaign. Following WWII, Bill rejoined M. Rothschild & Company, where he assisted his father and eventually became President of the firm. Bill served as President of the American/Indonesian Chamber of Commerce from 1968-71 and 1979-80. Bill was a Life Master bridge player and scratch golfer. Bill and his wife, Beverly were long time members of the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, NJ. Bill and Beverly relocated to Rancho Mirage in 2006, where they are members of Mission Hills Country Club. Bill loved golf and especially bridge and was a regular bridge player at Duncan Bridge Center in Palm Dessert. 1/3

TAYLOR--Mahlon Clinton. Mahlon "Clinton" (aka Clint) Taylor, born on June 11, 1926, passed away on November 19, 2015. Clint was 89. Clint is survived by his wife Diane (Bridee) Taylor; his daughter Ingrid and favorite son-in-law Gary Stefan, his daughter Karen Taylor three sons, Mahlon C. Taylor Jr., SellmanStanley Taylor III., and Kent Taylor; step-daughters' Kimberly S. Ratzand Leigh Ann Hunt: a brother, Joseph and wife Anita. Clint was hired by Insinkerator 1989 as the New York Area Manager. As a representative for Insinkerator, he worked with the New York City Council, various New York City Departments; the Mayor's Office and many of engineers, architects, and major contractor groups. With the help of Clint's efforts, the ban on the use of Food Waste Disposals was lifted on September 11, 1997. Clint was also employed by Eljer Plumbing Ware as a New York City Regional Sales Manager from 1963 to 1974. Clint was on the Board of Directors of The Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, and served as Chairman of the Membership Committee. He was recognized as Associate Member of the Year by the association in November 2002. He was a member of the American Society of Plumbing Engineers/New York City and the American Society of Sanitary Engineers of New York City. Clint was a World War II Veteran-U.S. Army with the 3rd Infantry Division attached to the 7th Army under the Command of General Patton. Condolences may be given in guest book at www.burroughsfh.com. In lieu of flowers please direct your donations to any of the following: Renovation Project: VFW Post #

SILFEN--David M.,69, passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on November 28th, surrounded by his loving family. David was a long-time senior executive at Goldman Sachs, enjoying a 28 year career with the Wall Street firm. David joined Goldman Sachs in 1968, where he was the first MBA hired in the Trading and Arbitrage division. He was named to the partnership in 1978. In 1990 David become co-head of the then-Equities Division, where he had global responsibility for the firm's activities for all equity securities. He was also a member of the Executive Committee, the senior governing body of the firm, and helped steer the firm towards its initial public offering. David managed and mentored many colleagues who would go on to illustrious careers of their own. He was very proud of their accomplishments. For the last 18 years, David enjoyed a second career as a dedicated philanthropist. He served on a number of boards for his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, including acting as the Vice Chair of the Board of Trustees and Chair of the Board of Overseers of the College of Arts and Sciences. David also served as a Trustee of the Riverdale Country Day School, and on the Board of Overseers for Columbia Business School and the Board of Regents for the Smithsonian Institution, where he chaired the Investment Committee. Outside of his work, David loved playing golf, traveling, and the company of his dogs. His greatest joy was becoming a grandfather. David was born in Queens to Herman and Esther Silfen. A lifelong New Yorker and devoted resident of the City, he is survived by his wife of 44 years, Lyn, son, Adam, daughter, Jane, daughter-in-law, Kelly, and two grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Dr. Ellen Margolin, and a very many friends. He will be missed. 1/3

GUPTA--Krishna. Krishna Kumar Gupta "KK" Passed away peacefully in his sleep on December 2, 2015. Born in Meerut, India on January 26, 1940, he got his MD from AIIMS New Delhi in 1962. He later moved to New York City in 1967 and joined Long Island Jewish Hospital. At LIJ, he enjoyed a fulfilling career as a Pediatrician under the Executive Director and Chief of Staff of the Schneider Childrens Hospital Dr. Philip Lanzkowsky. Dr. Gupta was one of the founding members of AIIMSonians of America (the AIIMS alumni association), and worked actively for it until his passing. He lived with colon cancer for eight years but still made sure to find enjoyment in every day. He had a fighting spirit about never giving up, and about finding happiness in the darkest of times. His selfless devotion to his family shall be greatly missed. He is survived by his two sisters, two sons, two daughters- in-law, three grandchildren and a large loving family. Dr. Gupta had a passion for Shakespeare, and his favorite quote is from Macbeth: Sleep that knits up the raveled sleeve of care. Sleep well KK, you have earned the rest. 1/3

SHORR--Beatrice, passed away peacefully on November 18, 2015 at age 97. Bea had survived her husband, Jack; her siblings, Marty and Harriet; and her daughters, Mimi and Maddy. She is survived by her grandchildren Eric, Amy, and Jonathan, who had the pleasure of adopting her in her last five years. Bea dedicated her working life to the family swimsuit design and manufacturing business, Crest Apparel, that produced under such labels as Oscar de la Renta, Wavelengths, and Little Dippers, which brought the iconic Wonder Woman bathing suit to millions of happy girls. Bea won five Earnie awards for design excellence and was a philanthropist with efforts in the UJA and David Yellin Teacher's College. Even in her 90s she captivated many with her charm, wit, and beauty. Please visit memorial: www.beashorr.com 1/3

COOPER--Dr. Rose A.,a 56-year resident of White Plains, NY, died at home on December 4, 2015 at the age of 96 following a brief illness. Dr. Cooper was born in Poland and at age 12 emigrated to New York City in the early 1930s with her family who sensed the looming threat of Nazi Germany. She met her late husband, Dr. Ira Cooper, at the City College of New York and settled in White Plains several years after obtaining her doctorate in education at Columbia University. She had a long tenure as the college admissions counselor at White Plains High School before embarking on an equally long stint as a dean at the Westchester Community College. She was also a past president of the American Association of Counseling and Development. Her career as an educator, touching the lives of countless young people, only came to an end upon her retirement a few months prior to her death. Dr. Cooper is survived by a daughter, Dr. Gale Cooper of Albuquerque, New Mexico, a son, Dr. Glenn Cooper, of Sarasota, Florida, his wife, Tessa Cooper, and their son, Shane Cooper. In addition, she is survived by her sister, Ann Kaplan of New York City, who was also her best friend. There will be a reception at 7-9pm Wednesday, December 9, at the Ballard- Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains. The funeral service will be held Thursday, December 10 at 9:30am at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations are encouraged to the Westchester Community College Foundation, Hartford Hall, 75 Grasslands Rd, Valhalla, NY 10595. 1/3

PUGH--Lawrence. Lawrence, "Larry", Reynolds Pugh, of Naples, FL and Falmouth, ME passed away Thursday, December 3, 2015 of respiratory failure. He was 82. His wife of 59 years, Jean Van Curan Pugh and his two daughters, Deborah Pugh Kelton and Diane Pugh Esecson were at his side. Born in White Plains, NY to Howard and Marjorie Slosson Pugh, he was a proud and active alumni of Salisbury School and Colby College and a U.S. Army Veteran. Larry served as CEO and Chairman of VF Corporation, an apparel manufacturing company, whose brands include Wrangler, Lee Jeans, and Vanity Fair. During his tenure he grew sales tenfold, making VF the largest publicly held clothing company. He also served as president of Samsonite Luggage, director of Black & Decker, and chairman of UNUM. Colby College remained an integral part of Larry's life. He was a life trustee there, serving on the board for over 30 years, including eight years as chairman. His commitment to Colby will live on through his wife, one daughter, and two grandsons, all Colby alumni. In his "retirement", he devoted his time and leadership to the boards of multiple community and educational institutions, serving as chairman of the Alfond Scholarship Fund, Portland Museum of Art, Reading Hospital, US Biathlon Olympic committee and board member of Maine Medical Center. He additionally served on the boards of the Coastal Maine Botanical Gardens (vice chairman), Artis-Naples board, Naples United Church of Christ (deacon), Boys & Girls club of Collier County. Larry was also the recipient of numerous awards including two honorary doctorates. Larry loved the game of golf, and sharing it with his friends and family. He was fortunate to spend the last week of his life on the course with his wife, daughters and grandsons. He was a proud member of Augusta National Golf Club, Portland Country Club, The Club at Pelican Bay (where he was formerly Chairman), Boothbay Harbor Country Club and Royal Poinciana Golf Club. Larry is survived by his wife, Jean Pugh, his two daughters, Deborah Pugh Kelton and her husband Bill, of Maine, and Diane Pugh Esecson and her husband Matt, of Hawaii. He also adored his four grandsons, Tucker Kelton, Josh Kelton, Austin Esecson and Kyle Esecson. There will be a memorial service at 11:00am Monday, December 7, 2015 at the Naples United Church of Christ. A reception will follow immediately at the Club of Pelican Bay. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Naples United Church of Christ Music Endowment Fund. Online condolences may be made by visiting www.fullernaples.com. 1/3

KERZ--Corinne Clejan, born on 17 March 1960 in Chicago, Illinois to Sheila and Deodat Clejan, died on 1 December 2015 after several years' illness. A graduate of the Lycee Francais, Barnard College and the NYU School of Business, she enjoyed a professional career as Controller of Health Management Systems, Inc. before devoting herself to her beloved children, Danton, Kolya and India and her step-daughter Andrea. Active at her children's schools and with a variety of charitable causes, Corinne will be sorely missed by her mother; her three brothers, Jean Pierre, Marc and James; innumerable dear friends; her many tennis buddies; the "Paillard Princesses"; and, most of all, by her adoring husband, Paul. 1/3
