SCHLESINGER--Sheldon J.,85, of Golden Beach, passed away December 2, 2015 surrounded by his family and members of his law firm. He was born in Brooklyn, NY and moved to Florida to attend the University of Miami and the University of Miami School of Law where he met his beloved wife Barbara to whom he was married for 60 years. They had two sons, Scott and Gregg, who both followed their father's lead and became lawyers and practiced with him. They were fortunate to have six grandchildren, a constant source of happiness. He knew as a very young man that he was going to be a lawyer and he enjoyed every minute of his career. His favorite place was in a courtroom. His passing will leave a void in the legal community where he was greatly respected by judges, colleagues and opponents alike. As avid supporters of civic and charitable organizations, the Schlesinger family is actively involved in the South Florida community. Mr. Schlesinger served on the Board of Governors of Nova- Southeastern Law Center and served as chairman of the Board of Trustees of Broward Community College. Early on he got involved with Broward Community College because he believed strongly in giving an opportunity for a college education to anyone who wanted one; a building on the Hollywood Campus is named for him. Sheldon J. Schlesinger was one of the most successful personal injury and medical malpractice attorneys in the United States. For over 60 years, he represented individuals and consumers in landmark cases across the nation. He was listed in every edition of the book "The Best Lawyers in America." He had, and deserved, a reputation for being one of the best trial attorneys in the United States. The Miami Herald described Shelly as "The Dean of Broward Civil Litigators." The Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel described him as a "Bulldog for the Underdog," a "super-lawyer in every sense of the word," and "one of the most powerful personal injury attorneys in the country." At the conclusion of a lengthy trial where his client emerged victorious, the presiding judge entered a court order describing him as "one of the most experienced and skilled attorneys which the Florida Bar has to offer," and that his "experience and ability in medical malpractice litigation is exceeded by no one." Mr. Schlesinger won significant verdicts and settlements in numerous high profile cases. He set national records for plaintiffs' attorneys, including products liability cases against major automotive manufacturers. In 1995, he was part of the landmark legal team that successfully defeated the tobacco industry on behalf of the citizens of Florida. He was one of the founders of the Broward County Trial Lawyers Association and served as its president. He was a member of the Inner Circle of Advocates, one of the nation's most prestigious organizations for plaintiff lawyers. Because of the number of high profile cases he won, he was the subject of numerous interviews and stories in newspapers, magazines and television. He appeared in Time, People, Forbes, Florida Trend, New York Times and the Wall Street Journal. He appeared on CBS 60 Minutes, ABC's 20/20, the Phil Donahue Show, and numerous other national and local television and news programs. Recently, he was inducted into the Trial Lawyer Hall of Fame held at Temple University in Pennsylvania; he was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award at the Florida Verdicts Hall of Fame by the Daily Business Review; and he was honored to give a Legacy lecture to his cherished Inner Circle of Advocates. He is survived by his sons: Scott (m. Anne) and Gregg; his six grandchildren: Charlotte, Alexander, Molly, Theodora, Samuel, and Theodore; and his brother-in-law, Larry Butler (m. Grace). The funeral will be held Sunday, December 6, 2015 at 2:00pm at Temple Beth El, 1351 South 14th Avenue, Hollywood, FL 33020, interment to follow at Temple Beth El Memorial Gardens, 4900 Old Griffin Road, Davie, FL 33314, (954) 584-7151. The family will receive visitors on December 6, 2015 following the interment, and on December 7 and 8, 2015 at the residence. Call (954)467-8800 for further details. 1/3
FEINSTEIN--Jerome M.,of Cresskill, NJ, age 96, died November 30. Predeceased by wives Muriel and Barbara. Survived by sons Miles and Jack. 1/3
BROKAW--Clifford V. III Holland Lodge #

BABKOW--Kathleen. Kathleen Gibbons Babkow, died peacefully and with no pain on November 28, 2015 at the age of 79. She is survived by her husband Alvin, her sons Jonathan and David, and her grandchildren Knox and Zachary. Her passing has left all of us with a profound sadness and she will be sorely missed. She was a wonderful and caring person who was loved by all whose lives she touched. As a longtime, devoted friend described her recently, she was a "second mother" to so many and a trusted friend to even more. With a knack for resolving life's situations, she was always sympathetic, patient and understanding. She savored life and all it had to offer, including a successful and loving marriage of over 54 years, two sons and their wives who adored her, and two beautiful grandsons. Kathleen was born in 1936 in Brooklyn, New York, the only child of Katherine Bohley Gibbons who also was born in Brooklyn. Her father, John Delaney Gibbons was born in Acton, Ontario, Canada. Her parents met in Nassau, BWI where both were employed. Her father managed a number of hotels including in New York City, New York, Clearwater, Florida and Boston, Massachusetts. After her father's death, she and her mother settled in New Jersey. She attended and was graduated from Ridgewood High School and Beaver College (now called Arcadia College). She applied for employment at McGraw-Hill Publications, and that is where she met her future husband. She left McGraw-Hill, took a job at Advertising Age, and shortly thereafter married in March of 1961. She stayed with Advertising Age until her children were born. She went back to full-time work in 1982 for Cornell Medical College as an administrator and remained with the College for 30 years. In addition to being an avid world traveler, she particularly loved working with all of the students and her colleagues at the College. A private family service is scheduled for Friday, December 4, 2015 at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street in New York. A memorial will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Friday, December 11, 2015 at Noon. In lieu of flowers, we ask that donations be made to Citymeals on Wheels. 1/3

GOODE--Frederick Wilson. Died at home in Berkeley, CA, on November 2, 2015. He was born in New York on January 3, 1926. He graduated in 1947 from Princeton with honors and degrees in Art History and Comparative Religion. He served as a Navy Lieutenant in both the Second World War and the Korean War. Frederick's career as a high school teacher began by chance when he was asked to fill in as a substitute religion teacher at St. George's School in Newport, RI. He was a gifted and versatile teacher and actor who taught the humanities at college preparatory schools on both coasts. He was well known for his booming voice, humor, mimicry and classroom theatrics, sometimes throwing books or jumping on top of a desk to convey his passion for the subjects he loved. Frederick will be remembered as the director and co-founder of The School of Arts and Sciences, an experimental high school in San Anselmo, CA. Here Frederick and his colleague David Donnelley were able to put into practice their innovative and progressive ideas on education. The school emphasized collaboration rather than competition, and encouraged students to be conscious of social values and the need to protect the environment. Frederick met his wife, Marilyn Van Hoosear, while she was attending graduate school at New York University. The two were married in 1955 and had a litter of five children: Jennifer, Eric and Christopher who live in New York; and Gregory and Melissa who live in California. Frederick is survived by seven grandchildren. After retiring in 1989, Frederick lived in Sonoma with Marilyn and kept a small studio in Berkeley. Over the years his paintings were shown in various galleries in Seattle and the San Francisco Bay Area. In 2002, Frederick met his partner Panya Pringchamras, with whom he lived from 2008 until his death. Frederick loved books, gardens, nature and life. He was a brilliant and complex man who will be missed by his family, his friends, and the many students he inspired. 1/3

RUNNE--Herbert Rein. 77, passed away peacefully on Saturday, November 28 at his home in Ardsley Park, Irvington, NY. He is survived by his wife Susan, daughter Jennifer, son Alexander and son-in-law Justin. Born February 5, 1938 in Paide, Estonia, he and his family escaped the Soviet invasion, living in exile in the Geislingen DP camp before settling in Lakewood, NJ. There he learned English, attended high school and became an Eagle Scout. He earned an A.B. cum laude in Politics from Princeton in 1961 and a J.D. from Yale Law School in 1964. He started his legal career at Cravath before devoting his professional life to the pharmaceutical industry. He served as corporate legal counsel for American Cyanamid and Pfizer, and lectured on the industry prior to retirement in 2008. Rein's greatest loves were his wife and children, and time spent at their home in Bethany Beach, DE. He also remained proud of his Estonian identity, reclaiming citizenship when the nation regained independence. A family memorial service was held at the Gorsline Runciman funeral home in East Lansing, MI, on Saturday, December 5. Donations may be made in his memory to the Estonian Evangelical Lutheran Church of Lakewood, 607 East 7th St, Lakewood, NJ 08701. 1/3

DRAKE--Susan Elston Wallace, beloved wife of Philip M. Drake, died as she lived, quietly with her daughter, Margaret, and her husband of 66 years at her side on Saturday, November 28, 2015 in Naples, Florida. She was a devoted mother to four daughters, Anne, Kathleen, Margaret (Todd Vallely) and Susan Holly (Todd Sylvestri). Susan had three grandchildren, Kathleen Grosse, Ross and Kevin Sylvestri and two great-grandchildren, Anna Bella and Michael Morrell. Susan was born on October 12, 1921, in Indianapolis, Indiana to Josephine and Lew Wallace. She was predeceased by her parents and brothers, Lew and William, and her sister, Margaret Daly. Susan graduated from Bennett College in Milbrook, NY. She worked at Simon & Schuster in New York before marrying Phil. She was a dog lover and had a dog at her side most of her life. Sue had many interests, including tennis and golf in her earlier years and needlepoint, Nantucket basket weaving, Mahjong and croquet. She worked on her needlepoint projects with great love, ultimately giving her creations to those closest to her. She approached these interests with great enthusiasm and basically taught herself croquet in her senior years. She was a member of the croquet clubs in Marion, Massachusetts, Greenwich, Connecticut and Naples, Florida and was considered a tough opponent on the court. Sue was an avid reader who enjoyed sharing her love of literature with her friends. She was known by many for the wonderful, well thought out gifts that she gave for no reason at all. Along with her husband, Philip, Susan helped establish the Whitby School in Greenwich in 1958. Susan was the great- granddaughter of Major General Lew Wallace, whose statue stands in Statuary Hall in the United States Capitol. He fought in three significant battles in the Civil War. In 1880, he authored Ben Hur, a best-selling novel that has been called the most significant Christian book in the 19th century. Sue enjoyed being near or in the water and was most happy in her home in Marion, Massachusetts where she spent over 45 summers enjoying her family and friends. Services will be held at 10:30am on Saturday, December 5 at St. Michael The Archangel Roman Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the General Lew Wallace Study and Museum, 200 Wallace Avenue, PO Box 662, Crawfordsville, IN 47933. 1/3

FISTER--Edward J. In Memory of a great American Patriot, Edward J. Fister, Chief Civilian Scientist of the Signal Corps., a pioneer in the development of radar, having installed same at Pearl Harbor. His career centered on the then-revolutionary invention called RADAR (radio detection and ranging). His responsibilities were taking lab and theoretical breakthroughs in radar from the lab to the field. Radar was possibly the single most important technology developed during the war, easily on a par with cryptography and the atom bomb. It was a key reason why England could win the Battle of Britain. Ed's work during WWII was critical to getting radar to where it made a difference, and hence to the war effort. His early projects included important complex radar systems, including the Variable Time Fuze, a miniature radar transmitter/receiver to be installed on the front end of a bomb that would explode the device at a set altitude above the target, enabling Allied artillery and bombs to increase their effectiveness. It was a revolutionary development and in this way we can say Edward John Fister had a very personal role in bringing about the end to WWII. For the VT Fuze he received the War Department Meritorious Citizen Award. The real men in black, of which Dad was one, worked on the Manhattan Project, set up Oak Ridge, worked at Area 51, White Sands Missile Range and more, all documented. Most importantly, these were men who could be trusted with our national security, setting up the DEW line, working on Project Diana, which gave birth to NASA. To honor Dad and all in that era, whose lives were lost at Pearl Harbor, and in the harrowing events of that terrible war. Love you, Dad. Ellen 1/3

EUSTIS--Truman William, III, 86, a former long-time New York Times attorney, died October 28. Eustis, born in Dayton OH, in 1929, the son of a General Motors engineer. Eustis attended Cornell University and Harvard Law School. He specialized in publishing and literary property for Paul, Weiss, Rifkind. He then worked at LOOK magazine, after which he went to The New York Times Company, finishing his career as Senior Attorney. He was active in the copyright and trademark legal aspects of their publications, including the Magazine Group. He contributed substantially to the law of new uses of copyright in the storage and retrieval of data and the legal aspects of the New York Times Cable operations. Eustis is survived by wife Martha; daughter, Kelley Eustis of Greenwich; son Timothy and wife Sarah and their two children. 1/3

SELLNER--Arthur B.,91, passed away peacefully surrounded by family on December 1st. We celebrate your long life well-lived as a native New Yorker, WWII hero, NYU alum, devoted husband to Aunt Judy, skier, handyman, friend to many, witty wisecracker, and our wonderful Uncle Art. Love, Mae, Ed and Nicole. Private family service in Massachusetts. 1/3

RUBIN--Danny. Once called, "The most dangerous man in America to American youth" by J. Edgar Hoover, Mortimer Daniel Rubin, known as Danny, died Tuesday, December 1, at the age of 84. Danny joined the Communist Party USA (CPUSA) during the McCarthy Era, moved by the idea of a political system based on social, racial and economic justice and equality. In that movement, to which he devoted the rest of his life, he met and married his life partner, Dorothy Cohan. The pair moved from Philadelphia to Brooklyn in 1960, where their children Rose and Joseph were born. Danny was a defendant in one of the McCarren Act cases that ultimately led to that law being struck down by the Supreme Court in the mid 1960s. Over the years, Danny took part in electoral campaigns at all levels, as well as every major social campaign from the Civil Rights Movement to opposing Bruce Ratner's Atlantic Yards project. He also served in many roles in the CPUSA, including as national organizational secretary and then national education secretary. He was active even this year. Danny loved Beethoven, chocolate, a good meal and The New York Times. He took pride in having met the great Paul Robeson twice. He was a gentle and affectionate father and grandfather who always had a hug and a kiss and a few choice words of advice. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy; children, Rose and Joe; daughter-in-law, Dolores; and grandchildren, Hector, Jason, Jesse and Selena. 1/3

FRANK--Charlotte S. Died suddenly at home over Thanksgiving weekend. Family and friends deeply mourn the loss of this visionary leader, co-founder of The Transition Network, a national organization for women over 50 - for which she received an Ashoka Fellowship - and the Caring Collaborative. Known for her numerous interests, sharp intelligence, warmth, generosity, and pluck, she was formerly Director of Contracting and Procurement for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and COO of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Survived by brothers Harvey and Fred, sister Suzanne, and eight nieces and nephews. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Children's Defense Fund and Meals On Wheels. Memorial at later date. 1/3
WADDINGTON--Leslie. Farewell to you, dear friend and colleague -- rare anomaly in the art world: a scholar and a true gentleman. With a tip of the hat from Timothy Baum and James Mayor 1/3

GANDOLF--Raymond L.,died peacefully at home on December 2, 2015, at the age of 85. He was the devoted husband of Blanche Cholet, loving father of five daughters, Alexandra (Matthew), Jessica (Lincoln), Victoria, Amanda (Martin) and Susanna (Robert), and cherished grandfather of Dillon and Caitlin, Elias and Dana, and Scarlett. Ray was born in Norwalk, Ohio and received a Bachelor of Science in Speech from Northwestern University. He was an actor, writer, television news correspondent and sports commentator. Ray contributed to the ABC series "Our World" as writer and co-host, was featured on CBS Sunday Morning, and reported from four Olympic Games. He received an Emmy, a Peabody, and a duPont Award for his work. Ray's unforgettable charm, intelligence, wit and warmth will be greatly missed. Family will be welcoming callers on Tuesday, December 8th, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, December 9th, 10am at The Church of St. Gregory the Great, 144 West 90th St., between Columbus and Amsterdam Aves. Interment to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery, New Brunswick, New Jersey. Donations in his memory may be made to Southern Poverty Law Center, Atlanta, Georgia. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Sheldon. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sheldon Goldstein. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Arlyne and their family. Robert D. Lang, President Harvey Karofsky, Secretary 1/3

GANDOLF--Raymond L.,died peacefully at home on December 2, 2015, at the age of 85. He was the devoted husband of Blanche Cholet, loving father of five daughters, Alexandra (Matthew), Jessica (Lincoln), Victoria, Amanda (Martin) and Susanna (Robert), and cherished grandfather of Dillon and Caitlin, Elias and Dana, and Scarlett. Ray was born in Norwalk, Ohio and received a Bachelor of Science in Speech from Northwestern University. He was an actor, writer, television news correspondent and sports commentator. Ray contributed to the ABC series "Our World" as writer and co-host, was featured on CBS Sunday Morning, and reported from four Olympic Games. He received an Emmy, a Peabody, and a duPont Award for his work. Ray's unforgettable charm, intelligence, wit and warmth will be greatly missed. Family will be welcoming callers on Tuesday, December 8th, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, December 9th, 10am at The Church of St. Gregory the Great, 144 West 90th St., between Columbus and Amsterdam Aves. Interment to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery, New Brunswick, New Jersey. Donations in his memory may be made to Southern Poverty Law Center, Atlanta, Georgia. 1/3

MAHER--John A. Lieutenant Commander John A. Maher, U.S.N.R-retired, died on December 3, 2015 -- his 85th birthday -- in Decatur, Georgia. He and his bride, Joan Therese Dawley, both Brooklyn natives, wed there in 1954. John is survived by Joan, their five children, and seven beloved grandchildren. Excluding Korean War naval service, John ushered at Ebbets Field from 1948 through the Dodgers' 1957 departure. Earning degrees from the University of Notre Dame and N.Y.U. Law, Mr. Maher was also a Food Law Fellow at N.Y.U. He then practiced law on Wall Street and in midtown Manhattan. When the late Winton (Red) Blount became Postmaster General, Maher was actively recruited as vice president-law and public affairs at Blount, Inc. in Montgomery, Alabama. He help convert then closely- held Blount, Inc.'s heavy construction interests to being publicly-held. In 1971, John turned to full-time teaching at The Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, PA, where he coached a national championship appellate moot court team. Maher became the law school's 8th dean in 1989. A highly distinguished, honored, and well published lawyer, Maher was active in many legal organizations including various Bar Associations and Cambridge University's annual Symposia on International Economic Crime. Maher was also Atlantic Liberty Savings, F.A., in Brooklyn, Board Chairman for five years. Maher's public service included President Lyndon Johnson's Consumer Affairs Committee, a Pennsylvania Securities Commissionership, and Training Officer of two successive national champion Naval Reserve units. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The John A. Maher Scholarship Endowment at Dickinson Law (KRimmer@psu.edu). 1/3

LOWE--E. Nobles. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Practising Law Institute (PLI) mourn the passing of long time Trustee, Nobles E. Lowe. Nobles was an active contributor to PLI and we shall miss his wise counsel and wisdom. Our sympathies to his family at this time. William P. Frank, Board Chair Samuel W. Seymour, Executive Committee Chair Anita Shapiro, President 1
GOLDSTEIN--Sheldon. He was a great and caring partner and a unique and special friend. Respected and admired. He will be missed. Condolences to his wife Lynn and all of his family. Herb Goldsmith 1/3

DEEGAN--Hon. Joseph F.,Jr. 91, died peacefully in his home on 3 December 2015. Graduate of College of the Holy Cross and Boston College Law. He served in the Navy and reserves, a Patrol Torpedo Boat skipper in the Pacific, retiring with rank of Commander. He was appointed Middlesex County judge in 1968, rose to Superior Court judge, serving until retirement. He is survived by his wife, Mary, children Jeff, Maura, Sarah Jane, Sheila, five grandchildren and, sister, Catherine Ann. Wake to be held at Flynn and Son Funeral Home, Perth Amboy on Tuesday, December 8, 2015, followed by mass and burial on Wednesday. 1/3

TOWNSEND--Eleanor Meneely, M.D.,a psychiatrist in New York City died at her home December 2nd, age 83. A retired member of the faculty of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons she was associated with both Presbyterian and Harlem Hospitals and for many years was director of The Harlem Center for Child Study. She attended The Brearley School and was a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College and Columbia University P&S. She was a psychiatry consultant for various institutions including Prisoners Legal Services. She was the daughter of Clinton Blake and Eleanor Meneely Townsend. She is survived by her husband of 53 years, Monroe Chasson and her daughters, Kate Chasson of Winter Park, CO and Sarah Chasson of Chevy Chase, MD, Frank G. Zarb, Jr, three grandchildren, and her brother Clinton (Bill) Townsend of Canaan, ME. 1/3
JOHNSON--Lisa M. December 7, 1990. Dear Mom, I will always treasure your memory. I hope Dad is with you. Love, Robbie 1/3
MINKOW--Carol. Always in our hearts and minds. Ed, Alex, Andrew and Dia 1/3

KERZ--Corinne Clejan, born on 17 March 1960 in Chicago, Illinois to Sheila and Deodat Clejan, died on 1 December 2015 after several years' illness. A graduate of the Lycee Francais, Barnard College and the NYU School of Business, she enjoyed a professional career as Controller of Health Management Systems, Inc. before devoting herself to her beloved children, Danton, Kolya and India and her step-daughter Andrea. Active at her children's schools and with a variety of charitable causes, Corinne will be sorely missed by her mother; her three brothers, Jean Pierre, Marc and James; innumerable dear friends; her many tennis buddies; the "Paillard Princesses"; and, most of all, by her adoring husband, Paul. 1/3

RUBIN--Danny. Once called, "The most dangerous man in America to American youth" by J. Edgar Hoover, Mortimer Daniel Rubin, known as Danny, died Tuesday, December 1, at the age of 84. Danny joined the Communist Party USA (CPUSA) during the McCarthy Era, moved by the idea of a political system based on social, racial and economic justice and equality. In that movement, to which he devoted the rest of his life, he met and married his life partner, Dorothy Cohan. The pair moved from Philadelphia to Brooklyn in 1960, where their children Rose and Joseph were born. Danny was a defendant in one of the McCarren Act cases that ultimately led to that law being struck down by the Supreme Court in the mid 1960s. Over the years, Danny took part in electoral campaigns at all levels, as well as every major social campaign from the Civil Rights Movement to opposing Bruce Ratner's Atlantic Yards project. He also served in many roles in the CPUSA, including as national organizational secretary and then national education secretary. He was active even this year. Danny loved Beethoven, chocolate, a good meal and The New York Times. He took pride in having met the great Paul Robeson twice. He was a gentle and affectionate father and grandfather who always had a hug and a kiss and a few choice words of advice. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy; children, Rose and Joe; daughter-in-law, Dolores; and grandchildren, Hector, Jason, Jesse and Selena. 1/3

DADAKIS--George, 99, of Harrison, NY and Delray Beach, FL, died peacefully on December 3, 2015, his wife, Lois, predeceasing him. Survived by his children, Roberta Mikus, Tom, and John; grandchildren, Jackie, Chryssi Mikus, Alex, and Ryan; and great-grandson, Will. Visitation on Thursday, 4-8pm, at Grahams Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Funeral on Friday, 10:30am, at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Savior, 2195 Westchester Ave., Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, please donate in George's name to the Salvation Army. 1/3

BUDMOR--Moshe. Loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle, teacher, mentor and friend. Died December 4, 2015 at home in Princeton, NJ. Composer, conductor, music educator. Survived by daughters Jean Lerner (Elizabeth Salen) and Laura Lyons, four grandchildren, several nieces and a nephew. His first wife, Katya Delakova, and his second wife, Lea Lerner, predeceased him. 1/3

WOLLMAN--Celia Edelman, died peacefully at home on Saturday, December 5. Ceil loved life, music, dancing, yiddishkeit, family and Herb, her loving late husband of 65 years. She leaves behind her children, Bernice (Warren Rubin), Lorrie (Mona Wollman) and Amy (Gerry Berkowitz); her grandchildren Dana Wollman, Brian Wollman, and Daniel Berkowitz; her brother, Arnold Edelman (Myrna); and many nieces and nephews. 1/3

SCHNALL--Edith Lea Spitzer, PhD, 93, of Bayside NY on Tuesday, December 1, 2015. Microbiologist, educator. Adored wife of the late Herbert Schnall, DDS. Beloved and devoted mother of Neil David and Carolyn Beth. Proud grandma of Simon Felix. Loving daughter of Irving and Sadie (Raab) Spitzer. Cherished sister of the late Gilda Kamelhar and the late Beatrice Braitman. For more information, call Neil Schnall at 201-233-6123. 1/3

SMITH--Sidney Wilson. Died November 29, age 60, at his childhood home in Memphis. Son of Virginia Genette Smith and R. Leigh Smith Jr., he attended Trinity, Choate and Dwight schools and Columbia University. He worked in computers at Time Inc. in New York before returning to Memphis, where he worked at Memphis Light Gas and Water and St. Jude Hospital. He also wrote a memoir, "Just Dirt." Survivors include his partner Cathy Ross, brother Randy Smith of New York City, nephews Will and Jack Smith, and step-mother Miraed Smith. A service will be held at Canale Funeral Directors in Memphis at 11am on December 9. 1/3

COHEN--Barbara Lackey, of Riverdale, NY passed away peacefully at the age of 81 years after an extended illness. She is survived by her husband Charles, her children Laurence Cohen and Julia Balk, her grandchildren Daniel Balk, David Balk and Dylan Cohen, Barbara graduated from Wellesley College in 1955 and held a Master's degree from Teachers College, Columbia University. Barbara was a talented designer, marketing beautiful jewelry under her own Barbara D'Oro brand. Funeral will be private; a memorial service will be held at a future date. Contributions can be made in her honor at the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, Radnor Station Building 2, Suite 320, 290 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA 19087. 1/3

GILBERT--Theodore, died December 6, 2015 in Flushing, Queens, at 87 years old. He was raised in the Bronx by Isidore and Rose, immigrants from Riga, Latvia, with his three brothers Jacob, Murray and Arnold. A graduate of Long Island University and Brooklyn Law School, he was admitted to the Bar of the State of New York in 1951 and practiced law for over 50 years. From 1966 to 1976, he worked for the City of New York, Office of the Corporation Counsel. At the time he left, he was the Chief of the Contracts Division. He then was in private practice in Queens until his retirement. He was a veteran of the United States National Guard. Married to his beloved and incredibly devoted wife, Mindy since 1966, they raised their two sons, Michael and Adam, in Flushing, NY. In addition to his wife and sons, he is survived by his beloved grandchildren, Katherine, Aaron, Victor and Ethan and daughters-in-law Chiu Yun and Lauren. A loyal reader of The New York Times, a long suffering Mets fan, always a quick wit and skilled wordsmith, he was an adored grandfather, devoted father and father-in-law and a loving husband. He will be deeply missed and always remembered. The family will hold private memorial services. Memorial contributions can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research: www.michaeljfox.org 1/3

SCHNALL--Edith Lea Spitzer, PhD, 93, of Bayside NY on Tuesday, December 1, 2015. Microbiologist, educator. Adored wife of the late Herbert Schnall, DDS. Beloved and devoted mother of Neil David and Carolyn Beth. Proud grandma of Simon Felix. Loving daughter of Irving and Sadie (Raab) Spitzer. Cherished sister of the late Gilda Kamelhar and the late Beatrice Braitman. For more information, call Neil Schnall at 201-233-6123. 1/3

MULROW--Dr. Patrick J. Dr. Patrick Joseph Mulrow of Jupiter Island, Florida and formerly of Perrysburg, Ohio passed away on Thursday, December 3, 2015. Born in New York City on December 16, 1926, he was the fourth child of Patrick and Delia Mulrow and was a loving, devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Dr. Mulrow was a physician, medical educator, prolific author and internationally renowned researcher. For twenty years, he was Professor and Chairman of the Department of Medicine at the University of Toledo College of Medicine and Life Sciences (formerly the Medical College of Ohio (MCO)). Dr. Mulrow was recognized throughout his life for his contributions to both MCO, and for the research he conducted in hypertension and the role of renin and other factors in the regulation of aldosterone production. He was a recipient of the Senior U.S. Scientist Award from the Alexander Von-Humboldt Foundation, and was President of the Central Society of Clinical Research. In 1991, Dr. Mulrow was elected Chairman of the Council for High Blood Pressure Research (American Heart Association) and in 1995 was appointed Secretary General of the World Hypertension League. In addition, he was elected to the American Society of Clinical Investigations, the Association of American Physicians and The Royal College of Physicians of Ireland. He served on numerous research committees of the The National Institutes of Health, and was an active member of the Executive Committee of the International Society of Hypertension and the Inter- American Society of Hypertension. He was also a recipient of the Irvine Page-Alva Bradley Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Heart Association's Council for High Blood Pressure Research. Dr. Mulrow retired in 1995, and became Professor Emeritus shortly after. In 2004, Dr. Mulrow received the MCO Career Achievement Award. Born and raised in New York City, Dr. Mulrow earned an undergraduate degree at Colgate University, and graduated from Cornell University Medical College. He completed his medical residency at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center followed by a fellowship in Endocrinology at Stanford University. Subsequently, Dr. Mulrow was appointed Professor of Medicine and Chief of Endocrinology at Yale University School of Medicine. Dr. Mulrow was married to Jacquelyn for 62 wonderful years. He was a proud father to Deborah Van Handel, Dr. Nancy Mulrow, Robert Mulrow, and Catherine Mulrow-Peattie and grandfather to his eight grandchildren, Maria, Stephanie, Jackie, Sophie, Aaron, Casey, Noah and Jack. Dr. Mulrow was the brother of Anne Gallagher of Ipswich, MA and of deceased sisters, Helen Collins, Mary Hoar and Delia Toomey. Dr. Mulrow was full of life through his last days with his family. His humor, grace, love and brilliance touched everyone who crossed his path. His light will continue to shine. Scholarship donations in honor of Dr. Mulrow are being received by both the Weill Cornell Medical School and the University of Toledo College of Medicine and Life Sciences. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Service entrusted to Aycock-Riverside Funeral and Cremation Center, Jupiter. 1/3

GLUCKSMAN--Paula, 92, Died December 4, of New York City. Widowed seven years. In the wake of the Depression and World War II, she came at 22 from Los Angeles to New York to seek her fortune, found a husband, John (of 60 years), a career, and a son. As Paula Green, she was a pioneer in advertising, for 40 years created famous and influential campaigns, including Avis "We try harder", and "Look for the Union Label" for the ILGWU. Sometimes she cooked. We had dinner together. We talked. She was an early example of a working mother managing a career. Survivor of breast cancer as a young woman, later writing a break-through TV ad on a woman's examining her own breasts for early signs. A survivor of esophageal in her 80's while taking care of her ailing husband, returning in 2010 to consult with Google and in 2011 as a guest speaker at Cannes' International Advertising Festival. Survived by brother Fred Green in California; a son Joel, daughter-in-law Hope, granddaughter Lily. Creative and determined, stood up for what she believed, fought to the end. A Founding Mother. Memorial service Wednesday, December 9, 2:15pm, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam. 1/3

BALDUCCI--Dr. Charles, passed away peacefully on December 6, 2015. He was born in Brooklyn on April 24, 1923 and grew up in Corato, Italy. He earned his Doctorate in medicine from the University of Genoa, Italy during World War II. He married in 1948 in New York and joined Flushing Hospital to build his career in pulmonary medicine. He worked until 87 years of age and lectured Flushing Hospital medical students until he was 90. Affectionately known as "Doc," he was an avid cook, gardner, teacher, author, entertainer, hunter and world traveler. He was most proud of his parents, Louis and Maria Balducci, who founded Balducci's in Greenwich Village, NY. Survived by his wife of 24 years, Soja, six living children - Emily Cardone, Louis Balducci, Grace Pratt, Adriana Gailing, Charles Balducci Jr. and Marc Andrew Balducci, 12 grandchildren and one great- grandchild. Sadly his daughter Mary Brennan preceded him in death. Services at Frederick Funeral Home, 192-15 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY on December 9 and December 10, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral is Friday, December 11, Holy Trinity RC Church, 14-15 143rd St., Whitestone, NY. 1/3

Ivan Berkowitz is a former member of the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers and he and Francesca were honored with the Distinguished Leadership Award at a Yeshiva College Dinner, and are significant supporters of our institution. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Ivan and Francesca and the entire Berkowitz family. May they be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

EVANS--Jeffrey T.,58, on December 3, 2015. Founding Partner of Safe Haven International passed away unexpectedly. The Memorial Service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th St., on Tuesday at 5pm. He will be forever cherished by his beloved wife Joy. 1/3

MAROLDA--Fred. Beloved husband of Marie. Dedicated father of Alexandra and Olivia. Cherished son of Gerard and Camille. Loving brother of Bill. Sadly lost his battle to cancer on December 5th. Fred was co-president and founder of Marolda Properties, Inc., a family run real estate investment and management firm, which he built with his brother and cousin. His love of sports, particularly basketball, contributed to his fifteen-year involvement in the New York Urban Professional Basketball League. He also coached his daughters in Yorkville Basketball, Softball, and West Side Soccer for many years. Fred's easy-going and humble leadership style, gentle nature and warm smile made him a favorite coach and player who will be greatly missed. He was a kind and giving person with an unwavering generosity that always put family and friends first. Visitation will be at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street in Manhattan, Tuesday, 7-9pm, Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, 627 East 187th Street, Bronx, New York on Thursday at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Fred's name to Lady Choz, Inc. at 21 Sheffield Court, Somerset, NJ 08873, attn: Earl Elliotte. Please note in honor of Fred on the memo line. Lady Choz is a non-profit organization serving underserved girls by teaching life lessons through the game of basketball. 1/3
